The last few years of her life have been more than a little painful. She lost a everything she held dear. She hopes coming back her childhood home will help her reconnect to who she once was and to find a bit of solace.However, she discovers more than she ever bargained for. First Maisey stumbles upon Rafe, a boy she briefly knew a life time ago and the man he has become is someone she cannot forget or ignore. Then she discovers the possibility of a murdered sibling she never knew she had. All of this is coupled with her reunion with her not so lovely and very controlling mom.It soon felt like Maisey was questioning everything but finding very few answers. It's the perfect storm of plot chaos but it works. Each scene flows into the next and there is never a spot where you want to stop reading. It all works out beautifully and it's why Brenda Novak is one of my favorite authors - her storylines are simply incredible.I seriously devoured The Secret Sister and I highly recommend it. It's a great book and one you definitely want to read.

Holy freaking hotness - I want my own Woolf Jennings.  Or maybe just a night or two at his club.  Wooziers - this man is one sexy cowboy and I cannot wait to get more from this series.  Sawyer Bennett's Wicked Fall was a tempting and passionate read - one that will ignite your desires and get your lady bits tingling.If you've read Shaken Not Stirred, you were already been introduced to Woolf. However, during Tenn's romance you never got a good feel for what was going on in his life - he was just portrayed as a wealthy player unwilling to settle down.His book, Wicked Fall is the start of the Wicked Horse Series and it is awesome.  You quickly learn that Woolf has a lot on his plate and it's not that he doesn't want to take on responsibility of his family's business, he just wants to make sure that he is also fulfilling his dreams.Driven by his own sexual curiosity and life style, Woolf expands his brand to own a bar as well as a sexual fantasy club with his closest friend. He thinks his life is now perfect - he finally has everything he ever desired.So karma hands him Callie. This spitfire storms back into his life and turns him inside out. Their feelings for one another run deep and have been ignored for a really long time. So when they give into their lust - it's explosive. Intense. Carnal.Their love story is exciting and I absolutely devoured every page. Because when Sawyer Bennett wants her characters to get naughty and downright sexually erotic - she nails it. EVERY SINGLE TIME. But she always balances it out with the right amount of romance and sweetness. It makes your heart beat a little bit faster and reminds you of what it feels like to be swept up in love.It's for all of these reasons, Wicked Fall is a top recommendation from me. Read it now.

Argggg!! So I devoured this book. It had a suspenseful plot filled with surprises and plot twists that left my jaw on the ground.  I really liked Relinquished and would recommend you check it out.Jules' world was dark and dingy.  It's a sad place that you desperately want to rescue her from.  This is coupled with her HORRIFIC past.  She is barely surviving and the only potential bright light in her life is her budding friendships with Holden and his brother, Dante.  They are the first people to ever show her any kindness, ever.  Their book is exciting and a bit thrilling.I did struggle a bit with the character's connections and the way the author shared their thoughts.It is Jules' story and it is told from both her perspective as well as Dante's.  So I honestly felt confused - the author was telling me about this romantic bond between Holden and Jules. Yet, she was sharing Dante's voice and story - one that was only connected to the suspense plot but not romantically.  I was baffled - I didn't know if eventually there was going to be an awkward love triangle or what was going on.  It left me with a weird feeling as I read.However, the book's plot plays out incredibly well.  The way the author blows everything you think you know up is amazing.  It almost completely redeemed the awkwardness for me.  It definitely made the story interesting.Relinquished is an entertaining story and my minor issues with the book should not discourage you from reading it.  It really is an awesome story.

Mia Kayla is new to me author but after reading her latest release The Scheme, I'm now a huge fan. Her book was so much fun to read and I highly recommend you check it out.The Scheme's plot is all about Kendy landing her perfect man. She moved to New York for a job and to fulfill an old prophecy given to her by a psychic when she was a teenager. She has it in her head that a certain doctor is everything she wants and needs.Enter Brian - an old acquaintance from back home.When an opportunity arises to make Dr. Hot Pants jealous - she jumps at the chance to use Brian in an attempt to get what she desires. However, it turns out completely different than Kendy expected.  Brian and Kendy start spending their free time together and then their feelings and desires erupt - almost uncontrollable in nature.  It's confusing for the two but awesome to experience.  I loved it!!Brian and Kendy's romance was light hearted and sweet. Their ploy to entice the good doctor is filled with hilarity and you know what will eventually become of the two. But that doesn't make their journey any less enjoyable or boring. Their quick wit and banter pulls you in and you're completely enchanted by their relationship.I absolutely adored this story.  It was entertaining and a must read for any fans of contemporary romance.

The latest release in the Knights Rebels series, Desertion, is a book I have been dying to get my hands on.  I desperately wanted Jesse's story and to meet the woman who would kick all the floozies out of his bed.  I knew when I started it would be entertaining and erotic - how could it not be?!?  This was Jesse.  But his story turned out to be so much more than I could have ever expected - I loved it.Jesse and Bell are two characters who are barely living.  They are hiding so much sadness and despair from their friends and family because have just accepted their fate... that true happiness is not in their future. Even though they find solace and incredible passion with one another - I wondered if they would be able to help permanently soothe each other's inner demons.Because Jesse doesn't want to forgive himself for things that's were beyond his control and Bell refuses to stop trying to make up for a lost life. Their journey wasn't about anticipating them surrendering to their lust because they did that easily. It was more about the moment they would finally move past their pain and accept that they deserved love and comfort.It was what made their romance feel so powerful and had me devouring their story. I was rooting for them to succeed and to find their happily ever after together. It's an awesome story.I have enjoyed all the books in the Knights Rebels series. I think it is because of River Savage's characters - she creates these raw and intense people and you're drawn into their world. Once I meet them, they always crack open my heart and sneak inside, captivating me with their abrasive personalities. Because beyond all the gruff, they are the most loyal men who love with all of their hearts - even before they realize they're doing it.It makes for a highly entertaining reading experience that you really don't want to miss out on.  Definitely check out the men and women of the Knights Rebels MC series.

I spent last week dialed into the violent and gritty world of Amity Cross's Royal Blood series. It's a dark environment filled with seriously nefarious characters.  A place where no one seems safe and where situations are so bad, people are risking everything to be free of it. However, I loved being there. I was completely immersed in Mercy and Xavier's romance because their love and relationship was this strangely beautiful light the shined through the chaos of it all.The latest installment in this series, Devil's Blood, didn't feel like it was about revenge as much as the previous books. It was more about this duo finding their new normal. Xavier and Mercy are unsettled - where do they go now?  They struggled quite a bit emotionally and to move forward but they had some major roadblocks in their way. It almost made me feel like their love wasn't going to be enough and it only made me root for them more.And then the Amity drop kicked the plot into high gear and everything goes to absolute hell for the couple. It was amazing.  I was on the edge of my seat worried for them and where I was once only curious about their future, I now was terrified that they might never get their happily ever after.I shouldn't have worried.  The way the author concluded their story was incredible - it unfolds in a manor that leaves you feeling addicted.  I devoured page after page and I loved every single moment in this book.I thought Devil's Blood is intense and emotionally charged. The sexual connection between Xavier and Mercy alone will leave you panting and wanting more. Add to that the drama and suspense surrounding Xavier's past and you're unable to put Devil's Blood down. It is an awesome book and I highly recommend it.

Sweet Jesus – what have you done to me, Tracie Redmond!?!  I am suffering from a crazy book hangover. Her book, Guided Love has me wanting to drop f-bombs left and right because this book infuriated me. It’s characters made me swoon. They made me laugh. And cry.  ARGGG!!  It created a mother load of feelings within me.I am not even sure where I want to start this review – so much happens in this book.  The gist of it all is that Sam is in love with her best friend, Camaron and he is a giant, selfish prick.  I wanted to lambaste him for his horrendous behavior. Seriously. He is the worst best friend ever. EVER. He made my heart ache for Sam.And let me just state for the record, I wanted to smack Sam upside the back of her head for seventy percent of this book. Or kick her in the shins really hard. And then I wanted to give her a bear hug. This girl, Sam was amazing. Smart. Loving. Hilarious. Yet, Sam had absolutely no self-confidence and every single time she accepted less than her worth, I wanted to kick her butt.However, the person I actually wanted to hurt was Camaron. I disliked him more than any book character I have meet in a while. No, that isn’t true – I absolutely hated Roni.  I think I’d like to harm Roni. (I told you this book made me impassioned – now I want to beat up these made up characters!!)Thank goodness all of this is balanced out with Axel.  Oh my swoon worthy man.  I loved him.  I would take a million scenes with Camaron and Roni just to get a few more with him and Samantha.  He was sweet and loyal.  Badass.  Enticing and sexy.  Did I say I loved him yet – because I did – I LOVED this character.All that Sam and this misfit gang of pricks endure – good or bad – captivates your attention. I especially thought Sam’s journey toward finding herself and then love was incredible.  The life she creates versus the one she expected will leave you feeling proud.  It is an awesome story and I can’t wait to read more. Don’t miss out on this experience.  Read Guided Love now.

Sweet mother of all things tempting.  I am completely addicted to The Scene series and I am PRAYING that certain people are not who they are be alluded to being.I thought the follow up installment in The Scene series was much more intense than the first one.  It feels like Nicole is digging deeper and deeper into the mystery that is her brother's death, only to find out she might not truly want to learn what happened. What should be helping her find peace is creating havoc in her life.However, that is nothing compared to her confusion about of her connection and attraction to Xavier.  Her brain is telling her one thing but her heart and body are telling it to shut the hell up.  She can't resist him and when she gives into her lust for him - wooziers - it's all kinds of erotic hotness.I am seriously loving the excitement and intrigue of it all.  The second part in the Scene series moved along swiftly and the reader is given a lot more details of Eli's life and his death.  We're introduced to a few more characters and it ended on a bit of a terse note.  I'm not sure how all of this is going to play out, but I honestly cannot wait to read it.I definitely suggest you purchase and read The Scene serial series.

I absolutely loved A Taste of Summer. This book created a slow aching burn in my chest the entire time I was reading it.  I couldn't put it down and it is a top recommendation from me.Summer and Carrie Ann fell madly in love while they were in college. They were each other's everything until their world crumbled when things didn't go exactly as they planned.  Ten years have passed since then and Summer has decided it is well past the time to fix their relationship. He wants Carrie Ann back and is ruthless in his dedication to prove himself and his love.Except Carrie Ann is holding on tightly to her pain and a few secrets.  Even though no one has touched her the way Summer did all those years ago, she is stubborn in her refusal to forgive.  It left me wondering and anticipating what would be the moment when Summer finally reached her.  What would it take for her to forgive and more forward?!I felt so much while reading their story that my heart hurt.  I felt the anxiety and stress of their reunion as well as the passionate connection that could not be ignored between these two main characters. Their journey was emotional and painful at times but their moments of sweetness blew me away.  I laughed out loud at the witty banter.  I shed a tear when I learned the truth of their destruction. Basically, I fell in love with Carrie Ann and Summer.Each book in this series is incredible.  To experience the romance and attraction between Beverly's characters is something you do not want to miss out on. Their stories unfold well and I am always caught up in the drama as well as the love story.  Definitely check out the Mathews Family series, especially A Taste of Summer.

Holy hotness. I didn't think that Dex and Raine's romance could get any more intense or erotic - but I was completely wrong.  Not only did their book get my lady bits tingling and my heart pounding but it also kept me on the edge of my seat - captivated and entertained by the suspenseful sub-plot.  The conclusion to their story was incredible and everything I could have wanted for this couple.Devouring Raine essentially picks right up where Taming Dex ended. The band is almost finished with their tour and all seems well. Dex and Raine's connection feels more solidified, thanks to their budding Dom/Sub relationship and the fact that they have no secrets between them.  They give and take what they need. Not in a selfish way but more so because they find solace in each other.Their second book's storyline moves quickly. Moving around between their training (which is highly arousing and seductive) to the unfolding drama of Raine's stalker issues (which was the right level of scary and tenseness). It's all seriously awesome. Both sides of the story balance well - escalating at a dramatic pace without it feeling overwhelming. It all just pulls you toward a thrilling and epic conclusion.I loved the addition of this couple's love story to the 69 Bottles series. I never reached a point where I wanted to leave Dex and Raine's world.  I would definitely recommend both Taming Dex and then Devouring Raine - they are can't miss reading!!

I was consumed by the second book in the Capital Confessions series.  Playing with Trouble was an incredibly fun and sexy read that I devoured in one sitting.  Blaire and Gray’s passionate journey toward finding happiness and solace in their lives is one you do not want to miss out on.I loved how nothing about this affair on paper makes sense.  Their student/teacher connection makes a relationship taboo.  The age difference is a stumbling block.  Yet when the two are together, it feels so right and so unavoidable. I was rooting for them.Blaire and Gray are at Hannover Law School rebuilding their lives – basically hiding out from their own harsh realities.  They’re both desperate to end the chaos of their lives. So they have carefully crafted plans to overcome their very public reputations and to secure their futures – all in hopes of finding a little bit of normalcy. They thought they could just lay low and regroup.  Neither one of them was expecting to find someone to care about or to experience the intense lust they feel when they meet.  It’s overwhelming and they almost have no clue what to do with it all.Their lives are a hot mess of drama.And the longer I spent inside of Blaire’s world, the more it felt like I was looking at a picture in a coloring book. Blaire’s picture (aka her life) has been completed as it was expected of her – delicately colored within the lines and done to perfection. Except Blaire’s life has been rocked and she was pushed to color outside lines. Her imagine will never be exactly as it was originally designed but the longer Blaire looks, the more she likes it the way it is. It makes her want to chase after what she desires and needs – Gray.  I loved it.I seriously could not get enough of this duo.  Every scene with Blaire and Gray kept a smile on my face.  Whether they were in class using verbal banter as their foreplay or being privy to their private sexual thoughts and actions – it all left me completely entertained and wanting more because their passion for one another jumps off the page.  They capture your attention and makes your lady bits tingle.  It is spectacular.Playing with Trouble is a top recommendation from me, as was the first book, Flirting with Disaster.  Definitely check out the Capital Confessions series.

Fighting Fate is not your typical happily ever after feel good romance book. The hero doesn't court his lady love. He doesn't bring her flowers or take her on glamorous dates but Ivy and Dax's journey together makes you enchanted anyway and somehow that makes you appreciate their love for one another so much more.Ivy and Dax are strong-willed survivors whose relationship starts with a crazy and intense situation. Nothing about their circumstance is normal and they are both trapped in their current predicament.  While this makes them understand each other better, there is a hesitation to truly commit. They know the other will manipulate and mold themselves to be whatever the situation calls for so they both worry that they are being emotionally deceived.Neither knows what is real or how a future together could be possible. Yet, you feel their connection and it snatches a hold of your attention until the very last page.  Scarlett Finn's characters are incredibly entertaining.I absolutely loved how the author has the plot playing out.  The couple's feelings had me feeling wooed and curious - I was devouring page after page - I mean, how can something beautiful be created out of something horrific?! I thought Fighting Fate's tale was a dark, twisted story that was completely seductive and highly erotic. It's awesome.I definitely suggest you meet this duo - their book is one you will not forget. Fighting Fate is can't miss reading.

Have you ever read a book that you absolutely loved and wanted everyone to read but you’re not totally sure how to express the genius hidden between the covers without sharing the plot twists?!? That’s me right now. This book blew me away. The romance between Alexis and Oliver in King of Hearts went beyond all of my expectations. I absolutely adored their story.Right from the start, I was amused and entertained by Alexis and Oliver. Their quick wit and banter made me giggle and I was crushing hard on the two. I thought they were both charming and incredibly engaging. I loved every moment they pushed each other’s boundaries while fighting their attraction and lust for one another. I highly anticipated the moment their relationship would change from coworkers to lovers.It was evident from the start that Alexis and Oliver belonged together but their journey toward happily ever after was not at all what I envisioned after reading the book’s blurb. The hardships and troubles that they had to overcome tugged at my heart and endeared their characters to me. It’s truly a spectacular story.King of Hearts is a top recommendation for me.  I loved every single minute I spent with this couple – I was totally enraptured with their lives and romance.

When I first started reading, I wasn't sure how invested I would be with the characters and plot in Mine. I was worried after the first few chapters that it was just going to be a quick novella filled with a erotic scenes and vulgar words but not a whole lot more. Don't get me wrong - that type of story is entertaining but I like my serial series to be more. I need to truly be enticed into wanting the next installment. My mind needs to be tempted while my lady bits are tingling.So I was more than pleasantly surprised when I kept reading Mine. The characters turned out to be alluring as well as arousing. Nixon and Brooklyn share an undeniable connection - one you want to spend more time with. It's awesome.They both clearly carry emotional scars from their pasts and have too many secrets. I felt more than curious to know them better - by the end I was desperate for more and for them to give into their attraction to one another.  These two - holy hotness!! I cannot wait to experience their passion when it is finally released!!AND THAT ENDING - OMG!! I am hooked. I want the next installment in this series and highly suggest you find out why. Definitely start reading the Imperfect Chaos series today.

Inside Game was everything I wanted and could have asked for in a sports romance book. Dramatic. Suspenseful.  Intoxicating.I have been waiting for this book since I started reading about the men of the New York Kings baseball team. I was more than a little curious to know what was going on with Drake Schultz. Why was he so bitter and angry? Had he been scorned by a woman? Was he living with a terrible secret or tragedy from his past? What made him so mean? But more than wanting to know all of that, I was desperate to meet the person who would help him heal.Drake's story was awesome. Not only did my opinion of him change completely, I ended up really liking this character.  He earned my respect which surprised me after reading the other books.  With each new chapter, I had a better insight to what caused his issues and life complications. It's an incredible plot.Drake's drama is coupled with his budding romance with Eva, his sober companion. Eva has no clue what she has meant to Drake over the years but she's nervous about what she is becoming to him now because their relationship cannot happen.  She's committed to helping him even at the cost of her own feelings.  The two fighting their lust is almost as spectacular as when they give into it.Their story makes for an exceptional read.  It's intense and enticing.  The connection between Drake and Eva leaps off the page and you feel their attraction to one another.  I absolutely loved it and definitely suggest you check it out.  Inside Game is a top recommendation from me as are all of the other books in this series.

Roxy Sloane is an word temptress. No wait - she's more like a dealer and she has made me a junkie to her product. Her characters and their worlds - sweet Jesus. Addicted doesn't seem to be a strong enough description to what I feel when I read her various series and I always need more.The first installment in The Scene was freaking enticing - thanks to the introduction of Nicole to Xavier.  Holy hotness.  (Plan to have your panties incinerated.) Roxy lures the reader into their lives with each page - curious to know more about them. To learn their secrets and to find out what happened to Nicole's brother. It is awesome.The Scene reads quickly and ends with a jaw dropping cliff-hanger that wasn't surprising but still left me squealing. That's the power of Roxy's stories. What should be predictable is entertaining.  I love it.Every time Roxy writes a new serial series, I make myself a promise. Don't start reading it until all the parts have been released. Save yourself the anxiety and stress of craving something you absolutely cannot get your hands on for weeks.Then I remember, I'm a junkie and I ignore my promises. I can't help myself - I love being addicted to her words. The anticipation and excitement of not knowing when I'll be cut off, makes each scene feel more intense - it's why everything Roxy Sloane writes is a must read.  Definitely check The Scene out.

Laguna Nights was more than a sweet and sexy second chance romance. It is a well written book that will capture your attention and a bit of your heart.  The two main characters, Josh and Madison were high school sweethearts whose relationship was destructed in a very public and heart-aching way. Laguna Nights is their story about healing and finding their way back to one another.When they are reunited it seems like fate is stepping in to right past wrongs. However, as I read more, I felt confused. It seemed like there is something underhanded going on behind the scenes.  It had me devouring chapter after chapter - trying to understand what really is going on. I was not sure if I could trust what the characters were saying and doing. There is a lot going on in this book.It makes for entertaining reading.The plot unfolds well and by the time you reach the conclusion you're very much enchanted by Josh and Madison. You will experience a full range of emotions with these two - it's great.  I ended up rooting for them and wanted them to find their happily ever after moment.Overall, Laguna Nights is a very enjoyable read and I would definitely recommend it!

I am absolutely loving Harper Sloan's spinoff series Hope Town. The children of the Corps Security men and women are just as fabulous and enticing as their parents were - if not more. The second installment in this series, Bleeding Love was spectacular. The entire time I was reading my heart was pounding, excited and happy to be falling in love with Liam and Megan.This book was honestly so much fun to read. Liam Beckett is on a mission. He spent his entire life watching his parents be completely in love and has been searching for the same type of connection and affection for himself. He knew instantly upon meeting Megan again that she was his one. So be prepared to swoon - Liam is going to melt your heart and his charming ways will wreck you for all other book boyfriends.It's completely an uphill battle to win Megan's heart. Her character is grieving and scared to truly live. I wanted to give her a hug and then shove her into Liam's bed. Not just for her - I wanted to be there too - listening to Lee whisper his desires and all of his naughty thoughts.Their journey together moves swiftly and before you know it you devoured their entire story. You're left with a smile on your face and probably in need of new panties. Additionally, you're gifted with more time with all of our favorite characters from previous books and it is awesome. All of it combined definitely makes Bleeding Love a must read book.

My wife liked these teardrop gold earrings and found that they are of generally good quality and more importantly, look nice. The earrings are not large at all and fit comfortably. All in all, a nicely crafted earring at a reasonable cost.

This is a great overview of the band that covers the 1974-1980 timeframe which finds the group at the height of their cultural influence. I generally liked the track selection, although I was never fond of Audio Visions (1980) so those tracks did nothing for me. Overall, the emphasis of this 2 CD set is on their progressive material; the "boogie" tracks are not represented.The tracks are presented chronologically and are largely taken from the studio albums with the exception of a single demo (Can I Tell You); a "new" track written in 1994; and live versions of Death of Mother Nature Suite, Incomudro: Hymn to the Atman, and On the Other Side. The sound quality of the live tracks is not bad, although the sound level varies a bit track to track.As a long-time fan of progressive music, it is the lengthier tracks that hold my attention, although the playing is top notch on just about everything they released (yes, even the "boogie" tracks). One thing that I loved about Kansas was their ability to make a 7 or 8 minute song seem to last for 20 minutes - they did this with a lot of instrumental preludes and interludes.  I also liked the energy of their music - these guys could simply rip, even in 7/8. Because the tracks are laid out chronologically, you can hear the gradual shift from more complex arrangements to a more straightforward approach by 1980.  I am of the opinion that the group hit an absolute peak in 1976-1977 with Leftoverture and Point of Know Return, respectively. I also enjoyed the Monolith album (1979), which is represented by three tracks. The last track on the set was written specifically for this box set and it is really nice; I prefer it over the three selections from Audio Visions.This "box set" is generally nice and features an informative booklet with photos of the group.  The sound quality is not bad at all, although there are issues with the sound level across tracks. Then again, this set predates the remasters so the sound quality is not as good as it could be. I should note that there are other compilations out there that offer better sound quality (Kansas: The Ultimate Collection comes to mind). I just got this box set for the demo, live tracks, and the new track Wheels.All in all, this is a great compilation of some of the finest material released by Kansas during their heyday. I now realize, some 30 or so years after the fact, that Kansas made a truly original contribution to progressive rock. If you are new to the group, you can't go wrong with this compilation. It does a good job of summing up their unique combination of sophisticated arrangements; blistering hard rock; and insightful lyrics that address the spiritual quest. Recommended along with the following albums: Kansas (1974); Masque (1975); Song for America (1975); Leftoverture (1976); Point of Know Return (1977); the live album Two for the Show (1978); and Monolith (1979).

My wife has been using this iHealth device for about two weeks now and generally likes it. The device tracks her steps per day, and total distance traveled; I do have issues that the unit will record a "step" just by moving your arm somewhat vigorously. This shortcoming aside, my wife finds that the unit motivates her to do more steps and believes that the output is accurate. After installing an app on her phone, my wife can now view historical data and track her progress. Apart from my issue with inaccurate data, two inconveniences that she noted was that (1) the instruction booklet is not the easiest to follow and (2) it is very hard to read the device in the sun.All in all, this is a decent way of keeping fit and tracking your progress as you go. My wife certainly likes it.

This twister set is a lot of fun for our kids (ages 7 and 8), although it is a bit annoying for certain adults.  Ok ok, my wife and I found the music to be irritating - it is not particularly pleasant sounding to my ears and it is pretty loud.  The annoyances with the music aside, the game is a lot of fun to play; especially with two players.  The game is easy to set up and seems fairly sturdy - this is important because there is a lot of foot stomping involved.  The unit takes 3 AA batteries.All in all, this is a neat variation on the classic Twister game.  Although I prefer the old version (the mat on the floor), this should prove to be a lot of fun for the kids.

This is a decent grill that we have used for a variety of foods including chicken breasts, hamburgers, grilled sandwiches etc. Because we use this indoors, I was a little concerned about smoke issues, but there are none, at least when preparing the food.  I should note that the grill smoked quite a bit when I first turned it on - rather, I plugged it in (there is no on/off switch).  I unplugged the unit, let it cool, wiped it down with a wet paper towel, and plugged it back in - that took care of the "smoking" issues. The overall construction of the grill is a bit cheap, but sturdy enough for general use. It is pretty easy to clean.All in all, this is a good grill suitable for indoor use. Just make sure to wipe it down thoroughly before use.

Our 7 year old daughter loved this Anna and Elsa tandem bicycle set. She was also delighted that it came with Olaf to ride in the basket in the front of the bike. The details of the bike are also pretty cool  - Anna and Elsa fit snugly into the bike pedals and move their legs when the pedals are moved. The music from the movie only plays when a button is pressed - short snippets only (maybe 10-15 seconds tops).  Overall, the quality of the toy is very good.All in all, this is a great toy for all fans of Disney's Frozen - our daughter is apparently obsessed!

My wife seems to like this skin toner.  She has found that it leaves her skin looking smoother without irritating or drying her skin out.The toner has a light "floral" scent that is not overpowering, with just the slightest hint of witch hazel. I also smelled a touch of isopropyl alcohol - there are alcohols in the toner including benzyl alcohol. Apart from some useless information regarding the percentage of natural ingredients (including those derived from organic farming), the composition of the mixture is not clearly printed on the side of the container. So, unfortunately, the consumer does not know what relative percentage the alcohols comprise (shooting from the hip, I can't imagine it is >1%).  Suffice it to say, that if you are sensitive to alcohols, this might not be the best skin toner for you. There are, in fact, alcohol-free alternatives out there that may be a bit cheaper.The toner has the consistency of water, so the application is neat and does not stain clothing. My wife has found that she does not need to apply a lot, so this 200 milliliter (6.8 fluid ounce) container has lasted a long time.All in all, this is good skin toner that has a light, pleasant fragrance. The toner is easy to apply, neat, and despite the presence of alcohols, has not dried my wife's skin out.

Our 7 year old daughter loves this toothbrush. It used to be the case that brushing teeth was a chore where we had to...pull teeth just to get the brushing done. Fortunately, the interactive part of the toothbrush keeps her engaged by allowing her to watch short videos on her iPad that show her how to brush. Although there were some slight hiccups downloading the application to the iPad, the problems were solved quickly.I think that the blending of an interactive video with what is such a mundane chore was actually kind of clever.  It has certainly made the bedtime process that much smoother - that, and she is now brushing her teeth regularly and actually enjoying it.All in all, this is a great tool for getting the kids interested in brushing their teeth. It certainly worked wonders with our children.

This 1969 release is fantastic.  Over the years I must have listened to this thousands of time - and I never get tired of it. For me, the appeal lies with the energy of the music, and the fact that the distinctive sound of the group had gelled.  This was riff-heavy bravado, yet with a subtlety and sophistication that would characterize their later output.Some of my favorite tunes are on this album including the bass guitar-heavy The Lemon Song, Ramble On, and the delicate Thank You.  Overall, the music presents a nice balance of heavy riffs and some quieter moments.  There are also nods in the direction of jazz-rock (What is What Should Never Be), some classical (Thank You) and English folk rock (the introduction to Ramble On. Although some of the lyrics are not to my liking (The Lemon Song comes to mind), there are the first signs of the middle earth references that would be in full bloom on later albums.  Ramble On comes to mind, where Robert Plant sings of meeting a girl in darkest Mordor, only to have her run off with Gollum. The blending of the Lord of the Rings with some of the uh, cheekier lyrics on the album makes for an interesting combination.The version of the CD that I own is the 1994 remaster, so this review should not be confused with any other version floating around out there - and there are several.  The sound quality is not bad, although there appears to be some distortion on a few tracks - this is especially apparent on sections where the drums, bass, and electric guitar are going full steam ahead. There is not much in the way of liner notes, although the inner gatefold was reproduced (based on what I remember of my old and dearly departed LP).All in all, this is one of my favorites from the group.  It has power. It has emotion. It screams, breathes, and sweats. And above all else, it just plain rocks.

This is a great charger cable that we use to charge our Apple devices including iPhones and iPads. The sturdy construction is a welcome feature - we seem to destroy charger cables at an alarming rate - the kids just wreak havoc on them.  The cable is long enough so that you can charge your device using those out-of-reach sockets while simultaneously using the iPad or other device - no need to stash the iPad out of reach. We like the red color -it makes it easier to find.  All in all, a sturdy charger cable that can withstand the rigors of day-to-day living.

This Queen Size Serta Regular 9" Stabl-Base Foundation was delivered in a large box. The mattress itself was covered in plastic which was a nice touch. Although the boxspring is light, it is bulky which makes maneuvering up the stairs a little difficult. Furthermore, because the boxspring is rigid, there is no way that it would make it up a really tight stairwell.  This is just food for thought though and not so much a criticism.The boxspring is sturdy and can stand up to the rigors of two children jumping up and down on it.  The colored pattern along the side is a nice touch too, although it helps if you have a nice bed frame and nothing under the bed.  We used light cloth "concealers" to cover our old box spring and the junk under the bed. We still use the concealer though - it just looks a little nicer.All in all, this is a nice boxspring from one of the better manufacturers out there. Although there does not seem to be an appreciable difference from our old boxspring, it certainly does its job well.

My wife used these patches to address a few wrinkles around the forehead and mouth. The gel patches were a departure for my wife, who typically uses a cream or serum. As she described, the patches were applied for 10 minutes and felt cool on the skin. There was also a slight tingling sensation. Nothing too horrific though - even when left on for longer than the suggested 10 minute application time. Overall, she found that the patches firmed her skin up and was very pleased with this product.

This live 1981 release came out at a time when I had just discovered Rush and culls performances from the Permanent Waves and Moving Pictures tours of 1980/1981. I had attended the Moving Pictures tour (and the subsequent Signals tour in 1982, which was my last Rush concert). As such, I found that this album brought back some fond memories and is a great souvenir from a time when Rush made some of my favorite music.The track selection is great and Exit...Stage Left could easily double as an excellent compilation.  The fact that the sound quality is so good, and the audience participation has been severely limited also contributes to the "compilation-like" quality of this album.  I think that the performances are excellent and the tunes, although largely played as they appear on record, are changed subtly here and there.  Nice additions include the drum solo on YYZ, the acoustic guitar solo piece "Broon's Bane" that leads into "The Trees" (and then Xanadu), and the extended electric guitar introduction to a searing version of La Villa Strangiato.Although some people have complained that this album is too polished, the smoothness does not bother me one bit.  I don't like attending live rock performances because of the obnoxious crowds, so the limited audience noise at the end of each track (and the sing-along on Closer to Heart) did not bother me too much. This is a live album after all. The sound quality is excellent, although the fact that this was originally presented as a double record with "sides" that had to be turned over does turn up every so often - Passage to Bangkok seems to come out of left field.All in all, this is a fine souvenir from the height of their powers. Recommended along with 2112 (1976), Farewell to Kings (1977), Hemispheres (1978), Permanent Waves (1980), Moving Pictures (1981), and Signals (1982).

This phone is great for just about anything - it is somewhere in-between a tablet and an iPhone, so the kids have been using it for games, in addition to general phone use. I don't think the camera/video quality is all that hot. The quality of the images on the phone are fantastic though - colors are vibrant and the images are crisp.  If you listen to music through a phone - I prefer a proper sound system - you might not be that thrilled.  The sound quality is weak. When played through a remote speaker, however, the sound improves a little. I personally find the larger size of the phone to be a bit bothersome - I like the smaller size of my iPhone much better. All in all, this is a nice phone that reflects current trends in personal phones - they seem to be getting larger. For the person that needs a no-nonsense phone to simply make calls, this may be a bit much.  However, for those people that use the phone for recording videos, playing games, accessing the internet, in addition to making calls, this really is a nice phone.

This 2012 compilation from Rhino is actually not bad at all. Although I am not generally fond of compilations, this 2-CD set works pretty well and is great to listen to in the car - I have a fairly long commute. Overall, as a long-time Yes fan, I found that this made a nice addition to my Yes collection although there were things that I liked and disliked.I liked the overall package, which (inexplicably) contains some of the cover paintings from the live Yessongs album (1973) and comes with a cover for the CD case. There are also some liner notes that, while not breaking any new ground, will provide the new fan with a nice overview of the group. I thought that the track selection was pretty good, even though the emphasis on CD 1 is on three albums released during the 1971-1972 timeframe (The Yes Album, Fragile, and Close to the Edge). In fact, Close to the Edge is featured in its entirety, which is pretty cool - most people regard it as their best album. One of my favorite tracks from Tales from Topographic Oceans (1973) made it on CD 2 in its entirety - this was another plus. Generally, I prefer CD 2 because of the wider range in tracks/albums. I also thought that the time period covered was good too (1970-1983). This was the time during which Yes made their biggest cultural impact.I never liked albums such as the not-so-great experiment with an orchestra on Time and a Word (1970) or the arena rock of 90125 (1983) so those selections did not do much for me.  I also did not like the fact that Relayer (1974) is only represented by a single edit (Soon) and that the 1969 debut and Tormato (1978) were ignored. An (ostensibly) representative overview for the new fan should try to include something from every album. I also did not like how the sound quality varies from track to track - some tracks are "hotter" than others so you will have to adjust the volume between tracks. The sound quality is not bad overall.All in all, this is not a bad compilation and may be the best Yes compilation out there for the fan (old and new alike). You also can not beat the low cost of this set - you definitely get a lot of tunes for your money.

For years, we have been stuffing our valuables into a very small safe - something about the size of a lunch box - the stuff that we could not fit was relegated to boxes. This safe is fantastic because it has just enough storage space that we can fit all of our valuable stuff in, with lots of room left over.The safe is very heavy so we keep it on a dry concrete floor in a storage room.  I am not concerned about moisture, because our storage area is very dry. Moisture, however, might pose problems in some situations - I would not, for example, keep the safe in a moist basement.  Although there are desiccant bags included with the safe, the amount of effort required to keep the safe moisture-free might not be worth it for some people. The desiccant bags have to be replaced every six months or so - maybe more frequently if the moisture levels are high. It is certainly not something that I would want to be worrying about.The safe comes equipped with a small drawer and a large drawer.  The large drawer can accommodate a large shoe box; the small drawer is good for smaller items such as jewelry and important documents. The safe keypad lights up when you touch it; programming the safe code is pretty easy. Whatever you do, make sure you have the code handy - we entered the code incorrectly one too many times and the alarm that went off was extremely loud. We use the code/key combination for extra security.All in all, this is an excellent safe that is large enough that it should handle the needs of most people.  The safe is extremely well-constructed and extremely heavy. It is, however, not so large that it can't fit in the corner of a storage room or similar setting.

My wife liked this facial treatment and seems to have noticed a slight improvement in the smoothness and tightness of her skin. She applies the product in the morning and at night as a light coating that she rubs in. She has found that very little is required and that the bottle lasts for quite some time.The product is largely odorless (although there is a very faint sourness), has the consistency of water, and contains an alcohol yeast extract "Pitera" (the non-trade name for the yeast extract is Saccharomycopsis ferment filtrate). This is the "miracle" anti-aging element that gives this product its elevated status and price tag. Yeast extracts are encountered in the fermentation of sake (Pitera) and beer, not to mention lots of cosmetics, including cheap products that you can find just about anywhere. Very little data have been published by Proctor and Gamble (they own SK-II) as to the effectiveness of Pitera relative to other yeast extracts. There is also a dearth of published peer-reviewed journal articles that indicate the effectiveness of Saccharomycopsis ferment filtrate itself.What this product does is hydrate the skin, which in turn contributes to the "plumpness" of the skin - the plumpness is achieved as the skin swells. This will make wrinkles seem to disappear and smooth out other imperfections.  I think this is what my wife is noticing, and if it works for her then that is OK by me.All in all, this is a good skin care product that seems to have generated somewhat positive results for my wife with no ill side effects.  As with any skin care product though, if you have issues with your skin to start with, consult with a proper dermatologist before using this product. Furthermore, before plunking down money for this stuff, experiment with other products - you may experience similar results at a lower cost. In fact, even my wife commented that she expected more "bang for the buck".

My wife listens to her iTunes through wireless speakers quite a lot and absolutely loved this speaker by Braven. We have owned other bluetooth wireless speakers but have not been satisfied with the sound quality of wireless speakers until now.I have to admit that the bass response of this speaker is impressive given the small size. The speaker is water resistant so it can be used in the bathroom while taking a shower or in other moist environments. The speaker is very easy to set up and pair with your devices and holds a charge for quite a long time - my wife used the speaker for one hour each day for a period of five days without having to re-recharge. The only drawback to the speaker is that it does not come equipped with a light that tells you when the unit is on and off. Although the speaker generates a different tone when being turned on and off, a light would make a world of difference.All in all, this is a great wireless speaker that boasts great sound quality.  It is compact and can be used in a range of environments.  Although an on/off light would be nice, it does not detract from the overall quality of the speaker.

Just like every debut album, this 1995 release from Norwegian post-progressive outfit White Willow has some fine moments, but also stumbles at times. Fortunately, as the group matured, their sound gelled, and the sophistication of the compositions increased (especially with the addition of keyboardist Lars Fredrik Frislie). I generally liked this debut though, and Ignis Fatuus is important because the band was up and running. Then again, I am a huge fan of the group and absolutely have to get everything they released.The tunes themselves are generally on the quiet side, and at times pastoral. One of the things that I like about this group is their blend of current indie rock and the best of 1970s progressive - I did not hear that blend on this debut. There are snippets of medieval English folk music here and there (Gryphon comes to mind). Unfortunately, these passages are not too well integrated with the rest of the tracks and seem at odds with the overall feel of the album.  The playing is very solid though, and both the guitarist and keyboardist turn in some good performances.Although I think the shorter tracks work very well, the longer tracks seem to meander aimlessly at times - there is little dynamic contrast, the melodies are not developed, and there is no sense of long-range planning.  The gloomy moods/textures that the band creates makes up for it though - this is dark stuff with a few nods in the direction of Swedish post-progressive outfit Anglagard. I thought the female vocalist was quite good - unfortunately, there are other (male) vocalists that do not quite hit the mark.The production quality is pretty good - there is a good balance of individual instruments and everything sounds crisp.  The CD comes with a booklet that features the lyrics, recording credits and some arty images.  I thought the package was very nice and have no desire to seek out the remastered version of this album.All in all, this album is significant in that White Willow was up and running.  Although most of the White Willow sound is present, they would release better developed records as they matured and gelled as a group. This applies to the excellent follow-up album Ex Tenebris (1998).

I spent a little time in the National Park Service as a field biologist during my undergraduate days and became very familiar with the use of two-way radios, the ten-code, how not to freak out over the radio in an emergency etc. I found that the most critical element of the radio was its ability to hold a charge - no power and you are up a creek (the units were old). We had been looking for a two-way radio as a means of alternative communication when on a family hike, keeping tabs on the kids, local stuff mainly. When we saw this unit, we snapped it up- it really suited our needs - I also made doubly sure that it came with a reliable charger.Although much smaller than the government radios I used, these things more than make up for it in features and ease of use. The radio is equipped with a small, yet powerful light that doubles as a flashing signal and an FM radio - the sound quality is what you might expect from a speaker the size of a silver dollar (kind of tinny and thin). With respect to the ease of use, simply turn the unit on, make sure both units are locked at the same frequency, and depress the PTT button to communicate. Our kids love these radios and use them quite a lot while playing outside - they are really good at using them and have learned not to change the frequency setting while using them.I have not been able to test the limits of the range of the radio, however. We have only used it while out of sight of one another in the woods, but still in close proximity (100 -200 feet). I have also not made use of the programming ability of the radio. The manufacturer has a decent website that has various software available for download and the programming of the unit seems fairly simple.With respect to the quality of the radios, they are generally well-made and solid.  The kids are a bit rough with them at times, but they have held up well to being dropped on the ground, buried in snow etc. The speaker is really good at handling higher volumes, and communications are broadcast with crystal clarity. Now for the charger - it works very well. The cradle holds the radio snugly, so there is no chance that it will not charge properly. The radios hold a charge for an extremely long time by virtue of design - during times of light use, ours have gone without a charge for at least 2 weeks. This will vary with the amount they are used though - if you use them 8 hours a day, you will likely have to throw them on the charger overnight for use the next day.All in all, this is a perfect two-way radio for use on a hike, a short trip, or during play. It is a high quality unit that reproduces communications with high fidelity. Oh, and the charger works really well too.

This was the last album released by the entire group; drummer John Bonham passed away shortly after the release of In through the Out Door (1979).  Although I do not rank this up there with my favorites by Led Zeppelin (III; Houses of the Holy; side 3 (vinyl LP) of Physical Graffiti), there is enough of the Led Zeppelin “thing” on this album that I generally liked it.  Come to think of it, I really liked the tune All of my Love back in the day, so this album also has sentimental value.The album has an overall softer sound to it and seems to me to be more reflective.  I don’t mind this one bit – Led Zeppelin always had a softer side to them, so it really was not that much a departure. I think the playing on the album is actually very good and Jimmy Page got some great tones out of the electric guitar.  I also like the use of synthesizers too (mostly Yamaha GX-1) – it lends the album an atmospheric feel. The greater use of synthesizers likely reflects the fact that John Paul Jones (and Robert Plant) did most of the writing. At the time, Jimmy Page and John Bonham were struggling with substance abuse problems.The only track on the album that did not sit well with me was the rockabilly of Hot Dog – although I appreciate the fact that the group was trying to shake things up a bit, this one tune did not work for me.Although the version of the CD I have has not been remastered, the sound quality is not bad at all. The CD booklet comes with some basic recording credits and a few arty images. The cover (by Hipgnosis) is pretty cool.All in all, this is a decent album that has a least a few gems on it. It is a little quieter than other Led Zeppelin albums but has enough of the Led Zeppelin sound that it makes for a pretty enjoyable listen.

After watching this excellent biography of Rush, I now realize the extent of the camaraderie that has kept them together through thick and thin. I was also provided with insights into their characters that I was not fully aware of, adding yet another facet to a group that I thought I knew inside and out.The care and attention that went into making this film is nothing short of spectacular; the sound quality is excellent and the interviews with the band members were generally insightful.  Of the three members, I found myself relating to Neil Peart the most, and no, I don't regard him as a sourpuss because he values his privacy.  His lyrics have been an inspiration ever since I started listening to the group, and his drumming is, well, mind-blowing. Come to think of it, I might pick up his book Ghost Rider, which chronicles the road he traveled (literally and figuratively) while recovering from the tragic loss of his wife and child.The film is laid out chronologically and nicely illustrates the changes that their music went through decade after decade. At the beginning, there is some cool footage of Alex Lifeson having a passionate discussion with his parents recorded sometime in the early 1970s- it paints a nice picture of an idealistic and principled young man. The film then progresses through their career, and the viewer is treated to live performances, excellent insights from producer Terry Brown, and tidbits on the recording process. Overall, the emphasis was on the 1970s material, and to a lesser extent the synth-heavy albums of the 1980s. My general impression was that the albums from the 1990s, 2000s, and 2010s were somewhat glossed over, with the exception of Vapor Trails, which was the big comeback for Neil.There are also interviews with various musicians (Kiss, Uriah Heep, Max Webster, Dream Theater, Metallica, Smashing Pumpkins, Rage Against the Machine, Foo Fighters, Sebastian Bach, Tool, Nine Inch Nails) and actors (Jack Black). Although I found the commentaries from the musicians and actors useless - OK, I will admit that Gene Simmons [Kiss] was pretty funny and the guy from Uriah Heep cracked me up-some of the interviewees did give you an idea of the broad spectrum of younger musicians that Rush influenced and continue to influence.The overall vibe that I got from the film was that the guys in Rush care very much for each other and are sympathetic to the needs of each; this became especially apparent when the personal losses of Neil Peart are discussed.  I also got the sense that while excellent musicians, they were very much down to earth; there are no huge egos on display here and Neil can almost be self-effacing at times. One other thing that I found refreshing was that there was not an emphasis on drug/alcohol use.  Although the use of alcohol is briefly mentioned, there was too much going on in a typical Rush piece for them to go on stage with their senses dulled. As such, drug use does not play a role in the story of Rush.All in all, this is one of the finest rock biographies I have ever watched and brought back some great memories of watching them in concert circa 1980-1981.  It focuses on the facts and the music; there is no drama, no ridiculous "arty" imagery, and no hysterical interviewers. Above all else though, this biography was just plain fun. So much fun in fact, that I have watched it well over ten times.

This SKLZ Quickster Soccer Combo System is a great net for our 5 and 7 year olds and they love using it for sports and just plain goofing around. The net is pretty durable and easy to set up. The fact that it serves as both a net and a "rebounder" is also nice - I think the kids liked using the rebounder a bit more than the goal net. My general impression is that this is a fun and durable net that offers our kids a great opportunity to get outside and get some exercise.

This base is, by virtue of design, heavy and stable. The adjustable knob is a nice feature and should accept umbrella poles with a variety of diameters. Although a minor inconvenience, the packaging for the stand was such that it made it difficult to get the stand out.The one aspect of this stand that has me a little concerned is the fact that the stand is composed of steel.  Although the outer covering may be weather resistant, the covering has the potential to wear off causing the steel to rust. At least that has been my experience with similar types of outdoor furniture while living in the northeastern US. We have not, however, owned this long enough to determine if it will rust.All in all, this is a nice stand that seems fairly durable although it may be prone to rust. Regardless, it will be kept under a table, so it might not be that big of a deal if it rots out.

We selected this air filter because our son suffers from asthma that is triggered by allergies to various air-borne particulates including animal hair and pollen. Because of this, we have steered clear of owning pets (cats and dogs) and we were also interested in a high efficiency air filter that would remove other particulates from the air, yet would not require an HVAC technician to install.  This air cleaner from Electrolux certainly fit the bill.The air cleaner is very simple to assemble and the parts all fit together snugly. The filters are arranged in series such that air passes through a fine-mesh screen, a HEPA filter, and finally a charcoal filter.  According to Electrolux, the HEPA filter is capable of trapping particulates as small as 0.3 microns (dust, pollen etc).  To put this in perspective, my understanding is that maples generate pollen with a diameter generally in the 23-36 micron range - my hope is that the HEPA filter will cut down on pollen this spring. If I read the manual correctly, the unit also acts as an ion-exchanger - this is just a fancy way of saying that the PlasmaWave technology uses positive and negative charges to convert harmful substances in the air to harmless substances such as oxygen.To test this unit out, I placed it in the kitchen where most of the hustle and bustle of daily life occurs - we had it in the bedroom but the air there is pretty clean so there was not much to observe. We just turned it on and let it work its magic - it really is that simple. To make things even easier, the unit comes with a remote - this would come in handy if you use it in the bedroom at night. With respect to the operation of this unit, it is generally very quiet and does not have a lot of bright, blinking lights.  In fact, Electrolux has built a light sensor into the unit that will automatically dim the lights on the control panel at night.  Although I say quiet, the unit will make a little white noise when the fan is in "Turbo" mode, which generally occurs during cooking. The fan will return to quiet mode once the odor is gone.  Overall, I was impressed with how quiet the unit is, particularly during conditions when air quality is good.  For those of you concerned with having a bulky air cleaner in your home, the unit is actually fairly unobtrusive.  We have it in the kitchen and because it is charcoal grey/black it blends nicely with the hardwood floors/stainless steel appliances and does not take up a lot of space.The maintenance of this unit will vary with particulate density - if there is a lot of dust/pollen you will have to check the unit more frequently.  The one component that I check frequently is the fine mesh screen - this acts much like a lint trap in the dryer.  The more particulates that get impinged on the screen, the lower the air flow, and the less efficient the unit will be so keep it clean.  According to Electrolux, under normal operating conditions, the filters are designed to be replaced annually. I went on to the Electrolux website and found that a package containing 1 HEPA filter and 4 charcoal cartridges costs approximately $80 (at the time of this writing).  There are cheaper options on the website to the cost I have cited, however - it just depends on what you want to replace. Of course, the filters are washable so you could probably get a slightly longer life out of them.All in all, this is an excellent filter that keeps the air in our house clean - this is especially important because our son suffers from asthma that is aggravated by allergies to pollen and other particulates in the air.  It is quiet, unobtrusive, and does not appear to use lots of electricity (it is an Energy Star product).

This is the heaviest of the first eight Black Sabbath albums with Ozzy Osbourne on lead vocals, both musically and maybe lyrically too. In fact, for those younger folks that are just getting into Black Sabbath, Master of Reality (1971) may be the one to start with - it seems most closely aligned with the current perception of 1970s Black Sabbath. In fact, Seattle grunge group Soundgarden covered Into the Void sometime in the 1990s.Musically, this album features bludgeoning electric guitar played at a crushing volume and a bulldozer-like rhythm section. Loads of riffs, often played in unison on the electric bass and the electric guitar, are major components of each track. Of course, there is the quieter, progressive side of Sabbath too, with the delicate acoustic guitar track Orchid and the quiet closing track Solitude. I should note that this is what makes Sabbath one of the most interesting of the British heavy metals groups (Along with Zeppelin) - their desire to experiment. This experimentation is in its infancy on Master of Reality but is present nonetheless.This version of the CD was released by US Warner Bros. The sound quality is OK and the liner notes feature a little blurb on the group. I am not, however, a fan of the US Warner Bros releases of the 1970-1978 Black Sabbath albums because most of them suffer from sound quality issues. In my search for an inexpensive alternative, I stumbled across a version of Master of Reality that was issued by Creative Sounds. I own both the US Warner Bros. and Creative Sounds versions, and feel that the sound quality of the Creative Sounds version is a little better. Then again, based upon my (foggy) memories of my old vinyl LP, the sound quality of the record was not that hot either. While the audio quality is not bad, the Creative Sounds version of the Audio CD is about as bare bones as it gets - there are no liner notes or recording credits. To their credit, however, Creative Sounds tried to mimic the cover of the old LP- on the LP, only Black Sabbath was visible (in purple), whereas the Master of Reality title was in black raised letters.All in all, this is a great album by the group that finds them starting to change their overall sound. Highly recommended along with the debut Black Sabbath (1970), Paranoid (1970), Vol. 4 (1972), the excellent Sabbath Bloody Sabbath (1973), and my favorite Sabotage (1975). Although Technical Ecstasy (1976) and Never Say Die (1978) have received mixed reviews (most fans don't like these two) I personally think they are great. However, I would start with the first six, then move onto Technical Ecstasy and Never Say Die.

This 1975 album is very sophisticated and seems to be presented as a song cycle of sorts - all of the tracks blend into one another. The desire of guitarist Tony Iommi to incorporate elements of progressive was really beginning to show.  Although I love all of the albums from the years with Ozzy Osbourne as lead vocalist, this one really stands out.  I especially appreciate the detail in each track, the variety in tone colors, a nice dynamic range , and above all else, the sheer power of this music.Although this album is dominated by the crushing volume of their unique take on heavy metal, there are quiet acoustic guitar passages, sections that feature a choir and synthesizers/mellotron, and sophisticated songwriting and arrangements.  Overall, this album is a good example of how many groups incorporated elements from British progressive rock into their music.  I love the moods on the album, which range from haunting and plaintive to heavy, with everything in-between. I also appreciate Tony's playing and the tones that he gets on Sabotage - his performances are both thoughtful and blistering.This version of the CD was released by US Warner Bros and features good sound quality and a little blurb on the group in the liner notes.All in all this is a great album that was the last to feature a unified group approach during the "Ozzy years". After this, Tony's interest in progressive created great friction within the band, particularly with Ozzy, leading to the ultimate dissolution of this lineup in 1978 or so.  This album is very highly recommended along with the debut Black Sabbath (1970), Paranoid (1970), Master of Reality (1971), and Sabbath Bloody Sabbath (1973). Although I think the follow-up to Sabotage is pretty good (Technical Ecstasy, 1976), not a lot of people have warmed up to it.

In my search for an inexpensive version of the Audio CD of Master of Reality (1971), I stumbled across this version that was issued by Creative Sounds under license from Dorchester Holdings.  Based upon a comparison with the US Warner Bros release, the sound quality of this version is a little better. Then again, based upon my (foggy) memories of my old vinyl LP, the sound quality of the record was not that hot either.  While the audio quality is not bad, this version of the Audio CD is about as bare bones as it gets - there are no liner notes or recording credits.  To their credit, however, Creative Sounds tried to mimic the cover of the old LP- on the LP, only Black Sabbath was visible (in purple), whereas the Master of Reality title was in black raised letters.This is the heaviest of the first eight Black Sabbath albums with Ozzy Osbourne on lead vocals, both musically and maybe lyrically too.  In fact, for those younger folks that are just getting into Black Sabbath, Master of Reality may be the one to start with - it seems most closely aligned with the current perception of 1970s Black Sabbath. In fact, Seattle grunge group Soundgarden covered Into the Void.Musically, this album features bludgeoning electric guitar played at a crushing volume and a bulldozer-like rhythm section.  Loads of riffs, often played in unison on the electric bass and the electric guitar, are major components of each track.  Of course, there is the quieter, progressive side of Sabbath too, with the delicate acoustic guitar track Orchid and the quiet closing track Solitude. I should note that this is what makes Sabbath one of the most interesting of the British heavy metals groups (Along with Zeppelin) - their desire to experiment.  This experimentation is in its infancy on Master of Reality but is present nonetheless.All in all, this is an awesome album by the group that finds them starting to change their overall sound.  Highly recommended along with the debut Black Sabbath (1970), Paranoid (1970), Vol. 4 (1972), Sabbath Bloody Sabbath (1973), and Sabotage (1975).  Although Technical Ecstasy (1976) and Never Say Die (1978) have received mixed reviews (most fans don't like these two) I personally think they are great.  However, I would start with the first six, then move onto Technical Ecstasy and Never Say Die.

We appreciate the flexibility of this flashlight/lantern combo and have used it in a range of settings, both indoor and out. In fact, the light (LED) is reasonably bright so it works well outside. Power requirements consist of 4 AA batteries - fortunately, the light does not seem to burn through batteries too quickly.Unfortunately, the light is not too well constructed, and the wrist carry strap fell apart after the first few uses. Apart from that minor inconvenience, this is a small, yet powerful light with the added feature of a strobe setting. All in all, the price is just about right.

This is a great, durable case that is a lot of fun - especially if you have young children that are Lego-obsessed. In case you were wondering, yes the little Lego guys do interlock with the case, so this is part toy/part protective case.Our kids love the fact that it looks like a big Lego and we love the fact that it actually protects the iPad from the rigors of day-to-day life. As a nice complement to the hard plastic bottom, the flexible cover allows you to set the iPad on a flat surface and prop it up at an angle. This is a nice feature; especially when traveling.Fortunately, the kids are not too rough with the iPad, although there is the occasional drop to the floor from a few feet up in the air. The hard plastic of the Belkin case has held up well during these falls, although it would do little to protect the iPad if it was purposefully hurled at the wall.

Although designed for the upholstery and carpet in your car or truck, we have used this spot cleaner on a number of things including sofas.  The machine worked wonders on the sofas- we thought that our toddlers had destroyed them beyond the point of no return, but the Bissell brought them back to life. I would also use this machine to clean spots on carpets in the house.The machine is lightweight, easy to use, and extremely loud.  While the loudness is not an issue outside or in a garage, it is a bit much for use indoors. The machine is very effective at removing stains, although you have to work a bit with the brush attachment at tougher stains - this is no different from any other spot cleaner we have owned. If you are concerned about making the carpet/upholstery/sofa too wet, just go easy on the water application and constantly  vacuum the water up as you go.The machine comes with a container of Oxy(gen) Boost stain remover and a container of Spot and Stain. You only need to use the Spot and Stain, whereas the Oxy Boost is reserved for the tough stains.  The Spot and Stain is concentrated (factor of 2) so you only need a small amount. This is nice, because the cleaner is just an additional expense.  Although it would be nice if the machine had a retractable cord, the cord that it comes with is not too inconvenient. Moreover, the cable is pretty long (approx. 15 feet) so it works just about anywhere.All in all this is a great cleaner that has a wide range of applications (all of them small jobs) The machine does a great job of cleaning, even with the tough spots and is easy to use.  Although a bit loud, I would recommend this spot cleaner to anybody.

My son (age 6) absolutely loves this Matchbox truck and has not stopped playing with it since it arrived.The appeal lies with the moving parts that the truck has: the snow plow extends, the cab of the truck flips up and the top opens up, the side walls flip out and so on.  To add to the fun, the truck comes with three characters with oversized feet that allow them to rock back and forth - very much like Weebles. The smaller characters can be launched off of the side walls. There is also a net that can be used to capture the Yeti.The truck is constructed of durable plastic.  Although the moving parts seem a little flimsy, they have definitely held up to the rigors of playtime. While there are no sharp edges, the truck comes with small accessories, so be sure to keep them away from very young children.All in all, this is a great toy that has offered my son hours of enjoyment. Furthermore, it is pretty much good to go - you don't have to buy additional (and more often than not, expensive) components. In fact my son has integrated the truck with his other toys pretty well. Overall, a fantastic toy.

Of the first six albums, this 1972 release always seemed to fall through the cracks for me. After listening to this album again for the first time in a (really) long time, I realize that most of my hang-ups have to do with the production quality and the disjointedness of a few of the tunes. In all fairness though, the music has enough of the Black Sabbath "spirit" that I enjoyed it - even moreso than when I listened to this on vinyl as a teen.Overall, Vol. 4 is a decent example of the Black Sabbath sound: a bulldozer-like rhythm section, heavily distorted "power chords" played at a bone-crushing volume, and the distinctive vocal style of Ozzy Osbourne. Wheels of Confusion, Tomorrow's Dream, Supernaut, Cornucopia, and Snowblind are great examples of this.On the other hand, Black Sabbath had started to experiment with their sound by this point and make use of different tone colors - strings, mellotron, piano-this likely reflects the guitarist's increasing interest in progressive rock. The experimentation was alternately thrilling; the mellotron (with string setting) drenched and melancholy track Changes is my favorite Sabbath track, and less-than-satisfying; FX amounts to little more than Tony Iommi fiddling with the controls on his guitar and an echo box. Tony did compose the pleasant acoustic guitar track Laguna Sunrise though - this is one of my favorites from the guitarist.The disjointedness of Vol. 4 rears its head on the first track - the instrumental track The Straightener is unrelated to Wheels of Confusion and should have either been omitted or fleshed out into a full-blown song (it really is a catchy bit of music). There is also the haphazard sequencing of tracks; there is not much in the way of natural pacing to Vol. 4. I blame the producer (Patrick Meehan) for this sort of thing though, not Sabbath - even though they partipated in the production.The sound quality of this CD reissue is horrific - unfortunately, I no longer have my old LP so I can't do a decent comparison.  As far as the sound of the CD goes, the bass guitar is barely audible, the cymbals and high-hat are "splishy", and there are noticeable (unplanned) shifts in volume. The liner notes provide the track listing, and a few notes on the recording of the album.All in all, this is a pretty good album by the group that endures to this day in spite of a few (minor) shortcomings.  My understanding is that many of the band members were suffering from substance abuse problems at the time of the recording, so we are lucky that we got anything out of them at all.Although I have a preference for the first three studio albums, any of the first six are recommended to newbies: Black Sabbath (1970); Paranoid (1970); Master of Reality (1971); Vol. 4 (1972); Sabbath Bloody Sabbath (1973); and Sabotage (1975).  If you are just curious about the group, the compilation We Sold our Soul for Rock `n' Roll (1976) does a nice job capturing the highlights of these albums and is pretty cheap - come to think of it, about half of the compilation is made up of tunes from Paranoid and Vol. 4. Enjoy.

This "ice cream maker" keeps our kids (ages 5 and 6.5) entertained for hours - they absolutely love it!  The appeal lies in the varieties of ice cream that can be made and the types of "toppings" that they can come up with. You are, of course, limited by the types of colored Play-Doh you have at your disposal, so the sky is not the limit.We have found that clean-up is not any tougher than other toys that use Play-Doh. Although dried Play-Doh turns up in some of the cracks and crevices, I will usually just give the affected piece a good rinse with water - that usually takes care of it. Our kids love to mix the "toppings" in with the "ice cream". Because of this, the original colors usually do not last too long so we are constantly buying new Play-Doh.All in all, this is a great toy that will keep your kids entertained for hours - just be prepared to shell out money for more Play-Doh - especially if they like to mix the colors together.

Deadwing (2005) finds Porcupine Tree in top form and is loaded with excellent playing and songwriting. Although a bit heavier and louder than some of their earlier albums, the music on this album is still killer Porcupine Tree through-and-through.
