Overall, this is one of the few newer groups that really grabs me.The album blends the influences of heavy groups like Opeth with melancholy, softer passages and has a gloom to it that I find very appealing - not sure why I like the gloom so much - it just seems to resonate more.  These are dark times after all and Porcupine Tree seems to have successfully tapped into this. The level of musicianship is fairly high and the arrangements are generally well thought out - the individual tracks seem to be arranged in a larger work. One pleasant surprise was the guitar solo by Adrian Belew (King Crimson).The CD comes with a booklet that features a series of arty images, along with the recording credits.  The sound quality is very high.All in all, this is a great album by a mature group with a mature sound.  Although heavier than some of the earlier albums, this is fantastic stuff that paves the way for the excellent Fear of a Blank Planet (2007). Highly recommended along with In Absentia (2002) and Fear of a Blank Planet.

This is a well constructed water tower that fits perfectly with our other Thomas the Tank Engine train set parts.  Our kids (ages 5 and 6.5) enjoy playing with the tower and filling the steam engines up - the water level in the tank "drops" as you lower the outlet pipe, and returns to its original "full" level when you raise the outlet pipe back up. The construction of the water tower is quite good; it is solid, and the materials are of high quality.All in all, the water tower makes for a nice addition to our Thomas the Tank Engine train set and provides hours of enjoyment for the kids.

This 1971 release sounds a lot different than Tommy (1969) and indicates how much the group had developed in only a few short years. There is certainly no shortage of popular songs on this album and the track listing reads like a greatest hits list. Although culled from a larger project that was shelved (Lifehouse), there is continuity to the collection of songs on Who's Next, which is a personal favorite.The album was recorded in fits and starts (the process is nicely detailed in the liner notes) with the end product being a definitive album by the group. Come to think of it, along with Tommy and Quadrophenia (1973), Who's Next defines the Who's mature sound: a mixture of hard rock, a smidge of progressive, and dynamics that range from soft to loud.I love the use of synthesizers on the album (mostly VCS3 and ARP 2500) and electronic processing, which lends the music a fairly distinctive sound. On the downside, I am not a fan of the (lyrically) silly tune My Wife (John Entwistle), which is really at odds with the remainder of the material. This same sort of thing drove me crazy with ELP.The production quality is (was) outstanding and the remastered CD does not fiddle with the original sound too much (at least based upon my distant memories of the LP). The sound of the drums is best described as thunderous, and there is excellent separation of individual instruments. The liner notes are very detailed and include an essay by Pete Townshend and some notes on the album by a rock critic.  The extra tracks are pretty cool and I have to say they are actually of interest.All in all, this may very well be the Who's finest moment.  A classic by any measure, it is highly recommended along with Tommy and Quadrophenia.  These three albums find the group at a creative peak.

This case features a plastic snap that mounts on the back of an iPad mini snugly. The case is easy to grip and is composed of hard plastic, so the back of the Apple Ipad Mini is reasonably well protected. This is plastic, however, so it is not likely to protect your Ipad from the force of falling on a hard surface from heights above three feet. My wife appreciates the color of the case and feels that it lends the Ipad "pizzazz".All in all, this is a colorful plastic case that should protect your Ipad from the rigors of day-to-day life.  It does not serve as a completely shock-proof container for the Ipad, however, so be careful and bear the limitations of a plastic cover in mind when using it.

This is a nice cover for our Ipad Mini from Belkin. Both our son (6) and daughter (4) use it; fortunately, no one complains that it is too "girly" or "for boys" - then again, they are more interested in the game that they are playing to take much notice of the Ipad cover.The cover fastens with a little magnet and is fairly durable. Because there are "bend points" in the cover, you can prop your Ipad up at an angle - this is nice if you are on a plane. The cover is composed of rubber and is covered with what appears to be some type of cloth/woven synthetic fibers. Regardless of what the outer covering is composed of - keep it away from spills and clean it frequently - otherwise, the cover will get pretty dirty.All in all, this is a nice cover for the Ipad. Just clean it frequently if don't want it to get too gross looking.

This collection of live material recorded during the 1973-1974 tour is just fantastic.  Not only does this sprawling set demonstrate their ability to play such complex material in a live setting, but it also showcases their considerable improvisational skills.  Welcome Back My Friends to the Show that Never Ends (1974) is killer ELP from start to finish.I had this (3 LP) set on vinyl a long time ago and only just barely remember it, so my ability to point out the differences between the LP and CD is diminished. However, I did recognize that the longer tracks are now presented in their entirety. The sound quality is about the same as I remember it – not too bad overall.Although the subtle details of this record have faded with time, the staggering virtuosity of the performances and the sheer electrical power of this live recording is something that was never forgotten. Each member gets a chance to shine – my favorite is Keith’s solo piano piece – and the ensemble tracks are spectacular –the Karn-Evil 9 and Tarkus suites are especially impressive.This remastered CD by Rhino is not bad – they attempted to reproduce the original liner notes and graphics and the sound quality is not bad for a live album.  Although I would have wished for some extra tracks, I was more than satisfied with the track listing of the original album.All in all, if you are looking for a live album by ELP during the height of their abilities, look no further than this.  Recommended along with ELP (1970); Tarkus (1971); the live album Pictures at an Exhibition (1972); Trilogy (1972); and Brain Salad Surgery (1973).

This Norton software is great - I am a bit biased though, I have been using Norton anti-virus software for a long time.The setup is very easy - even for folks that might not be computer savvy - and works its "magic" without too much active maintenance on your part.  There are four main components to the software including security, identity, backup, and tune-up.  The tune-up component needs a little tweaking at first - it would erase all of current log-ins so we would have to re-log onto our favorite websites.  Other than that, it does not take up a lot of memory on our laptop - as such, I have not noticed any slowing of the computer.Another nice feature is the high level of detail on computer performance, internet threats etc. Although it may be too much information for most folks, I like being able to review data from the four components so that I know exactly what is going on.All in all, this is a great anti-virus software package that really is the best line of defense against internet viruses, malware et al.  Trust me - I was more than happy to say goodbye to my old C-Cleaner.

This is a great steam mop with three settings that cleans effectively and is easy to use. The removable water tank is a nice feature - if you do not use all of the water in the tank, just empty it out.  The mop pad is easy to clean - just take it off the mop and throw it in the washer. With two toddlers we are constantly cleaning up spills - fortunately, the mop is designed to be very effective on tough stains (there is a small brush attachment). All in all, a great mop, easy to use, and it actually cleans the floor - even the tough stains.

I find this group to be one of the more refreshing acts out there right now - there is hope for progressive music yet.  One aspect of their music that is most refreshing is the successful blend of new music with the old; in this case, goth/indie rock with the best of 1970s progressive.  This is forward-thinking music at its best.Although Signal to Noise (2006) is a bit lighter than some of their other albums, there is still a brooding darkness that I find very appealing.  I also like the musicianship, the level of which is very high, and the keyboard playing of young Lars Fredrik Frislie really stands out - he favors the analog instruments like the mellotron, mini-moog, and other synthesizers.  A new female vocalist signed on for this album and her vocals are exceptional.With a total running time of 51:28, the tracks seem to be arranged in a song-cycle of sorts; the song-cycle incorporates vocal passages with more complex instrumental interludes.  The instrumental passages are fairly intricate and feature pre-composed solos - fortunately, there is not a lot of grandstanding.  Although a bit heavier than their other albums, the heaviness is not overbearing and is nicely leavened by the pastoral moments that the group is known for.The sound quality of this release is pretty good, although it varies considerably depending on the equipment that is used.  The CD booklet features the (great) lyrics, a few arty images, and the production credits.All in all, this is a group that I enjoy a great deal.  Progressive music at its finest - very highly recommended along with Sanctuary (2000) and Terminal Twilight (2011).

We picked this Tinker Toy Transit Building Set up for our son (age 5) and daughter (age 4).  Both of our kids loved this toy, with the crane being a favorite with our son, and the dog a favorite with our daughter.  Then again, the beauty of this set is that they can build anything they want.In contrast with earlier versions of the toy, the pieces are plastic.  They come in a wide variety of colors, shapes, sizes, and textures, and are easy to put together.  The pieces are very durable and of the highest quality - everything fits together snugly.One of the nicest features of the toy is that the pieces come enclosed in their own storage case - as parents with toy storage issues, it was nice to not have to run to the store to pick up (yet another) plastic storage bin.All in all, you cannot go wrong with this toy - it has been around forever for a reason.  Great toy for budding engineers.

We got this train set for our 5 year old son.  He was able to put it together by himself and build different versions with the same pieces - this is actually the nicest feature of this set. The set is also extremely durable - once assembled, it is virtually indestructible.  The pieces themselves are more interesting to look at than the wooden tracks that come with other sets.The only drawback to this set is that it only comes with one train - this is not too much fun.All in all, this is a durable train set that is a lot of fun for creative, young minds.  Just expect to shell out money for more trains.

This case served as a replacement for an old plastic case that was cracked and filthy after months of misuse and abuse at the hands of our toddlers.  Although my wife likes the color, I can't say that I am a fan of hot pink.  Furthermore, the Kindle has a tendency to slip out of the four corner fasteners on occasion, which defeats the purpose of having a protective covering.On the plus side, the cover is bright, so it makes it a bit easier to find the Kindle when it is buried under piles of toys and clothing strewn about the room. I also like the fact that it surrounds the Kindle like a book cover.  The cover is composed of slightly textured plastic and is easy to clean.  I would not, however, drop the Kindle from any height even with the cover on - this is just a flimsy plastic cover - not a shock-proof container.All in all, this is effectively an expensive dust cover for your Kindle.  The bright color is a lot of fun and the case should protect it from most of the trials and tribulations of day-to-day life (coffee spills, stray pen/pencil marks, grubby hands etc).  If I were traveling with the Kindle, I would most likely keep it in a briefcase or bag - the bright pink color would most likely just attract unwanted attention.

I originally had this 1975 compilation on vinyl and as I recall, liked it solely for the extended prog rock rave up of the Paul Simon tune America - this was recorded with the classic lineup of Rick Wakeman, Chris Squire, Steve Howe, Jon Anderson, and Bill Bruford.  I did like the earlier psychedelic rock  tracks with Peter Banks, however, but at the time was heavily into the full-blown prog albums like Going for the One, Relayer, and Tales from Topographic Oceans so I can't say that I was bowled over by the earlier stuff.  Furthermore, the Roger Dean cover art was a bit dicey - the back cover is likely not shown here for a reason.If you are like me and have to buy everything Yes ever released (I am obsessed) you will want to pick this up.  You may also want to get this if you just want a sampler of the early material (specifically, the first two albums Yes [1969] and Time and a Word [1970]) before forking over the money for the remasters.  I originally bought Yesterdays for America - which is now included on the Rhino release of Fragile, so I now consider Yesterdays to be redundant.The CD booklet of the remastered version of Yesterdays comes with the green photos of the various band members that used to form the dust cover for the record.  The sound quality is pretty good.All in all, this compilation is for Yes "completists".  In fact, I picked the CD up for nostalgic reasons only - it brings back pleasant memories of discovering progressive music as a teen.

As I recall, I bought Three Sides Live (1982) while in England at some point in 1983 or 1984.  At any rate, the record was pretty new when I bought it and presented a nice summary of early 1980s Genesis, along with some of their more progressive material.One of things that I liked about the U.K. version was that the fourth side was live and had a great version of One for the Vine on it - this is the version that made it onto this CD.  Back in the early 1980s, however, the U.S. release of the album had studio tracks on the fourth side (Paperlate, You Might Recall, Evidence of Autumn, Me and Virgil, Open Door).  The U.S. version of the album is available here at AMAZON and used copies are reasonably priced (Three Sides Live). Fortunately for me though, I am only familiar with the U.K. version, so I do not miss the studio tracks (good as they are though).I was always a fan of the early 1980s albums like Duke and Abacab, so I found the track listing to be pretty good.  However, I especially liked the progressive pieces such as the lengthy medley, and the entire fourth side.  The playing is pretty good and the two guys that Genesis hired to help out (Chester Thompson - drums and Darryl Stuermer - guitars/bass) are fantastic.  On the fourth side, Bill Bruford (drums) turns up on a few tracks, along with former guitarist Steve Hackett.The overall sound quality on Three Sides Live was always a bit thin - this definitive remaster does little to help correct that.  The CD booklet comes with a color image of the group playing live, liner notes, and recording credits.  Nothing fancy though which is in keeping with the theme of the original record.All in all, this is a fine summary of the live Genesis sound as it existed in the early 1980s and makes a nice complement to Seconds Out (1977).

While this doll may be great for collectors, it is not appropriate for child play.  In fact, the doll has not left the box - our toddlers would tear Barbie apart.  As a collectible item, however, it is beautiful.Our favorite thing about this Barbie doll is the packaging, which is designed to display the doll  - in fact, even our young daughter loved the backdrop.  Of course, the doll is quite nice too, and features a stunning red/silver ball gown and highly detailed makeup and hair.  My wife appreciated the other details on the doll such as the painted fingernails and the high-heeled shoes - in fact, she had to resist the urge to tear the packaging apart to actually hold the doll.All in all, this is a fine collectible that is better suited to being on display than being played with.  We will definitely save the doll for our daughter though - she will certainly appreciate "Barbie in a box" more when she is older.  This 2012 doll makes a nice companion to the 2011 holiday series doll.

We picked this up because it seemed like a fun thing to do with the kids (ages 4 and 5). Unfortunately, this cheaply constructed plastic slurpee maker from Umagine was a bit difficult to assemble, hard to use, messy, and yielded zero return.The slush is generated when a flavored drink comes into direct contact with a metal cooling canister containing ice and salt.  Ignore the directions, however, and add something healthy to drink such as apple juice for the kids (the target audience).  The suggestions on the box include soda and high-sugar fruit drinks - just like the junk you can buy at a convenience store like 7-11.The drink is then agitated until slush is formed.  The mixing takes about five minutes or so and requires you to really crank it - otherwise you will be mixing for a while.  Because the maker is flimsy and lightweight, there is the risk that it will topple over and spill its contents if you are not careful.  I got a little carried away and the handle slipped out of its fitting a few times.Once the mixing is complete, the slush is dispensed by pulling a sliding plastic "door" located at the bottom of the mixing container.  I found that the sliding door was so hard to pull out that I just ended up dumping the contents out of the top of the container into the plastic serving cups.  It was that or risk spilling everything all over the place.All in all this is an expensive and shoddily constructed slurpee maker.  It was difficult to assemble, very difficult to use, and did not yield as much fun as we would have liked.  I was, however, able to illustrate some basic scientific principles to the kids (the effects of cooling on liquids).  That was worth at least a two-star rating.

My four year old daughter loves this dollhouse.  I think the appeal lies with its large size, along with details such as the room under the stairs, lights that work, and door bells etc. (the dollhouse requires 3 "AA" batteries).The dollhouse was very easy to put together and comes with easy-to-read and clearly laid out instructions.  In fact, my wife was able to assemble the house in only a half hour armed with only a phillips-head screwdriver.The house is constructed of sturdy plastic pieces (colored pink, cream, brown, and green) that hold up well to super-hero "assaults" launched by my five year old son. Various pieces of furniture and four dolls (mom, dad, daughter, and a baby) are included.  The furniture and the dolls are well constructed and hold up well to the stresses imposed by two toddlers - the super-hero assaults can get pretty intense.All in all, this is a nice dollhouse by Fisher Price (even for a plastic dollhouse).  It may very well impress the wooden dollhouse lovers out there.

This is an inexpensive (cheap) coffee maker that we use on a daily basis.  Although we have owned Mr. Coffee machines for years, we were not exactly thrilled with this model. Like everything, however, there are pros and cons.The Mr.Coffee unit is easy to operate, although the water fill line is a bit hard to see through the window (which is located along the side of the machine).  After a few uses, however, you get accustomed to where the water level should be - we stopped checking the fill line after the first use.  The clock is a nice feature and the buttons used to operate the coffee maker are conveniently located around the clock.  The water filter that came with the machine is also nice; although it is unlikely that it is actually filtering anything, the gesture is appreciated.After a few months of daily use, the cleaner light came on and would not shut off. Whether related to the cleaning light issue, the machine would also shut itself off only 30-60 seconds after brewing.  As such, an entire pot of coffee would go cold if the machine was not manually switched back on. Fortunately, we were able to correct these problems by unplugging the coffee maker for a few hours and letting it "re-boot". One other development was that the paint on the heater plate peeled off.All in all, this coffee maker is fairly inexpensive and makes a good pot of coffee.  Although our experience with Mr.Coffee machines over the years is that they hold up pretty well, this model has required a bit more maintenance than other machines that we have owned. Ultimately, you get what you pay for, so if you don't mind tinkering with gadgets, this might be the coffee maker for you.

This is another high quality puzzle from Ravensburger that was fun to put together and looks fantastic when completed. With "only" 300 pieces, this was mildly challenging to put together - it took us approximately 2 hours to assemble.The individual pieces are soft and well constructed, and the image itself is quite nice (you cannot go wrong with Beacon Hill).All in all, this is a high quality puzzle with enough pieces that it makes for a mild challenge.  The completed puzzle fits on a standard kitchen table and can be assembled in a few hours - this is perfect for the time challenged.

This is a great Soft Machine album and a fan favorite.  Mine too.  What appeals to me the most about Third (1970) is the fact that the approach was purely exploratory.  How else could I describe an attempt to fuse minimalism, jazz, and psychedelic rock together?  Third-stream maybe?  At any rate, this music is just plain exciting - even decades after its original release.This was originally a double album, but they somehow managed to cram it all onto one CD (running time is approximately 75 minutes).  Only four tracks are included on Third - each is roughly 18-20 minutes long - and range from the roughly recorded live jazz on Facelift (recorded at Fairfield Hall in Croydon [January 4, 1970] and Mother's Club in Birmingham [January 11, 1970]) to the psychedelic rock of Moon in June.  Most of Moon in June features drummer Robert Wyatt singing (a wordless vocal) to the accompaniment of Mike Ratledge on organ.  Although I love the whole album, I am partial to the flat out jazz of Slightly All the Time and the spacey minimalism/jazz rock on Out-Bloody-Rageous.The tunes do not consist of much more than improvisation around a few pre-composed themes but man is it good.  The guys are all great players and can play jazz very convincingly.  Hands down, my favorite is bassist Hugh Hopper.  One of the distinctive aspects of the music is Mike's overdriven and distorted tone on the organ - I think he ran it through a fuzz box or equivalent.  He is also capable of a clean, "churchy" tone.  I also like the incorporation of minimalism into the mix - this lends some of the pieces a very hypnotic, dream-like quality - especially Out-Bloody-Rageous.  I also like the brass and reed players - they are excellent.This is not the remastered version of the album, although there is one floating around out there.  With the exception of the poorly recorded opening live track, the sound quality of the studio tracks is not bad at all.  This version of the CD is pretty skimpy.All in all, this is an excellent example of Canterbury Rock and a distinctly English take on the then nascent jazz rock style.  Although fans of the earlier, more psychedelic albums might get turned off by the transition to jazz, I think that this is a fantastic album.  Recommended along with Fourth (1971), which is essentially a jazz album.

The music on Banks of Eden (2012) consists of the same approach presented on their 1995 debut, which in turn, was merely a re-tread of the late 1970s-early 1980s stadium rock acts, along with American progressive groups like Starcastle.  The overall sound blends the harder edged sound of riff-heavy stadium rock with neo-progressive rock and perhaps a smidge of the soft adult contemporary rock style.Overall, the highlight of the album for me was the keyboard playing (Tomas Bodin) - he is just fantastic and I love his use of tone color (some of the synthesizer tones were generated with software). The players are all solid though and the new drummer (Felix Lehrman) sounds just like previous drummers; particularly Zoltan Csorz (an excellent percussionist by the way).  At times though, the new drummer reminds me of a very young Ian Paice (Deep Purple) circa 1970-1972.  The vocals and lyrics suffer from the same problems as on earlier albums - my wish is that they would either go instrumental or hire a singer/lyricist.Pop melodies abound and it is clear they spent a lot of time putting each track together. As featured on any number of their albums, Banks of Eden opens with a long track that consists of several unrelated bits and pieces tacked together.  The remaining tracks are not bad and are somewhat short (5-8 minutes).  My favorite of the "shorter" tracks is For the Love of Gold - this is a waltzy tune that was co-authored by Tomas Bodin and the guitarist (Roine Stolt).  The closing track Rising the Imperial, which was written by the bassist (Jonas Reingold), is an overly calculated and maudlin ballad that boasts Roine doing his best interpretation of the guitar solo on Comfortably Numb (Pink Floyd, The Wall, 1979).  This was my least favorite track.  Come to think of it, the main theme from this track is presented during a few points during the track Numbers.  Typically, restating central themes serves to draw connecting threads between different pieces.  I am not quite sure what the objective here was though - there is no relationship between any of the individual pieces.I was able to get the deluxe, 2-CD edition of the album fairly cheaply.  Total running time is somewhere around 53 minutes - I am still used to the running length of vinyl records so this was a perfect length.  The overall package is very nice and features some cool cover art and a booklet that has the lyrics and color photos of the group in the studio.  The sound quality is outstanding - very little compression was applied and the music sounds natural.  The bonus tracks on disc 2 (running time around 20 minutes) are OK -they sound like studio outtakes.  There is also a roughly 20-minute long video of the group being interviewed in the studio.All in all, this album will likely appeal to fans of the group.  It just did not push all of my buttons because I find their emphasis on stale stadium rock cliches and a reluctance to embrace musical ideas outside of mainstream rock frustrating - this seems to go against the very spirit of progressive music.  What is most frustrating, however, is that these guys seem content to just play it safe.  Progressive was never safe - it challenged the listener, it shattered the norm, and above all else, it was exciting.

Try as I might, album after album, I fail to make any connection with this group.  I can admit however, that they are capable of a good melody or two and sometimes their playing can be inspired (Space Revolver [2000] is not bad).  This 1995 debut certainly has loads of melodies and establishes the basic approach that they would follow for every album released thereafter.  That is, stadium rock with a dose of the symphonic pop style.The guys are all good musicians, just like the guys in any number of the stadium rock groups.  Hands down, my favorite track is "Kaleidoscope", which is a very nice acoustic guitar track that is surprisingly delicate and, well...thoughtful.  My least favorite track is the pop/R&B inflected "My Cosmic Lover".  In-between these two extremes, there is a lot of riff-heavy stadium rock with hard-edged guitar playing, a few atmospheric moments here and there, some nice Tony Banks -influenced keyboard playing, pretty bad vocals, and mind-blowingly bad lyrics.Yes, I found the lyrics especially troubling.  In that I grew up with the sophisticated lyrics of the (1970s) progressive groups, I found the puerile gibberish on this record to be more than I could stomach - it really ruined the listening experience for me.  One other aspect that I found troubling was the (apparently conscious) decision to equate music that sounds like Toto with music that sounds modern.  Given the wide range of musical styles that developed from the 1980s onwards, and that could be applied to a given framework (be it progressive rock or something else), the approach of the Flower Kings is both limited and suprisingly unimaginative.The version of the album that I have was released on Foxtrot Records and comes with the lyrics.  The sound quality is very good.All in all, this is lightweight fluff that is certainly not nearly as progressive as I was led to believe.

This is a nicely constructed plant holder that is durable and attractive.  Because it is made of metal (powder-coated heavy gage steel), however, we will likely use this as an indoor holder.  All this in spite of the claim that the holder is "rust-resistant".  If you use the holder on a carpet, you may want to get rug protectors because the metal feet will leave imprints. Watch out for sharp metals burs - we found a few and I had to remove them.

My 4 year old daughter had a solid 15 minutes worth of fun in the tub with this blue goo.  My five-year old son would not go near the stuff - he found it "disgusting".I followed the directions and put approximately 2 inches of water in the tub, added the blue goo powder, and mixed.  My daughter helped mix by wiggling all over the place - she really had fun with the stuff. As far as cleanup goes, it was a snap - I just dumped the enclosed salt packet into the blue slurry, mixed, waited until it had thinned out, and washed it down the drain.  There was no staining and no clogged drains.  I would not, however, use this product in a tub that drains slowly - the goo will potentially clog a partially obstructed drain pipe.I did, however, have a little trouble getting the goo out of her hair, albeit not too much trouble.  Evidently, the blue goo is composed of the same material found in diapers, so getting the individual particles out posed a brief inconvenience.  My solution was to just have her stand under the shower head for a bit until everything was washed outThe only drawback that I can see is that while the entertainment value of the blue goo is high, it is short-lived.  This is a novelty item, pure and simple.

My wife picked this moisturizing hair oil up for herself, but I found that using it also helped correct my dry scalp/hair issues.  However, the product also makes your hair very greasy - in fact, because I tend to use too much, my wife suggested I use it at night, rather than during the day.  This is not Moroccan oil after all.The oil has the odor of suntan lotion (probably the shea butter), which is something I do not like - I am a bit too conservative to use overly perfumed hair products.  Unfortunately, there are no directions and I had to determine what amount to use through trial and error; at first, I put too much in and my hair looked like I had dumped salad oil on it - very greasy.  If you use a little bit, which will vary with the amount of hair you have, your hair won't look too greasy.  Unfortunately, this might defeat the purpose - a tiny bit won't moisturize either your scalp or your hair.The packaging is a bit tricky - I had to peel the back label off to see the ingredient list, which was comprised of several oils.  If the thought of dumping oil in your hair does not sound appealing, then steer clear of this stuff.  The first two ingredients include mineral oil and coconut oil - that may explain why it smells like suntan lotion.  There are lesser amounts of other oils including: palm oil, wheat germ oil, sweet almond oil, sunflower seed oil, soybean oil, and Moroccan ironwood oil.Now that summer is here, keeping my scalp and hair moisturized requires some effort.  Unfortunately, I do not like having greasy hair, so I have had to seek out other hair care options.

Our kids (ages 3 and 5) had a "ball" putting this creative Ravensburger puzzle together.  The puzzle is of high quality and extremely durable - the pieces are constructed of sturdy plastic, so once the two halves of the puzzle are completed, they fit together to form a ball that can be (gently) rolled around.For those of you with little time on your hands, or kids with limited attention spans, the puzzle is easy to put together and takes no time at all; in fact, the kids were able to put this 40 piece puzzle together with minimal supervision.  There is also the added thrill of building a spherical puzzle - this was a first for us.  It was especially exciting for our 5-year old son - he has been an avid puzzle builder since he was 3, so a special puzzle like this had him smiling from ear to ear.All in all, Ravensburger makes some of the finest puzzles out there.  This puzzle has the added twist of turning into a toy once the puzzle is done - our kids loved that feature.

A very fun and "light" experiment kit for kids. I say light, because you'll still need to sit there with them and go over things. You'll also need a lot more ingredients than they provide, so be prepared. You don't want to break this out and not be able to do anything because you don't have the ingredients.The WOW factor of these experiments are very fun though. They are a great way to show your little one what can be done with different chemicals.

I really like the applicator, the medicine fits right in and you apply it with a few clicks. It keeps it off your fingers and applies to the dog easily. This medicine works, the fleas are off the dog. We usually use the expensive pill, but I noticed he was scratching again, so I applied and they went away. Nice. I'm convinced.I've also noticed no reactions and he's shown no sign of being uncomfortable.

It smells exactly like you would expect, just like the essential oils it is named from. You spritz this in the toilet before you "go" and you'll sniff pleasant air through the whole experience. No one wants to smell the nasty...! Then it's a convo piece, when your friend comes out of the bathroom you guys can laugh about your witty happy odor maker. And you won't have to smell their excrements. Win. Win.I liked the smell of the Lemon and Bergamot. It was a good combination and nothing like the air-freshener you buy for "after the fact" cover-ups. Great and fun idea and it'll keep your bathroom smelling lovely.

Good knife, it was very sharp on first use. I like the fact that it sharpens in its case. I had no issues as far as it being too think or with the sharpening, since I've had it for the last week. I'll update if it dulls in the future.The handle is very sturdy, the knife is actually HUGE. It's not your everyday slicer. Pull it out when you need some serious cutting. Overall, I liked the knife. You do have to clean it every time you pull it out though, before you cut anything, just because of the sharpener.

Well, I didn't really get to look much at this watch, my child grabbed it and ran off with it and I haven't seen her since. I did manage to ask her a few questions as to her liking of it and she responded with:BEST THING EVER!When I asked her if it was easy to set-up she came back with a recorded message from the phone in a variety of computer voices saying:SO EASY SO EASY SO COOL-OH-OH-OOOOHShe would play with this all day if I didn't take it from  her. I don't want her wear it to school though. She loves taking pictures with it, I finally managed to get it from her to check out a few key features and they were easy to use and figure out. It takes video and records sound and even has a camera. She enjoys the app that measures how "funny" your picture is.The case that it came in was interesting and fun. And the look of the watch is also fun to sport. Great toy for kids and they'll think you are the best for getting it for them.

This is a beautifully constructed toy that stimulates your child and gives them basically something to look at while you are driving. Who wants to stare at the back of a seat? No one. Not even your baby. This is a pretty addition to your car that will give your baby a little calming "art" to check out.It quieted baby and wasn't too complex. The shapes and images are fun.

This is great for the money, it's an inexpensive surge protector, if you are looking for just a few more outlets with relatively basic protection, this is a great one for you. If you need more than the basic protection for your electronics, you might want to step up to a higher level of protection. The switch is easy to turn off an on and there is an okay placement of the plugs. Again, this is your typical surge strip for a good price.

A beautiful watch, it is a striking piece and lightweight, definitely something that would make a great gift and a great everyday watch to wear for a man. The packaging and set-up of the watch was styled nicely and felt expensive.The face of the watch was unique, the date area stood out with it's different styling. The band was sturdy and made out of genuine leather which I liked. The clasp was sturdy and intense and took a bit of maneuvering to put on, but worked well once in place.My first issue arose with the instructions, it didn't seem like the instructions were for this particular watch, setting the time and date was not done like it was on the instructions.My second issue was that it does not keep accurate time, in a 24 hour period it lags behind 4 minutes. In the grand scheme of things–not huge, but I do like my watches to be on the second.

Oh man, these are cute and decorative and small. They match my kitchen, they look good on the counter–but the moment you use them, well they aren’t exactly “heat resistant.” The advertisement says “heat resistant” up to 425 degrees. Our oven was on at 400 and we used it to pull the pan out. There was this sudden smell of burnt synthetic rubber - and then there is a line across the neoprene where the pan touched. That doesn’t seem like it’s working. That is actually PRETTY scary. I don’t think we’ll be using this very much.

Great idea and ingenius design. My child had no problem with breakage, which is the MAIN reason mechanical pencils are a terrible investment. Press hard and they break, which is an issue with most young children and tweens. Even adults have the issue. This did not happen with these pencils. My child loved them and she didn't have to stop and sharpen them constantly. Great colored pencils. They were also easy to hold in her hand.Definitly a great idea and I wish someone would have come up with this a long time ago. I need the "regular" pencil color, like now.

Amazing and fun. This worked just like it should and made a great snowball for my child and we even used it to crunch ice for our screwdrivers - gotta get the whole family involved!This comes together easily, in fact you just basically pull it out of the box, plug it in and it works. One button on the top of Olaf's head and the ice crunches. Ice did get a little bit of everywhere in his tummy, so be careful when you are pulling open the door, ice pools on the "shelf" in the door.It comes with a set of ice trays, which are a little hard to pop out, might be better served with silicon trays - but that was an added bonus. I do wish it would have come with maybe one or two starter flavors - so remember if you pick this one up remember to grab a flavor with it. Disappointed children aren't fun.Overall great product. Has a huge footprint though so have some counter room.

This product is a very pretty case. It FITS the iPAD Air perfectly. It is simple, it is put together well and it protects my iPad. It folds back so I can set it up so it faces me and it holds it in place. I really can't ask for anything more. It's SUPER cheap, so really, I don't expect it to protect it from falls, spills etc. I just want it to get some sort of extra protection.I have had other boxes​ and super tough cases that are a pain in the but, especially when I use things like Paypal Here and have to attach a card reader to my iPad. Pain in the butt. This one is not. It's simplicity is what the selling point is.

The Avery Textured White Scallop Round Tags are just perfect and very similar to the Scallop Round Tags (41557) just without the hole punched. These have adhesive on them though, so they can easily be placed on a jar, or box. Fun fun! These were perfect for my mason jar products. The textured look gives them a professional and high-quality look to my product. I make my own lotions and scrubs and give them as gifts to family members and friends. Adding a cute label to them just pulls it all together.I love that you can go online and set up your template there and then just print them. I wasn’t too sure about the 4x6 sheets, but it worked easily. I don’t know why they are doing them so small, I would like to seem them as a full sheet, especially for the price, but the product is nice and they worked well. Just wish there was more for the money.Overall great quality paper. Beautiful end result.

Cute idea for weddings or free giveaways for you business. I set these up for a school meeting as giveaways, with a little inspirational message on them. They got a ton of compliments. They aren’t that fancy but the results are cute. I would suggest these for wedding/party favors on a budget, or cute freebies for a craft fair or big meeting.I love that you can go online and set up your template there and then just print them. I wasn’t too sure about the 4x6 sheets, but it worked easily. Especially for this product. Out of all the 4x6 sheet labels that Avery offers, this one you got the most bang for your buck with 120 labels. Perfect amount. I do still think these are pricy though.Overall fun product, great labels for the DIY party planner or crafty business person.

The Avery Kraft Brown Round Labels are probably my favorite out of this group. I love the look, the texture and the presentation of these. It gives them a crafty feel, with the DIY flavor, but also a professional and clean presentation.  I make my own lotions and scrubs and give them as gifts to family members and friends. Adding a cute label to them just pulls it all together.I love that you can go online and set up your template there and then just print them. I wasn’t too sure about the 4x6 sheets, but it worked easily. I don’t know why they are doing them so small, I would like to seem them as a full sheet, especially for the price, but the product is nice and they worked well. Just wish there was more for the money.Overall great quality paper. Fantastic overall appearance. Beautiful end result.

The Avery Textured White Scallop Round Tags are just perfect! The textured looks give them a professional and high-quality look to your product.  I make my own lotions and scrubs and give them as gifts to family members and friends. Adding a cute label to them just pulls it all together.I love that you can go online and set up your template there and then just print them. I wasn’t too sure about the 4x6 sheets, but it worked easily. I don’t know why they are doing them so small, I would like to seem them as a full sheet, especially for the price, but the product is nice and they worked well. Just wish there was more for the money. Overall great quality paper. Beautiful end result.

These Scallop round labels from Avery are wonderful and easy to use. They are pearlized and give a great look to any gift or product. I make my own lotions and scrubs and give them as gifts to family members and friends. Adding a cute label to them just pulls it all together.I love that you can go online and set up your template there and then just print them. I wasn’t to sure about the 4x6 sheets, but it worked easily. I don’t know why they are doing them so small, I would like to seem them as a full sheet, especially for the price, but the product is nice and they worked well.Printing on the pearlized look didn’t quite give me the beautiful print I wanted, I think this would work better with hand-drawn sentiments if you have a beautiful hand. Overall though, great labels and I was pleased with the outcome.

I am pretty impressed with this daypack, it seems to have EVERYTHING in it. It's padded, so it was comfortable to wear. The straps fit nicely on my body and it didn't weigh me down. I usually run around with a laptop and a tablet. Over-achiever and all that, but I was using a simple pack and I didn't feel it gave my electronics enough protection. This one does. It even has a dedicated pocket for my sunglasses so I don't mess those up also. It also has enough room that you can put your phone in there and it's got a hard casing so you won't have any breakage.It seems they thought of everything with this bag. There are pockets here and there that hold, organize and protect anything you would need to bring with you on your adventure. I use this mostly for light traveling. I have a bigger pack for traveling via plane or train.The inside extra pockets are mesh, so you can easily see what you stashed in there and nothing gets lost.There are attachments for your keys, or hiking gear, which is nice. You can use this pack for outdoor adventures also.The straps are padded, but not as comfortable as their other packs, which is something I usually like about Thule, this sat a bit differently on the body, so the back of the pack pressed against my neck. So, I loosened the straps and it felt too loose on me. So I tightened them back up. I found a happy medium, but I still felt it sat too high on my back.I LOVE the easy grab zippers. They fit perfectly in your fingers and make for easy unzip/zip. You don't think about these things until you try and unzip something and it drives you crazy because your fingers slip. Not on this backpack. Love those easy grab ones.I also LOVE the fact that it is water resistant. You put the waterbottle in the side pocket and realize too late it's leaking. Ruined laptop. not with this one.Overall, lightweight. Padded and protects my electronic goodies. You can't ask for anything better. If they just made it a bit more comfortable​ it would be perfect.

This is a great product. It's easy to use and my child loves it. It set-up in minutes and it required very little supervision. My child is eight and she read through the directions and was able to create her clings with us just watching over her for a little while and then we let her go at it. She made colorful window clings for a few hours, completely entertained. It was different and fun for her and didn't take a whole bunch of bulky things to do it. It was all together.This set made about 15-20 clings. Each cling took about 5 minutes to dry, so you don't have to worry about anything messing up. The mixing and set-up was also easy and wasn't that big of a mess. The only thing that got out of hand was when she decided to mix glitter in with the concoction. Overall, great experience and perfect gift for your crafty kid.

I’ve used many brooms in my day. I’ve used synthetic brooms, bamboo, the one with all the sticks that break off all over the place, even a great Asian broom that I need to buy again, it is kind of small though. This is my first Rubber Squeegee.I wouldn’t exactly describe it as perky though.One, it was easy to put together, even though you really have to JAM it in the hole. Screwing it together only worked with the head of the broom. The pole part I had to really force it in there by slamming it on the floor. Luckily it didn’t break, but I could see this happening.Then for the sweeping part. It’s not an easy sweep, the rubber on my hardwood floor drags a bit, so it’s not a smooth push and pull. It does get up a lot of the items, mainly the animal hair – which we have a lot of. But, the little pieces of paper (I have a crafty kid) doesn’t come up as easily. But it was efficient. Use it with another broom and your vacuum for optimal floor cleaning. I wish the head was a bit bigger…but other than that it did the job.

I was just in the process of moving, so this little thing was a life saver for my husband and I!  We do not have a hand truck, and really needed one to help move boxes and some larger items into our new home.  I was excited to get this item just at the right time, which also allowed me to leave an honest review if it actually worked well or not.  Well, it did.This can hold up to 150 pounds, which when moving, I realized is most of the things we will need to use it for.  It did not come with any instructions, but I was able to figure out how to use it pretty easily.  Once you have it set up, you are ready to go.This will be great to have around when you have to move boxes or other heavy items.I was sent this for free in exchange for an honest review.

I am a huge moisturizer believer, and I also love anything with coconut oil, so this was a must try for me.The packaging is nice and this comes with a pump, which is also a feature I prefer in my beauty products.This is a nice and light moisturizer.  It is creamy and goes on my skin nicely.  It absorbs quickly so I can use it day or night.  It does have a faint smell and does smell a little like coconut.  The smell does not bother me at all.I have only been using this for a few days.  It has not made me break out like some moisturizers do.  I can not say if it has improved my skin yet, but I am hopeful.I was sent this item at a discounted price in exchange for a review.

This is such a large strainer and great for so many different things.  The one thing I really love about this is the size of the holes.  It provides enough room to strain liquid, but they are small enough that you are not going to lose any food items when using it.  That is something I have run into when using my previous strainer.  I would always lose some food as it would fall through the holes.  I no longer have that issue with this.I have used this several times, and put it in the dishwasher. It has held up nicely and is a great quality.I was sent this item for free in exchange for an honest review.

I have heard so many great things about Garcinia Cambogia, but unfortunately it does not seem to work for me.  I have tried several brands and I have not felt or seen any difference.  I think this is one of those things that will effect people differently, so I can not take off stars for that.  My mom has used this with great success.I was sent this for free in exchange for an honest review

Let me start off by saying that I have very oily hair.  I think there is sometimes a myth that if you have oily hair, you should be careful with using hair masks or argan oil as it can make it even more oily.  I have to say, I think that is for sure a myth as this mask works great with my hair.I use this in the shower about once a week.  I leave it on for several minutes and then wash it out.  My hair is soft and clean feeling.  It does not make my hair oily, and really helps with my tiny frizz that I always have.  If you are suffering from fly aways, breakage, or dry hair I recommend giving a hair mask a try.I was sent this item for free in exchange for an honest review.

We had an air purifier for the baby's room but we were not really happy with it as it was loud and blew a bit of cold air when it was doing its cleaning so we tried the the AeraMax Baby DB5 Air Purifier and so far we are very pleased.The product is very easy to set up- it basically works straight out of the box but you do need to take the plastic off the filters and reinstall prior to use.  Then just plug in, let it go through its start up cycle and let it go. Other then that, I can't find any fault with this product at the moment. With two kids, traveling can be a bit of a pain, especially when you need two car seats on the other end.  The J.L. Childress Universal Side-Carry Seat Cover does not take all the hassle out of the trip but it does make it somewhat easier. On our outbound trip we used the product to carry the car seat we kept with us through the airports. It worked reasonably well- the seat was easy enough to get in and out of it as the bag is very roomy and we could even stuff more of the babies toys and accessories in it.  The bag is nylon so it is strong but it folded up small enough to stuff under the babies seat when in flight.  The staps were comfortable enough for short walks but they did start to dig into your shoulders after a while as there was no padding.  Overall, it served as an oversize backpack for the seat which was nice.On the way back, we put the older child's car seat in the carrier and checked it and despite losing some of the functionality by not having it with us, we actually liked this option more as it really saved the seat from getting beat up while in the hold. The seat cover really held up and we were able to grab and go once we got the luggage.Either way, this is a durable product that wil make travel with the kids somewhat easier- at least on the car seat...

I learned how to use a sewing machine when I was young on my grandmother’s machine but I have never owned my own until I got the Singer 1304 Start Basic Everyday and after just a few weeks, I am not sure why I had not gotten one before.  Even if I never find the time to actually make things, just the time it saves on basic mending is worth it.The machine itself is fairly small for a sewing machine and lightweight so it is portable- perhaps a better word is storable in that you can unplug, put on the top shelf and then get down when necessary. Even though it is not that heavy, I would still describe it as sturdy and I anticipate it will last a good while with proper care.  Setup was easy- there are basic instructions and if you follow them, you will be redoing hems and patching holes in a matter of minutes.  It even comes with some thread already so there is no additional material needed to start using it out of the box.As I said, I probably won’t ever use this machine to craft my own clothes or anything, and in truth, this is what one might describe as a “starter kit.” I am sure it is capable of being used for heavy duty sewing but you might be better off with an upgraded machine if you are going to be making serious handicrafts.  What this machine can do is save you time and money- I have two boys, and with them, two dogs and a cat in the house, things get torn, ripped, and trashed with some frequency.  I tried to fix what I could with needle and thread but some stuff was either unsalvageable or I would have to pay the astronomical prices at the local seamstress (10 bucks for a ripped pocket!).  The Singer allows me to make these repairs in minimal time.  Honestly, I’m not sure why I didn’t get one sooner.

Our 3-year-old loves when he gets access to his dad's IPAD, so we were excited at the possibility of a child appropriate tablet.  Overall, the LeapPad2 GLO has a lot of plusses.  First, it has a very sturdy case that keeps both the device and screen protected.  The buttons are clearly marked and easy for little fingers and our son quickly figured out the basics.  It has front-and-back facing cameras, a microphone, nice sound quality and decent screen resolution.  There is an attached stylus, but the touch screen does fine with fingers as well.Some potential cons.  The LeapPad2 requires 4-AA batteries to operate and goes through them fairly quickly.  We had to replace our first set after around 4-5 hours of use.  LeapFrog does offer two alternatives to this.  The $12 Leapfrog Leappad Accessories On-the-go Bundle. Flower Carrying Case, Car Adapter & $15 Digital Download Card, which is a good deal considering it includes a $15 game credit in addition to a case and a car adapter.  There's also the pricier (at over $30) LeapFrog LeapPad2 Recharger Pack (Works with all LeapPad2 Tablets), which includes both rechargeable batteries and an AC adapter.  It's half the base price of the device, but probably a worthwhile investment if your child is going to be regularly using this product.The other issue is the content.  The device comes preloaded with several nice apps and games and includes a credit for one more.  You can both download apps directly to the device with a USB port, or there are games that can be bought on cartridges (tiny versions of the old Tandy squares from my childhood).  Either way is an easy purchase and LeapFrog offers a large variety of apps on their website.  The downside is that the apps are pricey - on average between $10 and $20.  Now, the quality of the apps is high and they are definitely geared at teaching young kids.  However, compared to what's available for a kindle or smartphone for free to under $5, it's a steep jump, so should be considered as a factor when purchasing.  Another plus of the games is that if you're looking for a specific product tie-in, LeapFrog is likely to have it.Our son loves this tablet and I think it's a good, solid option at an overall reasonable price.  It's attractive, durable and easy to use.  I think it's probably better for the younger end of the targeted demographic, but I look forward to being proven wrong over time.

I was looking to replace my two year old Samsun S3 smartphone which was running low on memory.  This is a great smartphone, particularly for the price and considering that it's unlocked.First, the phone - it's a comparable size to my old Samsun, although more of the phone is used for the screen.  Screen color and definition and the speakers offer a good quality sound.  It's large enough to feel substantive and be easy to use the screen, but small and slim enough to fit into a pocket without awkwardness.  The basic interface is nice and the phone works well overall.Setting up WiFI was super easy, and if you don't want to install a SIM card, the phone operates excellent just off the Wi-Fi network.  Installing a SIM card is easy (just pop off the back and slide it in.  It only takes micro SIM cards, which is important to note.  I was able to easily and quickly download all my previously purchased apps using Wi-Fi.  The keyboard, and basic built in apps are handy, but there are not so many built in apps that I felt clogged up from the second I got started.  The phone charged quickly and easily and accepted charges that can multi-function.Overall, this is a great little smart phone if you're not interesting in paying a huge amount.

First, let’s just get this out of the way- if you get the Radio Flyer Ultimate EZ Folding Wagon thinking it will pass for the Radio Flyer red wagon of your youth, you will be disappointed.  Although this looks like the classic wagon in form, it is probably much closer to think of this product as a double stroller then a wagon.But that ok! In fact it’s great- we have two children, ages 10 months and 3 years and although we have a Phil and Ted double stroller, we find that we can’t really carry all the things we need in it when we go places- what with diaper bags, snacks, drinks, etc. The Radio Flyer solves these problems- there is plenty of room for two kids to sit- the recommended age is 1 and a half but our ten month old loves it and can sit up, buckled in just fine.  There is also plenty of room in the middle for all the accessories needed as well as cup holders both in the wagon for the kids and outside for parents drinks.  The canopy top provides complete top coverage, unlike the typical stroller cover and comes in handy, especially on a hot day.  The icing on the cake is that since the Radio Flyer folds up, it does not take any more space than the double stroller in the back of our car.  Overall, this is fast replacing our stroller as the go-to child conveyance in our house.The product itself is typical Radio Flyer high quality- we have the typical red wagon and tricycle as well and we can’t say enough.  Construction was fairly simple and the instructions were easy to follow.  Just to note, and another reason I say the product is not really a wagon is the side are really just a red canvas material, that won’t really allow for much impact.  In addition, the wheels are set so that they have great turning radius, but they are thinner and connected to higher, thinner rods then the wagon.  Bottom line- this is for hauling children and their gear, not for racing down hills, tying to the back of bikes, and all those other great things we did as kids but wouldn’t dream of letting out kids do today.  The seats are hard plastic with a safety belt and the canopy top seems to be the same material as the sides.  The only complain I really have is that once folded, sometimes it is a bit hard to unfold.Overall, if you need a double stroller or are ready to ditch the traditional stroller, this may be what you are looking for.  We really enjoy taking our kids on walks in this and they love it as well.

Its kind of hard to believe that even with the long litany of tragedies and wars of the 20th century, something on the scale of the India-Pakistan partisan, which saw 12.5 million people displaced and up to a million killed, should be somewhat overlooked- at least in Western texts and thought.In that sense, Midnight’s Fury by Nisid Hajari is a critical book in that it tells the story of that fateful year of 1947, concentrating on the leaders- Gandhi, Nehru and Ali Jinnah and the choices they made and the ways they got swept up in history’s tide and overtaken by events. Hajari also chronicals the British’s rapid, one might even say chaotic departure from the subcontinent and the vacuum that ensued that was filled by ethnic and religious violence.This is a well-written book that really delves into that year. The scholarship and research is self-evident as Hajari brings primary sources into sharp focus to display how both sides got caught in a cycle of action and reaction and the results that followed. The book is detailed but not overly gory as he relates the violence and atrocities that racked India and Pakistan during this time.If I have one complaint, it’s that Hajari does not much to place the situation at the dawn of the partisan in much context- understandably this may be a lot but at least a brief overview of the British Raj would be in order and placing the contest in the UK’s history and policy in the region. Then at the end, he sort of tails off at the end of partisan and does not really close any of the threads that were left open. For example- how Pakistan was split into two that almost guaranteed a coming civil war, which finally happened in 1970-71 when Bangladesh broke away.However, this is not to take away from the sheer power of Midnight’s Fury, which tells, in gripping detail, the story of one of the largest displacement of peoples and mass killings the world has ever seen, but depressingly, seems to know too little about.

If you travel enough, you seem to gravitate towards a particular travel guide that best suits you.  For us, that is the Lonely Planet series- it gives a wide range of options in a number of different price ranges and has nice write-ups of most attractions, not only in the major cities but in out of the way places as well.  The write-ups are informative with schedules, prices, an often suggested times to go.  They even will caution against going if they feel it’s not worth it which allows the traveler to make up their own mind.In that respect, the Lonely Planet Scotland is a welcome addition to the series.  It starts with suggested key highlights from around the country, mixing urban (Edinburgh and Glasgow) with more remote locals and islands, and even throwing in golf and whiskey.  It then makes itinerary suggestions if you have certain interests and has a calendar of festivals and events to help plan events as well.  It has some general tourist guidelines such as climate, transportation, visa need, etc. Finally they get into the different regions- as one might imagine the largest sections focus on the main cities but they do a great job of breaking the country down by region and giving the adventurous traveler a reason to get out of the cities and see more out of the way places.Having said that, we were a bit disappointed in this version of Lonely Planet.  One reason we really liked the series is that they always have a history section that traces the history of the city, region, etc that they are covering.  This one has it but it is sorely lacking. The write-ups are a half page at best and not very informative.  In addition, other Lonely Planet guides have inserts throughout the book that illuminate some local tradition or lore but this has none of that.  I suppose they figure the reader is familiar enough with the subject or it would make the book too long/thick to be useful while traveling but surely a better balance could have been struck.Overall, though, another fine effort from Lonely Planet that really opens up the possibilities when visiting Scotland.

I have very thick, wavy should length hair and I'm always looking for new ways to tame it. If I'm going for style, normally I'll either get a blow out (if I have time and cash) or use a flat iron. I have a Remington NEW Wet 2 Straight Ceramic Hair Straightener with 2" Inch Ceramic Plates, All NEW Steam Vent Technology, Fast Heat Up & Swivel Cord and it works great, although nothing is as good as someone else doing my hair.  I was initially a bit dubious of this device, since my hair does not respond well to brushes in general (I literally don't own one).The single biggest perk of this item is versatility.  I travel a lot, so appreciate any time I can bring one item and have it serve several purposes.  If you're going on a trip and want options with your hair, this will definitely provide it.  You can flat iron, add some curl or body, or just use it as a standard brush (not for me but I understand that most people have a better relationship with brushes than I do).I found the straightening element worked well overall.  I won't be getting rid of my other flat iron any time soon - the bristles made it very hard to get all the way to the roots of your hair, and I found that while it was a good flat iron, I like my Remington a bit better.  I liked being able to trap the end of my hair into the iron to start the curls.  Due to the size of the tube, you get fairly large, loos curls.  For thick hair, I found this slightly less effective, as I had use fairly small strips of hair to allow sufficient exposure to the rod.  However, I have friends with thin hair, and have no doubt that for those whose hair is less bushy, it would work very well.I think the bristles were my least favorite part, as I had to be careful when unwinding curls to ensure they didn't get brushed out and puffy.  Again, it all depends on what type of hair you have.  I will definitely be throwing this in my suitcase next time I want some options while traveling, while keeping the luggage on the light side.

Ok- I’m just going to put this out there- a 5 and a half pound bag of candy is probably not for everyone but for those that either eat or need a lot of candy, you could do worse than a ton of Blue Raspberry Jolly Ranchers.I have to assume that if you are reading this, you have an idea of what a Jolly Rancher is but if not, it’s a hard candy that comes individually wrapped in a small rectangular piece about the size of a nickel (well- if nickels were rectangular).  They have a number of flavors but the basic ones are watermelon, grape, cherry, green apple, and blue raspberry.So- I hear you asking- why would you buy a gigantic bag of only one flavor when you can get bags with all five flavors?  Well- it’s like this- Blue Raspberry rocks- it’s not just the hypnotic light blue color but it has a sublime raspberry taste that can’t be beat- ok, the watermelon is close but blue raspberry edges it out by a whisker. And like the green M&Ms, they are always- and I do mean always, underrepresented in the bag.  Oh, I know the manufacturer says they mix all the flavors in the bag evenly.  Lies! There are never enough Blue Raspberry, and that dear reader is why you need this product.  If you need a five pound bag of candy that is.

I love Thai curry, yet with a regular work schedule and two kids, taking the time to make a proper curry paste isn't an option.  Maggie offers a decent option if you'd like to cook a curry at home, but have limited time.  This is a large tub, so if you don't plan to make curry regularly, it may not be your best option.  It's great if you're cooking for a dinner party and want more than a small serving, which is the option of most single-serve packet brands.  In addition, I found that it stayed well if you seal in a zip lock bag and keep it in the fridge, but after about 6 weeks the flavor starts to wane.It's super easy to use.  Open the pouch, sauté some of the paste in oil, add coconut milk (or combine coconut milk and broth to reduce the fat content) and add your choice of protein and veggies and let simmer.  The dishes are easy to reheat and make great leftovers.  This curry is fairly salty, so I like to include some citrus (fresh lime juice) to cut the salt and not too spicy, so if you’re a big heat fan you should plan to add some more on your own.  Overall, it’s a good way to “spice up” your dinner options.

We found ourselves in the market for a more heavy-duty crib mattress cover as our 8-month old is now drinking his bottle by himself and refuses to go to sleep without it (and yes, this includes waking up multiple times a night to "fill up").  As you might imagine this cause a delightful little two-fer problem in that he makes a mess while drinking and, well- he stresses the limits of his diaper during the night.  Given the situation, we took the opportunity to try the Serta Perfect Sleeper Crib Mattress Cover.The product itself is everything it claims- the top is 100% cotton and very thick and soft, while the sides are an elastic polyurethane.  It does fit a regular sized U.S. crib mattress; however the elastic is just a bit loose.  This is not an issue as I think most would use a cover sheet but if you did just want to use the pad itself, it might slip a little.  The pad seems to just come in the one color and style- white with the Serta sheep pattern plus stars on top of it. The design does show through a white sheet if you look hard enough and although the sheep are cute but I could also understand where some people might not want to have a corporate logo showing in their baby’s bed.  If this is a factor, a colored sheet hides the pattern quite nicely. The quality seems in line with other mattress pads we have owned- either adult or baby- which is to say holds up fairly well to frequent washing, and does not seem to rip or tear too easily.  As for being waterproof- we have already had to change it out a few times in the morning and it seems to be holding its own against the formula and other liquids being thrown its way.The last note is the thickness on the top- I don't know if our baby notices the softness or not. There is no discernable way to tell if he is sleeping better on this pad verses the others we rotate out with it as he still loves getting us up at night, but I have to admit, it does feel good to lay him down on such as soft nest.Overall, this is a nice, quality crib pad, and at $20 dollars is a good value.

We've used a wide variety of bottles and nipples between our two children. I found these to be a solid, middle-of-the-road bottle, but was not overly impressed by the anti-colic feature if your child truly has issues with gas.  The shape of the nipples was fairly unique – significantly smaller than the Munchkin LATCH line of bottles, and the Playtex Ventaire that also have an anti-colic feature.  The head of the nipple is very small comparatively, and would be useful with a younger baby.  They most resemble the infant nipples used by Madela.  AVENT offers a range of nipple speeds, and the size does work with an older child, but our son who was used to a wider nipple from the Playtex and Munchkin took time to adjust.Instead of a mini-bottle, the 9 oz bottle is great for older babies.  Our 8 month old son goes through 6-9 oz in a feeding, so the larger bottle is easier to use than many of the other brands which have only 6-8 oz bottles.  This is particularly true if you’re using formula, which requires the extra space to add the powder to the water and mix.  I also liked that amounts were listed not only in US oz, but in ML and UK oz.  We live overseas and having a measurement that makes sense to our child care provider is a huge plus.The bottle comes apart easily for cleaning, and has only three parts.  My biggest concern was the “anti-colic’ element, which is basically rivets in the nipples.  Our son, who is not prone to colic, did fine with these.  However, I feel the actual anti-colic value here seems less than that of the Latch or Ventaire.  That said, our son had no more issues with these than with the other brands.  Overall I found it to be a good bottle/nipple combo, and easy to use.  If your baby is particularly colicky, I’d recommend one of the other brands, but it’s a very good standard bottle overall.

We are always in need of additional crib sheets as our 8-month old is now drinking his bottle by himself (and making a mess I might add) so we took the opportunity to try the TL Care Deluxe Cotton Flannel Crib sheet.  The product come in a number of fairly standard colors- blue, pink, white and who could forget celery and ecru (we have ecru – or as I like to call it, off-white).  The quality seems in line with other crib sheets- which is to say it fits well, hold up fairly well to frequent washing, and does not seem to rip or tear too easily.To compare it to other crib sheets, we also have the American Baby Company Heavenly Soft Chenille Fitted Crib Sheet.  The TL Care is in no way as soft but it is a more natural fiber being 100% cotton which is a plus and quite frankly, I don't know if our baby notices the softness or lack thereof or not.  There is no discernable way to tell if he is sleeping better on one or the other as he still loves getting us up at night.Overall, this is a nice, quality crib sheet, and at $15 dollars is a good value.

I have always enjoyed historical tracing books such as “Salt” or “Cod” that take one thing and trace it through history and “Rain: A Natural and Cultural History” by Cynthia Barnett is in the same mold. True to the title, Barnett traces human interactions with rain (or lack of rain as the case may be) through the eons. She weaves cultural references and natural science together to show man’s attempts to understand this phenomena and in some instances, attempts to control it. A bit unlike other books of what I consider its genre, “Rain” is less history- after all, can one really dispute the absolute necessity of it, and more a look of mankind’s relationship with it. Therefore she does rely a lot more on poets then historians but it is still a compelling look at something we take for granted, especially the warning that we may be taking rain too much for granted and risk contaminating it even further.Overall, it was a thoroughly enjoyable book. The writing is crisp and compelling and the narrative is brisk and keeps the reader’s attention. One could quibble about examples she uses or ones she does not (What- no Credence Clearwater Revival and "Who'll Stop The Rain"???), but given the absolutely overwhelming amount of source material, that seems like a pretty churlish complaint. Barnett clearly knows her stuff and is totally in synch with her subject. This is a perfect book if you want something weightier then a beach read but also want to learn something.

Our oldest son just turned three and over the past six months or so has become much more interested in playing with items that Mom and Dad use.  We started him out with a toy kitchen and a small Melissa and Doug Wooden Tool Box and although he loves the kitchen, he played with the tool kit one or twice and did not touch it again (our eight month old on the other hand loves it!).  Since he did like the larger kitchen ensemble, we, took the opportunity to get the Lanard Workman Ultimate Workbench and it has been an unequivocal hit.The work bench itself is made of hard plastic pieces, with a cardboard backing.  The table is almost two feet off the ground so it’s a good height for the target audience of about 3-6 years.  The back part rises to about three feet so all in all it’s an imposing toy but not too big to be intimidating to our three year old.  The bench is fairly easy to assemble and has hooks and areas to hand and store all the tool toys that come with the set.  The plastic is sturdy so I am confident it will last long enough for our second son to play with it as well.  The only slight negative is the cardboard backing is a bit flimsy.Although the bench itself is fairly impressive, it’s the array of tools that comes with the set that is truly astounding. It has all the usual ones- wrenches, screwdrivers, saws and hammers- but it also has a nail gun and lathe (with attached baseball bat no less) that are battery powered to move and simulate the real equipment.  There are also 15 each of nuts and bolts.  All the pieces are colorful, hard plastic that can withstand hard play. I am actually less concerned about these toys then I am with the wooden tools in the Melissa and Doug tool set.  Best of all, all the tools are pretty good replicas of real tools, albeit a bit smaller for smaller hands.  I don’t think I can say enough about this point as our son really likes to play with the same things he sees his daddy use (except the lathe- we don’t have a lathe although my husband now says he needs one…).  It really is a good lead-in to the real things as my husband is working with our son on the importance of putting the tools back in their areas and making sure they are properly cared for, well- as well as a three year old can take care of things.  The urge to throw things is strong in that one.At about $75 dollars, the Workman Ultimate Workbench is also a good value.  That is comparable to larger workbench toys from other major brands that do not contain the same amount to tool toys and significantly cheaper than some brands. If you are looking for a quality toy work bench, with a good selection of toy tools at a reasonable price, this is a great option.

I didn’t really know what to expect with “Women of Will” by Tina Packer.  From the name, you could pretty much deduce it would focus on the female characters, especially with a secondary title of “Following the Feminine in Shakespeare’s Plays”, which sounds intriguing in theory, but how would it work in practice?After reading the book, I am still trying to figure out how it does work in practice.  Much like Will Shakespeare himself, the book is a bit of a mystery, wrapped in a riddle, inside an enigma (to paraphrase Churchill…)  To begin with the book is not an academic work in that Packer does not spend much time- any time really, citing source documents or such.  Her only sources are the plays themselves which she is intimately familiar with from her stage background.
