In that respect, she really brings to life the characters she focuses on and interprets them in her own way- much like every director or actor has since Will first wrote the plays, but you can’t help but come away with the feeling, that it remains just that- her interpretation of these characters- not Shakespeare’s.The book itself is broken into five acts that Packer uses to trace her view of the changing way women are portrayed in Shakespeare.  Starting with Kate from Taming of the Shrew, which shows in her opinion, a sophomoric view of women as property, she traces what she sees as the advancement of his views on the status and value of women through five “acts”, ending with the stronger, nobler women characters, to be found in Marina (Pericles) and Hermoine (The Winter’s Tale) as she tries to theorize how the idea of the female changed through the writing and what might be the cause of it (Love Actually).Which brings us to the second conundrum about the book- The writing is good and engaging but one feels they must already have a Master’s in Literature to follow her sometimes.  I am reasonably familiar with a large number of Shakespeare’s plays but Packer left me in the dust and never looked back.  For a scholarly work, I would expect this, but for a book that basically outlines the author’s insights, a bit more background would have been handy.None of this is to say I did not enjoy the book- I actually did.  The author’s enthusiasm for the subject is infectious but it is not light reading.  I don’t necessarily think the reasoning is entirely accurate but the book is a great view of how Shakespeare’s women characters evolved over the course of his career.  In that respect, and for anyone who is looking for a contemporary retelling of Shakespeare, this is well worth the read.

I loved paper dolls as a kid, but they are not so common these days. The paper dolls that are available tend to be fairly expensive and not particularly high quality - a younger child just isn't capable of not destroying them. This product, the T.S. Pirates of the High Seas Wooden Magnetic Dress Up Kit, is the perfect compromise, as this set is comparably priced to some paper doll books I've seen.Overall, the set is great, particularly for little ones who like pirates. We have others in the same line of product but this is the first we have that does not seem especially geared towards girls.  It should be noted that the others have also worked well three-year-old boy, but- well- hey- these are pirates.  There are two main pirate figures with interchangeable pieces of assorted pirate garb, hats, swords, pirate chests, and other pirate paraphernalia such as a treasure map, spyglass, flag, and even a monkey. The pieces are well made, have lots of detail and the plastic pouch they come in makes for an easy way to store and transport what could otherwise be lots of annoying pieces. The pieces stick well, but are easy for small hands to manipulate and are durable, so can survive normal pre-schooler play. The one drawback is that some of the pieces are really small so if you have younger children in the house, you do need to be careful as they can be a choking hazard.  In fairness to T.S. Shure- they do label this very clearly on the packaging.If you have a child who likes pirates, this is a great set, has quality, well made pieces and can offer hours of fun.

I have very thick, somewhat wavy should length hair and I'm always looking for new ways to tame it.  If I'm going for style, normally I'll either get a blow out (if I have time and cash) or use a flat iron. I have a Remington NEW Wet 2 Straight Ceramic Hair Straightener with 2" Inch Ceramic Plates, All NEW Steam Vent Technology, Fast Heat Up & Swivel Cord  and it works great, although nothing is as good as someone else doing my hair.On the plus side, I travel a lot and this is dual voltage so can go with me.  It's fairly compact and lightweight.  However, I'm not sold overall.  First, the glove.  Why is there a glove you ask?  To be honest, I'm still not sure and I didn't like wearing it.  Your hair definitely has to be dry before using this, so you better have time to first blow dry, then style.  Heat control seems to be an issue and I had to be careful not to burn myself.I'd also say, this might be more successful for someone with different hair.  My hair is very thick and hard to style.  If you have thinner or straight hair, I think this would do a decent job of giving you volume.  However, if you're not an expect, for thick hair, it can only exacerbate existent problems.

To be clear, I'm not sure that I actually "like" this toy, but boy is it a hit with my two sons, aged 3 and 8 months.  We had purchased Tiny Love Crosby Clip-On Crab Stroller Toy when our older son was a baby and it is still popular with him on longer car rides.  The older boy likes lions, so we thought this might be good to entertain the baby in the car.First, it's big.  This thing takes up the whole car window.  The lion hangs by a plastic bar with two (strong) suction cups that hooks onto little pegs on lion's paws.  That's also the basis for the lion's ability to move around.  It's bright, colorful and has a nice texture if baby wants to touch it.  It also comes with a small rattle with a wristband which is fun for baby as the lion appears to be sound activated and turns on when baby shakes his wrist.I'm not sure if it was designed by a drunken collage student, a genius or a combination of the two.  The lion dances and roars to frat party style electronica.  Now, since my older son's favorite form of communication is roaring, this makes it incredibly popular.  The three year old loves it.  The 8 month old stares at it raptly as thought it is even more interesting than his older brother (this is by no means a small feat).  So from the "entertaining children" perspective, it's a big hit.  From the adult perspective, I can mostly live with my sons being entertained by a roaring, lion drunkenly gyrating to bad electronica in the car.From the "how long can you listen to this without going crazy?"  Well, that's a personal question.  For us, the entertainment value has outweighed the annoyance and after the initial surprise, the music is actually a slightly refreshing change from the standard 4 tinny classical tunes on most baby products.  Overall, our family finds the lion a roaringly good time.

In our area, rainy season means flea season.  Last rainy season our vet told us that no matter what we put on the cat, it would keep fleas away but couldn't eliminate them because they were, well, everywhere.  In order to avoid fleas becoming resistant, we've used a number of brands, including Frontline and Advantage.  I found this product to be as successful in eliminating fleas as the other two, and significantly more reasonable in price than Advantage (it is price comparable with Frontline).As with any skin application, it is easy to use and quick to apply.  Put it on your cat and within 24 hours fleas and flea eggs are out of luck.  It doesn't have a strong odor and other than feeling slightly greasy, isn't unpleasant when you come in contact.  After about a day, it absorbed into our cat's fur and didn't even show where it had been applied.If you're in a flea environment, this product worked well for us is keeping fleas outdoors instead of on our cat, was easy to apply and reasonable priced.  A win overall.

In our area, rainy season means flea season.  Last rainy season our vet told us that no matter what we put on the dogs, it would keep fleas away but couldn't eliminate them because they were, well, everywhere.  In order to avoid fleas becoming resistant, we've used a number of brands, including Frontline and Advantage.  I found this product to be as successful in eliminating fleas as the other two, and significantly more reasonable in price than Advantage (it is price comparable with Frontline).As with any skin application, it is easy to use and quick to apply.  Put it on your dog and within 24 hours fleas and flea eggs are out of luck.  It doesn't have a strong odor and other than feeling slightly greasy, isn't unpleasant when you come in contact.  After about a day, it absorbed into our dog's fur and didn't even show where it had been applied.If you're in a flea environment, this product worked well for us is keeping fleas outdoors instead of on our dogs, was easy to apply and reasonable priced.  A win overall.

Our 3 year old loves trains.  He discovered Thomas shortly after turning two and got his first train set at 28 months. Ever since, he can spend hours playing with his "choo choos" and loves to set up elaborate tracks and push them around all day. He saw this set, stopped what he was doing and spent the next 2 hours playing with it non-stop.  He spent the next two days carrying the "ship" with him everywhere he went, so from that perspective, there is no question that this item is a hit.While we have purchased a number of the Thomas series wooden trains, most of his tracks are Melissa & Doug Deluxe Wooden Railway Set or 100 Pieces of Bulk Wooden Train Track. Compatible with All Major Brands Including Thomas the Tank Engine.  This is largely due to my refusing to pay for the larger Thomas kits, which are significantly more expensive.  However, this was a nice set to supplement the others and to give his train building a bit more of a Sodor feel.The set itself contains a limited number of track pieces and cannot make many configurations beyond that shown on the box.  Instructions for that configuration are included and when set up, it nicely creates a small figure-eight with the ship, a tunnel and a small vender.  The pieces also fit interchangeably with our other sets (except that the Thomas tracks are too wide for ourWooden Train Expansion Pieces Raised Track Support ( 6 pack) so you can mix this in with a less expensive set of tracks quite easily to expand the fun.  The tracks are high quality, with some nice detailing and fit together well.  Some of the tracks have road designs on the bottom, so if you have toy trucks they would also be useful.  However, this set includes only a special "celebrations" Thomas (who looks like normal Thomas, but with what appear to be fireworks on the side) and a follow car for Thomas.  The ship is a fun addition with a few little flags that pop up from the smoke stack if you push a button and once you figure it out the tunnel is cool.Overall, if you have a train lover in your house and particularly a Thomas fan, it's pretty sure this set will delight.  It clearly has a target audience and at least in my house, it really hits the mark.  Parents, however, will have to ask if the price is right.

We're Melissa & Doug fans and were looking for something for our son who just turned 8 months and can sit up on his own and crawl. It's rated for babies 9 months and up, but I actually think it would be better for younger babies.The item itself is adorable. It's soft, brightly colored and well made. The "wheels" sit on the ground and are attached. The "dashboard" required 3 AA batteries (not included), which allow the three "lights" to activate and music to play. This particularly happens if the key is put in the ignition and turned. The steering wheel rotates all the way and the dashboard attaches to the front with some strong Velcro. I found the buttons a bit hard to activate, but it still worked well and our son lived the side "mirror" and smiled every time he looked at it. There is an open area under the front so baby's legs can just stick right out and it even allows older children (like jealous big brothers) to be able to get into the chair for as long as their entertained. There's a little mesh pouch on the rear and even a cup holder for baby's bottle.The downside is that since our baby is already moving, he didn't want to stay seated in the chair, even with the lights, music and other attractions. Which is why I recommend the toy for a baby younger than the noted 9 months. If we'd had this for our son when he was 4-7 months, it would have been perfect. However, he likes it for the first couple minutes, then arches himself of the back and since the car is several inches tall, attempts to bonk his head on the floor. Also, given the size, I think this item might be hard to wash as it definitely won't fit in a washing machine.However, our household cat decided that this is the greatest thing we've ever owned.

I have to say- the Fisher-Price Comfort Curve Bouncer may be the first Fisher-Price accessory that has disappointed me.  We have had some our children have not particularly cared for but I was always happy with the functionality, design, and the fact that they were sturdy enough to be used, thrown in a closet and then brought back out for our second child.  We got this product as we have already had a metal frame bouncer so wanted to try this model to see if the added mobility was worth it.  I have to say- so far the answer is no.The first thing you notice is that it is more difficult to assemble then other Fisher-Price products- not necessarily hard, but just more cumbersome.  Many of their products don’t require tools at all but you need a screwdriver for this one.  Again- the setup is not difficult but compared to their other products, it is more effort.  Once the chair is set up, it consists of fairly flimsy plastic around a light wire frame for the base.  I understand that the plastic has to be flexible in order for the seat to bounce, but it just seems really thin and not at all sturdy.  The chair is rated up to 25 pounds but our son is about 18 pounds and I am already a bit uncomfortable with him in the seat.  There is a noticeable bend when he is placed in it that you don’t get with the typical metal framed bouncers.  I guess the bottom line is, although light and portable, this chair does not feel sturdy and I don’t think it will last a particularly long time.  The seat has a vibrating mechanism but it is only one speed and the motor is a bit loud.  Also, unlike other Fisher-Price bouncers, there is no music.  In fact, for baby’s entertainment there are just two danglies that hook on to the play bar.  The play bar itself is just a strip of plastic- not rigid at all- that clips into the sides of the chair.  In addition, and I realize this is a matter of taste- I don’t find the design particularly attractive.  The seat cover is covered with colorful little spheroids that resemble the old AT&T logo.  I understand some may be tired of the usual Fisher Price motif of bright colorful animals but this design looks like something straight out of the 70’s.There are some positives to this product.  As I mentioned- it is extremely light and portable.  If you need mobility, it will definitely give you that over a normal bouncing chair.  In addition, in contrast to the rest of the chair which seems pretty flimsy, the danglies may be best I have ever seen.  There is a little deer and raccoon figure with a little rattle attached to them that are colorful and well made.  Even if we give away the chair- we are so keeping the danglies.  I guess the last positive- and the reason this chair is not rated lower is that our child does enjoy sitting in it.  I won’t say he likes it better than other bouncers but about the same and in the end, I guess that counts for something.

The Fisher-Price Woodlands Friends Space Saver Jumperoo is basically a scaled down, portable version of their Jumparoo series.  We have a Rainforest Jumparoo and are on our second son with it and they both just love it.  We got the space saver model as we are doing a bit of traveling and thought it would be handy to have somewhere fun to plop the 7 month old while we chase the 3 year old.  In that respect, it does the trick- it is fairly lightweight, folds up easily and is portable, which if you are familiar with the full-size Jumparoo models, know is just not an option with them.The product itself has the standard Fisher Price motif of colorful animals and bright patterns.  This model has squirrels and frogs.  One other positive is all the colors are gender neutral so there is no "boy" or "girl" model, so it is good for all children!  As with most Fisher-Price products, we find the Space Saver Jumparoo to be of high quality that should last and allow you to use the product until your baby outgrows it and even for future children.  It is sturdy plastic with plenty of support and balance and is easy to set up as everything just snaps into place.  As with other Fisher-Price bouncers, it is adjustable, has several dangly things meant to catch baby's attention, and noises and lights that play when he is jumping.Having said that, we do prefer the full size model.  This Jumparoo is fine but we feel the bigger version gives him more movement- the chair swivels in a complete 360 to allow baby to follow things that are going on in the room. The full size model also has three posts with the elastic material attached whereas this model only has one.  You can just tell, this model is a bit more of an effort to bounce in and he gets tired more easily.  Of course we realize that you have to give something up for the mobility and space savings but if you can only get one and your space permits, we would recommend the full size version over making this your everyday bouncer.  However, if you have the need and the budget for a mobile version- then this is the one you need.

As we move around a lot with our jobs, we wanted to get our older son something to give him a better understanding of the world but that would also keep his attention. The T.S. Shure Map of the World Magnetic Playboard seemed like a good option even if our son is younger then the recommended age 6 and up.  We have other T.S. Shure products and find them fairly well made but not things that will last forever.In this regards, the world map is in line with the company's other products.  It is colorful but the pieces are thin and although will last a while with responsible play, probably won't hold up to heavy play.  The map is also somewhat smaller then what I expected. With 100 pieces, I just expected a bit bigger- the font is hard to read and the artwork, although very good and whimsical is also small.On the plus side, the product does do what we want- it helps us start a conversation with our son about the places we have been and is helping him start to understand the different regions of the world.  The pieces are color coded by continent and for the most part are geographically correct.  There are some quibbles of course (What, no Kosovo??) but as we aren't trying to make a political statement with a child's map, we are not too concerned about it.  Initial reaction to the map has been positive and many of the magnetic countries have migrated to the fridge as well.Overall, we are enjoying the product and yes, it would probably last longer and be more informative in the hands of an older child, but our son does really like it and we would recommend this as an introductory toy to world geography.

We have been using the Fisher Price Sit Me Up Floor Seat for 4 months since our son was about 3-months old and are thrilled with it. It's a great place to put him down so he can see what is going on around him and presents a nice change from the reclining bouncer, as it provides enough support to hold him erect while also providing containment. I also think it helped develop the muscles related to sitting upright as he was able to sit and hold himself up at about 6-months old- much faster than his older brother. In addition- he loves it. He has a better view of the room and just seems more alert and interested in his surroundings when sitting upright.The product itself has the standard Fisher Price motif of colorful animals and bright patterns. This model is a blue frog with a green foot rest but they also sell models with a lion and a monkey. One other positive is all the colors are gender neutral so there is no "boy" or "girl" model, it all depends on what animal you think is cutest. As with most Fisher-Price products, we find the Floor Seat to be of high quality that should last and allow you to use the seat until your baby outgrows it and even for future children. It is sturdy plastic with plenty of support and balance. Although the warning clearly states not to place it on elevated surfaces due to the possibility of baby tipping him or herself over, we have not found that to be a problem. We place it on our (very wide) kitchen island so he can watch as we feed his older brother and it is quite sturdy. The seat portion is deep with fabric that connects to a high ring around his chest that does not allow him to escape or to lurch about too much. There are two detachable toys, but he does not play too much with them as he prefers that most wonderful of all toys- a spoon. The seat also folds up for travel if you want to take it with you.  We have not done so but it is light enough that I don’t think it would be very burdensome.We find the product superior to the similar product we had, the Galt Playnest and Gym - Farm. The Fisher-Price assembly was simple and it takes up significantly less space. Although the Galt allowed baby a greater range of motion, the Sit Me Up allows baby to sit near you and observe, while still including some (limited) built in toys for entertainment. Comparatively, this is also about 30% less expensive. It also helps provide some protection from his rampaging older brother as the later can't try to lift the baby from this as he does with the bouncers we have. If you're looking for an alternative to the traditional bouncy chair, we can highly recommend this item. Once the baby can hold his head erect, he can enjoy this chair until he outgrows it, which we estimate should be at about one year for us as at 18 pounds, it is already getting a bit tight to get him in and out. I really like it and wish we'd had one for our first child.

We have been using the Fisher Price Sit Me Up Floor Seat for 4 months since our son was about 3-months old and find it indispensable.  It's a great place to put him down so he can see what is going on around him and presents a nice change from the reclining bouncer, as it provides enough support to hold him erect while also providing containment.  I really think it helped develop the muscles related to sitting upright as he was able to sit and hold himself up at about 6-months old- much faster than his older brother.  In addition- he loves it.  He has a better view of the room and just seems more alert and interested in his surroundings when sitting upright.The product itself has the standard Fisher Price motif of colorful animals and bright patterns.  This model is a yellow lion with a green foot rest but they also sell models with a frog and a monkey.  One other positive is all the colors are gender neutral so there is no "boy" or "girl" model, it all depends on what animal you think is cutest.  As with most Fisher-Price products, we find the Floor Seat to be of high quality that should last and allow you to use the seat until your baby outgrows it and even for future children.  It is sturdy plastic with plenty of support and balance.  Although the warning clearly states not to place it on elevated surfaces due to the possibility of baby tipping him or herself over, we have not found that to be a problem.  We place it on our (very wide) kitchen island so he can watch as we feed his older brother and it is quite sturdy.  The seat portion is deep with fabric that connects to a high ring around his chest that does not allow him to escape or to lurch about too much.  The foot rest has tiny squeakers that baby can push on but our son does not really activate those- maybe when he is a bit bigger.  There are two detachable toys, one a lion rattle and the other some colorful circles that our son likes to suck on while teething.  This model also comes with a detachable tray.  We thought that would end up being more handy then it is as our son is still too young to have snacks and will probably outgrow the seat before he is on cheerios or other similar items.  Basically the trey can help to catch whatever toy he is playing with but not much else as far as we can see.We find the product superior to the similar product we had, the Galt Playnest and Gym - Farm.  The Fisher-Price assembly was simple and it takes up significantly less space.  Although the Galt allowed baby a greater range of motion, the Sit Me Up allows baby to sit near you and observe, while still including some (limited) built in toys for entertainment.  Comparatively, this is also about 30% less expensive.  It also helps provide some protection from his rampaging older brother as the later can't try to lift the baby from this as he does with the bouncers we have.  If you're looking for an alternative to the traditional bouncy chair, we can highly recommend this item.  Once the baby can hold his head erect, he can enjoy tis chair until he outgrows it, which we estimate should be at about one year for us as at 18 pounds, it is already getting a bit tight to get him in and out.  I really like it and wish we'd had one for our first child.

We have had a Fisher Price Bubble Mower for a few years already so as with any "Lawn Care Device" it was getting a bit old from overuse- the only difference is that our three year old loves his mower while his father, well...not so much. With our younger son just learning to walk and premonitions of sibling arguments in the future, we took the opportunity to upgrade to the latest model.For starters, the new model is very similar to the older ones. The big difference is the older one had a movable throttle which this one does not have, but this one has a transparent top and you can see the fan whirling inside. Overall, though, it is the same classic toy and since it is Fisher-price, it is made of high quality, safe plastic. I am confident that any toddler will enjoy pushing this toy around the yard, the house, anywhere really...and then screaming with delight at all the bubbles they are creating. The only catch is that you should invest in a higher quality of bubble liquid then what comes with it if you want to get the most out of this toy. You will have to buy more soon anyway as the machine runs through it pretty quick.Overall, however, I can't say enough about this toy. My older son loves it and the younger son loves looking at the bubbles for now and soon he will be able to push his as well. The only problem is that I am not sure having two of them will be sufficient to stop the inevitable arguments.

We are always looking for ways to stimulate our son’s interest in learning as well as keep him busy, so, although he is three and a little young for the target range of the Summer Bridge Activities Pre-K-K workbook, we got it in hopes that we could work our way up to the activities with him.  In that, we were not disappointed.  There are a number of exercises that we can work with him- some obviously that will need to wait until he is a bit older, but for the most part, everything seems age appropriate and ideally suited for kids in Pre-K or Kindergarten.The book itself is large, nicely printed, and divided into three sections, each with its own exercises and goals.  The pages are perforated so they pull out easily.  The book also plus contains a reading list, flash cards and stickers to use as incentive.  I was happy to see a number of books that we currently read to our son on the reading list.  This can be seen as a negative as maybe the level should be a bit higher, but I assume it’s not just reading the story but talking about them with your child as well.  Section 1 contained the more basic exercises as you might imagine- exercise with numbers, shapes, etc which honestly, is about where our child is right now.  If you do have a kindergarten aged child, this section may be too elementary.  Section 2 also had counting, colors and brought in handwriting.  This is where it started to go beyond us, and Section 3 which phonics and handwriting were for the most part beyond what our son could do himself and needs an adult to guide him through. Overall, we are very happy with the book- some exercises hit home more than others at the moment but there is enough for a few years range from about 3-6 in the book to make it worthwhile.  The best part is that no single exercise is so time consuming that the children will get too bored and it is a great opportunity to interact with your young one and help them enjoy the process of learning.

I loved paper dolls as a kid, but they are not so common these days. The paper dolls that are available tend to be fairly expensive and not particularly high quality - a younger child just isn't capable of not destroying them. These are the perfect compromise, as this set is comparably priced to some paper doll books I've seen.Overall, the set is great, particularly for little ones who like horses.  Most reviews note this is good for girls, however it has also worked well for our almost-three-year-old boy.  Although the main doll is a girl, our son loves horses and enjoyed playing with both characters.  The range of clothes for "Emily" is great - lots of equestrian wear.  However, I think a few more options for the horse other than a saddle would have been good.  The pieces are well made, have lots of detail and the wooden "frame" they come in makes for an easy way to store what could otherwise be lots of annoying pieces. The pieces stick well, but are easy for small hands to manipulate and are durable, so can survive normal pre-schooler play. There's a stand so that "Freckles" can stand up, but it doesn't fit quite perfect.  Also, there's no way to get Emily to be able to sit on Freckles.  That said, those are minor quips and don't impact my son's enjoyment of this set.If you have a child who likes horses, this is a great set, has quality, well made pieces and can offer hours of fun.

We are an expat family and want to ensure that our sons (almost 3 and 7 months) grow up knowing about the United States.  We were delighted with this map, as it is a great tool/toy to help with that goal.The map is colorful, durable and interesting to look at, making it a great addition to the wall in our older son's room.  It has grommets to make attaching to the wall easy and non-destructive to the map.  It includes state capitals and interesting facts about the states, some geographic landmarks, and items commonly associated with each state (a space shuttle for Florida, redwoods for California).  Sometimes the additional information covers up parts of the state's shape, but overall it's a good and sufficiently accurate, particularly for younger children.It also includes removable stickers, with notes to personalize places for children, marking things like where grandparents live, vacations, places they want to visit, etc.  Overall, I think this will be a great tool for us to help our sons become more familiar with our home country.  We also got the Melissa & Doug Wooden USA Map Puzzle, which is a nice compliment to this map if you're trying to use it as a teaching toy about the USA.

I loved paper dolls as a kid, but they are not so common these days.  The paper dolls that are available tend to be fairly expensive and not particularly high quality - a younger child just isn't capable of not destroying them.  These are the perfect compromise, as this set is comparably priced to some paper doll books I've seen.Overall, the set is adorable.  There are two bears and lots of clothes, ranging from jeans to ballet wear, dresses, costumes and accessories.  The pieces are well made, have lots of detail and the wooden "frame" they come in makes for an easy way to store what could otherwise be lots of annoying pieces.  The pieces stick well, but are easy for small hands to manipulate and are durable, so can survive normal pre-schooler play.  We have an almost 3 year old, who really enjoyed playing with the bears.My only suggested improvement relates to this being a product clearly aimed at girls.  With two bears and the amount of clothes, this could have easily divided into one of each gender with clothes for each.  Instead it was 100% female clothes, which limits it somewhat.  A boy could still play with this, but with only minimal changes, it could be a great gender neutral toy, instead of one focused towards little girls.

I started reading the Showalter's Lords of the Underworld series a number of years ago and loved the original books.  However, I have to concur with those who say that her work over time has begun to vary in quality.  Don't get me wrong, this book is fine....but just that, fine.  Perhaps it is the spinoff world - I don't think the Angels of the Dark series has the same "spark" that the LOTU does.  Perhaps its that the characters seem to now be caricatures of  those from the earlier books.  Gwen's inner strength and spunkiness, once it broke through her timidity in The Darkest Whisper was well written character development, versus the forced feeling I had about Elin.  Perhaps it's the sitcom-esque forced cast of secondary characters that now must exist in any given book, but all these contributed to this book just not having the same quality of Showalter's earlier ones.I will also say, I feel like Showalter was trying to get on board with the Fifty Shades of Grey bandwagon with the whole sex issues for Thane.  She got through the Darkest Pleasure, about the demon of pain, without having a hero who liked sexually abusing women, so I'm not sure why she needed to go there in a book in which that storyline really added nothing.  Which goes back to me saying Thane was fine.  I'll admit I really liked the recent Darkest Touch.  However I had a hard time getting through this one, and normally I'll devour these type of books.  This wasn't a terrible book.  But it didn't show the high caliber story this author is capable of.

Ahh duct tape- the handyman’s (and not so handyman’s) band-aid. If something springs a leak, needs a patch, whatever, just slap a couple of pieces over it and press on. Every house should have a roll around just in case and since we were deficient in that, when the opportunity came to get the Iron Grip Black Heavy-Duty Duct Tape, we jumped at it.As far as the product, this is excellent tape- it’s tough, its sticky and it’s a huge roll so you won’t run out anytime soon. You can tear it if you apply enough pressure but it’s easier to cut it off- and don’t forget to dog ear the edge so you can start the unrolling easier the next time. The few times we have used it so far, to fix a few things that have been lingering, it has worked just fine and gotten the job done.So why the three stars then? Well- quite frankly- this may be more tape then the average (and below average) do-it-yourselfer needs. I don’t find it such an improvement over 3M and Scotch brands for basic jobs that it justifies the premium you pay for it. It also is extremely sticky sitting the drawer so if you don’t use it on a regular basis, it creates a bit of a mess, leaving sticky residue on whatever it is resting on. It also has an odor, which while not strong, is noticeable.Just to close- you can’t go wrong with the Iron Grip as it is serious duct tape and will accomplish any task duct tape possibly can but there are cheaper alternatives that will probably do just as well

As the owners- human servants might be a more apt description- of two 50 pound former street dogs, let me just say cows ears are a lifesaver.  Not much slows down our dogs but at least a nice big cows ear gives them pause for 10 minutes or so as they devour them.  Yes- I know these are all day treats for smaller dogs, but well, as I mentioned- former street dogs.  We have tried a number of different brands, not so much as we really liked or disliked any particular brand, but living overseas, we have had some issues with shipping, as well as often we would look for the product on sale as they can get a tad expensive if your dogs get one or two every day as ours do.In that vein, we are quite satisfied with the Red Ear Brand.  They are comparable in cost to other major brands, they sell through Amazon so we did not have an issue sending them to an APO address, they arrived promptly and they are much the same quality as other brands.  I noticed that the ones we have received so far are smaller than some other brands- particularly the HDP Jumbos, but not so much so that we consider them to be a bad bargain.  The only minor complaint we have is that they do not seem quite as clean as others we have received.  These still had some black, crusty matter on the inside of the ears- not that the dogs seem to mind in the least, but you do notice it.  On the plus side, they do not leave any odor- sometimes we have noticed a faint odor from boxes or bags of ears but these don’t have one, nor do we find any trace of one after the dogs have eaten them.Overall, we like this product and if your dogs like cows ears, they will probably like this product as well.  Although we don’t have any particular brand loyalty to Red Barn, we will probably end up ordering this product again based on price and shipping.

As we are on our second child and numerous pets, which currently include two dogs and a cat, we have had and still own a multitude of baby gates but the Munchkin Auto-Close Designer Safety Gate, Dark Wood is by far the swankiest we have ever had.The first thing you notice about this product when it arrives is that it is heavy.  The middle frame is solid wood and the ends where the anchoring rods attach and sit is a pretty heavy metal as well.  In addition to its weight, the wood is a rich, dark shade that looks very attractive set off against the white of the rest of the gate.  Once you get it out of the box, it is relatively easy to set up.  The anchoring rods screw out until they are firmly wedged against the door frame and you tighten to hold the gate in place.  The frame fits regular sized doorways and passageways but also has extension sections should yours be wider than normal.  Once placed properly with sufficient tension, the gate is secure and I don’t really worry that it will fall out or a child or pet can knock it over.The gate itself is easy to operate- it has a button on top that you depress to open and the gate can be swung open either way and then will lock automatically as it swings back through the middle position.  If there is a flaw with the gate, this is it as there is not a locking mechanism to prevent a child from depressing the button and opening it him or herself depending on their dexterity.  This is a minor quibble though on what is overall an excellent safety gate.So- an excellent, durable product that even adds a touch of style with its dark wood slats?  What’s not to like- well, I guess what you have to ask yourself is do you really need and/or want an $80 baby gate.  We have Carlson Pet Gates which are all metal and work on the same principle with the screw anchors and even has a locking latch and a small kitty door built in that costs $38.  We also have the Safety First Easy-Fit Security Gate that cost $25- although in all fairness, those are somewhat of a pain to use with the sliding plastic panels and locking arm.  Even the Munchkin Easy Close All Metal Gate, which at $42 is half the price.  Basically, you are paying double for the looks and style. As I am somewhat utilitarian, I can see splurging for one, but will probably stick with the cheaper options for corralling my pets and kids for the most part.

I feel I have to start this review with a disclaimer- I know the first thing anyone should want to know about headphones, especially a $200 set is how they sound, followed by comfort, style, etc but I have to admit, I have a tin ear so let me start by saying the House of Marley EM-FH041-MI Liberate Bluetooth Wireless Headphones sounded just fine to me.  I know some of the other reviews go into sound quality at different ranges but I really just needed a pair of headsets I could wear on flights as well as watch TV and listen to music at home once the kids are in bed so I don’t wake them up.  The Liberate work great for that, the sound is clear and I don’t notice much if any drop off of clarity using Bluetooth vs the cable.So with that out of the way, let’s turn to comfort.  The earphones are round and on the smallish side. I find they don’t cover the entire year and the top bar does not constrict quite enough to touch the top of my head.  This means the full weight is on the ears- which is not uncomfortable per se but you do have to readjust them every so often as the weight will get to you after a bit.  I don’t find this too burdensome but my husband does- he used a Dave Clark Aviation headset when he was in the military which has an oval, elongated earphone which covers the whole year so he says he can’t get used to these.  Frankly- they are light years ahead of earbuds!As for style, the Liberate is hard to beat.  The set is well made and looks great.  The wood panel is thin but adds a touch of elegance.  The buttons on the right headset took some getting used to, but blend seamlessly into the design.  I like the envious looks I get when I take them out on a plane.  I also like that they are good to travel with.  They fold up and come with a nice carrying case and the battery lasts a sufficient amount of time- you can use them for the better part of a day without a recharge so that is also handy when traveling.Overall, I am happy with this headset.  I realize they are pricy but they fit what I need them to do- namely travel with and allow me to enjoy shows and music when everyone is asleep with enough sound quality and style to make them enjoyable to own.

As most people with children can tell you, kid’s toys are like water- they expand to fill all available space.  So, when we bought our son the Melissa and Doug Deluxe Train Set, we should not have been surprised that the 130 piece set soon proved insufficient to fulfill his ambition to cover the entire living room floor.  To rectify this, we purchased 100 pieces of bulk wooden train track by Kid’s Destiny.The set advertised that it fits all major brands and although I can’t vouch for others, it is indeed compatible with the Melissa and Doug set.  In fact, we store all the pieces from both sets together in the same storage box and after a few months, I could not tell you the difference between them.  The pieces are well sanded and grooved and the trains, including Thomas accessories, roll just fine over them.The only slight complaint I could make about the set is that it does not contain either male-male or female-female connection, nor does it contain ramped track.  The set, which consists of 25 each of 3.5" curved, 6" curved, 3.5" straight, and 6" straight pieces  will allow you to greatly expand your track but you will need another expansion set if you want to build more bridges and ramped track.  In addition, more male-male and female-female connectors are needed if you expand with more special pieces such as bridges or tunnels so you need to make sure those expansion kits have more of them.Overall, however, this set does exactly what we wanted, which was to provide enough pieces to allow our son to build to his heart’s content- or at least cover the available space we have- at an affordable price.  We recommend this if you too need extra track.

Packed with educational value, this is more of a teaching aid than a toy in itself. As a parent, one can use the full potential of these Picture Boards by actively engaging your kid while making learning alphabets as purely fun.You can teach lower case, capitals, sounds, and also colors with these boards. The Melissa and Doug quality is really superb as always and the make is very sturdy. This will stand the rough handling of a toddler and will make an ideal gift for a 3 yr+ toddler.

Largely, I agree with the ideology of the author (my other opinion being good leaders know who to follow, when need be),This is one of those books that'll stay on your table for some time since a lot of what's written isn't preachy but hard hitting, real truth coming from experience. Having seen some success in the professional world myself, it's a nice breather to hear what echoes well with my own opinions are.The preface sets the tone for rest of the book. And that should give the reader a good idea if the book is meant for them.

Heavenly tasting and in such great packaging, We all enjoyed every piece of it. We got the box when the weather wasn't warm anymore, and didn't' have to worry about them coming melted (like some of the reviewers did). The box was so pretty that it can be gifted as is in the holiday season. The overall packaging was also very good to prevent any damage to the chocolates and can work as a good online gift option.Giving 4 starts since I found them a bit expensive, despite all the great taste and pretty packaging.

Very good quality and extremely easy to use dishcloth.And so good looking (especially the ones with pattern) that guests question if the purpose of the cloth is actually cleaning.We are using them in kitchen for some heavy duty stove and counter cleaning. The dirt wound't stay on the cloth when shrugged off, neither would the water when rinsed. It felt so light as if it has a mind of its own and wants to keep itself squeaky clean (wink).

Lately Speck has been making some high quality cases and is a much preferred brand of choice for our iPhones.This case is no exception and is very solid and sturdy. It is very easy to slide on or take off from the phone and provides an excellent grip. All the ports and buttons are easily accessible with no issues at all.For the current price it does seem to be expensive, however if your handling deserves a solid case while keeping the iPhone design and color visible, this is the one to go for!
Very impressed with the high quality of the cups. And a no straw solution is so helpful in making cleaning easy.My toddler son absolutely loved it, and the colors and the numbers.

The PUR water quality is good and has been in market since a long time. We have used PUR pitchers and like taste of water. This pitcher itself is very compact and handy to keep during travels, especially international where the bottle water quality can be questionable.The filtration time is not too long, however the size of the blue container is a bit small. Ideally it should be near 50% of the whole pitcher. As of now, this pitcher requires many refills everyday. We are using this primarily for outdoor use like during picnic, while on patio etc., where this becomes a nice buffer of filtered water.The LED indicators are nice to have, however not really a must since you would know that the life of the filter is over based on the taste of water and the speed of filtration.  They might come up with a Bluetooth connection in their next version to pop up a notification on your phone when the filter needs to be changed :)!

The Adora doll is ADORABLE. One just cannot miss the possibility of immense fun a kid will have from the delicate looking doll. I as an adult loved it and wished I had this when I was a kid.The various removable limbs and changeable accessories and dresses give a child's creativity and curiosity a nudge (see pictures). I presented this to my toddler niece who was immediately hooked on to it. No wonder, it's her constant companion now.Will it stand the test of time, that needs to be seen. It is indeed made of very good quality fabric and the doll accessories are also not bad at all. She's been extra gentle and careful with dealing with the doll so far and had adult help when "unbuttoning" the limbs.

A good travel buddy, these pouches are very handy especially when on the move with an infant.While I like most of the ingredients, I'm not a fan of the corn bit. This plus all the other fruits make it higher on sugar content. So do not be surprised if the baby is especially active after gobbling down a meal coming from the pouch. What I do to tone down the sugar is mix it with another whole grain based cereal, thus adding some flavor to the baby's food.It's okay for the price, but it hard to find cheaper stuff if one wants to go organic.

The infant cereal has great ingredients. That's beyond any doubt.Anyone aware of what processed rice cereal is actually providing in terms of nutrition will no more willingly offer it to their children. Just like us, rice cereals - especially the fully processed ones that instantly mix in any form of liquid, are not allowed for our kids. The processing pretty much takes away the outer coating that makes the digestive system "work" on the food, hence developing it in turn.This infant cereal comes with all likable ingredients and they're organic, plus it is lower on sugar (3g per serving). What I would have loved to see is were the grains whole or processed? And were the apples pealed or with skin (not as bigger a concern as is the grain).The price is a bit steep too for just 8 servings ($5.75). Hence the 4 stars.

We've used huggies pull ups in sizes 4 and 5 and I'm very pleased with them. Good quality, good absorption of both pee and poop and no rashes.The kiddo finds the Mickey mouse on it appealing too :-). Especially when he wouldn't consider pull ups as read diapers and wouldn't allow us to put him in these.For the pricing, pull ups are way more expensive than regular ones but thats the price one has to pay for moving out of them (potty training).And these are at least 10-20% more expensive than the luv's diapers, which are good quality too, but not as great looking.

This is my first pair of the pod, but fifth swaddle from the same brand.The quality seems very good, although I have not washed it for more than a few times. For the others, it has remained the same over the past few years and it is still good quality soft cotton. Note that the color, size or quality did not change at all after the washes in the few days span.We used them primarily and on a daily basis for the first few weeks o swaddle our infant transitioning into the outer world.Overall pleased with it!

This is my fourth pair of the original swaddle from the same brand.The quality has remained the same over the past few years and it is still good quality soft cotton. Note that the color, size or quality did not change at all after several washes in the one month span.We used them primarily and on a daily basis to swaddle our infant transitioning into the outer world. The velcro is top notch quality and never gave us any problem. A small opening at the back is helpful in checking the diaper status.Overall pleased.

Being a CrossFitter, I use the foam rollers on a very regular basis before and after the workouts (WODs). This one is specifically designed to provide a deep massage for sore tissues and is very effective indeed. It is challenging to use it everyday unless you are a serious athlete. However, when I really need this deep massage, it works best!Being an 18" roller, it is compact, dense, and easy to store or carry. It fits well in my gym bag for the occasional outdoor workouts. Most other rollers are 24" in length and can a bit large to store.It is a bit pricey, however worth it if you plan to use it regular. SPRI roller material is very high dense foam with a solid plastic core, thus ensuring longevity.

Superb Quality, these paper towels are way better than what I was using earlier for household chores.It's claims of "extra scrubbing power" is indeed true. The paper is thicker and slightly stretchier, especially when wet. I have definitely used it atleast once after giving it a rinse under the running water.I like to make the most use of the paper and would have preferred if it came in half sheets instead of full. Well in that case I just tear it into half as I can still make most use of it with minimal wastage.

The one reason we really will go ahead and buy more of this brand in this size is the price for quality. For ($0.21) per piece, it doesn't get much cheaper.These diaper are true fit. We have rarely had any mis-haps with these with a few exceptions here and there. But let's face it, that will always be the case given any diaper. The reasons are pretty simple - Either too big or too small or too full. And these are acceptable reasons.We have used this brand in this size for our first kid and now again for the second one. Huggies vs. Pampers vs. Luvs vs. store brand diaper is an excellent topic for conversation among new parents and there is no one clear winner. However, for Huggies we have been lucky enough to find good deals on prices more frequently than Pampers and maybe that's why we ended up using them more often.The diaper material is very soft and the absorbing properties are good to contain and prevent the "potential decimation" :).

This review is based on the feedback provided by my wife:"Great fabric, and very very comfortable daily wear boyshorts. Also, inexpensive for the price!I've had them only for a few days,so need to see and update the review on how long the cloth runs."

Just like most other reviewers, this is a good supplement. We've used it during my wife's pregnancy and to great effect.Prior to this, she was taking the Solgar Magnesium Citrate which unfortunately is the only good option (and not so pricey) I came across. However, one with no citrate is always welcome for its better absorbency. Recommended for the price! ($14 FOR 240 TABS)

The iPhone 6/6S armband is indeed a great product by Belkin. Having been used several such armbands in pasts, this one is certainly much better on several aspects:- The look and feel of this product is high quality and not really plasticky type.The finish of the case and the plastic in armband is very complimentary to an iPhone.- The band goes all the way around for a comfortable feel.- The fabric on the armband behind the plastic clamp for phone is coated with a rubber base to make it waterproof and protect phone from the potential sweat flooding on your arm after a tough workout :).- The plastic case has a good finish and provide a very good accessibility to the iPhone ports. In some other cases, I had problem accessing these ports since the opening was too tight or close. Not in the Belkin case though.- For someone who is regular with fitness activities, the case can be left on phone all the time. I do not see that an issue and plan to use the plastic case as the main case for the phone. It does add some bulkiness to device and could be an issue if you prefer to use your phone bare-naked!Price is a bit on the higher side, however has a high potential to provide the value in terms of continuous protection and functionality to your phone while supporting fitness activities.

We've used many other brands of diapers - Pampers, Huggies, Luvs, target store brand, CVS. From Pampers, it was the swaddlers and sensitive that we used most during the newborn to size 2 timeframe. We liked swaddlers.We also liked the Huggies Little Snugglers since they also come with indicator line.And here's why -Apart from the high quality, nice smelling diapers, I like the fact that thy have not caused any skin irritation or rashes even when soaking wet. This is extremely important for the baby's health and parent's sanity.The indicator is truly effective and it doesn't just give away a binary answer on what to expect - Diaper is wet or Diaper is dry. It will show a shorter blue line if the diaper is slightly wet. For those with very sensitive skin, this is quite a helpful feature since parents can immediately decide if they want to change the diaper or not.However the only reason this one gets 4 stars is because they're indeed expensive

My wife used it a few times before providing feedback. This is what she had to say -- It left the skin satiny soft for many hours- No sticky feeling at all- The fragrance was mild and subtle- The ingredients didn't' cause any irritation or redness- The price is quite comparable to good products an is in the same range- She will buy this again

With two arches/rods, this gym is twice the fun. We like that fact that our son can play with it on both sides in either orientation and there is something for both hands and feet. We had the Piano gym for first one, which was also and had a different value. For this infant gym, I'd say the mat should be a little bigger. Once they start moving on their stomach, this will be too small to stay and get engaged.Overall, the lifespan of such a gym is not more than 4-6 months and we expect to get the full value in that time frame.This is FP quality with good plastic and rods...doesn;t feel cheap at all. Mat is washable and the toys can be cleaned with baby-safe sprays etc.

Got a wrong product from Amazon Vine and unable to provide a good review. We received a pair of cute girls gloves and a baseball ball instead, while we were expecting a boys batting tee. The gloves are cute, however made for at least 6+ yrs or above...more likely 8-9 yrs old girls.Can't provide a fair review as we were not able to use the product.

Completely useless product. It drains the Nikon battery overnight as the memory card light keeps blinking.I have used the other Meike for a Nikon D7000 over last 4 years with no issues. However, this one for D750 is horribly designed.Save your money and effort in dealing wiht the customer support and returns here.

My wife used this during her first pregnancy and is using it during her second as a body massage oil. Needless to say, she loved it enough to go for it the second time. Her feedback is very positive on this product and uses it on a daily basis. Neither of us found the lightly scented fragrance overbearing or the oil too sticky. Will recommend to anyone.

Excellent product which stands tall on it's 100lbs claims. I have it as an accessory next to my the study table where I needed more room. The teal color is a funky blue shade. The quality of the metal is really good too. I had it hold upto 100lbs of book weight for a week and so far see no signs of the metal bending. The drawer too is great for holding stationary.

Pros:- Excellent quality like most Fisher Price products.- Good for infants under 6 months- Easily RockableCons:- The handle is nightmarish to remove- Disassembling is almost not possible- Taking a slightly grown baby in and out with the handle on can be tricky

Being in upstate NY area, and so close to the Finger Lakes region, we are self-confessed wine lovers and drinkers. I have heard about the the Aerators, seen them, and have friends who vouched for them, but never used one before reviewing this Tanor's product. Oh boy, what a difference does it make. Now it feels like we have wasted all those good wines by letting them sit in the glass for aeration!The Tanors Wine Aerator is small and very easy to use. Once you get used to of using this Decanter, you may never like the wine directly through a glass. Similar to another reviewer, we also tested this Aeration process by drinking same wine with and without and could feel better aromas, longer taste on the palate, and got a better understanding of food pairing now.For the price, this is a very good product and would also make a perfect gift for wine drinkers as well.

A must-have in every kitchen, this handheld blender has become an ideal buddy in several culinary expeditions of mine in our kitchen. Being not a great cook and suddenly becoming responsible to feed myself and my toddler was a big challenge. Thanks to such kitchen tools, whipping eggs, making salad dressings, or making gravy in a Crock-Pot after cooking a whole chicken became very easy.Made of sturdy materials, it stands perfectly stable and is an ideal blender with 2 speeds and a powerful motor.

Great bodywash, good scent..not pungent or overpowering. Smell stays for sometime not long though as you may expect. As a shampoo-conditioner it is good for short hairs only. If you keep your hair long and style the, I'd suggest using other special brands like Mitch or American Crew.

This is one of the ideal protein supplement, if you intend to add some variety to your protein intake especailly during the day time. The caffeine intake helps me to avoid the afternoon sleepiness. I take it usually in afternoon and not as a post-workout supplement after an early morning work out. So, the additional 20gms of protein is certainly helpful to keep the levels high thorughout the day.GNC sent me a handout with a $10 coupon for this product only and that's how I ended up trying it and eventually subscribed it here on Amazon. If you get that coupon, its worth trying.So far, I have only mixed it in unsweetened almond milk and cocnut water, and it mixed very well, thouroughly, and evenly.If you leave it mixed for long time, like a whole day, the sweetness will somehow rise to the top and will become too sweet, even after shaking it well. I don't know whay that happens, however I do not leave it mixed for long now.Overall, another good product from ON, a bit pricey but effective. Since this is eligible for subscribe and save discount, you may get 15% off on a regular basis.

We trust Tom's products and have also used their toothpaste and diaper cream. This sunscreen is no exception in terms of quality and ingredients. After using a few times this summer, noticed that the lotion spreads very easily and leaves a slight pinkish tinge on his skin. However, that neutralizes slowly with time. We have observed avoiding of sunburn and reduction in redness of facial skin with the use of this lotion and hence recommend it.  I'm also glad that the ingredients are all natural and there is nothing to worry me, especially the neutral smell.

It's a cute travel buddy for my toddler who can get restless on longer drives. And we're always concerned for our iPad slipping out of his hand (on purpose or unknowingly). The Tablet cover is cute enough to draw his attention and let him be okay without holding the iPad in his hand.Installation was easy, as expected. The velcro seems to stick tight and the quality looks pretty good too. I'm not sure if it will stand much abuse at the hands of a toddler, but we will see how that goes in the time to come.I also liked that it can stand upright and the child can view it even when we're sitting at a restaurant. So far we were using water glass as a way to keep it in position and trust me it was a dangerous idea every time and would keep us on our toes, in case the glass falls or the ipad is pushed with force.So far I'm very happy with the produce and will recommend it for the price as well.

Amazing product from Thule that can hold the 2 bikes firmly and strongly. Thule quality, build, and durability is well known and worth the price, if you are serious about biking. I also have a Yakima King Joe Pro 3 which is about 60% of the price of this Thule and works well too. However, Thule is built for rugged and off-road handling when you drive your SUV to a rustic outdoor terrain for the fun of extreme biking.It comes with an installation guide, which is very detailed with clear instructions and is easy to follow. There is a vehidle fit guide also included in the packaging which helps to identify the right setting of the dial and adjust the overall span. The Fit Guide is also on thule website, and you can check whether this product fit your car or not prior to making a purchase.When fully folded for storage, it is only about 7" in thickness and thus can be stored in the truck itself while using minimum space. This is big feature, especially for the ultra long winter season in northeast.Excellent product, though pricey, but one gets total worth out of it.

Loved the crib toy and yes, it's big enough to catch the baby's attention. I was quite pleased at how Tiny Love has used both sides for showing day and night. My toddler loved it too and enjoyed playing with it for a bit.Had no problem installing it on the crib and could get this done under 5 minutes. The size and weight is just right for an infant to hold and to play with, when it is not hanging on the crib.I did, however, find it a bit pricy and would rather spend a little extra for the musical crib mobile which is way more engaging for an infant up to 8 /9 months.
An elderly member in the family used this for many months and recommended it for anyone who needs them. Also that they have good absorption and comfortable to wear all day.

Used it indoors for cleaning mold on the wooden cabinets in kitchen surrounding the sink area and it worked pretty well.Depending on the amount of mold, you may need more than one pass of "spray and scrub" and will certainly see some very good results.It also worked well on vinyl and overall the product quality pleased us.

This is an excellent stacking toy. There is much more to enjoy here than just plain simple stacking activity. The own shape is attracts the babies and the sounds are pleasing to the ear. There is a rattle and squishy ears which are good teethers. We found this to be equally exciting for a 2.5 yrs toddler who loved bouncing it around. Overall, its a great value for money and can engage babies for long time.

The jump rope is very sturdy and has some weight to it. Being used to of speed rope in CrossFit, this is a big change for me. Apart from that, the length of this rope is too long. Being a 5'7" person, I had to adjust it a lot before coming to the right length. The rope is thick and you can fold and adjust as much inside the handles. Eventually you might have to cut some rope to adjust to right length. I believe it won't be an issue for taller people.Rope is very good and I am sure that it will go long. One thing to keep in mind is that if you a new learner and tend to get stuck...it will hit you on the back side....either slowly you will get used to it or figure out the movement to get single unders and double unders :).

Within 3 weeks of use, I can feel the difference in my form during the strength exercises in CrossFit WODs especially due to improved footwork. These Nano 2.0s are a perfect companion for any CrossFitter and are truly a must-have. Note that these do not provide any arch support and are designed to keep your feet flat in order to get a flat grip and be able to push the ground across the whole feet. Most other shoes are curved up in the front of the feet and hence you don't get that full push.These do run a bit tight and open up very little with use. So, it's a good idea to pay attention to the Amazon guidelines and the size fit recommendation which shows up while making a purchase here.With the Nano 4.0 cost being a bit prohibitively high, I am glad that my coach advised me to go with 2.0 at a much reasonable cost.

So I was one of the many guys who hated, I mean HATED Justin Bieber since his rise to stardom.  I would get angry at the thought of him even existing.  Suffice it to say, I wasn't a fan.  Then a few things seemed to work in Justins favor for 2015.  First off, he was the subject of a Comedy Central Roast which replayed constantly during the beginning of the year.  The Roast was funny and at the end Justin gave a believable eulogy to his old ways and hopeful possibility of a more respectable future.  That made me really start to think that, if I had his voice and money at his age(we are the same age actually), then I'd probably be as reckless.  But alas, I wasn't going to go buy his early albums still.  Then the next thing happened.  He released the song "Where Are U Now?" in collaboration with Jack U(most notably Skrillex).  It was the perfect summer song with production that was very unique.  Finally, Justin made the Prestige of his comeback with the release of the single "What Do You Mean?" which followed the new vibe in production started by the Skrillex collaboration.  I was actually looking forward to this album.  I wanted to hear a whole album of similar songs and more maturity.  The album didn't disappoint.  And as for that other 'forgettable' boy band One Direction releasing their album the same day, well I listened to it and its more of the same from them and nothing new or notable(They peaked in creativity on Midnight Memories, their only good album, but that's a separate review).  This album is the one to get.  If you hated Justin Bieber, then you might like this like I did.  Its just a nice break up album that isn't just for break ups.  The singing is mature and spot on and the production is crisp and unique.  Here is a track by track review of the album that could reinvent the most hated success story of the 2000s.1.  Mark My Words: The album starts off slow with this song full of crooning.  The instrumental sounds like a loop of Justins distorted humming and it works nicely.  Justin reaches divine high notes and showcases how much of a good singer he really is.  Toward the end of the song the production by Blood catches up with the emotion in his voice as it comes to a close.  I just wish it was maybe at least 30 seconds longer.  This is a great introduction of the more adult style this album is full of.  9/102.  I'll Show You: Another Skrillex produced song and it shows.  The production is really becoming his new trademark thankfully instead of that awful dubstep that he used to make.  Blood also helped with this song too as they create a common flow to continue the album.  If you like "Where Are U Now" then you'll like this.  Very emotional and classy.  But lets not forget the main man himself with his sensual vocals.  This is destined for the club.  Also don't forget to make love with this in the background.  Thats something I'd never say I would do Justins previous music that was meant for the tweens.  This is pure adult love making music at its best.  9.5/103.  What Do You Mean?: The mega hit comeback lead single.  Yes we all know the lyrics are simple and not very impressive, but the vocal delivery is top notch.  Great sing along song with a nice tropical dance pop production that just gets the body moving, even if you can't dance.  There's no surprise why it was JBs first number one song in the US.  Very infectious. 9.5/104.  Sorry: The second Skrillex produced single.  The buildup to the chorus is so great it makes my heartbeat skip.  Speaking of the chorus, talk about catchy.  This is the type of infectious song that many will love to hate.  You will have it stuck in your head.  It's one of those singing in the shower songs.  Also a great song to play when you're trying to win back your lover in a fun way.  Get ready to groove on the dance floor to this too.  10/105.  Love Yourself: This is a nice acoustic guitar driven ballad with some of the more mature and modern lyricism.  Though this isn't a dance song like most of the album, it still keeps the same vibe as the other songs.  There is also a nice surprising trumpet solo that gives it more class.  This ones a great tune but not a huge highlight aside from the solo.  Others might like it more than I do.  8.5/106.  Company: The dance aspect of the album returns with this song.  The production is in the same style as the Skrillex produced songs and I might even go on to say it's slightly better.  The bass is very groovy.  I would choose this as a single.  The lyrics are simple like the lead single but gosh does it get stuck in your head.  Mature dance pop.  9.5/107.  No Pressure Feat. Big Sean: This is an R&B pop gem with acoustic guitars similar to early NeYo songs production values.  Of course the chorus is catchy, but it isn't one of Justins more impressive vocal performances.  Still great though.  I thought Big Sean would ruin the song as he isn't one of my favorite rappers.  In fact, I never liked Big Sean.  But he provided a decent guest rap verse.  Still he didn't really add to the song.  Justin really does make sure you know its his song with the catchy chorus though.  The song really does grow on you.  9/108.  No Sense: At first I hated this song.  I felt it didn't even fit right with the rest of the album.  But that soon changed.  The production is very trap like.  Travis Scott gave a better rap guest vocal than BS.  This is in the same league as Justin Timberlakes collaboration songs.  This is one of my guilty pleasure songs from the album.  Another modern love making song that Justins previous tween fans wouldn't have fully appreciated.  Just shows his growth again.  9.5/109.  The Feeling Feat. Halsey: The songs picks up speed again with this urgent dance pop track.  I never liked Halsey, but she really shines in the emotionally charged mega infectious chorus.  I think its one of the best choruses in pop music I've heard in a while even though its so simplistic.  Skrillex is lurking in the production again with his experimental dance beat antics.  I can see this as another hit single.  One of my favorites from the album.  10/1010.  Life Is Worth Living: Things slow down and quiet down again for this uplifting ballad.  This one really showcases Justins songwriting and puts his vocals upfront once again, but don't get me wrong there are some nice little treats in the production.  During the Comedy Central Roast for Bieber one of the comedians jokingly compared Justins voice with Stevie Wonder.  This is makes that comparison seem more true.  But don't think I'm saying they sound the same.  I can already see some people scoffing at that, but it's just a compliment for the vocals on this track.  Very feelgood relaxing ballad.  9.5/1011.  Where Are U Now? Feat. Skrillex and Diplo: The song that really paved the way for Justins comeback in 2015.  I'm glad this Jack U hit track was included on this album even though it's not fully a Bieber song.  The real star of this song was always the production.  Justin gives an amazing comeback performance, but we all know that screeching violin/flute sound during the chorus is one of the most emotional heart wrenching piece of music production ever created.  It was the highlight of Jack Us album, and it's still one of the big highlights of this album.  It never gets old.  I could listen to this song for hours.  If you haven't already, add this to your workout playlist.  10/1012.  Children: The final Skrillex produced song.  This is the most EDM styled song but at the same time it keeps to the consistent vibe of the rest of the album Skrillex seemed to have influenced the others to take as well.  Lyrically this is something the younger Bono of U2 would be singing about.  Its nice to see Bieber having faith in the children of the future, because I don't.  But I still love this song to death.  Its also a good workout song. 10/1013.  Purpose: The album closes with another ballad.  This time its a nice quite piano tune.  Its a very powerful love song.  The ending of the song has Justin speaking some words of wisdom.  At first I felt the words of truth but after multiple listens I found myself skipping to the next track on shuffle after the singing part stops.  The ending part is one of the few attempts at maturity from Bieber that I think didn't work.  I know it sounds bad when I put it like that, but I still think its a great song.  9/10So I can't believe I actually like, let alone purchased a Justin Bieber album.  This could be Justins first step into Justin Timberlake territory.  Hopefully if his friendship with Skrillex stays strong they can work together from now on.  I'd love to hear a JB album with production handled entirely by Skrillex the way Timberlakes albums are handled by Timbaland.  This shows many examples of Bieber maturing and growing, but he's still in the fixing stage.  The songs are all good to great.  There are no duds.  No filler for me.  This isn't the same JB that I grew to hate since his inception on the music scene.  Everyone was rooting against Justin during his years of recklessness.  Many were certain that Bieber would go the way of many forgotten child stars.  He proved them and me wrong.  He came back bigger than ever and this album proves he is a force to be reckoned with in this ever changing music industry.  I really enjoyed this album.  If you hated Justin Bieber like most did, don't be afraid to give this album a chance.  You just might change your mind.  I'm a hypocrite for loving this album so much after all the negativity I had for him prior to this.  I hope this review wasn't 'too late for me to say sorry', because this album is going to be on replay for a long time.

I'll admit that like most, I discovered this band from their their mega hit single "Sweater Weather".  It was such a winter-esque pop delight in the best way.  One of the best songs of 2012.  I also began to wonder whether the band would continue on the upward spiral or become a one hit wonder.  When I listened to their debut album "I Love You" I can honestly say I wasn't a fan.  (Don't discount my review just yet).  I agree that their debut album had some good catchy songs, but in all honesty it was just forgettable.  It wasn't a surprise that their next singles didn't have even half of the impact as Sweater Weather.  The album didn't sell well and other than "Afraid" no other singles really went anywhere for the band.  So in 2015 when I heard of the band releasing a new album I was on the fence.  The lead single "R.I.P. 2 My Youth" didn't impress me on my first few listens.  I'll get back to that song later in the review.  The song didn't hype up the albums release really.  In reality most people had no clue the album was even dropping on its release day.  I actually didn't even plan on listening to the album until a good friend of mine brought it up the night it came out and told me it was good.  I trust his opinion most of the time so I checked it out online and liked it enough on my first listen to buy it the next day.  If the first part of my review seemed negative I want you to know it gets better and better now that I've listened to this album a few more times.  I liked this album, a lot.  Here is my track by track review of what I think is one of the most surprisingly great albums destined to be underrated this year.1.  A Moment Of Silence: This is my only beef with the album.  I'm sure there is a deep meaning to this, but I lost interest in it quick.  Honestly just a waste of a track of silence.  Call me disrespectful to the bands intentions, I think this track added nothing to the album.  (no rating)2.  Prey: This is where the music really begins.  And boy does it kick off perfectly.  I love the aching vibe in the vocals.  There is already obviously a lot more soul in this albums singing compared to their first.  The chorus tops things off to make this hopefully another big single for the band and possibly a career saver(more on that in a bit).  A great beachy beginning to the album.  10/103.  Cry Baby: This might be their most pop infested song so far.  It grooves by.  The vocals are in the vein of MJ stylistically and I love it.  The instrumentation is spot on.  There is even a hauntingly beautiful guitar solo.  It's almost like the bands take on "I Can't Go For That" by Hall and Oates.  The vibes of the two songs come from the same musical universe.  I am rooting for this song to be a single.  In fact I think this would've been the better choice for the lead single.  Maybe my favorite song from the band so far.  11/104.  Wiped Out!: The epic title track.  Not as catchy as the first two songs but still wonderfully crafted.  There is even a bridge section similar to that of Sweater Weather.  There are some vocal effects that might turn off some listeners but I think they are used masterfully and add a lot to the emotional effect of the song.
