Halfway through the song their is a second bridge that picks up the paste of the song into sonic speed almost as it leads to the final act of the track.  The songs ends sounding like a completely different song it began as and its just great.  Some uptight listeners might call the antics of this song 'pretentious', but I call it great musicianship and art pop I can listen to on repeat.  10/105.  The Beach: Honestly, this should've been the title track.  The album being titled The Beach would work so perfectly with the artwork.  But the vibe of this song is just unheard of.  Another single worthy song to save the band.  The notes the vocals reach during the chorus are achingly beautiful.  This is similar in sound to a recent genre called PBR&B, but I'd personally describe this as Gothic R&B Alternative Rock.  10/106.  Daddy Issues: The title isn't appealing, but gosh the music is.  This is a perfect low key dance song.  The lyrics are sweet and great to listen to with a lover.  It's ominous in a positive way.  Not as great as the others, but still really really good.  9/107.  Baby Came Home 2/ Valentines: Another soothing epic.  The layers upon layers of musical bliss in this song is very cinematic and emotional.  The vocals even contain some nice falsetto.  The different musical cues throughout the song are clever too.  But there is an unneeded section in the middle of silence that really added nothing to the song.  The last 2 minutes were interesting upon my first few listens but I started skipping to the next song before the end soon.  But the rest of the song is still amazing.  9.5/108.  Greetings From California: There is a somewhat apocalyptic sadness present in this song in my opinion.  I'd compare it's style to the band Glass Animals which is a compliment.  Very tropical jungle-esque.  Nice musicianship as with the rest.  9.5/109.  Ferrari: The title made me think this was going to be a mindless party song that would kill the vibe of the rest of the album.  I was wrong.  There is a slight industrial vibe throughout the song as if Trent Reznor tried to do some indie alternative music.  Its a groovy industrial dance pop song.  Very somber surprisingly.  9.5/1010.  Single: This song sits next to Cry Baby as one of their most pop infested songs.  The lyrics are sad but the music is mostly positive which makes it even more beautiful.  It starts off soft before blowing up into a feast for the musical heartbeat in the middle before ending the way it began.  I love this song.  It has more of that slight R&B influence too.  Nice.  10/1011.  R.I.P. 2 My Youth: The lead single.  Now I somewhat disapproved of this song when it first came out leading to the albums release.  But dare I say this song has grown onto me so much it's almost scary.  I just can't get it out of my head.  This is the true definition of a song that gets better and better.  I didn't really like it at first but now I can't get enough of it.  But that doesn't change the fact that leading to this albums release this single went nowhere.  Maybe it'll become a huge hit.  Maybe not.  If the other songs released as singles don't do anything for the band then this could be the single that killed their career.  Again, I love it to death now.  I personally hope this turns into a sleeper hit like Sweater Weather or at least enough of a hit that it leaves room for other singles to burst onto the scene bigger.  We'll just have to wait and see.  (Maybe future readers will wonder what I was talking about because it became a huge hit)  Still a great closer to the album.  Some critics have criticized the move of putting this at the end.  I think it ended the album perfectly.  10/10So this album was a vast improvement on their mediocre debut album.  I know many of you really loved that first album, but I can confidently say this one is much better and more respectable.  It's also surprisingly very mature.  The style of the album is very different than what was heard from the band before.  But before anyone starts complaining too soon with remarks like "They changed their sound too much!  This isn't The Neighbourhood", how can anyone be so sure of what this bands sound really is so early in their career.  Honestly I'd love for them to abandon most of the style heard on their first album.  They didn't just experiment on this album.  They changed for the better.  This isn't a rock album.  It's not even an alternative rock album fully.  I would compare the style of this album to the R&B influenced 'AM' by Arctic Monkeys.  The American version of that albums vibe if you will.  I'll say its Gothic R&B Alternative Art Pop.  Critics have been kinder to this album than their first, but not kind enough in my opinion.  A lot of the critic reviews for this that I've read seemed lazy and as if they didn't really listen to this masterpiece of modern music.  Yes, this is a masterpiece.  As I've stated before, if the singles don't pick up momentum then this will be labeled as a commercial sophomore slump and it might be impossible for the band to recover, which would be a shame since this album is pure musical art and pleasure.  I want more people to hear this album.  It's the perfect combination of a winter/summer album.  Of course many people who are going through bad break ups or other losses will find solace in this album but this album is great for music lovers regardless.  It has been on repeat for the past few days and I cant get enough of it.  We could have The Neighbourhoods 'Pinkerton' on our hands.  And no I'm not comparing them because they sound nothing alike.  I'm saying this could be a album that was received poorly upon its initial release before becoming regarded as a classic in the future.  But its already a classic to me.  I don't know what else to say.  This is a step in the right direction for the band and I loved it.  It's in my all time top 10 favorite albums already and I don't say that lightly.  Worth more than a purchase.  I'd love to see this album played live.  Okay I think this is the longest review I've typed on here.  Let me get back to enjoying the vibrations.  R.I.P. 2 My fingers.

I cant believe I only now discovered this amazing musical wizard.  It was a chance encounter.  I was just looking at a website for new music and saw that this album was getting the best reviews out of all others released during the same week.  I had no idea who Destroyer was.  So being intrigued I did a quick search for the singles of the album.  It was love at first listen for songs like 'Dream Lover' and 'Time Square'.  The classy and sophisticated sound of the songs just swept me away.  So I looked more into this guy finding out he's been around since the early 90s which just made my mind boggle.  I read that his albums all had a different sound yet were all distinct to him and that was so true when I listened to his earlier albums like the amazing 'Kaputt' and 'Trouble In Dreams'.  But we were here to talk about this perfect album.  I was strongly disappointed but not surprised to find out that no store in my city carried that album.  So as I type this review I have to admit I don't own the album YET.  But that doesn't mean I haven't had it on replay on Spotify for over a week now.  I'm waiting for any store to carry it or maybe eventually order it on here.  I will have it in my grasp.  So anyways I saw that there have been no reviews for this album on this site yet which is a shame.  So here is my track by track review of one of the greatest things to ever grace my ears.1.  Time Square, Poison Season I: The album starts with a slow and soothing version of a later track.  A great and smooth introduction with nice quiet orchestral moments accompanying the soft vocals.  A nice greeting from the album.  9.5/102.  Dream Lover: The first song I heard from the album upon discovery.  The upbeat style is similar to Arcade Fires early work but is also very original and catchy.  The saxophone during the chorus is so painfully addictive.  One of the few really upbeat songs but still very very good.  The song gives me a feeling of constant happiness yet it also has some tragic beauty to it.  9.5/103.  Forces From Above: Violins lead the song with a nice bass and rattling/jungle drums.  The vocals are calm and mysterious. I love the way this one builds up and basically jams.  Around 2 minutes in things get more urgent sounding for the chorus.  It's a very exotic song.  Like something that would play in a action movie as the characters enter a nice foreign city.  When the saxophone comes in you know things come together perfectly before ending smoothly.  10/104.  Hell Is an Open Door: Another song that is drenched in perfect orchestral soundscapes.  The violin riff combined with the emotional saxophone always tug at my heartstrings.  A very fancy song literally.  The lyrics are clever.  The part that mentions the angels in the song is followed by a perfect fluttering sound.  Its those little moments.  A perfect song with great meaning.  One of my favorites.  10/105.  The River: Another relaxing song.  The piano stars with smooth singing before the sax come in to help you take in whatever view you have while listening to this one.  Very atmospheric.  I always imagine sitting at a coffee shop along the beach or a nice river during the sunset.  It's just a very soothing song.  The way the piano ends the song repeating the saxophone riff always tops things off perfectly.  Another favorite.  10/106.  Girl In a Sling: Another slow and soft emotional song.  The instrumentation on this is divine.  For me its a perfect song for 'understanding' someones hardships in life.  It could make you cry when played during the right emotional moment.  10/107.  Time Square: This is the new theme song for Time Square.  Or it should be.  The lyrics are basically the same as the opening song but more upbeat and with a traditional pop sound.  I hope someone uses this in a movie or commercial because it has such a classy and cinematic feel to it.  The guitars and sax compliment each other so well.  It just fits the New York style perfectly.  10/108.  Archer on the Beach: Such a groovy and mysteriously seductive bass guides the song.  The lyrics are so obscure and great as they paint pictures in your mind.  Another jamming track with classy jazz influences.  10/109.  Midnight Meet the Rain: This one has a 70s yet modern feel to it.  Its like a soundtrack to a detective drama that could play during a old school crime solving montage.  Not among the best on the album though.  8.5/1010.  Solaces Bride: This song marks the beginning of the perfect combination of tracks to end the album.  Everything about this song is perfect.  The lyrics contain more tragic beauty.  The guitar is sad and romantic.  A bit after the 1 minute mark a soothing orchestrated part takes place that is probably the most beautiful piece of music I've heard ever.  This is candy for the ears.  Pure and simple.  Among my top 10 favorite tracks ever.  Seriously.  11/1011.  Bangkok: Another perfect and epic relaxation song.  It just amazes me how someone could come up with such lush sounds as this.  It's a great love letter to a city.  The song is about Bangkok but the style has pure classy sophisticated New York written all over it.  Near the 3 minute mark when the pianos get faster with sexy Saxophone in the back you'll know what I mean.  Always seems to calm me down nicely.  11/1012.  Sun in the Sky: This one musically sounds like a companion to 'The River'.  The guitar and sax just make my heart feel like its tied to a kite.  I always get a music high when listening to this album by the time I get to this song  I'm nearly at a loss for words.  Just know it's pure magic.  11/1013.  Time Square, Poison Season II: A final take on the Time Square track as a closer.  It starts slow but ends very smoothly.  It's a beautiful goodbye from the album.  9.5/10So its been two weeks since the albums release when I type this review and I'm so far the only one?  Hopefully this changes quick.  It would be a criminal injustice for this album to not be heard by as many people as possible.  It's one of those albums that makes me think I'm lucky to have been alive when it came out.  It is a wonder how this guy isn't a bigger name in the music industry.  And no I'm not trying to be an annoying hipster and sound cool for knowing him now.  I actually am rooting for this guy to get more and more popular.  If you liked this album then I highly suggest you check out his albums 'Kaputt' and 'Trouble In Dreams'.  Then maybe even more of his early work.  I do think this album will really finally give him the exposure he's deserved for years apparently.  I still can't believe his previous masterpieces slipped my music radar.  This is album is the work of a living musical wizard genius.  This album is so classy it'll make you want to put on your nicest suit or dress and just take in the mood.  One of the greatest albums of all time.  I say that confidently.  Listen to it.  Share it with as many people as you can.  It's worth it.

I first found out about this amazing duo by chance in 2012.  I was walking in a bookstore when I heard a song that instantly struck me in awe almost putting me in a trance standing there.  I used a music recognition app to find out that it was 'Wild' by Beach House.  So I bought the album Bloom and have listened to it at least 30 times since.  It was one of the most beautiful albums I've ever heard.  I instantly compared them to Cocteau Twins, another great and similar band from the 80s/90s.  Of course I listened to the bands earlier work too and found favorites in Teen Dream and Devotion but I ultimately still named Bloom as my favorite so far.  So during the 3 years since I would periodically look into whether the band was releasing a new album to no avail.  I almost forgot about them when suddenly they released the song 'Sparks' and news of a new album in the Fall of 2015.  I was intrigued also by the title.  When they said they were going back to basics I was still excited but somewhat hesitant as I loved their lush sound from Bloom most.  I made myself not listen to anymore songs released before the album so that the feeling of discovery with each track was much more sincere, especially since there are only 9 songs.  Well when I finally purchased the CD and held the smooth velvet case in my hands I knew I was in for something extra special.  I was right.  After multiple listens so far, here is a track by track review of one of the most beautiful and emotional albums I've heard.1.  Levitation: This song slowly builds up the atmosphere with keyboards and minor drum beats.  Victorias angelic vocals glide through.  At first I didn't think the singing was as good as others but after repeated listens I found myself singing 'Theres a place I want to take you' in my head.  The second half features an emotional guitar croon that creeps in perfectly to complete the soundscape before fading away nicely.  The title of the song explains how it feels listening to this perfectly.  Amazing opener.  10/102.  Sparks: The lead single.  At first I wasn't that impressed.  But the song just kept getting better and better.  It is a very spacey song that again sounds just as the title implies.  The vocals in the first half remind me of M83.  Then toward the end Victorias distinct lullaby style brings it to a close.  The main riff is so alluring.  By the time the main riff repeats itself one final time it sounds like a friend departing whom you wished would stay longer.  Each time I listen to this song I feel like I'm saying goodbye to someone I love.  It's so profound the way music can make you feel.  Especially when done right like this.  10/103.  Space Song: This sounds like it could've been on Bloom.  I fell in love with this at first listen and it has only grown more and more on me.  It's just so great all around.  The main riff on this one is so gorgeous it's hard to describe.  I would have to say it sounds tragically beautiful.  Like endlessly floating through the night while the one you love is floating a distance in front of you that you can never catch up to.  I know, it sounds depressing, but not in the mopey way at all.  Oh and Victorias vocals of course are so sensual and perfect.  This is a new favorite.  This is one of those songs I could  never get tired of.  11/104.  Beyond Love: Another song with a tragic beauty in its sound as if the title didn't hint at it.  The lyrics are so eerie yet delivered so smoothly.  Victoria really is beyond human in her vocal abilities.  The main riff is sad in a good way.  Think of your lover or the one that got away while listening.  Or just relax and enjoy.  Another great track.  9.5/105.  10:37: The beginning drums sound like the introduction to a ceremony.  Then the vocals slowly soar through the song.  This one keeps that Cocteau Twins comparison strong.  Such a relaxing song.  The guitar are so simple yet elegantly great.  I always picture myself floating down a mystic river on giant lily pads staring up at the stars when listening to this.  But thats just me.  Great playful relaxation song.  9.5/106.  PPP: This song.  Wow.  The main riff.  The way Victoria talks seductively in the beginning before singing so beautifully that I feel like I'm drowning in divine delight.  The melody of this song can either make you cry or feel exceptionally happy, or both.  The eerie guitar solo is just so beautiful gorgeous haunting elegant.  I can't even really put to words how it makes me feel.  This song is sure to be a emotional roller coaster throughout the years.  This one is an instant classic.  If I was a filmmaker I'd want this to be in my movie.  11/107.  Wildflower: The synth and guitar in this one brings to mind the 80s.  A quick but twinkling song that I wish was twice as long.  Just sit back and let this one guide your thoughts.  Another relaxation gem.  9.5/108.  Bluebird: Another one that I strongly wish was longer.  This is a jam.  Everything is perfect again.  The drums.  The staccato style guitars that just glide through the chorus.  The keyboards.  Victorias heavenly croon.  I am constantly amazed with this one.  This is the sound definition of good music.  Love it.  10.5/109.  Days Of Candy:  I read that the band used a choir of 24 for this song and it really shows.  The beginning is slow and haunting in the way she sings.  Then the drums quietly kick in with some great emotional guitars.  The final 2 minutes of the song are the best.  It sounds like 3 seperate songs yet one song at the same time.  Such a great and endearing way to close this emotional masterpiece of an album.  10/10Dare I say it?  I think I like this album more than Bloom.  Thats just my personal opinion.  I am still in awe just thinking of the way this album moved me.  I've listened to many albums of many genres throughout the years but I can't say any have struck me like this.  As I said, tragic beauty is present in almost all tracks.  Finding love, losing love.  Happiness, depression.  Relaxation, pure ecstasy.  This album somehow combines all of that in its craft.  Part of me hopes they don't release another album in a while so I can enjoy this even more.  I almost have this irrational fear that they will release an album that I will like more.  I feel like I have found a perfect album.  Of course many will strongly disagree.  But this is my opinion.  Maybe you wont feel the same way whether you love this album or not.  But I highly recommend you listen to the album at least 3 times before you form your full opinion.  Hearing this album gave me the feeling of wondering how I lived all those prior years without it.  Though I'm sure this album will be great year round I think that it is the perfect soundtrack for the Autumn season the most.  This is also one of those albums that really needs to be purchased physically.  You cannot fully experience the album without feeling the smooth red velvet that the CD is wrapped in.  If you already love Beach House, then you need to get this now.  If you're new to the band then prepare yourself for a beauty in music you've probably never heard before.  Do the ears of the world a favor and spread this music to as many people as you can!  I will be cherishing this album till the day I die.

I was long expecting Detox.  When he suddenly announced it was shelved and was instead releasing this companion album to the Straight Outta Compton film I was disappointed but at the same time relieved to have something new at least.  Here's a problem.  Dr Dre was such a snobby pr*ck about this albums release method.  He is the first music billionaire yet he decided to make this an Apple Music exclusive for two full weeks.  I don't use Apple Music and probably never will.  It was a wimpy move in music.  I couldn't find the album online and didn't want to risk any viruses from downloading it elsewhere plus I didn't have the time to worry about it.  So I waited the two weeks for it to be released on CD.  Still no freemium Spotify though?  Gosh Dre really is a @#$%.  Anyways leading up to the CD release I read many reviews.  It was universally loved by the critics.  I couldn't wait to hear Dres supposed final masterpiece.  After finally having it in my grasp, it was clear that the critics were probably on Dres payroll.  This album isn't a masterpiece.  It isn't bad either.  It's just good.  And 'just good' wasn't worth all the hype.First off, the production on the album is crisp and smooth and of course full of soulful funk.  But here's the thing, it was all very forgettable.  I listened to the album over 5 times to let it seep in fully.  Still not amazing.  Not what the critics made the album out to be.  Its funny nowadays most of the time when critics hate an album the fans love it.  This is one of those rare times when critics love the album, but though the fans don't really hate it, I can see many others aren't as impressed either.  This truly was Dre trying too hard to sound relevant after 16 years between albums.  Like I said, the sound of the album is nice and modern, but just not special.  Weird since Dre is known for his high standards and perfectionism.  Now to Dres rapping.  He was decent but he sounded like he was the guest on someone elses song on each song.  There are even two songs he isn't even on???  The topics just made me roll my eyes.  The choruses were catchy but also strangely unappealing.  When I saw it on Amazon it was listed at the time as the number one bestseller in POP Rap.  That explains the sound perfectly.  I like catchy feelgood soft pop rap, but not from someone like Dr Dre.  Like I said, this album barely had Dre rapping on it.  It was like a Calvin Harris album where he thought production was enough to stamp his name on it.  The guests steal the show almost 99% of the time.  Which is good and bad.  There will be people who just love the album but I'm sure more people will toss it aside after a week or two or maybe less.  In a world were new music is constantly shifting and pushing boundaries and blowing minds, this album was just a letdown, especially by Dres standards and the hype.  Honestly even if the album wasn't hyped up I probably wouldn't be impressed still.  I'm sure it took a lot of work for Dre and company to put these songs together, but does that mean it payed off?  I don't think so.Dre worries about making money so much yet this album quickly declined in sales.  The Apple Music exclusive sold a robust 300,000 in its first week.  But even after the actual CD release it was apparent that many weren't buying it anymore.  This album will barely go Gold(500,000), which is still good for others standards, but not for someone who was supposed to be a mega seller.  Maybe Dre should revisit Detox and finish that.

Disturbed  are one of the most popular modern heavy metal/hard rock related bands.  David Draiman had the uncanny ability to roar like a demonic animal in the catchiest way possible while also singing melodically and soulfully.  His voice is one of the most recognizable in Rock alongside Robert Plant, Ozzy Osbourne, Serj Tankian, Anthony Kiedis, James Hetfield, Bono, etc.  Their previous full length album Asylum wasn't as big a seller or as popular as their first albums but I still think it contained a lot of the best work from the band.  But that was in 2010.  Lots of things have changed in the five year gap between albums.  Rock music was slowly taking a backseat to hip hop and dance/pop in terms of sales and popularity.  Modern Hard Rock and Metal were almost totally nonexistent in the charts and it became rare for a band of any rock genre to even go platinum.  Some of you might be thinking "who cares how much they sell their music is good".  But I'm pretty sure Disturbed care  David even said before the release of this album that he's gonna see to it that Rock isn't dead.  So when this album was even mentioned in the summer of 2015 I was half excited and half apathetic.  Mostly because their lead single, however really good, was a major letdown.  It was not nearly as good as it should've been for a comeback single.  The subsequent songs released afterward and before the albums release didn't offer much more either.  I actually lost all interest quick and thought one of my favorite bands from 10 years ago were now going to have to become another band that was once on top and now struggling to stay relevant.  When the day of its release came by I completely forgot about it.  Until I saw it in the new releases on sale and I just couldn't resist giving it a chance.  So when I got home and listened to it once, I was in utter disappointment.  Unimpressed.  Feeling cheated out of 12 bucks I could've used for something else.  But then I remembered how I shouldn't judge an album from one listen alone.  I put it away and listened to it again a second time a few hours later.  It still didn't click.  I was about to give up on it but for some reason I listened to it another time.  Something happened.Suddenly I was singing along again.  I was going along with Davids signature 'raaaaaah's.  I was air drumming especially to the future hit 'Fire It Up'.  This has been said many times before by many others and myself.  This is an album that gets better with each listen.  It evolves.  Its almost like it changes form.  I think that the lead single is still the weakest track.  But its still good.  Their cover of 'The Sound Of Silence' at first sounded like awkward karaoke from David.  But it really blossoms into a ultimate subdued anthem.  I'd say this sounded like a combination of 'Believe' and 'Indestructible'.  It doesn't bring anything new to the table for the band.  But so what?  Its the same sound, but it's not the same songs.  This is what some people don't understand about what can be good about a band not venturing away from the sound that made them liked in the first place.  Disturbed wouldn't sound right if they experimented too much.  Critics most likely will not be too kind to this album because they are the people who mostly listen once and decide in the moment.  I'm starting to think music critics nowadays need to meet a quota to get paid or something so they just write quick unhelpful reviews.  This album deserves attention.  It'll be great for your workout playlist for a while.  This is for old fans of the band and hopefully new fans as well.  It isn't the 'Pet Sounds' of metal.  It's another album of exactly the type of music you'd expect from Disturbed.  Also it isn't their best album.  Those reviewers are probably speaking in the moment too but in a too highly positive manner.  It's just a good album to remind people that Disturbed still have it in them.  And I'm fine with that.  Standout tracks for me are 'Fire It Up' which had some negative responses on Youtube at first because of it's weed influenced lyrics (But come on other great bands have sang about it such as Black Sabbath - Sweet Leaf, TOOL - The Pot).  Other standouts are 'The Light', 'You're Mine', 'Save Our Last Goodbye' and 'The Sound of Silence'.  All of the tracks are nice though.  Like I said, live with this album for a bit before really judging.  I'm not the first to say that and won't be the last.

I'm a newer Clive Barker reader.  But don't discount my views on his work just based on that.  Unlike many I really enjoyed this one a lot.  I liked The Hellbound Heart.  But of course I saw the movie version first and like it more surprisingly.  The novel version didn't really even showcase Pinhead except for maybe in a few sentences.  Yet he is the main identifier of the movie series and the major plot point of this sequel/reboot even if his name is changed.  I've also read Barkers Book of Blood volumes which are spine tingling horror collections.  But so far my favorite novel of his is the not much mentioned debut novel The Damnation Game.  But lets get back to this.  Yes I give it 5 stars unlike the majority who have apparently had their much too high expectations murdered with this book.  I saw the reviews but still paid the full 28 bucks for this.  It was a risk I took as I usually get books used or online for cheaper nowadays.  The risk paid off.  Apparently this novel has been talked about and in the making for almost 2 decades before its release.  Plot points being hinted at are probably what disappointed many readers when many of the said plot schemes weren't even in the final book.  Though I understand many of these reviewers disappointments, I still found myself personally enjoying this very straight foward and epic horror novel.  I saw it as a more intricate sequel and end to the movie series of Hellraiser.  Yes the writing style of this book isn't as in depth or mindblowing and poetically terrifying as many of Mr. Barkers previous works, but it was still a mesmerizing epic.  I'd say it's his most accessible book in terms of writing style.  Of course the blood and gore and horror elements aren't for those with weak stomachs.  (Spoiler: theres a very uncalled for rape in the story).  But I'd say any adult who is a fan of a good horror story by someone not named Stephen King would like this.  (love Stephen King too though)  This book was strangely appealing to me.  It was like a very long epic horror movie.  I do believe that if Clive were to really put the effort into it that he could adapt this into a decent movie.  Maybe the finale Hellraiser movie.  Hellraiser: Scarlet Gospels.  Sounds cliche and too sequel-ly.  Oh well.  Or just call the movie Scarlet Gospels.  Either way I enjoyed this horror read.  If you can stomach some of the more weirdly terrifying elements then I highly recommend this.  If you're a fan of the Hellraiser movies but haven't really read the books of Barker, then I'd say give this a short as a closer for the series.  If you're a long time Barker fan then I dont know what to tell you.  You might love it like I did.  You might not.  It's a mixed bag with this book.  I just know I'd read it again when I have the time.  Oh and also for new Barker fans, I highly recommend The Damnation Game as well!.

I wasn't really a fan of Tame Impala before this album. I listened to their previous albums and though I agree they are great classics in their own rights, their style wasn't for me. Then one day a friend of mine showed me their song 'Cause I'm A Man'. I was impressed. But it wasn't until I heard their song 'Let It Happen' that they had my full attention. It was one of the most epic and catchy electronic rock songs I've heard in recent years. So I read up on the mastermind behind the band Kevin Parker and his comments regarding this album. I was especially intrigued by the fact that it was basically abandoning the psychedelic rock nature or their previous efforts in favor of more synths and electronic aspects. Then behold the song 'Eventually' was released. Probably one of the greatest songs of all time. But still, leading up to the albums eventual release I almost forgot about the album coming out. But once again the week the album came out there was my friend again reminding me of the album and telling me how great it was all around. So I gave it a preview listen online and liked it. I also couldn't help but to see that other reviewers were calling it another classic breakup record. I love breakup albums the most. So I went and purchased the album and gave it a good few listens and I'm glad I did. Here is a track by track review of this amazing musical journey.1. Let It Happen: As I said, this is an epic synth dance disco rock song. The main synth riff is so urgent and infectious. In fact this entire song has a feeling of urgency as if one was being chased by bad guys throughout a maze like dance floor. At nearly 8 minutes it has more replay value than most 3 minute songs I've heard recently. There is just a bit guitar in here so don't worry if you were concerned that there would be no guitar at all. The final half of the song gets almost robotic in the vein of Daft Punk perfectly. This is also one of my new workout playlist tracks for the gym! Amazing song. 10/102. Nangs: This is a short cut. At first I thought it was going to be an interlude but its just a quick song. It's very trippy and layered with repeated vocals throughout. There's something soothing about it that makes me wish it lasted longer. Still very dreamlike. 9/103. The Moment: Another upbeat disco rock track. The repeated synth riff is simple and genius. There are atmospheric sounds faintly in the background that seem like faint orchestrated parts. Kevin sings in a relaxed voice throughout with infectious wit. The lyrics are very nice too. There is also an interesting synth solo that sounds exotic. 9.5/104. Yes I'm Changing: Things slow down for this very emotional and masterfully executed ballad. This is probably Kevins best vocal performance yet. I never thought he could sing like this. This should be a single. The lyrics are very reflecting. The production really makes you get lost in the soundscape. The final minute change tone to somewhat gothic keyboards ending the song in a hauntingly beautiful manner. A perfect song. 11/105. Eventually: Another perfect song. As I said earlier this is one of the best songs of all time in my opinion. It's a break up song, but from the point of view of the person doing the breaking up. The harsh but tuneful synth riff throughout is tragic and gorgeous. There are sudden stops throughout that just work so well. The vocals of course are emotional and almost remorseful to the lyrics. Its a sad song for a break up. I suggest you not listen to it during a bad break up. Still a masterpiece of a song. The final part of the song features this synth riff that just leaves me in near tears each time no matter my mood. I'm surprised this hasn't become a mega hit(yet) as it's also the catchiest song on an album full of catchy tracks. A beautiful emotional tour de force track that I would call the Song Of The Year. 11/106. Gossip: The synth of this song sounds like what its title suggest. It's as if the sounds are gossiping to each other. Very clever short interlude. 9/107. The Less I Know The Better: This one features more of the disco rock style. The guitars are back again with a funky groove throughout along with Kevins fun vocals despite the tone of the lyrics. The final verse of the song sounds like it should've been a chorus for the song its so playful and sad. A great unconventional possible hit! 9.5/108. Past Life: This is just amazing. The verses are spoken word and tell such a beautiful story about a past love. The chorus is sung in heavenly manner. Though at first some might be off put by the effect put on Kevins voice during the verses it actually feels like it couldn't work without it once you get used to the song. Very dreamy and heartbreaking yet it ends on a positive note. 10/109. Disciples: Another really short song. Not an interlude. Just a quick and awesome song. Its a nice fast song and I understand why its so short, but I wouldn't mind if it was twice as long either. Oh well that's what the replay button is for! 9/1010. 'Cause I'm A Man: This is the closest thing to the psychedelic style but also in tune with the rest of the album. It's a very relaxing and empowering song. I was impressed but it's not my favorite on the album. Maybe it'll be yours though. 8.5/1011. Reality In Motion: I like the laid back playful tone of Kevins singing again on this song. He makes it seem so effortless. It's a real head bobbing song. Of course like most of the songs it changes style a bit toward the end. There's even a slight guitar near the finale. Very nice. 9/1012. Love/Paranoia: Wow. Can this guy do no wrong? Just as the title suggest this one is full of love and paranoia in its sound and lyrics. It also a slight R&B feel that is pulled off almost too nicely. Very emotional too. Less than 30 seconds to the end it gets a so good with guitars and orchestration that I wish it lasted much longer. Dare I say it? Another perfect song. 10/1013. New Person, Same Old Mistakes: The album began epic and fast. It ends epic and somewhat slow, in a good way. This song just has such a classy vibe to it. Everything about this song is smooth from the production to the style of the singing. This sounds like the perfect song to listen to while walking down a cityscape while wearing your best suit or dress with your head held up high. It's a very mysterious song as well. A great way to close this emotional album. 10/10So this album was a pleasant surprise and a nice treat. Very few times are full albums so consistent. This was epic and full of genius but at the same time very catchy and accessible. Something that is very rare to find in music nowadays. It is also the best all out break up album for me. But don't get me wrong, even if you're happily in a relationship or happily single you'd appreciate the beauty and sound of this. It's hard to fully explain just how magnificent and near perfect this album is. Like I said, I wasn't a fan before this album. Hopefully in further released the band explores more of this sound or maybe another. I'm sure Kevin is a class act with whatever style of music he tries to make. You will dance to this. You will relax to this. You might even cry to this. Don't be ashamed if you do! This is a very satisfying and smooth headphone album of heartbreak. Close your eyes. Let the music take you to abstract places in your mind. I seriously think this is a candidate for the Album Of The Year. It would be a criminal injustice if it wasn't even nominated at the Grammys. (Future people was I right or wrong?) If you liked their old albums but have an open mind for new sounds then you might like this or maybe not. If you like good electronic rock then you'll love this. I suggest you listen to it online first and if you like it then buy it. But be warned, once you get into this album, you'll never get tired of it!

I first got into Miguel as an impulse buy. His song 'Adorn' was still blossoming. I loved the style of the song and the high notes he could hit so effortlessly. I knew I was listening to a new icon of music. So I walked through a music store sometime after and saw his album 'Kaleidoscope Dream' on sale and picked it up. It was a huge breath of fresh air with its wispy production and soulful melodies compared to most of the genre today. The album was tapping into a new genre thats slowly taking the world by storm called PBR&B. It has also become a standard album to listen to while making love for many people. So I was in high anticipation of Miguels next move. I was wondering how he could top the legendary song 'Adorn'. In the meantime I checked out his debut album which was also good but not nearly as groundbreaking and masterful. Finally he released the lead single for this album 'Coffee' but I was at first disappointed upon hearing that it was not only just a reworked version of a song from a EP he released in 2014, but that he added a rap guest vocal to it by Wale, which totally ruined the song. Wale isn't bad, and rap isn't bad, but Miguels music doesn't work best with one guest verse from a rapper. His vocals do however work great when he himself is a guest on a rappers song usually singing the chorus. But I didn't give up on his new album as he released more songs prior to the album that kept my interest high such as 'face the sun'. So when the disc finally hit stores I purchased it. After many repeated listens here is a track by track review.1. A Beautiful Exit: The album opener begins with a few seconds of a news reporter before this sonic guitar comes in. Miguels singing in this is similar to his song 'The Thrill'. During the chorus the sonic guitars are layered with more elegant guitars that work so well. This song is a beautiful entrance. 9.5/102. Deal: This one starts off somewhat slow before turning into a jam with a groovy bass. The chorus sounds fun and playful like some oldschool funk song, but I think the real star of this song is the production. For the first time I'm not too impressed by Miguels vocals. Don't get me wrong, the song is nice. I just wouldn't list it among his best material. The last half with hints of Miguels higher notes and group vocals along with some distinct guitars before slowing down into a slow jam are the best parts. I wish the slow jam toward the end lasted longer! 9/103. The Valley: The production of this song is similar to late 90s Nine Inch Nails, which is nice. The vocals are seductive while the lyrics are far from innocent. It's a sexy song to make love to like you're 'filming in the valley'. Miguel swears with class. For anyone who doesn't know, the valley is alluded to as the place in Hollywood where many porn films are filmed. Get ready to add this to your sex playlist, but you can listen to this as casual listening just as much. 9.5/104. Coffee: Boy was I glad that Wale wasn't on the album version! No offense to Wale fans, but he really ruined the song. But this pristine version of the song with Miguel alone is just perfect. It has Miguels own sensual production with his sexual vocals. Sadly the song hasn't impacted big, yet. It's no 'Adorn', but thats like expecting Led Zeppelin to make another 'Stairway'. Expect this one to never get old. This one will put almost anyone in a good mood. 10/105. NWA Feat. Kurrupt: Seeing the guest rapper on the title I was ready to be disappointed. But unlike the alternate version of 'Coffee' that was ruined, this one actually works. Kurrupt isn't the best rapper. He isn't the ideal for this song seeing it's title either. His lyrics aren't impressive, but the way he delivered them were in tune with the style of the song that now I can't see this song without him. But now lemme talk about the main star Miguel. He sings in a falsetto for the whole song nicely. The production gives the song a feeling of walking an island at night seeing various people making love. Or at least that's how I'd picture a music video for this. Good song that almost proves me wrong about MIguel and guest rappers. 9/106. Waves: This is the catchiest song on the album by far. I can see this becoming a hit single. This is something Bruno Mars would be impressed with. You can interpret the lyrics literally or metaphorically and it works great either way. Make babies to this song or enjoy it at a beach party! A master funk pop song. 10/107. Whats Normal Anyway: This is the best song on the album in my opinion. It's a laid back song. It's a self pity song almost but reminds itself that being yourself is important. It's also a great song for how most mixed kids feel growing up. The production is full of sonic textures and emotional synths. Great song to just listen to with good headphones while walking around a city and thinking about life. 10/108. Hollywood Dreams: This is a great motivational song in nature. Decent lyrics. The groovy guitar riff marches throughout. It's very catchy and Miguel sings nicely throughout as expected. Just a feelgood song. 9/109. Destinado A Morir (Enter.Lewd): Usually I don't really like interlude type tracks. This one was okay. It would've worked better as a full song. It doesn't even really lead into the next much better track. Others might like it, but for me it's just okay. 7.5/1010. ...Goingtohell: Great song. The music is just perfect. The tragic and romantic lyrics and vocals are vintage Miguel. I know the lyrics are pretty straight forward but the song itself always gives me this feeling of going through very tough times with a lover together. There's even a nice guitar solo. The chorus is so elegant and laid back. One of his best by far. 10/1011. Flesh: This song brings to mind sensual gothic vampire style romance. It sounds silly to some maybe but I mean those old school vampires in black leather before Twilight ruined them. This sounds like it could be part of their playlist for eternal love making. Its so beautiful and almost haunting in a good way. Get ready to breed to this. 10/1012. Leaves: Another song where the guitar is upfront for more genre bending. It starts off soft before it ends with a bang. This one is a sad song to listen to thinking of the one that got away. Prepare to have memories of a past love haunt you in the last minute of the song. Unless you're in a happy relationship now so you'll just see this as a great mellow song. It's great either way. 10/1013. Face The Sun Feat. Lenny Kravitz: Now when I saw the Kravitz name on this song I assumed it was gonna be like one of his funk rock jams from the 90s. No offense to him, but I'm glad it was nothing like that! This is just a romantic slow song with great guitars and probably Miguels best vocal performance on the album. Kravits probably plays the guitar including a nice solo, but he also has a nice backing vocal part. This is the type of guest that builds the song perfectly to compliment the main artist. I really hope this one becomes a single. Not only is it one of his best songs but its a perfect closer to the album. The lyrics are so gorgeous and romantic. Anyone else singing this type of song would come off as corny, but he delivers it all with class. This is in the ball park of 'Adorn', maybe even in a bigger league. Perfection. 11/10So I'm gonna say it. This was better than Kaleidoscope Dream. Its more consistent. I loved that album but there are a good 3 or 4 songs I would skip on it. This album isn't as catchy at first, but it is a clear example of an album that gets better with multiple listens and never gets old. This one is a seed that you plant and it grows into a musical tree of sensual magic for your ears. If you don't like it at first, I urge you to put it away for a few days, then revisit it and see how it sounds somewhat more welcoming to you. But of course some people just wont like it no matter what. In those cases those people shouldn't trash the album but just move on. Some have compared Miguel to Prince. I think that's a lazy comparison. They both have stylish hair and they aren't tall individuals and they incorporate rock and roll elements but they really don't sound the same. Also this isn't R&B or PBR&B, well not entirely. I'd say this is the midpoint between both genres. It does have a few good examples of PBR&B throughout such as 'Coffee', 'Whats Normal Anyways' and ' Face The Sun' but as a whole this is almost hard to put into one genre. All I can say is it is great romantic music. Even if you don't have a lover, this is stylish classy music to listen and relax to. This is one of the best albums of 2015 and probably the best R&B related material in years. Yes even better than that D'Angelo album. Go ahead and dismiss my opinion and maybe my review just on that comment. Regarding the PBR&B styled songs. If you liked them, then you should check out the singer known as 'How To Dress Well', especially his album 'What Is This Heart?', as he's one of the few in the genre who gives Miguel a run for his money. But yes, this album is near perfect. If you like Miguels style then you'll either love this or be disappointed. Hopefully the former.  I can see this becoming known as a classic.

I remember when fun. was gaining momentum in their career with the song 'We Are Young'.  I honestly didn't like the song.  The reason I bought their second album the day it came out was because I read that it was inspired by the sound of Kanye West(production, not lyrics) and in some aspects, Queen.  So I bought the album 'Some Nights' and it became one of my main soundtracks for my life as a 18 year old in Miami at the time.  Oh the memories the album still brings to my mind these days.  So as you can expect I was strongly anticipating a new album from the band for years.  Sadly no new studio album materialized.  Then lead guitarist Jack Antonoff embarked on his solo career with his project Bleachers and a new album.  I liked it.  I didn't think it was as good as fun. though.  So then came the announcement of Nate Ruess pursuing a solo career as well.  I was somewhat excited.  When he released his first single 'Nothing Without Love' I couldn't help but compare it to the fun. song that made them famous in the first place.  I honestly again didn't really like it as much as I wanted.  But then he released the song 'AhHa'.  That song was like a sequel to my favorite fun. song 'Some Nights'.  So I was again excited for the albums release hoping to get the closest thing to a new fun. album.  I was right.  Sorta.  It's impossible not to compare this new album to Nates bands work, but that's the reason I bought it in the first place.  I was not disappointed.  Here's a track by track review.1.  Grand Romantic (Intro): Much like the theatrics of 'Some Nights' this one is impossible not to compare to the operatic aspects of Queen, and I love it.  Great baroque opener.  I actually wish it was longer and louder though.  9/102.  AhHa: Some people are trashing this song.  I at first was annoyed by the constant laughter in the background, but it really stuck with me for the better.  Yes like I said it's like a sequel to the song 'Some Nights'.  I didn't realize it at first but the lyrics of the pre-chorus are directly taken from the ending portion of the song 'Some Nights' which is cool.  Its a very anthemic song.  The production is grand.  Great song to work out to or listen to on a road trip.  I don't like how it ends abruptly though as I always think theirs something wrong with the track each time.  Still a great catchy pump up song.  10/103.  Nothing Without Love: I didn't like this song that much at first.  But I couldn't stop it from taking over my mind with its infectious melodies.  Still not one of my favorites though.  If you liked 'We Are Young' then you'll like this, but this is better in my opinion.  9/104.  Take It Back: This is where the romantic aspect really starts.  The old crackling record player sound in the background was off putting at first.  It has such a relaxing and heartbreaking sound.  But nonetheless it's one of the most beautiful songs I've heard lyrically and musically in a long time.  There's even a great guitar solo.  Sam Smith would be impressed with this one.  I would've chosen this as the lead single.  10/105  You Light My Fire: This sounds like it took all of the biggest pop hits of the 80s and tried to mash them together into one song and it works.  I do think the chorus is the least appealing part surprisingly but the production throughout and the verses make up for it ten fold.  Nice playful retro tune.  9/106.  What This World Is Coming To (featuring Beck): This is a beautiful mellow song.  Some have compared it to Lennon which is on spot.  Becks appearance is nicely done without overshadowing Nate at all since this is his album.  The first half has more of Becks style while the last half is vintage Ruess.  This is a modern classic.  9.5/107.  Great Big Storm: This is another insanely catchy song.  It will annoy some at first.  But trust me this is one of those songs that you'll find yourself suddenly singing in the shower its so infectious.  The lyrics are also very meaningful.  The style of the song is like a playful musical storm.  9.5/108.  Moment: Another possible future hit.  This is a piano driven power ballad with a chorus that's destined to be cried to.  I can see the sea of cell phone lights during a live performance of this while Ruess pours his heart out.  A great song for a farewell to a relationship you wished wouldn't end.  10/109.  It Only Gets Much Worse: The title should already foreshadow the sad song ahead.  It's truly sad and beautiful.  The orchestral background is tragic beauty in musical form.  This one breaks my heart in a good way?  The way Nate delivers the chorus is smooth.  This is the kind of song you'll see in a montage of heartbreak in a movie.  10/1010.  Grand Romantic: This is such a great companion to the opening song that I wish it followed that song.  It seems to work better played alongside its intro counterpart.  This song truly is full of romance.  Its such a gorgeously crafted song.  Then when you think its over the baroque Queen-esque choir from the intro song repeats but much louder and more magically.  Such a great song.  10/1011.  Harsh Light:  This song was originally performed by fun. live but alas it has appeared on this album.  This studio version of the song is a breath of fresh air though.  Nates chants of "We All Got Scars" will get lodged in your cranium.  There is a instrument similar to a flute heard briefly during the bridge section that is such a great attention to detail that I love in the production.  This one gets better with each listen which is saying something since the song is instantly lovable.  10/1012.  Brightside: Wow what a way to end an album full of love songs.  There is a twinkle to this songs melody that gives it a dreamy tragic feeling.  The baroque style musical cues throughout are just perfect.  Nate gives one of his best vocal performances as well.  It really feels like a drunk dream full of loving memories in musical form.  The way Nate playfully says "And look at you" just feels right as the album comes to a celestial close.  10/10So I'm sure some of you were tired of all the fun. comparisons but its almost impossible not to mention them since this truly sounds like the next album from the band.  Which is a good thing.  Look back at the cover artwork.  The music matches the mood and style of the artwork almost too perfectly.  I could almost see balloons flying up into the unknown in my mind at the end of most of the songs.  It's not a happy album, but it's a beautifully orchestrated one with vocals that pull on your heartstrings.  Nates voice is a trademark now.  It's like anything he puts his vocals to turns into magical music.  Also another reason the similarities to fun. were prominent was because the production team was basically the same.  This is a great album for break ups.  Even if you're happy in a relationship you could listen to this with your lover for its beauty and show your partner your Grandly Romantic musical taste.  This is truly a pop masterpiece.  I promise if you already like anything Nate has been apart of including fun., The Format or just his guest vocals on many other artists songs, then you'll more than love this.  I can proudly say it's much better than his fellow bandmembers solo Bleachers album, which was also good.  I say it's one of the best albums of 2015 and truly one of the best ever by a lead singer going solo.  This demands repeated listens.  One of the best albums in the past 10 years and worth the money.

Its no surprise that I discovered Of Monsters and Men when they released the song 'Little Talks' and took the world by storm. When I first heard of them I just dismissed them as an Arcade Fire ripoff band but I quickly changed my mind. Their debut album was one of the best of 2012. The band became somewhat of an everyman band. The public didn't hate them. You wouldn't be made fun of for telling anyone you liked the band. Critics liked the band too but they weren't Grammy darlings. I always thought of them as a folky version of the xx. They did continue to pave the way for indie/folk rock to reach bigger audiences. So after the success of their first album I was curious to see what the group would do next. Almost 3 years passed since and I almost forgot about the band honestly. In todays music landscape, 3 years between albums can sometimes break an artists career. When the band released their lead single "Crystals" I wasn't that impressed at first. Sure it has grown on me like a parasite like most good songs, but it just never hit the world hard like the singles from the first album. They released a few more songs to hype up the release, but for the most part if you weren't already a mega fan of the band you probably had no idea the album was hitting stores. I'm not a mega fan of the band. I said I liked their first album and was eager to see what happened next, but I was totally surprised when I saw that they released their new album the same day as another band I actually love more, Muse. But, for some odd reason, I bought this album over the Muse album despite it being more pricey(I still listened to the Muse on Spotify of course though). It was an impulse. So when I got home I looked up information on the new album to see if I should keep it. I keep telling myself I won't listen to critics reviews anymore, but my curiosity always has me wanting to know others opinions. So I saw that the critics weren't too kind on this album and it almost made me return it. I didn't, and I'm glad I didn't. After a few listens of this impulse buy I found it mesmerizing. Here is a track by track review.1. Crystals: Like I said, this lead single wasn't as impressive at first. But gosh has it grown on me. Those 'whoah oh oh ooohs' are irresistible. This really is a beautiful song. The short bridge section of the song that leads to the last repetition of the chorus always gets me. It wasn't a big hit at the time of the albums release but it does have potential to change that. Great opener. 9.5/102. Human: A quiet starting song with soothing distance humming in the background. When the vocals start things really take off. I can see this being another decent single. The lyrics are darker but its so gorgeous it has that special appeal to be used in movie trailers and soundtracks. The melody isn't that obvious at first but it will hit you hard when it finally does. Its tragic beauty in song form. 9.5/103. Hunger: This is a very atmospheric song and I love it. The dual vocals work great in this song. I love their dual vocals most compared to them taking turns with lead vocals on a lot of songs. I can see this being another hit song. You'll see many people covering this online. I love the drumming on this song and its theatrical ending. 9/104. Wolves Without Teeth: This one is catchy all around. The verses and chorus could be switched and still be infectious. There are many layers in the background that really make this song stellar. This is one of those songs that makes you discover more and more with repeated listens. The last minute is so corny but powerful I really love it and wish it lasted longer. One of my favorites. 10/105. Empire: This is almost similar to 'Dirty Paws' in structure. The lyrics just sound so magical. It's like the words were made to be in this song. This is what I would've chosen to be the lead single if I was in charge. Its majestic instrumentally and infectious vocally. This is the type of song that reminds you to have a great imagination. Let the music paint a picture in your mind. 10/106. Slow Life: This is the grooviest song from the band so far. The guitar and drums jam throughout as the bass grooves along. That bass though. This is epic and dreamlike. This is the perfect bridge between the first and second half of the album. 10/107. Organs: At first I didn't like this song. I recognized it was great, but it just wasn't my cup of tea. But boy did this song prove me wrong. It's slow, but its so persistent in its beauty and it forces its melody to get stuck in your head. This is a song that many will cry to when their down. It will be one of those healthy cry-fests that you need to remind yourself you're human. I already have this on reserve for when I'm in a crisis in my life and just need to sit back and let the music guide my emotions. You can listen to this with others, but I think this is best enjoyed alone for life introspection. I hate it for making me unable to resist it. 9.5/108. Black Water: Just the title itself sends my mind dark gothic imagery. The song is just that. Very folky gothic and it works well. When I listen to this song I imagine a dark figure staring at the sea from a castle in the night. Can this song make a song that isn't just pure gorgeousness? The last two minutes of the song is probably the best two minutes of the entire album. That's saying something considering how great the album is. 10/109. Thousand Eyes: This one starts off as the quietest song on the album before it builds up into a climax that never really happens. Reminds me of Sigur Ros instrumentally which is a huge compliment. If I ever became a movie director I wouldn't want this in my movie. 10/1010. I Of The Storm: Such a gorgeous and emotional song. This will be a big hit. This song will stand the test of time. Everything is perfect in this song. Every little musical layer is placed perfectly and if just any small part of the song was removed it wouldn't sound complete. Its not a happy song. But it's still musical beauty. 10/1011. We Sink: I always hold closing songs to a higher regard. I feel every album should close with a lasting impression and not just 'another song'. This is that lasting impression. That's all I need to say. It sums up the beauty of the album perfectly. Its a cinematic ending perfect for the credits to play to. 10/10So once again the negativity of so called professional critics need to be ignored. This album was released to little hype and it might slip under many listeners radars which would be a great injustice. This album isn't as instantly catchy as the first. But I will say with confidence that I think this album is better as a whole. If you're a mega fan of the band, you will love this without a doubt. If you're one of those who loved the bands first album but didn't really keep up with them after that, then this will remind you why you liked them in the first place like it did for me. Hopefully this album rebounds with its subsequent singles and inevitable uses in soundtracks and trailers. You might have already heard this album on replay at bookstores. I know that most of the critics are people who probably listened to the album once or twice and tossed it aside. Trust me, this album will hit you hard and demand repeated listens. This is a perfect addition to any summer playlist. If you're going through a break up or another sad event, this album will comfort you when you're home alone and need the motivation. The album artwork reminded me of something that I couldn't quite put my finger on at first, then it hit me. It reminded me of the album cover for Sigur Ros untitled album. They are another brilliant Icelandic band worth checking out. But yes, this album is one of the best alums of 2015 and I hope it holds strong. It serves as great driving music. Great background music or your personal soundtrack for magical motivation. This is not a sophomore slump. Its a sophomore bump. It's probably one of the best albums of 2015 that many will not even hear. So I'd help spread the word if I were you to change that. Highly recommended.

I'm a newer fan of the Pixies/Frank Black, as I was born just when the band was breaking up initially. I'm not trying to impress anyone saying I'm young and blah blah like a hipster. The band just clicks with me so much. I can proudly say they have quickly become my favorite group. I still listen to all kinds of music but so far I've never had an obsession with a bands music quite like I have for the Pixies. I've only really started listening to their music fully recently, but they really almost instantly took the throne for my all time favorite musical artist. I've read about the bands history, watched old and new live footage that I wish I could've seen in person, and of course listened to all five of their full length albums. Surfa Rosa gets so much acclaim for its raw and unique sound for its time and it should, but I think it's my least favorite album of theirs. It's still great though. I will say it now that Bossanova is my all time favorite from the band. Doolittle is my second favorite. Trompe Le Monde is my third favorite. I even put their 2014 Kim-less album ahead of Surfa Rosa, because. I enjoyed it a lot more. I even checked out some of Frank Blacks early solo work. Teenager of the Year is still one of my favorites as well. So back to Doolittle now. I know I said it wasn't my favorite album from the band, but I do acknowledge that it's their best. What else can I say that hasn't been said throughout the years? Doolittle is a landmark album. It literally changed rock music. It's great. It's the bees-kness. When I first bought this album I literally listened to it for 4 hours straight and that wasn't enough. I still listen to it regularly even if I'm trying to find new music. Here's a track by track review for other newcomers who happen upon this review.1. Debaser: Such a great opener that instantly showcases all aspects of the band. The fun bass, awesome guitars, parading drums and of course Frank Blacks insanely catchy shouting vocals. It's guitar riff is always stuck in my head even after hearing the rest of the album. 10/102. Tame: This one took me a while to like. I can see some people liking it instantly. It took me a few listens, but it really latched onto me. The angry chorus just gets my blood pumping. Great bridge part as well. Its funny knowing that when offered a slot to perform on Arsenio Hall, they wanted to play this song but were quickly denied because of its angry unconventional style unheard of then. Great song though. 9/103. Wave Of Mutilation: Another track that showcases the great riffs Santiago can produce along with Franks more melodic soothing vocals. It just gives me this warming sensation every time I hear it. 10/104. I Bleed: So this is one of the specific tracks that I think Kurt Cobain was influenced by. It really has the blueprints for the sound of Nirvana and grunge altogether. Bass upfront with some awesome guitars sneaking around every corner while Frank and Kim sing together in such an awesomely haunting way. The angst-filled guitars during the chorus are so good too. 10/105. Here Comes Your Man: Oh the big hit of the album. It's probably the catchiest song from the band alongside 'Dig For Fire' from Bossanova. It's just so different than anything else from the band musically and lyrically. It's great. That guitar riff. That chorus. If you like this catchy more mellow side to Franks vocals you should check out his second solo album 'Teenager of the Year' as well. Such a beautiful song that I'm sure will still sound brand new even 50 years from now. 10/106. Dead: This will sound strange and crazy for most listeners at first. It sure did for me. But the screeching guitar along with Blacks cartoony crazy vocals really get stuck in your head after repeated listens. It's one of the bands acquired taste songs. There is a nice melodic guitar part during the chorus though thats always a welcoming gesture. Strange and good. 9/107. Monkey Gone To Heaven: The second catchiest song on the album. The lyrics might sound silly and obscure but there is a deep meaning. The chorus is enchanting and almost hypnotizing. I like the use of violins as well. I love the bridge section a lot that leads into the finaly chorus too. Oh and I forgot to mention again how awesome Santiagos guitar is. 10/108. Mr. Grieves: This song begins with a sound similar to Tom Waits in style. Frank does this insane laugh that makes you know you're in for a ride. When the song picks up speed it gains more melody and undeniably catchy vocals. It's a sound the band didn't really move onto their future albums but I love it. I know Frank loved short songs, but I wish this was longer. 9.5/109. Crackity Jones: There are some silly spanish lyrics mixed with the english and more of the fast insane vocals that might turn off some listeners not used to the style. The fast guitar riff throughout is just incredible! 9/1010. La La Love You: David the drummer takes over lead vocals on this song with his nice Elvis styled singing. It's a cute love song that shows off Davids ability to kick butt on drums and sing a catchy tune at the same time. Nice guitar work and whistle moments too. I wish David was used more vocally like in this song. It's always fun watching the live videos of this too. 10/1011. No. 13 Baby: I love how the band can be insane wacky with vocals and catchy at the same time. It shows off how the band can end a song with a groove. 9.5/1012. There Goes My Gun: The shouts of 'Yo ho' seemed silly at first but like most of the bands music, it makes perfect sense in due time after repeated listens. It is another example of the bands ability to make short but lasting top tunes. 9.5/1013. Hey: Hey! This is just an awesome amazing perfect good great song. Such a powerful track that has so many layers to it. The way the guitar riffs of Santiago and Black compliment each other along with the rest of the band are just unexplainable. I just love this song. 10/1014. Silver: This is a very cinematic slow and haunting song sung by Kim. It really sounds nothing like the others which is why the album and band are loved. It's not my favorite, but I never seem to find the need to press skip. It feels like something you'd hear in a dramatic and tragic movie scene. The slide guitar done by Kim is nice though. 9/1015. Gouge Away: What a way to bring it all together for this groovy rock ending. It's a strange biblical love song about, gouging your eyes out. Haunting yet strongly appealing. Smooth edgy closer to an amazing album. 9.5/10So, yes the hype is real. This album is timeless. It's all over the place in style and it works well. Something many bands fail to do with full albums. It's quick and really demands multiple listens. It rocks. It jams. It pops. This is the Pixies best album. Their Magnum Opus. But like I said, that doesn't mean it has to be my favorite. If you're a newcomer to the band I'd recommend listening to Bossanova(My favorite). Then listen to Doolittle(Their best), then listen to Trompe Le Monde(Also great), then Surfa Rosa. If you end up loving Surfa Rosa or are someone who already does, then ok, doesn't mean I'm gonna start loving it the same way. Then after you have their original line up material seeped into your head, give their newest album Indie Cindy a chance. I really like it. Some trash talk it, but their mostly biased just because of Kims departure. It's a nice album that stands tall along the rest. Also check out Frank Blacks first two solo albums because they really do sound like 'what if' Pixies albums. I might even say 'Teenager of the Year' is as good as if not better than Doolittle. But yes, Doolittle is the masterpiece force of music nature that everyone is saying. In this modern music landscape I'll say you should listen to it on Spotify then actually buy it. I did. It was worth every penny.  This album is 7.  You'll understand after listening to it.

The xx have always had a special place in my music collection.  Sure they aren't my all time favorite artists but they are definitely one of my top go-to groups.  Their first album was an instant atmospheric guitar twirling classic that showcased their ability to fuse indie rock with nightclub vibes.  Their second album focused a lot more on the nightclub vibes and lost one of the key guitarists that made the first album so great, but it was still a great almost underrated second album.  Ever since, I've been patiently waiting for any announcement on a new xx album.  I knew Jamie was the main producer and beat maker of the album, and he had his own sorta solo effort a few years back in the form of a collaboration remix collection with Gil Scott Heron.  I thought it had the great production and style of the xx but with Gils soulful raw voice, but I didn't really give it much attention.  So then I hear some of Jamies solo songs leading up to this album.  Songs like 'Girl' and 'Sleep Sound' were mesmerizing.  Then he released the song 'Loud Places', which featured his xx bandmate Romy, along with an awesome video.  It made me even more excited, even though I knew Romy wouldn't be on the entire album.  Usually I stay away from almost entirely instrumental albums, but once the album finally came out I gave it a listen on Spotify and I couldn't resist.  It was some of the classiest electronic music I've heard.  I had to have it physically.  After multiple listens so far, here is my track by track review.1.  Gosh: This opener has an urgent feeling to it.  The bass thumps as the beat runs along.  The chants of 'Oh my gosh' are somewhat humorous but they work well.  This is the type of song you'd hear during a chase scene in an action movie and I like it.  Also good to listen to during a workout.  The last half of the song takes a different approach with its ominous bass and playful siren-like synths closing the song perfectly. 9.5/102.  Sleep Sound: This version sounds different than the one released beforehand, and I like it a lot.  The song features some heavenly plucking sounds along with a distant soothing bass.  There are also these strangely appealing sounds throughout that seem to be that of voices put through some vocal effect.  This is really an out of this world sexy song that needs to be played loud whether in a car or at home or on some decent headphones.  I can see this being played a lot when I go to the beach during the summer.  10/103.  SeeSaw featuring Romy: The ending of the last song merges into this song nicely.  The drums are faster and the synths are so beautiful.  Romys evangelic vocals sore in the near distance throughout the song.  If the xx release a new album soon I'd love to hear more of this side to them!  Definitely a new house classic.  10/104.  Obvs: There is a slight tropical vibe similar to Jamies production in The xx song 'Reunion'.  But things just keep building up and the song ends in a totally different place than it began which always leaves me in awe.  There are even distant Lion King style howls in the distance in some parts that make me feel relaxed.  10/105.  Just Saying: I saw the short length and thought I'd be disappointed.  Its a very soothing interlude that I'm sure would work great in a movie soundtrack.  I think I hear some Romy in it at a certain part.  I just wish it was longer.  Not really disappointed, as its a good relaxer, but still not one of my favorites.  8/106.  Stranger In A Room featuring Oliver Sim: The other xx bandmate song.  It gives off the illusion that it might be a fast song with its quick synths, but it's probably the slowest vocal featured song on the album.  Its impossible not to compare it to the xx since Oliver is the prominent singer in more songs than Romy.  Reminds me a bit of 'Fiction' from the band, but of course without the beat.  Great beautifully sad song as always.  Its a nice midpoint for the album.  9/107.  Hold Tight: The first half sounds like something Trent Reznor would be proud of.  Then the second half speeds up with its drums.  Another one that sounds worthy of being part of some climatic action sequence in a movie. 8.5/108.  Loud Places featuring Romy: Such a beautiful song.  The production just sounds the perfect soundtrack for a soothing night out in the big city.  Romy even shows off her xx guitars even if only slightly in the background.  Of course the ending lyrics leave that lasting mark on your heartstrings.  It's a perfect song.  I don't know what else to say.  10/109.  I Know There's Gonna Be(Good Times) featuring Young Thug and Popcaan: This really sounds out of place among the other songs.  But does that make it bad?  No way.  This is one of the catchiest xx related songs.  The beat and synths were made for the club.  The Hip Hop/R&B vocals are delivered undeniably well even if its in a style foreign to others on the album.  I can already see Hip Hop artists hearing this and begging to have Jamie produce for them.  Hopefully the xx's next album explores this style more but without the constant swearing.  The band itself just doesn't work well with vulgar lyrics, but this song does, and I'll be jamming to it all summer.  I can see this being the big hit of the album maybe.  10/1010.  The Rest Is Noise:  This is beautiful 'noise'.  Its dreamy and fast paced production with heavenly vocal howls throughout in the distance remind me of M83.  There is also a synth moment that is very similar if not the same as that of 'SeeSaw' accompanied by a gorgeously elegant piano.  It then transitions into a club song in the last two minutes smoothly.  Its the longest song on the album but it doesn't feel long enough.  I could listen to this alone on replay for hours and not get tired of it.  11/1011.  Girl:  That groovy bass throughout is....groovy.  There is more of those otherworldly vocal chants throughout the song.  Toward the end there is an industrial part that I wish was longer as it also features some nice guitars.  It's a great song and a decent closer to the album, but I feel like the previous song would've closed the album better.  Still good.  9.5/10So this was a great album to vibe to especially for a summer soundtrack and late nights out on the town during any season.  I was on a Pixies binge when this album came out.  They are my favorite group and a totally different sound altogether.  But this album broke me away from that binge.  Thats how worthy and great this is.  If you like The xx, you'll either love this or hate it.  If you love House/Electronic/Dance then you'd be in for a treat with this collection of songs.  I can tell this will be revisited throughout the summer and many summers to come.  Jam to it at home or relax to it.  Use it as background music as you get things down around your place or while you study.  Drive through the night with it as your soundtrack.  Go to the gym and workout/stretch to the vibes of this.  Close your eyes and lay down while the album takes you somewhere in your thoughts.  Open your eyes and maybe even go for a nice stroll if you can with this guiding your steps.  It's basically an electronic album that would work well as a soundtrack to almost anything you do.  I love it, and as I said before, I hope Jamies band The xx explores more of the sounds heard here. These thoughts I've expressed in this review were after at least 5 listens through.  Upon my first listen I wasn't really impressed, but I urge you to push forward with repeated listens like I did so this can fully seep into your mindset.  This is really worth the money whether you download it or buy the actual album.  Probably the best album of any genre in 2015 at the time of its release in my opinion.

I avoided this album upon its initial release because of the mostly mixed to negative reaction from critics compared to the almost unanimous critical praise of their first four albums.  That was a huge mistake and clear example of bad judgement on my part!  I'm actually a newer fan of Pixies and Frank Black, especially since I was born around the time they first broke up.
