I discovered them through many outlets from their inclusion at the end of Fight Club to the comedic cover of 'Here Comes Your Man' on 500 Days of Summer.  I had read about the bands history and how important and groundbreaking their first two albums were.  I completely ignored their albums Bossanova and Trompe for no real good reason at first.  I never really listened to Surfa Rosa but just took the critics words for it.  In fact I never listened to any of their albums entirely until recently, remember my age so give me a pass.  For some reason I decided to check out the Pixies albums in 2015 finally.  But not before I checked out Frank Blacks solo albums.  I only listened to the first two.  Teenager of the Year is now one of my favorites of all time.  So I listened to each of the bands albums fully a few times each.  I didn't like Surfa Rosa as much as everyone else.  Sure its great, but I just never got into it.  Doolittle is of course amazing.  But then came Bossanova and Trompe, which I thought were their worst albums based on lower sales at first which was very stupid of me.  They ended up being my favorite albums of the band, Surfa being my least.  I can already see hipsters shaking their heads and arrogantly blindly disagreeing.I realized finally that I should not give a crap about critics reviews.  I paid too much attention to Pitchfork, who is the almighty hipster music haven.  They worshiped this band but hated this album which turned me off from it.  I'm glad to say I have finally denounced giving a crap about what those hooligans at Pitchfork have to say, good or bad, about any album.  It's mostly the hipsters who are blindly angry at this album just because Kim Deal isn't on it.  But, even though I'm a newer fan of the band, I'm pretty sure I know that Kim herself has said that she is just the bassist and Frank Black is the main man.  Its true.  I never really liked the few songs that Kim wrote for the band which included the overrated 'Gigantic'.  Her absence isn't even that big a deal.  If she had been with the band, she would just be doing bass not writing the songs.  Okay, now onto this album.  The album would only sound slightly different if she was still in the band, and I personally don't care whether she comes back or not, even if she is talented and hot.  This contained some of the most emotional and accessible songs from the band.  Like some have said, this has more in common with Bossanova and Frank Blacks early solo career and that's good.  It does sound more modern.  The songs do sound more radio friendly as a whole compared to the old albums having only a few radio songs per album.  So what if almost every song sounds like it could be a single?  This is why hiipsters are annoying.  They will make an album or band seem horrid if they sound catchy or commercial or dare I say "Mainstream".  I loved the bands hardcore songs like 'Debaser' and 'Tame' but I loved their more melodic and soothing songs like 'Velouria' and 'Letter to Memphis' much more.  This album is full of those 'Velouria' type songs and some harder songs like the opening track 'What Goes Boom' which is vintage harder Pixies.  I can understand why there is much less of the hardcore Pixies sound.  Its simple, Frank is old and I like that hes writing more friendly and soothing songs for the band.  The songs 'Greens and Blues' and 'Indie Cindy' are so beautiful.  'Greens and Blues' particularly has such infectious twirling surf guitars and a chorus that pulls the heartstrings.  I wish that was a hit for the band.  The single 'Bagboy' has a chorus that almost pays homage to Debasers chorus.  By the way the chorus features what sounds like Kim, but isn't.  Every track on here has something special and appealing.  Its not groundbreaking, but it doesn't have to be to be considered great.  Thats what many people nowadays get wrong.  The track 'Ring the Bell' is one of the obvious attempts at a more modern style, and I like it alot.  The guitars are very U2 and heartwarming.  'Another Toe In The Ocean' is another great song full of layered melodies.  'Snake' is what a James Bond Pixies song would sound like.  It's a fast song with some great edgy guitar work and Davids awesome drumming.  People make Kim up to seem like the biggest part of the band.  Sure her bass was nice in some songs, but I'm pretty sure I liked the guitar of Santiago better.  Franks vocals are better and he IS the mastermind of the band from the beginning.  Davids drumming skills are as good as ever too.  He also even had a good lead vocal track on 'La La Love You" from Doolittle.  When I think of a new Pixies album, I dont worry about how often I'll hear Kims backing vocals, I was actually looking forward to David doing more vocals alongside Frank.  Using a female, or anyone that sounds like a female (BagBoy) as a backing vocal on some songs are pure proof that Kims contributions are very replaceable.  If you're not a closeminded hipster who disowns anything from this band without the entire original lineup, then you'll love this album I'm sure.  If you liked Bossanova, you'll love this album.  The melodies Frank and Santiago make on these new songs are just great and stand tall next to what many consider their best albums.  Like I said, even if Kim was still in the band her contribution would be small.  She was barely noticeable in Bossanova and Trompe, yet those were hailed by critics.  This is what the Pixies would sound like today, and it sounds nice.  It's only been a year since Indie Cindy hit stores officially and it's being dismissed a lot.  I say give it 5 to 10 more years and it'll have many critical re-evaluations.  I'm not saying it will be hailed in high regards like Doolittle and Surfa, but I'm sure it will be considered another worthy classic for the band.  Hopefully another hit cult movie uses one of these new songs for a soundtrack and brings in even more new fans.  I really wanna hear more of this new Pixies in the coming years.  If Kim does ever come back, then okay to that.  If she never comes back, then okay to that too, you already know I like this new yet familiar sound the band is producing.I'll consider this the Pixies most accessible album so far.  I like it.  Sorry I ranted on too much about all the dumbfounded naysayers and Kim.  Just know this album really isn't nearly as bad as many are saying.  Give it at least 3 listens before you really decide if you like it.  I know I love it.

I've always liked The Killers.  Sure they had hit or miss albums.  Hot Fuss is a modern classic that brought back sounds of the 80s in good infectious fashion with it's post-punk revival vibe.  Their second album had a change in tone to Heartland Rock similar to early Springsteen, which sounds good on paper but was far from their best album even though the lead single, 'When You Were Young', was one of their most memorable.  Day and Age was slightly better but still a slight downward trend for the band.  I still to this day think that Battle Born is the bands best and most underrated album.  Brandon himself recently disregarded the album, but I think that was mostly because of its lack of success compared to others.  He'll appreciate his Frankenstein monster album soon enough again.  So enough of me being typical and yapping away about The Killers and let me talk about Brandon Flowers and this new album.  Many will disagree but I thought Flowers debut solo album was a near dud.  Sure it had the hit song 'Crossfire' and some other decent songs, but it was not an amazing album.  It just didn't work for me and its no surprise that the sales of the album quickly failed.  This new album on the other hand is a huge breath of fresh air for Flowers solo career.  When I heard the lead single 'Can't Deny My Love', I was blown away but I was worried it would be the 'Crossfire' of the new album, meaning, the only good song.  As he released 3 more songs from the album I was quickly proved wrong as each one seemed to be better than the other.  I'll say this beforehand.  It's impossible to not compare this album to The Killers, because Flowers was the main identifier of the band and his voice and style hasn't really changed much in this solo release.  That being said, remember when I said that Battle Born is The Killers best album?  Well this album is even better.  Here is a track by track review.1. Dreams Come True:  Talk about a great opener!  Such a dreamy and upbeat uplifting pop gem.  The horns throughout are just classy and the chorus is so catchy it gives me a tingly feeling.  The last minute and a half is extra amazing.  Possibly the best opener of Flowers career so far, including that of his band.  10/102. Can't Deny My Love:  The lead single.  I love the song.  Its like a modern take on the classic song "I Need A Hero" but with male vocals.  It's an anthem for sure.  The groovy guitars, the synths, the vocals, the beats, the awesomeness.  It's a shame it hasn't hit as big as it should've.  This is the type of song that sounds like it would dominate the world but it hasn't.  Hopefully it rebounds.  Great song, but believe it or not, it's definitely not the best on the album, which is a good thing.  9.5/103. I Can Change:  This is another one of Flowers U2 inspired songs.  If you hate U2 sorry but this is a compliment to say this sounds like a lost U2 track from the early 90s.  Things start off slow before the beat and synths come in, then comes the heavenly evangelic backing vocals throughout that are similar to U2 hits like "Ultraviolet" and the recent "Iris".  This song just gets better and better.  Great inspiring love song that I'm sure would sound great in a 80s style montage in a movie about a guy trying to win back his girl!  10/104. Still Want You:  At first I wasn't that impressed with the song as a whole when it was released.  But its just so impossibly catchy.  It gets twice as good with each listen and never gives up.  The playful staccato synth thoughout just makes me feel good.  The chorus has an oldschool betty boop feel but if that sounds off putting to some don't worry, it really works.  Another song to win back an ex that you know shouldn't be an ex.  9.5/105. Between Me And You: Another early Springsteen styled song.  It really sounds like it could be among songs like 'Jungleland' and not feel out of place.  Very romantic and emotional track.  I think his vocals are the best on this track.  Sure he doesn't really reach any high notes, but its his overall performance that just impresses so much.  Everything about this song screams romance, and not corny at all.  10/106. Lonely Town:  Just wow.  What a great song this is.  It has everything.  Catchy vocals that you will have stuck in your head.  Awesome attention to detail to every instrumental aspect even if it's just something small in the background.  Great lyrics.  A perfect song.  Some will complain about one certain moment in the song that uses autotune, but ignore those bigots.  This song is something divine.  10/107. Diggin' Up The Heart: Another gem!  This one features a strangely appealing guitar riff in the beginning before it turns into a perfect synth song for the road.  There is this great background synth during the chorus in the second half similar to the opening track of Battle Born that is just pure eargasmic.  Love it.  10/108. Never Get You Right:  Can it be?  Another great song?  Yes!  This is another one that pays so much attention to detail with its little moments you'll miss on your first listen.  This song is meant for headphones or good quality car stereos.  Such a feelgood song with another chorus that you won't get out of your head.  The production is so crisp and beautiful!  10/109. Untangled Love:  Another Springsteen styled song in the verses with a little Bono styled chorus again.  I just love Flowers ability to come up with some of the most beautifully catchy chorus's.  He really knows how to use backing vocals or effects perfectly without sounding generic.  There are nice guitar moments throughout in the slight background throughout too. 9.3/1010. The Way It's Always Been:  A great closer to the album.  Very soothing.  Theres the typical Flowers light Queen styled vocals that sneak up to remind you its there.  But mostly its a laid back and relaxing.  It's definitely not as catchy as the rest but so what?  Just a nice song to sit back and enjoy.  If you don't like it at first, listen to it a few more times and it'll grow.  9/10So this was a much better album than Flowers debut solo effort.  He doesn't stray too far away from the style of The Killers and thats good.  Sorry naysayers but not all solo artists need to break away from the sound that made them loved in the first place.  This is the style of music that Brandon does best.  Honestly if he made an all out Alt Rock album that experimented with wacky sounds too much I think it would've failed.  This is just an all out catchy and beautifully epic pop rock album that does what many recently have tried but failed to do, and that is to perfectly pay homage to the sound of the 80s.  Dare I say it?  I think Flowers took the best part of 80s pop and improved it for a modern album.  Yeah I can already see many of you shaking your heads at that comment but its very true.  Don't be too hipster and realize the truth of this mans genius and musical power.  Yeah honestly this sounds like another Killers album, but much better as I've stated.  I know many will think "But the rest of the band matter too", and thats true, but they don't matter nearly as much as Flowers.  If his band released an album without him, it wouldn't be The Killers.  Flowers voice is the ultimate legacy holder of the band whether its with them or solo.  This album keeps that legacy going.  Hopefully this album finds the success it deserves.  It needs to be heard.  Not overlooked.  If youre a fan of his band, then you'll more than love this album.  If you're new to this mans voice and style, but love the sound of the 80s, then remember my previous comment about that.  If you love good music, you'd be doing your ears a favor in checking this album out.  It's a rare pop album that has no filler and doesn't stop in its quest to make you love it.  Highly recommended.  Its worth the money.  I'd even say you should actually purchase the CD.  Sure you can enjoy it on Spotify, but having this gem physically just makes it that much more endearing.  Your choice though.  Great album.

I originally bought this as a Mothers Day gift.  But upon hearing the actual CD I had to copy it onto my phone too because this is just gorgeously delivered music.  The fact that he covers popular Musical Broadway songs is a major plus.  I listen to a wide variety of genres and I'm a guy who doesn't typically veer toward this genre, but I couldn't resist the appeal of this album.  If you like his style already you'll love this album.  If you need good beautiful powerful music that will bring back memories of musicals such as Willy Wonka or even Sweeney Todd then this is a great addition to your music collection.  I never thought I'd find myself listening to Josh Groban, but here I am and proud of it.  Other men who claim false masculinity against this type of music are fake men.  This is extravagant music for anyone of all ages and gender!  Highly Recommended.  I might even say this could be nominated for Album of the Year.  I can really see this being a megahit.  Just great music you would be insane to pass up on.

I didn't listen to this album when it was first released, mostly because I was only 7 years old at the time.  But I did discover it in 2008 during my freshmen year in High School.  I wasn't emo or anything, but I was drawn to the emotional angst and beauty of this band at that time in my life.  But as years passed by I've stretched my musical taste to a wide variety of genres and ultimately stopped listening to the Post-Grunge/Alternative Metal genre that this band was wrongfully clustered with.  The genre was just a fad that didn't last long and was this bands rise and fall.  I was walking in a used goods store in my town and saw this album for 50 cents.  I remembered how it was a special album along with their followup "Year of the Spider".  So I bought it and all the nostalgia came rushing back as I rediscovered why this was a stand out in the rock music scene of the early 2000s.  Almost all bands associated with Post-Grunge or Alt Metal seem bland and generic.  There were few original bands.  But honestly it's hard to really classify the music of Cold in a single genre.  They were one of the most underrated bands in their prime.  They have made new albums since, but sadly they have crashed downhill.  This album in my opinion was their opus.  It stands out so well against other forgettable bands associated with the genre like Staind or Limp Bizkit.  The best comparison for this band would be the band HURT, but with vocals somewhat similar to Creed or Bush.  Now I mention Creed, but I'm saying this band was much more talented and original during this albums release.  The instruments are so melodic and sonic.  The vocals are so crisp.  Sometimes they have a raw nature to them and sometimes they have this gorgeously emotional delivery.  This is in my opinion one of the most beautiful alternative metal albums.  Its definitely one of the most thoughtful as well.  Here is a track by track review.1. Just Got Wicked:  The guitars are rocking right away.  The verses are grungy followed by a chorus that channels Nirvana.  Wicked opener to a classic.  9.5/102. She Said:  The song begins with a gorgeous piano that almost brings me to tears with each listen before it turns into a groovy grungy rock song.  This one features another angsty grunge chorus that just works well.  The guitars are echoey and thoughtful.  9/103. No One:  The big hit from the album.  The emotion in the vocals of this song are just unheard of.  The background vocals are so haunting and make this song one of the best from the band.  The guitar riff is hauntingly emotional as well.  A song with depressing lyrics that doesn't bum you out at all!  In fact I think this is motivating.  10/104. End Of The World:  The way Scooter delivers the verses just sounds cool.  The chorus makes it sound like it could've been a hit if released as a single.  The guitar chimes that sneak in the background throughout are nice especially with headphones.  9.5/105. Confession:  Such a beautiful guitar riff.  The verses sound so soothing in a way before the rocking chorus hits.  Should've been a single in my opinion as well.  The power in the vocals complimented by the guitars is just perfection.  Another one of the bands best.  10/106. t's All Good:  Another example of the band complimenting soft relaxing guitar and laid back vocals with rocking choruses.  This is an anthem that I wish more people knew!  Its all good!  9.5/107. Send In The Clowns:  One of the heavier songs on the album featuring Aaron Lewis of Staind.  I still think this band deserved more fame than them though.  This is included to satisfy the Nu Metal fans back when the genre was big.  The chorus is similar to 'Just Got Wicked'.  Its a good hard song to work out to.  The ending with the screams of 'Send in the Clowns' isn't that appealing anymore.  There's a reason Nu Metal only lasted a few years.  Still a good song!  8.5/108. Same Drug:  Back to what the band did best, grungy artsy emotional ballads with rocking anthem choruses.  The bridge section features some overlapping vocals that are trippy but nice.  The guitars are just so great!  9/109. Anti-Love Song:  The angriest song on the album.  I don't listen to music like this anymore on a regular, but I can't resist the appeal of this song.  It's so angry but it doesn't sound too over the top like screamo or some heavy metal vocals.  Great song to work out to.  I'd compare the nature of the vocals in this song to Trent Rexnor in Nine Inch Nails 'Downward Spiral' album.  9.5/1010. Witch:  The guitar screeches through the verses and rocks through the chorus.  The female vocal howls are haunting but just work so well accompanied by Scooters rocking crooning.  The last half of the song are the best part.  9/1011. Sick Of Man:  The lyrics are depressing but don't confuse this with emo at all.  I find this to be a very introspective song lyrically.  The instrumentation of this song is further proof of why this band stood out from the multiple copies of copies of bands that crowded the scene when this band was at their prime.  This sounds like if The Cure tried to do Alternative Metal and succeeded.  10/1012. Outerspace:  Another awesome rocker of a song.  The guitar riff just gets the blood flowing switching from screeching to twirling in the background to plain rocking out.  The bridge contains an awesome Cure-y guitar riff before rocking out till the end of the song.  Oh and as always Scooter just brings the goodies with his vocal style.  This is the best all out rocker on the album.  10/1013.  Bleed:  After 12 emotional rock anthems comes this acoustic ballad to calm down the vocals.  This is a very very beautiful song about the love for music.  This just feels so relaxing and inspiring somehow.  Great swan song for the album.  10/10So this is without a doubt the Colds masterpiece.  It was appealing enough to open the door for their mainstream success at the time and different enough to set them apart from the dozens of bands during the time all trying to recycle the same style.  Sadly those other bands who were much less talented(Creed, Puddle of Mudd, Nickelback) prevented this band from really reaching superstardom.  Their album after this "Year of the Spider" is their close second best album.  It hit big with the song 'Stupid Girl' and contained even more melody and emotion.  Sadly after that album their key guitarists left the band, one joining Evanescence.  That really put a major dent in the bands chances at becoming a household name.  In fact, even though some people like the bands recent albums, I'm telling you they seem to have lost their way and appeal.  This is a classic.  As a guy who abandoned the post-grunge/alt metal bands like most for indie rock and 80s synth revival sounds among other genres, I'm telling you this band was a diamond in the rough of the genre.  Seeing the cheap price here on amazon for this album and "Year of the Spider" I suggest you purchase both if you need a reminder of the sound that almost dominated rock in the early 2000s.  I'm glad I rediscovered this album after all these years and I hope many others do and keep it alive.

I loved Mumford and Sons first album.  I only somewhat liked their second album despite it surprisingly winning Album of the Year.  I never really cared much more for the band.  In fact I didn't even care to watch their music videos so I actually forgot what they even looked like.  When the band announced that they would be going 'electric' I was excited.  I said I loved their first album, but I would take synths and electric guitars over banjos any day.  So my first thought was that they were going to follow in the steps of Arcade Fire who went into disco indie rock territory with the post Album of the Year album Reflektor.  The lead single "Believe" was released and my hopes for a Mumford Reflektor went out the window.  I loved the song but it didn't seem worth the hype.  They also released "The Wolf" which was also a decent song but far from their claims of real 'electric'.  I didn't discount the album yet though.  I wanted to know for sure what the band considered electric.  So the album finally came out and I decided to preview it a few times on Spotify before considering buying the actual CD.  I'm glad I didn't buy it.  I listened to it through 5 times and it just didn't click.  They went sorta electric, but somehow they got even more boring.  Some of the hooks in the songs are catchy but very forgettable.  The lyrics are so cheesy and cringe worthy most of the time.  The only decent songs that save this from getting a 1 star rating from me are 'Believe', 'The Wolf'', 'Hot Gates', 'Only Love' and 'Snake Eyes'.  But even those songs are forgettable aside from the lead single.  Also note that only one of those songs isn't a single.  I really don't remember any of the hooks.  I said some of them were catchy, but I can't sing a note of any of the songs if you paid me to.  The so called electric guitar riffs were so bland.  This will sound hipster, but its also true, the band has become generic and boring.  This isn't them experimenting.  This is them preparing for their downfall.  Not all bands have everlasting success.  I predict this will be the beginning of the fading of Mumford.  This album might do well in its first weeks on sale but it will fall off quick.  The band needs to really concentrate if they wanna get up from this slump.  I can see some people enjoying and even loving this album, but that doesn't mean its good.  I see more people hating it.  I tried to like it and not be part of the group, but its hard when the album really is as bad as people say.  If you're a hardcore fan of the band, then I dont know what to tell you.  You could gamble a few bucks on this album, but I suggest you listen to it online first and see if you like it first.  Like I said, some people will love it, but more people will hate it.  Proceed into this album with caution, especially if you're a fan of good music.

I tried to give them a chance after Adam left.  I tried to not be one of those who automatically dismisses someone for a line up change like this.  I really tried.  But the band just isn't the same.  They shouldn't even use the Three Days Grace name anymore with this new guy and sound.  People try to say bands need to experiment and explore new sounds.  That's true.  But at least when most bands experiment and explore, they keep their core sound intact.  This new guy is the ultimate downfall of TDG.  It's true.  Hardcore fans will stick around by the handful only.  But after this album, say goodbye to anyone caring about the bands new material.  If bands like System of a Down or Disturbed or Korn or any of these bands changed their lead vocalist, their would be an outcry.  Adams voice was a trademark to TDG.  This is full of 'ok' at best songs that sound like they would be hits in 2002.  Like I said, I tried to give this new guy a chance.  He just isn't good.  When you heard Adam you knew it was TDG.  Half the time when I hear these new songs I forget I'm even listening to this band anymore.  I've listened to the album 5 times and it doesnt work.  I'm glad I didn't buy it.  If you simply are one of the people who can't let go of the band no matter what because youre a mega hardcore fan who can't move on, then you should buy this.  If you like Three Days Grace, stay away from this.  This is one of those examples where its okay to use the phrase "their old stuff was better" and not sound like an overbearing hipster.  This is a band trying too hard to move on just to make money even if it's with horrible music.  This is a prime example of when a lead singer becomes so important to a band that they matter more than the rest in brutal honesty.  Take a look at the new Breaking Benjamin song, another band of similar genres.  The only remaining member of that band is the lead singer and their new stuff sounds amazing and refreshing.  This is very bad.  Goodbye Three Days Grace.  Live off of your royalties from previous albums and songs that you should really thank Adam for.  If you like good music, for the goodness of your sanity, stay far far away from this failing record.

Like most so far, I discovered Future Islands from their masterpiece breakthrough album "Singles" and their amazing showstopping performance on Letterman.  They had this unique but familiar sound that was irresistible.  The lead singer had this raspy soulful voice accompanied by lavish synths and lush guitars with nice 80's style beats.  It was truly a career changing album for them and I'm glad it shot them into the spotlight.  It's also interesting for me to know that they are from a town near my small town which is rare.  So I listened to Singles over and over without even thinking of their past work.  But one day I couldn't help it and had to check out their early albums.  I am so happy that I did because this album and "On The Water" are amazing in their own rights.  I would pick this album between the two as the better though.  I couldn't find a copy anywhere in the US so I had to order it on here.  I controlled myself not to listen to it on Spotify or any other site before it arrived.  It was well worth the wait.  After a few listens already here is a track by track review.1. Walking Through That Door:  The album starts off quick with this emotional song for the dance floor.  The synth riff in this is simple but impossibly catchy.  Sam's singing is on spot as expected.  Great intro song to a great album.  10/102.  Long Flight:  Another perfect synth riff with rolling drums and bass.  Sam has a different sound to his vocals on this.  It's almost like he's trying to imitate Elvis, but failing, and sounding great at the same time.  The final repetition of the chorus hits this note that is just pure gold.  Great song to listen to while thinking over a relationship.  10/103.  Tin Man:  This band just keeps bringing the awesome synth riffs.  Sam does another uniquely raspy thing to his vocals on this.  My girlfriend jokingly said his voice almost resembles Dracula.  It's a funny thought, but when listening to this song, it kinda works.  There is a sneaky guitar in the background too and I love it.  I just wish it was longer!  9.5/104.  An Apology:  Right off the bat this sounds like a companion song to "Long Flight".  They really sound like they should've been placed back to back with each other.  It's such a relaxing song.  The synth in this one almost resembles a magical flute its so enchanting.  Again Sams raspy crooning voice works well against this relaxing beautiful backdrop of a song.  10/105.  In Evening Air: Usually I don't really like interludes especially on short albums.  But this one was just so good.  It was soothing and hauntingly beautiful.  It went by fast and led into the next song so well.  9/106.  Swept Inside:  This song has more guitars upfront with the synths in the background.  I'd compare this instrumentally to The Cure.  The vocals are more relaxed on this one even though the song is very upbeat.  The final 90 seconds of the song have Sam repeating a refrain that just sounds like a lullaby.  Another great great song.  10/107.  Inch Of Dust:  Can this band do no wrong?  Another amazing song?  I think so.  The way the instruments of this song work together is just insane.  It's like a small orchestra.  Another great song for pining over a relationship.  Just perfect.  It does end abruptly though.  10/108.  Vireo's Eye:  This song has a speedy vibe to it.  This sounds like the perfect song for a movie where the main character hurries to their lovers place full of passion only to find that they are with someone else.  It's a sad song delivered in a happy way.  Very nicely done.  10/109.  As I Fall:  I always hold higher standards for the closing songs of any album.  Usually I feel disappointed, but not with this.  Such a beautiful and tragic song.  Not only is this the best song on this perfect album, but it's the longest too.  So more to enjoy.  The atmosphere is just so haunting and heartbreaking.  But I love it!  The song ends with 2 minutes of gorgeous textured music that slowly fades.  It really feels like the ending to a movie that you never get tired of watching.  10/10So this ended up being one of the best albums I've ever heard.  I don't say that lightly as I've listened to many albums from genres all over.  I'm glad this band got noticed with their Singles album.  If not for that I wouldn't have ever heard this masterpiece.  Hopefully their next album takes the band even further so more people check out this album and "On The Water".  If you are here because you found out about Future Islands because of their newer albums and want to know if they had that spunk early in their career, then look no further.  This album will no doubt be considered a classic in years to come.  It already is one for me.  As I've said, I've listened to many albums so far in my life and I can say proudly that this is instantly in my top 10 all time favorites.  If you're a Future Islands fan, then this album is a must.  I might even say I like this better than Singles.  If you are new to the band, then this is a must as well.  If you just like good music to take you to special places every time you hear it, then this album is a definite must.  Highly recommended.  I just know this will be highly regarded and in high demand very soon!

I'm not trying to sound hipster even though it may sound like it when I say I will always think "Transatlanticism" is the bands greatest album.  Through the years after that album the band still made great music with each release, but I always found myself secretly wanting another album that hit me in all the same ways as the aforementioned album.  Then comes this album.  This collection really sounds like a spiritual successor to the big T.  It left me with that same feeling of raw emotion.  Feeling sad like I just experienced a break up, but at the same time hopeful even if only for a bit.  I always thought that "Black Sun" wasn't as great of a lead single as others from the band.  It grew on me, but then I heard the radio edit of the song and was even more disappointed.  The radio edit cut out a good minute worth of the best moments of the song.  So if you're a newcomer and you're here because of that radio edit, then I assure you the album version has more to offer!  Other instant classics include the should-be-lead-single song "No Room In Frame" which is a great break up song of course as most of the songs are.  This song contains guitar moments very very reminiscent of the big T's elegant hopeless style that I loved.  "You've Haunted Me All My Life" is a beautifully tragic musical account of failure to keep a relationship kindled in the vein of "Tiny Vessels", which is their best song ever in my opinion.  But unlike that song, now the narrator is the one who "don't mean a thing" to her.  "The Ghosts Of Beverly Drive" is just infectious even if the chorus gets a bit repetitious.  "Everything's A Ceiling" is an undeniably catchy song about, you guessed it, unrequited love, a topic that will never grow old in music!  The topic of being far away from the one you love while she/he is with someone else constantly replaying in your head is just so sad and true for many.  "Little Wanderer" has a great REM style hook about it.  "El Dorado" is a glider of a song with soaring vocals and more great tragically beautiful instrumentation as you'd expect from the band.  The final song "Binary Sea" is another example of the bands epic song per album like the big T title track and Codes and Keys epic sad anthem "Unobstructed Views".  Though this one is notably shorter, but nonetheless epic and gorgeous.  I didn't mention every single song but I assure you they all have something special about them.  If you are going through a break up or divorce, you'll find this album helpful in coping.  Even if you aren't in a sad state of mind this album has the ability to catch your attention and not bum you out but instead have you hooked on its beauty and execution.  This isn't the best album from the band, but it's still great.  I suggest putting this album and Transatlanticism in a playlist together and hitting shuffle.  The songs on both albums work so well together.  Or just listen to it by itself.  If you're a fan of the band you'll love it or you wont.  If you're new to the group you'll love it or you wont.  I can't say everyone will love the album, but I can say if you give it a chance that after a few listens it might be one of your favorites.  I dont know, just preview the songs, especially the ones I mentioned, and if you like what you hear then I strongly recommend you buying this album.P.S.  Too bad this is the last album with Chris Walla.

I haven't been a fan of the band since the beginning. I love the band but they were never in my top 10 favorite all time music artists. Honestly I discovered them through their album "We Were Dead Before The Ship Even Sank". I loved the nautical theme and sound of it. I still considered it my favorite release from the band. Then I listened to "Good News For People Who Love Bad News". I had known the hit song "Float On" but never really looked into the band before. Many consider it one of their better albums, but I personally only liked half of the songs. I then worked my way backward through the bands discography. Their landmark album "The Lonesome Crowded West" was my second favorite. I'm sure many hardcore fans will strongly disagree and say it's the greatest thing from the band, but that's just my personal opinion. So after initially discovering the bands music, they seemed to stop making music. I would eagerly wait for the bands next move for 3 years, which is how long most albums are released apart from each other. I eventually virtually gave up on any new material from the band around 2012 as many other bands and artists were releasing great albums from different genres. Then suddenly near the end of 2014 their was news of a new single "Lampshades on Fire". All of my hope was instantly reignited as I heard the thumping pop rocker of a track knowing a new album would follow shortly after. The song proved to be another hit and I'm glad the band has showed they can still be relevant in the constantly changing music scene. In the months leading up to the album they released 4 more swell songs which only made my anticipation even greater. I waited 8 years for this album, and I am not one bit disappointed with the outcome. Here is a track by track review.1. Strangers To Ourselves: This is such a relaxing introduction song. The violins throughout are heavenly. The vocals are just gorgeous along with the faint guitars throughout. Just beautiful. 10/102. Lampshades On Fire: I'm sure if you're new to the band this is the reason you're here. This was a worthy lead single that almost explores all of the sounds the band has experimented with in their career. It's a rock song good for parties with lyrics that mean so much more. Brock showcases his distinct lispy ranty vocals with sprinkles of his more elegant singing in such great fashion. Just great. 9.5/103. Sh*t In Your Cut: Nice title right? This song starts out slowish with plucking drums before the guitars steal the show. The vocals are more of the mix between Brocks chanting and singing. The song ends with great group vocals that the band does best. 9.5/104. Pistol: This song seems to be getting hate from many. Many have gone as far as to call it one of the bands worst. I can understand why many dislike it. The vocal effect used in the song can sound annoying at first. The style of the song is very different for the band sounding like a rip off of 80s Depeche Mode. I however got over it and actually think the song is fun and gets better with repetition. Not their best, but not horrible at all. 8/105. Ansel: Back to typical MM. This is a glowing track with colorful melodies and a nice guitar riff. The song sounds almost tropical in a way but has dark lyrics. Its a short song but it such a profound lasting effect to it. 9/106. The Ground Walks, With Time In A Box: Another interesting title. This is another of the songs released leading up to the album. The band takes a stylistic detour into disco rock. I thought it sounded similar to the style Arcade Fire explored in Reflektor. The song is full of funky and spacious guitars and horns and twists and turns. Around the 2 minute mark the chorus hits with what can be described as entrancing and very original. I wish it was repeated more than twice though. A friend of mine called this one of the best songs he's ever heard, and that's coming from a guy who wasn't familiar with the band. At 6 minutes this song flies by with style. 10/107. Coyotes: Another slower song. It was released shortly after 'Lampshades' with a very adorable video of a coyote. The soft guitar riff is nice but the chorus is just elegantly delivered. It almost brings about tears with its beauty. I'll compare this to the previous albums 'Little Motel' but this is honestly better. Just a beautiful dreamy song all around. One of the best from the band. 10/108. Pups To Dust: This song returns to the sound of earlier MM with its relaxing westernized guitars. It really sounds like a lost track from 'Lonesome Crowded West'.  It's another anthem for the band with lyrics that mean so much. The mood of this song is melancholy but not in a bad way. It's another dreamy song. 9/109. Sugar Boats: This song returns to the nautical style of their last album with some carnival sounds as well but without Johnny Marr(Sadly). The guitars are nice and rocking still and interesting horns are prominent throughout. Its a fun song from beginning to end. 9/1010. Wicked Campaign: This song almost dives into heartland rock territory but maintains the indie sound. It's a very catchy song of course. The chorus has that U2 stadium appeal. It's a song that leaves me with a feeling of being inspired. 9/1011. Be Brave: The song title says it all. The vocals are more of the chanting with the quiet laid back singing sliding in now and again. Reminds me of their song "Florida" just a bit. 8.5/1012. God Is An Indian And You're An A**hole: One of the longer more interesting titles, but the shortest song. The title might offend some, but the song is executed nicely. Not one of my favorites though. I'm sure many others will like it more. 7.8/1013. The Tortoise And The Tourist: The trademark guitar style of early MM is back on here again. Its another rocker with a haunting tone. It manages to be a bit harsh and melodic at the same time. The chorus is strangely addicting in a way that pumps you up. 8.5/1014. The Best Room: One of my all time favorites. I've replayed it more than 100 times before the albums released and never grow tired of it. For a time it became my gym soundtrack. The lyrics are reportedly about a UFO experience that led to a certain tacky hotel. The guitars are great and instant classic riffs. The vocals switch between chanting and singing perfectly. It's a beautiful rocking song. The bridge section with intertwined vocals is infectious. I would compare this to "Steam Engenius" but catchier. One of the bands best. 10/1015. Of Course We Know: This is a dark toned closer for the album. Very apocalyptic in a way. I compared the style to Sigur Ros but with vocals from Brock. The guitar style on this one is very Post Rock. When I first heard it I didn't think it was amazing. But now I think its the perfect ending. The background vocals compliment the lead singing in a strangely touching way. It's a powerful outro song. 9/10So this album was a nice reminder of how great this band is. This is a musical journey as cliche as that sounds. It manages to be strange yet appealing at the same time throughout. You will need to be able to devote your full attention to fully enjoy all of the intricate aspects of the songs. I know I will continue to find new things in each song. I might even find a new favorite in a song that I previously didn't think was the best. It's a great soundtrack for driving or just background music at home depending on your mood. Some have said the album seems too long. I think the longer the better honestly. More music to digest! I won't say this is my favorite album from the band fully, but I can say for now it's a tie with this and "We Were Dead". If you're already a MM fan you'll either love this or at least somewhat like it. If you're new to the band and you liked 'Lampshades' you'll love the album. If you like good new music then give this a listen and see if you like it. 8 years and not only is this album worth it, but the band says a follow up album is on its way. Hopefully as great as this album if not better!

I remember when "Night Visions" first came out.  Imagine Dragons was virtually unknown.  I purchased the album the day it came out partially as an impulse buy and partially because of the sleeper hit song "It's Time".  The album had a familiar yet unique catchy sound that I really enjoyed.  They aren't in my top 10 favorite artists, but I thoroughly liked them immediately.  Then the song 'Radioactive' became one of the biggest hits of 2013 and propelled the band into super stardom.  I digged the song, but I honestly never really loved it like most.  Mostly because it just didn't fit the style of the majority of the other songs.  Some other bands even rode along with the success of the band with similar sounds such as American Authors.  There were also the detractors.  People who labeled the band the next "Nickelback" in a negative way.  Needless to say, I was anxious for their next move.  Their second album would decide whether the band was a fluke or in for the long run.  Finally they released their lead single for their second disc.  "I Bet My Life" had the same sound as many of the songs from NV but with a slight soulful backdrop.  I enjoyed it nonetheless.  They released another song titled "Gold" which I was disappointed in initially because of its electronic sound trying to emulate "Radioactive" but just sounding much less memorable.  I was starting to not feel that interested in buying the new album in fear of it having too much of the electronic 'Radioactive' ripoff sound.  Before I spoke too soon they released yet another song which was said to be the official second single "Shots".  The title suggests party shots, but the songs lyrics turned out to be so deeply beautiful and infectiously delivered in a dance rock manner that I was excited again for Smoke and Mirrors.  Well when the album finally arrived I was actually feeling questionable about buying it again, partially due to the long wait for it.  I wasn't the only one apparently since the Best Buy didn't even bother to take the album out of the storage yet on its release day until I asked about it.  But I still bought it, like Night Visions, as an impulse buy.  I read many mixed critics reviews feeling like I had wasted money before I even listened to it.  I'm glad I can say that most critics are dead wrong about the album.  Sure it's not the most amazing thing ever, but it's still a good modern album that I'm positive many will come to love.  Here is my track by track review.1.  Shots:  This is a great dance rock track.  I'm sure this will be a hit at clubs and parties.  The lyrics aren't happy or sad.  They are somewhat gloomy in a nice way.  The guitars are nice.  There are the typical Imagine Dragon chants throughout but the slower delivery of some of the verses are the best for me.  The chorus will pull on your heart strings and make you wanna get up and dance.  Add this to your workout playlist.  Great start to the album.  9.5/102.  Gold:  I said earlier I was initially disappointed with this song when it was first released.  But I've grown to like it.  Still not among my favorites though.  I do like the whistle hook.  The lyrics do have some good meaning.  The chorus wasn't my favorite either but it still manages to get stuck in my head.  The guitar toward the end is a highlight.  Not a great song but not bad at all.  8/103.  Smoke and Mirrors:  The song starts off slow and gentle like 'Demons' before exploding into a somewhat unexplosive catchy chorus.  The final two minutes were a nice surprising and soothing ending to the track.  This song will get better and better with repeated listens.  The guitar solo is really nice!  Something you haven't heard from this band.  Gives it a classic rock feel with modern touches!  9/10.4.  I'm So Sorry:  People have compared this track musically to The Black Keys.  Its hard to deny it because if you played this song to me I wouldn't guess it was Imagine Dragons, but it is.  But then again, whose to say what sounds like ID and what doesn't this early in their career.  It's a nice rocking song.  The bridge part with what sounds like female background vocals is the best part.  This is the type of song you'd hear in a action movie trailer.  Another workout playlist worthy song.  8.5/105.  I Bet My Life:  This song didn't hit big leading up to the albums release.  Well not by ID standards.  But it's grown on me so much I'm surprised it hasn't become such a mega hit yet.  I'm confident that this song will have longevity to become a big hit, as "Radioactive" didn't hit big until long after it's initial release.  The chorus is impossible not to have on replay in your head.  The soulful background mixed with folk guitar and a rocking chorus are the recipe for a great rock anthem!  Very personal lyrics for Dan but also very universal at the same time.  Great song that sounds even better among the rest of the album.  9.5/106.  Polaroid:  This is a nice playful song with a nice melody throughout.  There's a hip hop feel to the delivery of the verses.  There are also nice 'doo doo doo' moments throughout and group vocals.  People seem to look down on constant "whoahhh"s in songs nowadays but this song uses them well.  The soulful bridge section till the end sounds like something from a Hozier track.  Some have said this song is a filler but I like it.  Just a nice feelgood song.  9/107.  Friction:  There are nice Middle Eastern style guitars in this one you don't hear often in music nowadays.  Brings back memories of System of a Down.  The yelled vocals almost remind me of Michael Jacksons vocal delivery.  This is a rocker.  It changes tempo throughout nicely.  Another addition to your gym routine as well.  9/108.  It Comes Back To You:  This song has a great guitar hook thats similar to U2, more specifically their song "When I Look At The World".  Thats meant as a compliment.  Immediately this is a candidate for hit single.  Probably the catchiest song on the album!  I just love this song.  The vocals.  The guitars.  The 90s laid back drums.  The production.  I hope they release this as a single.  I hope it doesn't become this albums "Amsterdam", the best track from their debut that wasn't released as a single.  You wont get this out of your head!  10/109.  Dream:  Leave it to this band to follow a great song with another great song.  This is a hauntingly beautiful ballad.  The chorus is just delivered in a heartbreakingly gorgeous manner.  Their are string instrument moments that just add to the beauty.  An instant classic.  10/1010.  Trouble:  This sounds like it was Bruce Springsteen inspired and I like it.  It doesn't fit well with the rest of the tracks stylistically, but it's still good.  Its a really fun and uplifting song.  Not the best, but still nice.  8.5/1011.  Summer:  The title says it all.  This is a great summer track.  It's another dance-rock track with a nice eerie effect in the hook.  It really does feel like a song to listen to while driving through a summer sunset.  I didn't think the chorus was special at first but like many great ones it grew on me soon after.  The guitars are nice as always too.  9/1012.  Hopeless Opus:  The verses are hip hop tinted and playful like in 'Polaroid'.  I think someone else also said this and I agree, that this sounds like a male version of Lorde in the chorus.  Guitar solo is a highlight of course.  This is just another decent feelgood song.  Nothing wrong with that.  8.5/1013.  The Fall:  The moment this song opened I knew I was in for a great closer to the album!  This is the perfect song to end the album like a credits song.  There's something tragic yet uplifting about the music and lyrics and vocal delivery that works so well.  This is a progressive pop rock song.  It also has a beautiful cinematic feel as it builds to its climax.  I'm glad this track lasts the entire 6 plus minutes.  It's a very gorgeous ending that leaves you wanting more. 10/10So this album left me wondering what was going on in most of the critics heads who gave scathing negative reviews for this album.  They seem to hate catchy stadium music in a biased manner.  I would take this over some of the trash some critics hail as great albums.  This isn't the next 'Nickelback'(which is a horrible comparison), this is Imagine Dragons and they have made another classic pop rock album.  I might even say it's better as a whole than Night Visions.  Night Visions had at least 4 tracks I would skip.  If you liked their first album, you will definitely more than enjoy this album.  It's another different yet familiar sound for the band.  If you aren't even a fan of the band and just like good music then this is recommended.  Sure its not the best album of all time.  But it's not trying to be.  It's trying to be an accessible album with great hooks and fun melodies with some dark moments sprinkled around.  I'm not saying all critics are wrong.  But in the case with this album and plenty of others, they did get it wrong.  We all have opinions, but to trash this album the way some have is just unbelievable.  I went into this disc expecting something horrible based on critic reviews and I was surprised at how much I loved it.  This isn't a sophomore slump, well unless it ends up bombing in sales, which I doubt will happen.  I'm not forcing anyone to buy this album, but if you like good music and are willing to pay for it, then this is the album for you.  Highly recommended.

I'm a newer fan of The Smiths.  I was born in 1993 so sadly I didn't grow up with them.  I'm also not a hipster like most people my age who know the band.  I honestly discovered them through the movie 500 Days of Summer when their song "Please Please Please Let Me Get What I Want" was used perfectly in it.  But at the time of discovery I still didn't really listen to the band other than just a few songs like their singles.  Then suddenly in 2014 I had an urge to really listen to the bands catalog.  I read about the bands formation and career and break up.  I listened to their album "The Queen Is Dead" and loved it.  That was just the beginning for me.  I decided to give Morrisseys solo career a chance and when I went to my local used goods store I found them to have one album from Morrissey which I impulsively bought.  That was my first Morrissey/Smiths related purchase.  It was "You Are The Quarry".  I had no prior knowledge of the album and I was blown away by its beauty, humor and amazing execution.  I then ordered "Vauxhall And I", another Morrissey solo album, which became one of my instant top 10 favorite albums of all time.  I was not far from done.  I listened to a mix of The Smiths first two and fourth albums and Morrisseys "Bona Drag" and loved them.  Then I was stricken with whether I wanted to order "Hatful of Hollow" or "Louder Than Bombs"(or why not both?), and I decided on this one after giving Hatful and listen on Spotify.  24 tracks and over 70 minutes?  I think yes.  So now I have LTB and I've listened to it 5 times already so far.  I can confidently say this is now my favorite release from The Smiths, yes even more than TQID!The collection is too long for me to give my usual track by track review, but let me just tell you that every single track is a hit with me.  I never find myself skipping over any of these songs the way I eventually do with most albums.  My favorites are the incredibly catchy "Ask" with its nice background effect and singalong chorus, the relaxing steamroller "Half A Person", the quick but infectious "William...", and the pop masterpiece "Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now" among others.  There are so many good songs I am constantly discovering more and more with repeated listens.  Even the cover song "Golden Lights", which some consider the dud on the album, is actually really catchy and great in my opinion.  The two best slow relaxer songs for me are "Please Please Please..." and "Asleep" which ends the album ethereally making the ending feel like the end to a good dream, except unlike most dreams, you can actually repeat this as many times as you can.  Johnny Marrs guitarwork throughout is top notch.  My favorite example of his guitar skills are on "Rubber Ring", "Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now" and "This Night Has Opened My Eyes", but his craft is evident throughout as well!  Morrissey is just amazing of course.  He has such an uncanny ability to command any melody given to him with humorous and meaningful lyrics.  He can go from his usual baritone to falsetto with ease and divine skill.  I actually like these songs over many of the songs on their actual studio albums.  The song "Back To The Old House" is one of the bands most gorgeously tragic ballads.  This is the bands essential release.  The album that I'm sure is able to convert any music lover into a fan.  It is fun.  It is emotional.  It is amazing.  You'll find yourself unable to get many of these songs out of your head throughout the day.  This isn't 80s music.  This is timeless music.  For fans of good music that will never get old.

I still remember my first encounter with MM music.  It was in 1998 when I was only five years old.  My oldest brother was showing me the music video for 'The Dope Show'.  I was traumatized by the appearance of The Goddess Bunny toward the end whom my brother had convinced me was 'Bloody Mary'.  Well you can imagine I steered away from MM music as I grew up after that only really knowing and liking their song 'Beautiful People'.  But in 2011 I suddenly had the urge to look into the band after learning that one of my favorite musicians Trent Reznor had worked closely with the band early in their career.  I began reading about the bands history and the true nature of their songs.  I'm glad I suddenly gave this band a chance that year as I listened to each and every album in a weeks time during my time in Miami, a city that Brian Warner had spent some time in before truly forming the band.  I loved his Trilogy albums.  I liked Grotesque.  I only subtly enjoyed his recent albums after that.  'Born Villain'  was a step in the right direction for the band for me.  But it still lacked in my opinion.  I enjoy music of a wide variety from rock to rap to dance to pop.  To put that in perspective, the next album I'm looking forward to in 2015 is from Modest Mouse, a very different genre from MM.  Recently their haven't been many good metal or hard rock albums in the past few years.  It was almost like the genre was dying.  The last somewhat hardcore music album I purchased was NIN 2013 album.  Then in 2014 when I heard the single 'Third Day of a Seven Day Binge' I was instantly back on track.  Too many people dismiss Marilyn Manson immediately just based on his appearance and costumes.  But most people have no idea how intricate and powerful his lyrics are and how impressive the bands instrumentations can be.  If someone saw me on the street they wouldn't guess that I listen to this band, but that doesn't matter.  What matters is how solid this album turned out to be.  But I must say I do like Mansons attire in the cover of the album, which I also think is the best album cover of their career.  It's almost Joker--esque.  Though I've said I listened to all of the bands albums, this is honestly my first actual album I've purchased from them, and it was worth it.  Here is my track by track review.1.  Killing Strangers:  As Brian has stated, this song showcases the blues inspired style right away.  The guitars are rocking throughout with some of that haunting vibe the band is known for.  Great powerful vocals too.  9.5/102.  Deep Six:  I honestly didn't really like this song at first when it was released.  But like most hit singles, it grew on me like a parasite.  This album version with its slow intro build up was nice and made it a much better song to me.  Great lyrics.  Great industrial track that I hope brings back the popularity of this genre!  9/103.  Third Day of a Seven Day Binge:  One of the best songs by the band ever.  Definitely the best track from them in over 10 years too in my opinion.  This song is just sexy.  Mysterious.  Brooding.  The raspy crooning by Warner is just infectious.  The guitar work is perfect.  Like many are saying, this is one of the prime examples on the album of how mature and evolved the band is even without its original members.  10/104.  The Mephistopheles of Los Angeles:  I like to think I'm intelligent, but I really did have to look up the word in the title.  I'm liking the guitar style of this album already!  Warners vocals are laid back for such a rocking song, but I love it.  9/105.  Warship My Wreck:  Gotta love the wordplay.  This one starts slow and brooding before suddenly the band somewhat kicks off in this steamrolling way.  Its really nice on the ears.  The vocals are some of the most emotionally powerful I've heard in this band in a long time.  This one reminds me of some of NINs more apocalyptic work musically.  The final minute features some haunting group vocal work that just works well too.  Great midpoint song.  10/106.  Slave Only Dreams To Be King:  The song begins with a sample of a speech, and ironically the vocal style of this one is almost speech-like.  Another great industrial track meant to be played loud though.  Great pumping song to add to your workout playlist as well.  Deep lyrics that showcase much more than what the title suggests!  9/107.  The Devil Beneath My Feet:  I read a critic compare this album slightly to the band Interpol in its sound.  This song is the song that makes that comparison almost legit.  I wouldn't mind hearing this dance rocker in a club.  There is a nice electronic area within the song that surprisingly works amazingly well!  Don't be fooled again by the title, this is a deep song with great meaning and some of the best guitar work from MM in a while.  I would choose this as a single.  10/108.  Birds of Hell Awaiting:  Aside from MMs appearance, it's these titles that make some people think this is a satanic band which is entirely false.  The lyrics will state otherwise.  Even though this has haunting hell-ish howling within the song, the song is still good.  The bass is nice similar just a bit to that of The Dope Show.  The guitar riff is very bluesy and nice.  Not my favorite, but it could grow on me more.  8.5/109.  Cupid Carries A Gun:  Infectious and creepy good.  There is even more of that raspy crooning very similar to Third Day Binge.  There is even a nice bell toll throughout.  This song just works all around.  One of the best on the album and will surely be another great single.  Also another great workout playlist addition!  9.5/1010.  Odds of Even:  A slow burner closer and its great as expected.  Just masterful guitar work throughout.  Things almost reach orchestral quality toward the end.  Epic end to this unexpected classic.  9/10As everyone is saying, this is much more mature than you'd expect from this band.  Each song works as a piece to a puzzle.  This album would be incomplete if any instance of the record was gone.  I know I've praised the vocals and guitars throughout, but I almost forgot to mention the great overall production from Tyler Bates which gave the album an almost cinematic feel.  Tyler Bates is a very up and coming name in the film industry with his most popular film score being of Guardians of the Galaxy, the score, not the old school soundtrack.  He is also responsible for the great bluesy guitar riffs throughout.  Hopefully Bates is here to stay with the band in the long run.  It's rare that a band that peaked in the 90s would put out such a masterpiece nearly 20 years later when most bands would be long forgotten.  I would compare this comeback to the recent comeback David Bowie had in 2013.  Many years from now, this will be one of the albums that people will remember this band for.  Now this album will be divided with negative to positive reviews.  There will be the people who are stuck in the 90s and haven't matured through the years as Warner has.  People who haven't grown up to put it more bluntly.  They will probably trash this softer more old school rock sound.  Then there will be the people who did grow up and will appreciate the new mature nature of this middle aged Warner.  Then there will be the people who have no idea about MM from the 90s and will discover a new favorite in this album.  I can see people who didn't like MM like this album.  This is a good album to start with whether you listen to his other work or just enjoy this album as a standalone.  For fans of good music.  But I will say that this isn't an easy listen even though it is very melodic.  I recognize how great it is, but at the same time it isn't the type of album you can binge listen to on repeat for hours.  This is a good but exhausting experience.  Listen at your own precaution, but enjoy.

Like most others, I learned of this band through their infectious song "Gooey".  I heard it play on the radio one day and it was love at first listen.  I quickly google searched the band and discovered this album.  I previewed a few other songs such as "Pools" and "Hazey" before I finally couldn't resist myself from buying the album.  The group sounds so polished and complete.  I will say that upon my first listen of this album I was somewhat disappointed though.  I felt a bit cheated because I expected more of "Gooey" type songs throughout the album.  I listened to the album again an hour later and many more times since and I discovered that the songs were all latching onto me like parasites.  I was entranced and hooked to the textured layers and soulful vocals.  Here is my track by track review of what I believe will be considered a classic soon.1.  Flip:  The bass of this song comes in waves throughout the song.  At first I didn't really like this one.  But I began to find it more exotic and anthem worthy quickly.  The vocal style in this one just sounds unique in a great way.  Good intro to a true experience of an album.  9/102.  Black Mambo:  Again, first listen didn't really impress me.  But that changed soon after.  The vocals are so elegant yet powerful.  The main riff is so chill and almost has a old school hip hop feel.  I'd compare the riff and vibe of the instruments in this one to "Clint Eastwood" by Gorillaz.  The vocals mirror that of Robert Plant slightly!  Toward the end there is an awesome guitar section that is just sexy.  This is one of my favorites.  10/103.  Pools:  The electronic jungle feel of this one is so infectious.  The verses are playfully catchy.  The chorus is nice and pumping.  I cant help myself from singing along "I smile because I want to".  This really does make me feel like I'm at a party in the jungle!  Another instant classic.  10/104.  Gooey:  This is probably the song that made you look into this band.  I haven't heard a song as beautiful, sexy, and mysteriously catchy as this in a long time.  It is one of those rare songs that will never get old.  I've listened to it over 100 times so far and I still can't get enough of it.  I know this song will become an anthem.  The vocals are gorgeously executed.  The music is sensual and tantalizing.  The chorus is one of the most infectious of all time and I don't say that lightly.  This is one of the greatest songs written and performed in my opinion.  This song is.....gooey.  The music video is strange but it works so well and I can tell it will go viral.  11/105.  Walla Walla:  The jungle vibe continues here.  There is another infectious riff too.  The vocals are playful again and impossible to not want to sing along to.  The band slightly showcases some psychedelic vibes in this one toward the end.  Very trippy and cool.  9/106.  Intruxx:  This is an interlude.  I wish there were actual vocals aside from some hums.  I like the sound of the song.  It really builds up the mood gently before the drums and guitars really kick in.  I usually don't really like instrumentals as much, but this one really holds its own!  Perfect midpoint for the album.  9/107.  Hazey:  Another bass infested song.  The trip hop beat and soulful instrumental makes this one extra amazing.  This is another hit for sure.  The chorus is pure sex music.  The group really makes it sound easy to make such masterful music! 10/108.  Toes:  More great vocals textured with a chorus almost impossible to dislike.  The the guitar just strides nicely in the background throughout.  The bridge is almost trippy but still great.  9/109.  WYRD:  Another 'old school hip hop' inspired main riff.  There really is a magic ingredient to the vocals of this group.  They seem to be unable to make bad songs.  The song does end with 30 seconds of unneeded background sounds though.  9/1010.  Cocoa Hooves:  Don't you just love the titles of these songs?  This is one of the more relaxing songs.  This takes the music and vocals all over the place and I love it.  Really epic and chill at the same time.  9.5/1011.  JDNT:  The style of this song is just so mysterious and awesome.  The vocals are the best alongside 'Gooey' in the verses.  The pace of the song almost has a classy jazz vibe to it without the jazz instruments.  Great ending to this masterpiece of an album.  9.5/10Hidden Track:  I'm not a fan of hidden tracks that are accessible only after minutes of silence.  This could have easily been included as its own track or not at all.  It's not really as impressive as the rest of the album.  I like it, but I don't find myself listening to it as much.  It does have a nice refrain though.  8/10So this album was a clear example of an acquired taste.  Some may love it right away.  Some will be disappointed completely if they don't give it a chance.  I am glad I didn't dismiss it after my first listen.  I had expected an entire album of "Gooey" clones at first.  Though none of the songs sound like 'Gooey', I can say that the album as a whole is a gooey masterpiece in itself.  They literally get better with each listen.  These songs really sink in.  There is a consistent electronic jungle vibe that creeps throughout the songs.  The production is crisp all around. The vocals are some of the best and most gorgeous I've ever heard.  It is completely original yet familiar at the same time in its sound.  But it is clear that the band has it's own sound.  Many will compare them to Alt J at first, but I can say confidently that this band has more potential.  Plus, just the song 'Gooey' itself gives this group an automatic legendary status.  If you like textured music with soulfully elegant but powerful vocals, then this album is perfect for you.  In fact, I recommend this to anyone who likes good music altogether.  Just give it a few listens before you fully judge it!  This is one of the only recent bands alongside Arcade Fire that are instantly in my top 10 favorite music acts of all time.  I am almost sure this will be considered a masterpiece by many in the future as it is already for me.***(Hey future people, was I right?)

Like most of the country, I discovered Calvin Harris through his breakout international single "Feel So Close". I was certain that Calvin Harris was the future of dance music. But during that time, I discovered that Calvin Harris was making good music long before that song and it's album came out. It was typical that the USA were late in his discovery. I decided to check out his first two albums "I Created Disco" and the amazing "Ready For The Weekend". Both albums were gems. Then his album "18 Months" was released. It was okay. It had the obvious hits, but were was Calvin Harris vocally except on one or two tracks? It had great production and guest vocals. But the guest vocals took the spotlight. So some time later in 2014, he releases his best single to date "Summer" and once again he shines with his vocals. I was excited for the album hoping that this time around Calvin would be singing more on his songs again. Then the song "Blame" featuring the phenomenal John Newman was released. Though I was disappointed to hear another guest vocal, I ended up loving the song. But still, I held onto hope that Calvin would feature more of his own singing on his new album instead of relying on others. Calvin Harris singing on his own produced songs was what set him apart from the likes of David Guetta and Avicii. It showed that he was a great producer and a good vocalist. But before the release of the album, it was revealed that this would be just like 18 Months with an overabundance of guests. I wasn't planning on buying the album at all. But I decided I needed some good new songs to add to my workout playlist and I assumed this would do. I impulsively bought the album and gave it a few listens. Here is my track by track review.1. Faith: Great opener. The album credits say that John Newman is a writer on this one. But I'm glad that Calvin takes on vocal duties! It isn't his best produced song by far, but its a definite club track. 8.5/102. Under Control Feat. Alesso and Hurts: A song released long before the album was even announced. Great guest vocals from Hurts and co-production by Alesso. It has Calvins typical chorus, EDM instrumental, chorus, and so on vibe. The vocals really do shine though. I'm surprised it wasn't a bigger hit in the US. Great song to dance to and work out to. 9.5/103. Blame Feat. John Newman: More guest vocals, but I'm glad so far they are great, and John Newman delivers. This cat can sing! I'm sure this song will do for John Newman what Disclosure did for Sam Smith. John already has a hit in this US, but this song will solidify him as a force to be reckoned with! Great Calvin Harris-isms in the production of course, but John Newman really stole the show with this one. This is really John Newman featuring Calvin Harris honestly. 10/104. Love Now Feat. All About She: I'm slowly getting used to the fact that Calvin is relying on guest vocals again. This felt like a 90s dance club lost hit. The strings incorporated in the production give it a classy dance feel. Though not as great as John Newman, the vocals are still amazing from All About She. Could be a single. 9.5/105. Slow Acid: I'm not a fan of dance instrumentals. Especially the ones that Calvin has been doing since 18 Months. This was okay. Its a definite club track and could maybe be used in movie soundtracks for action films during club scenes. But even with all of that, I still find myself skipping this song some of the time. But it's good for working out. I just would rather hear more vocals to go with the textured production. 8.5/106. Outside Feat. Ellie Goulding: Calvin and Ellies second collaboration. The production is crisp in this one. Ellie gives a good vocal performance, though not as good as Newman. This is one of his few guest vocal songs that really makes the guest vocalist seem like just that, a guest. Don't get me wrong, Ellie is great, but the production is just extra infectious on this one. 10/107. It Was You Feat. Firebeatz: The Moby style vocals are great.  At first I thought the song was annoying when the thumping beat came in.  But it quickly grew on me.  The loudness of the main beat compliments the calmness of the vocals so well.  This is original and a great work out song.  9/108. Summer: Its no surprise that I'm going to praise this masterpiece. Amazing production and singing from Calvin. The summer anthem of 2014 and another song that will become timeless. Vocals still are not as great as John Newmans guest performance, but the production just invades my soul no matter how many times I hear it. This is one of those rare songs that will never be graced with the 'skip' button. 11/109. Overdrive Feat. Ummet Ozcan: Another guest production, but with NO vocals. I found this unworthy of even being included in the album. It's not horrible. But it doesn't even fit into the rest of the album. Its obviously good to add to your workout routine, but it's also so forgettable. The production is great, but also annoying at times. The title says it all except I would call it 'OverDONE' instead. Its a shame that the longest song on the album is easily the most forgettable. 7/1010. Ecstasy Feat. Hurts: Here's something you don't hear often from Calvin. A ballad. The vocal performance by Hurts is beautiful. The title suggests it would be a club song, but this song is ecstasy in a different way. This is gorgeous. But the production once again is in the background again while the vocals take over. Another song that could be considered Hurts featuring Calvin Harris and not the other way around. A relaxing ballad to calm you. This song is you stepping out of the club to recover and relax before heading back into the madness of the club for more. 10/1011. Pray To God Feat. HAIM: I was extra excited for this song because HAIM are one of my favorite bands. I wasn't disappointed at all. Amazing Fleetwood Mac-esque vocals with modern CH production. I hope this becomes a single! 10/1012. Open Wide Feat. Big Sean: This is the worst guest vocal. But still an okay song. It also just doesn't fit in with the rest of the album. I love rap and hip hop, but I've never liked Big Sean, and this song doesn't change my mind. Luckily the production is great. But again, the production doesn't match Big Seans annoying rapping. He should have chosen a much better current rapper like Macklemore, Drake, Schoolboy Q, Logic or Kendrick Lamar. The production saves this from being a disaster. 8/1013. Together Feat. Gwen Stefani: The production sounds like Calvin Harris is ripping off himself. But it is still infectious. Gwen Stefani is a great singer and its no surprise that she soars in this one. 9.5/1014. Burnin Feat. R3hab: I was going to dismiss this immediately because of its guest production with no vocals, but I was surprised to find that I liked this for some odd reason. But that quickly changed again as I found myself hating it soon after. Very lukewarm song. Another good workout song, but horrible standalone song. It just feels out of place anywhere outside of a club setting. 7.5/1015. Dollar Sign Feat. Tinashe: I'm glad to hear a PBR&B singer mixed with CH! The bass is killer in this one. Its almost industrial and EDM at the same time. Tinashe is great, but she didn't really explode vocally. Still, very infectious! I love the song, but I thought it didn't feel like an album closer. 9.5/10So this album was full of good songs and some filler. But this is not a 5 star album. I give it a 3.5/5, but I guess rounding it up to 4 stars is acceptable. The production is great, but at the same time repetitive. Individually the songs are amazing, but as a whole, the album seems scattered. Though there are some consistencies in production, it all just feels like a greatest hits album of lost hits. Calvin Harris isn't the star of the album. Aside from in "Summer" and maybe the opening track, this feels like a collection of songs that featured Calvin Harris production, not an album that Calvin Harris needs to brand his name all over. A good chunk of these songs are destined to take over clubs around the world. As stated before too, this is full of good songs to workout to. This is a great album of catchy songs with crisp production, but this is not a good Calvin Harris album, if you get my drift. If Calvin was honest he would title the album "Calvin Harris and friends - Motion". I don't regret paying for this album, but I also don't think it's a masterpiece.
