But you're going to have to be aiming at large, chunky icons like the CALL ANSWER or PHONE DIALER because you simply will never get precise aim with the 1/4" wide fingertips.All in all, a great glove because it's a hand warmer that is LESS clunky to have on when trying to deal with your phone in cold weather. But it in no way solves the glove dilemma and I don't think any other product out there could claim to do any better.

Sadly, among the mixed reviews here, I have to weigh in on the Con side of the argument.I would give this one star, but I don't like to say I truly "hate" anything.Though I sure am disappointed.Now I realize, these are cheap. But my kids both have even cheaper products similar to these at school for dorm use, and they've been great -- so price shouldn't be an issue and, as some reviewers here have had much success, obviously isn't ultimately the deciding factor in performance.I have done everything, according to the manufacturer's directions and the troubleshooting advice of some of the better and more thorough reviews here on Amazon.I've even posted and cross-talked extensively in the Help Forum, but to no avail.It's set up properly, there are fresh batteries, I am scanning and almost instantly (one or two scans after reset) getting my TV audio. But it only works within 2 or 3 feet of the transmitter, while virtually every FM radio station being broadcast from within a 50 mile radius is coming in loud and clear.If I hold the unit or, better yet, the hard-wired connection (which is tangle free and which I've tried in front of, behind, under, over, and next to the TV monitor) I can get a clearer signal. But would I have purchased a wireless headset if I wanted to watch TV while standing AT the TV?Nope.Literally, sitting on the edge of my bed maybe four feet away, the signal turns to fuzz with some occasionally discernible TV dialogue coming through.This is not a good unit for me. I hope if you choose to purchase this product, that it proves to be better for you.

An amazing homage to the Disaster Films on which I fed as a kid. They're all, to some extent, skewered here, from "Poseidon Adventure" to "Earthquake" with a layover at "Towering Inferno" on its way to lampooning the entire "Airport" franchise.You have to love a movie that has Stockard Channing (doing, here, an incredible Stockard Channing impression -- a meta-reference to her own self-awareness of her trademark mannerisms as a character actress) delivering with sincerity a line such as "We hope you enjoy your first stop on your non-stop trip from New York to Denver!").The primary conceit of the film is that the rich and famous and entitled (if only self-proclaimed) are taking a bus -- A BUS -- to Denver. No spoilers, though it's not exactly "Citizen Kane", but at the height of the dramatic goings on, you should never EVER stop to consider, "why the heck don't they just pull over on the shoulder?"Loved it. I've been looking for it for 30 years, and I found it and I loved it. Brain candy that nourishes the soul with laughter while rotting the grey matter.

I've owned several, more expensive Immersion Blenders, and this was by far my favorite.I will buy this one again in a heart beat, because honestly it did everything it's supposed to AND cleaned up very easily.Biggest point of contention I have with all products in this category is "does junk get stuck in the bottom?" These are often engineered for more chopping or more aerating or more something, but never LESS clumping and clogging.This one clumps and clogs less.I recently replaced it with a different brand that was discounted at retail and had two speeds. Never again. I'm going back to this one.It didn't even break down or crack or anything I could blame on the unit itself in my need to replace it.Pretty-but-brainless, I was using it to save a "broken" caramel for a buttercream, and in my haste, using it while the caramel was boiling away, I let it spend too much time against the bottom of the lava-hot saucepan as I worked it.It melted enough to bend it unattractively inward -- and STILL the darned thing works fine. I just can't look at it, because it's a constant reminder of my own failings. I hurt it. It is a symbol, now, of my shame.So I took it to work, and I use it in the kitchen there, though infrequently. My guilt remains hidden, because I have so much more about which to feel guilty at the office than I do in my kitchen.And this contraption has nothing whatsoever about which to ever feel shame. It's a loyal and effective champion of kitchen mixing causes.

...but the product description never promised it to be anything else.This is not a mini-muffin tin. It's a hemisphere mold, comma, Mini.For those vexed by it being smaller than they wanted, that's not the product's fault. A Mini Cooper is a tiny, sporty vehicle -- not a Mini Truck. And you can't be mad at it for not being a mini truck because it never said it was.So you can't be mad at a mini hemisphere mold for not being a mini cupcake pan.It never claimed to be.This will work BEAUTIFULLY for one-bite petite baked goods. It is not going to make a mini muffin. I bought this specifically because I have a dozen mini muffin tins, and I wanted something smaller that would also provide a more unique, not-cup-like shape for candies.If you're tired of rolling out ganache centers for your truffles, pour the warm ganache into these, cool and unmold, ad dip in your coating.Professional-looking candies with a uniform presentation.And you can eat them in the back seat of your Mini Cooper.

Just in playing around with this for a half-hour I'm already looking for other sizes.It's got a super-effective cutting mechanism leaving no "hanging chads", and is so simple to press that even a supervised child or arthritic senior can use this with comfort and ease.It's bulky, mind you, but no more so than you'd expect. While it doesn't matter for cut-outs, realize that it does require you to be within about 1/2" of the edge for matting purposes -- so you won't be able to punch out a window halfway down a scrapbook page, though I don't know any similarly priced, easily handled unit that offers such flexibility.This is a great value, and I'll purchase from EK Success again in the future without hesitation.

Overall, a decent value, but these are what I perceive to be negatives:- Not very true to size. Be cautious when ordering, and go a size smaller. I take an 11 very comfortably, and these size 11s leave room for a friend and a snack. I'm hoping thicker socks in winter will take up some of the slack, but these aren't necessarily cold weather boots alone, and I know that in the Spring or Fall they're going to feel wobbly without the extra stuffing.- Very wide throat. These have zippers, but to be honest I can slip into them with little effort without unzipping them. This is going to make anything but boot-cut jeans rather difficult to wear over the boot, and even a slim slack tucked in (the way I normally prefer) doesn't take up much space. The overall look, then, when tucked, is -- and not unflatteringly, mind you -- more "Pirate" than "Biker" or "Hipster".- Buckles are adjustable, but mostly ornamental. Hoping to "take them in a bit" I tightened the buckles a notch; this caused the rise of the throat to start folding unattractively, but it helped across the instep.- I can tell after an hour of wear that in short time, due to the way the leather folds on the foot just from walking, that it will crease and dent or crack along the already growing wrinkles.- Maybe I've never paid attention, or maybe it's a problem with this particular design, but I cannot remember ever owning a shoe that had a seam on the insole quite as conspicuous as this. Looking down at your feet, imagine each being a clock face; on the left at 2:00 and on the right, in mirror opposition, at 10:00, a heavyily stitched seam runs the inch or so up from the outsole to the upper. It's not a decorative choice; it's an oddly situated suture. Imagine if you had a face lift, and the surgeon decided that straight across your cheek was the best place for a repaired incision. That's what this looks like.- The leather will look much nicer when it's broken in, but that sort of lends well to expectations of longevity.This is a pretty attractive and very comfortable, seemingly sturdy boot. So I'm not complaining -- I'm just not throwing a parade in its honor.** UPDATE: 11/16/2012 **I have now been (almost literally) LIVING in these boots for three days. I have received no end of compliments, I am totally pleased with the fit with just a white sock, and they seem to be getting more and more comfortable with each hour.I've also upgraded my rating from 3 to 4 stars because I think that these are already proving to be an incredible value.I still thing the styling is weird with that funny stitch near the toe, but I'm getting to look at that like a birth mark -- part of its unique charm, and its own brand of beautiful.

My teacup Chihuahua takes an XS in virtually everything she wears.I double-checked their sizing chart and she is, according to the manufacturer, an XS by their standards as well.While the sweater fits, it's really snug and rather on the short end. I've never had as much difficulty getting a shirt onto her as I did with this, though it was, in the grand scheme of things, not the worst problem we encountered in our relationship.The styling and detail are lovely, so I can't take away stars for that -- and she's really warm and comfortable wearing it.But if your pet is borderline size-wise, I'd definitely err on the side of the larger size.

- Attractive, as water-resistant footwear goes. Much more appealing than a duck boot.- Rubber sole and textured, rubberized outsole, for puddle plodding.- Genuine leather upper is treated to resist water as well.- Natural/Poly blend fur is both attractive as trim and very warm and very comfortable inside.- Sizing runs true, but both the lacing and the give of the boot itself allow for a variety of sock weights depending on personal preference or warmth needs.I had done extensive research and comparison among boots with similar looks and utility, at varying price points, and am perfectly happy that I chose this boot above the others in its field.

You have about two episodes to fall in love or become repulsed. There is no gray area with this show's characters and premise.The writing and acting are just about flawless as comedies go, and the cast is nothing short of brilliant.Or, it's an exercise in ego and as overbearingly soulless as "Seinfeld" (which was written by this series' star and creator, Larry David), and the characters should be taken out in the rain and shot for their lack of humanity and interest in anyone's satisfaction but their own.You decide :)

I had been using a different brand of the exact same thing for a year.This is less expensive, and a more appropriate size for my teacup Chihuahua.With a hundred in a pack, they last forever. Well, not exactly; but I do leave one down for a few days until she uses it a few times between walks. They are compact enough to keep in her usual spot, and lock in moisture and odor perfectly.The one exception, which has more to do with my pet than the product, is that the 1" border is not itself absorbent. Thus, if your pup gets too close to the edge, it will bleed off and get sucked underneath, so you need to position them in such a way that they can't comfortably aim anywhere but within the quilted area.When it does seep, on hard surfaces, the wetness gets sucked under and distributed, so you lift the pad to find a nearly 2-foot square puddle.If used on a carpeted surface, I can only imagine this would wreak havoc on your rugs.

I've been waiting to see this for eons. I finally found it the other night and was thrilled to have finally sat down to watch.I love a few things: Myrna Loy, whose beauty belied her exquisite comic timing; William Powell, who could be captured on black-and-white film doing nothing more than reading his junk mail, and still be alternately heartwarming and hysterical and worth watching for two hours; and the era, which is captured beautifully here in terms of the costumes and sets, the social interactions, the dialogue, and the morals and mores of the day; and snappy dialogue sparked with wit and intelligence.This is typical of films of the era in that the acting is not consistent. While the stars are indeed stellar, some of the other actors must have been related to or lying under the producers, because while it's a comedy, I found myself laughing at the occasional artless delivery of lines and physicality.Atypical of the films of the era, this manages to cross genres, between comedy and true whodunnit mystery, sacrificing neither through the combination. The writing is crisp and witty, and the twists and turns in the unfolding detective plot will truly leave you wondering which of the many suspects is to blame until the very last.The one totally confusing part for me: three actresses who are all about the same age, all about the same level of not-too-pretty, and all with about the same amount of screen time (with only one exception, never sharing a scene), all seem to share the same platinum blonde wig, as well. I was about 45 minutes in before I realized they were different characters.A must-see. I've added the whole series of "Thin Man" films to my watchlist now.

With so many thorough and spot-on reviews here, I will just toss out the following:- I grew up on the TV series, and though glossy and modern, this is a fitting tribute.- Depp is his usual, scenery-chewing, glorious self -- a character actor of the highest order.- Getting past the fact that Tim Burton cannot make a movie these days without his own wife (Helena Bonham Carter), Johnny Depp, and one or both of them wearing a red wig, this is much more in the groove of his older, classic films.- Having worked off-Broadway with the original Angelique, Lara Parker, I spent the whole movie looking for her cameo; I never spotted her. Apparently, less cameo, more ballyhooed background work.- This is DARK. If you were led by the trailer to expect a comedy, you are not going to find it here. BUT, it is darkly comic and there is a general mood of frivolity and levity; it is not a heavy drama.- This is not for the kids. Though there's nothing showing that should be covered by a bathing suit, there is one particular sexual situation that is beyond saucy and rough, and there's plenty of blood -- though being a hater of the gore genre, it wasn't so heavy as to make me uncomfortable. It's more staged than realistic.- Overall, a well spent couple of bucks and couple of hours.

I never suffered the desire of some to have hamburgers and hot dogs all be of uniform size and shape and fit one universal bun.I believe in diversity. In people, and in grill meats.What I DID salivate and jump joyously for was the fact that now virtually anything that can hold its form (either raw or mixed with a breading or dough or semi-frozen) can now be dogged, dipped, and fried on a stick.I am still going nuts with the possibilities, but turn anything you want into a meatball paste, and dip it in tempura or beer batter, and ooh Daddy. I also bake them to insure they're cooked through.But I have indeed also gone old-school and made meat mix into a no-casing sausage and pan grilled the result, and plainly and simply, this product easily does as it promises.Unique multi-piece design makes for a bit of a learning curve, but also makes for brilliant clean-up.

Ateco makes great quality products at a low price. No exception here.Bakers from newbie to pastry chef should always have these on hand. It's impossible to switch out decorating tips due to whim or error without these, so I tend to install couplers regardless of the task, no matter what.A definite staple, and this is a great deal.

Conveniently packaged and inexpensive, these wipes start off as a great value. Add to that their very pleasant scent and no disagreement from my easily disagreeable chihuahua, and these are a perfect, quick, freshen-up when pets are lightly soiled or in need of a between-baths sprucing up.A single wipe leaves my teacup looking refreshed and smelling squeaky clean.

That's how much I needed this app on my Droid.Fires can rage, hungry babies scream, dogs in urgent need of a walk can paw mercilessly at the door, and SWAT teams and attacking alien forces may burst through windows and walls, but I'll never know.I'm trying to bomb little green piggies.Beyond addictive.

This book takes a look at the lives of professional spammers and the empires that they have book. While fundamentally the book is interesting, it suffers from a bit too much drama. Although spam is an issue that plagues the computer industry, it isn't nearly as critical as viruses, cyber attacks, and many other things that go on in the industry, and doesn't seem to me to be as looming a problem as the author portrays. I also found the drama associated with his trip to Russia to seem a bit overstated. While the author may very well have been scared to travel to Russia, it isn't the scary country of James Bond movies, and one doesn't put ones life in ones hands when traveling there any more than many other places. The best part of the book is the description of the wars that broke out between the various spam groups.

This is a very interesting autobiography written by a former CIA and FBI agent who got caught up in an overzealous political prosecution that falsely tarnished her as a terrorist. Although certainly the book is biased, it rings true and tragic. The author is a friend of a friend, which makes it particularly of interest to me. It takes a look at her life, the horrible childhood she had growing up the middle east, her efforts to become a citizen and contribute back to America, her time working against terrorists, and then ultimately the case that caught her up in a web of misfortune.

A very pleasant book that looks in the lives of those that live in a small town in the north east. You'll meet dairy farmers, maple syrup farmers, blueberry farmers, a town historian and more. The pace of the book wanders around with a pace similar to the speed of life in the town, and it is a delightful and pleasant read that will have you coming away longing for the small town life of what seems like a lost America. Enjoyable and a great first work. Looking forward to more from the author

This is a really fun book. The author worked as a television producer in Russia, and as such had access to a broad variety of people and stories, ranging from a group trying to preserve destruction of historic homes in Moscow, to a woman completely torqued by the criminal criminal justice system, to a politicians, models, oligarchs, crooks and prostitutes -- in a world in which anyone can be a mix of all of those at once. It is a fascinating look at the machinations behind what Russia has become, as it yet again burns through its promise with tragic corruption. The book is a fast and fun read, the stories are engaging, and certainly seem consistent with much that I have seen there. If you have an interest in Russia, it certainly is a fun read.

I have mixed feelings about this book. The book combines personal stories about life in Cuba and the exile community, with gorgeous photographs, and a broad mix of recipes. I enjoy the writing and the stories, and the photographs really capture a sense of sun soaked environments and the food. But, i'm not as positive about the recipes for two reasons. One is simply a matter of personal taste -- many of the recipes don't sound like something I'd want to cook. The other side is that the recipes are fairly terse. This is typical of many cookbooks, but I find I like cookbooks much more that go into details of ingredient selection, how to know if it is prepared properly, etc. For example, I find the writing about food in the The Square cookbook to be much more inspiring. Certainly, the food presented in this cookbook is fairly straightforward to cook, but with so much poetic waxing in the world about Cubano sandwiches, i was hoping for a bit more waxing in the recipes.I'll certainly cook some things from the cookbook, but I was hoping for a bit more on the recipe side than it delivered. Still, I'm glad to have it in my collection

Awesome device. I have several Synology NASs, and this one takes the cake. Normally i get them empty and set up my own drives. I have to say, having it preconfigured is way easier, and saves hours and hours of time. Basically you unpack the unit, plug it in, and you are done.Synology units are rock solid, easy to work with, have a clear UI, regular updates and lots of good features. This one is a very beefy NAS with lots of storage and good CPU space.Altogether very happy with it.

This is a pretty cool little device. It is a USB rechargeable flashlight that also doubles as a phone charger. So basically, you plug the flashlight into any USB charger, it charges away. Now you have a very bright LED flashlight with a convenient light form factor. To me, this is great. I always like to have something like this when I travel because you just never know... and dealing with batteries on the road is a drag. And, since my cell phone is often dead by the end of the day I can use it to recharge that up with some juice... but without making the phone bulkier such as with a Mophie. I think it is a cool holiday gift for folks.For the downside, don't even bother reading the instructions. If you are over 20 you probably can't read the print without a magnifying lens. It would have been nicer if the charger cable used a standard adapter so you could use a single iPhone cord to both charge a phone and charge the battery... i hate having *so* many cables to carry around. And finally, the on/dim/flash switch would have been much nicer if in a different area and a tad bigger.But, the functionality and price are pretty cool

This is a delightful and moving autobiography that contrasts the author's life in Russia with her life in the United States, where she moved pre-perestroika by marrying an American. Although the story delves deeply into the life and challenges of an immigrant, it also revolves around her relationship with her mother and daughter, and their experiences in the country as well, the former as a post-perestroika immigrant with no English, and the latter as native born and thus culturally so different. It is a moving tale about the struggles of an immigrant, but more, the struggles of family relationships. She perfectly captures the sense and fear of parenting a tween and teenager, and it is a moving story of overcoming adversity, dealing (and not dealing) with family relationships, and the joys and guilt associated. I found it quite pleasurable.

This book takes a fascinating look at neuropathology. The author is an eminent doctor, and the book discusses the value on personal examinations of patients and the many clues that can help unravel the nature of a disease. Although he discusses scans and other automated techniques, a lot of the book focuses on the fascinating ways that diagnoses are often missed with a physical exam. It portrays the deep depth of diagnostic learning that comes with experience, as evidenced through a broad mix of cases of patients with diseases ranging from aneurisms to ALS to Parkinsons. It talks about how the disease works, how it manifests, how it can be diagnosed, as well as mixing in deeply personal stories about the lives of those impacted by the disease. It also mixes in some stories of diagnoses gone wrong.Although there are a few areas that could use some more editing, altogether the book was extremely interesting and engaging, and should be of value to those interested in medicine, the brain and psychology. A very worthwhile read

This book is a mix. The early chapters are quite interesting, taking a look at a mix of psychological and mathematical principles behind decision making, and the various things that we often do wrong when assessing issues. The later chapters spend more time on information clarity and dealing with weeding out truth from fiction in the online world. While I found the first chapters quite good the latter chapters dragged on for me, becoming far more obvious and repetitive, and dealing less with interesting anecdotes and examples. While many people are misled by online web sites and don't approach with proper skepticism, having endless chapters and tips on common sense wasn't useful. Overall, though, there are definitely some good anecdotes and examples of how people tend to misjudge or incorrectly analyze situations. For example, it deals with confirmation biases, the strange math of false negatives, and many other topics. Still, not as good as some other books such as Thinking Fast and Slow.

This is an interesting book, that takes a look at why, despite all of the evidence and the dire consequences, we completely ignore the perils of climate change. The author approaches this from several angles, looking at the psychology of disaster recovery, religion, cognitive biases, collaboration, threat and time, as well as mistaken approaches in attempting to deal with climate change. The general message of the author is bleak, but the background and methodology of the book is quite interesting. It is a worthwhile read for those worried bout climate change and frustrated with why it gets no traction with the general public or politicians.

I found this book a bit disappointing, especially compared to some other books by the author. The author is an eminent Sovietologist, and has spent much time in Russia. The premise of the book is fascinating: what happened to the survivors of the Gulag. To the extent that the book portrays the lives of a variety of Gulag survivors, with what it was like for them in and out of the Gulag, the book is quite good. It is a worthy and interesting topic. The problem with the book is that it spends too much time on the author's experiences with the survivors and less of the survivors experiences. I would have found the book significantly more interesting if the balance were opposite. More survivors, more survivor stories, more Gulag stories, and follow ups ... that would be great. But as it is written, it is too much about the author's life and experiences.

This is a very emotional, cathartic story about a young Jewish boy in Kharkiv Ukraine who moves to the US as part of the great Soviet migration post-perestroika. He writes about his life in Kharkiv and the difficulties he faced there, and then the challenges of immigration ... what it was like to get permission to leave, leaving through the border, going to temporary placement in Austria, and then the eventual move to the US. He weaves in remembrances from his childhood, the experiences of immigration, and what it feels like looking back. The book is beautifully told and emotionally raw and honest. For me, I was surprised that this is his first book. It has excellent pacing and feel. As someone who has been to Kharkiv many times and knows many immigrants from that part of the world as well as many people who live there, I found the book particularly interesting. The author neither glorifies nor vilifies himself or the past, but rather deals with a very complex set of issues in a fascinating way. I absolutely enjoyed this book and certainly recommend it to others.

For me this book is somewhere between 3 and 4 stars. The book takes a look at two communities: one in the midwest and one in Mexico, and examines the impacts of NAFTA. It profiles a set of factory workers at a Maytag plant, and how their jobs and lives changed through different management, acquisitions and then finally outsourcing to Mexico, as well as workers in Mexico, and how their lives changed with the influx of large factory jobs, significantly lacking in rights and safety compared to the American jobs. The book does an excellent job of looking at the problems introduced in this process, and the struggles on all sides before and after.Although some may criticize the book for its pro-labor bent, I didn't find that at all problematic. While it would have been nice to have more perspective coming from the management side of the industry, the issues to the workers speak for themselves in a very humane way. While obviously the sets of issues with the collapse of American manufacturing are complex, the point of the book is to look more at its sociologic impacts rather than assess whether or not the overall economic changes made sense or not.The subject material is quite interesting, but at times I think the writing style could be a bit more engaging. It certainly isn't an academic book, but it could have done a bit better of a job of letting us into the lives of those portrayed.Overall, an interesting read

This is a fantastic, moving story about the battle between scientists and environmentalists and the US Navy, over the user of sonar that kills whales. In an effort to detect enemy submarines, the Navy invents a very intense sonar system. Its great at detecting enemy subs, but it also kills whales, leading to mysterious mass strandings. This book traces the history of the weapons systems as well s the marine biologists studying whales, the tragic killings associated with use of the sonar, and the law cases that try to reduce the impact. It is a fascinating and deeply personal story, and well worth reading as we grapple with our increasing destruction of the world around us. A must for any environmentally oriented person.

This is an interesting book that takes a look at a famous vineyard in France. The owner is being blackmailed by a mysterious person who threatens to destroy one of the worlds most important vineyard if he is not paid a minor fortune. The book weaves back and forth among the history of the family and their many generations of vintners, the history of the region and in particular the politics of pre-revolutionary France,the wine itself, and the criminal act and detective work to apprehend the criminal.It's an interesting story, but at times the various backstory feel a tad forced, as if there to give the story a bit more mass. The historical aspects were interesting, but I would have preferred that they were tied more or extended more into the present.All in all, an interesting read.

This is a fascinating book, in many senses a set of vignettes, as the author covers Americans at war in the Middle East. The book is told first hand, as the author scrambles under gun fire in a street in Iraq, deals with the death of soldiers around him, watches executions in Afghanistan, and deals with the chaos and horror of the situation in the Middle East. The book doesn't focus on history or take sides, as much as it tells stories, from the perspectives of many different sides. It is fast paced, gripping, and quite fascinating, and I'd highly recommend it.

This book takes a look at the mathematics of gambling. Each chapters starts with some basic math around statistics. If you haven't ever studied statistics or basics of algebra, you might find this daunting. If you have and have just forgotten such things, then it is a reasonably fast and understandable refresher into sets, series, combinations, permutations, standard deviations and so forth. After a brief section on math, the book looks at various games of chance: blackjack, craps, roulette, poker, pai gow and many others... and explains the math behind them. For example, what games in a casino have the best odds for the player? what strategies should you play against a poker machine? it all boils down to a simple law the author shares -- if you can understand the game easily, the odds are not in your favor. It's an interesting exploration of how to analyze how often you are likely to use with the various casino games and why the casinos set the rules the way they do. You may find it more valuable to skim through the details of each analysis to focus on the end results, or you might want to read through to see how you can derive house odds and hand probabilities yourself.If you are looking for a guide on how to play blackjack or poker, this isn't for you. It will cover the basics and show you how to think about such things, but you really will want to look for a different book.Sometimes I found the book went into far more variations than was interesting to me. I wasn't approaching it looking for a math class, so as such, seeing the math for a dozen variations of roulette didn't add anything for me.Still, an interesting way to get grounded in statistics with some practical problems, and a good way to see why gambling is so good for casinos.I also like that it points out many of the common fallacies you will see in casinos, such as "its been red five times in a row, i better put money on black".

This is a beautiful cookbook from an absolutely fantastic restaurant. Every thing served in the restaurant is immaculate, with amazing tastes, textures, colors and presentation, and the book does a great job of explaining how. The book begins with a brief story about the chef, and, as with other books by top chefs, this gives a lovely sense of his personality and philosophy.The recipes are not for the faint hearted. These are serious recipes that are not trivial or fast to cook. But, unlike many cookbooks, the author does a great job explaining what you have to worry about -- what the timing is like, what ingredients are most important, exactly how you have to chill something from the cooking, how to tell if it is over or undercooked, how things are going to change during the process. And each comes with a lovely photograph showing what it is supposed to be like.It really is fantastic food and a very fun, informative cookbook. Of course, I'm not sure that I will venture to source some of these things because the recipes are elaborate, but everything is inspiring.

Prior to reading this book, I must confess that I never understood or even thought about what goes on in a morgue and how autopsies are used for investigations. This book is a fascinating glimpse into that world, told my a medical pathologist. We learn how she entered the field, and first hand examine a variety of cases she worked on, from the tragedy of the World Trade Center crashes to suicide and murder investigations. The book reads like a set of vignettes, albeit ones derived from wielding of a scalpel. Utterly fascinating if you have an interest in science, but certainly not for the squeamish. Very fun. I devoured it during one flight.

I'm quite fond of books on neuropsychology and science history, and this book blends both for a romping tale of the discovery of a mix of various diseases and how they were discovered. It takes a look at traumatic brain injuries throughout history, ranging from a king who died from a jousting injury, to presidents and many others, and along the way looks at theories of brain functioning, plasticity, and various odd conditions such as people that can't recognize their relatives when they see them, but recognize them fine if they speak on the telephone. An interesting exploration of brain theories and discoveries, all within a fast paced historical framework.

This is a rather curious book that reads very similar, in many respects. to A Clockwork Orange, but where the state apparatus is playing the part of the merry droogs, raping and pillaging the citizens. I'm told the original Russian is very flowery, which doesn't quite come across in the translation. It tells the tale of a security officer in a futuristic post-Putin Russia, where the state is a mix of Tsarist and Stalinist Russia, a blend of totalitarianism and religion, and where the government exerts its violent forces as it sees fit. It is part 1984, part dystopian Sci Fi, and part just crazy. A bit tough at times, surrealistic throughout, but sadly predictive of many things that are going on in Russia today.

This is an engaging story about a Viet Nam Marine officer who, 13 days before the end of his tour, runs over a land mine and is severely burned leading to permanent severe facial scarring. The autobiography discusses his service, his recovery, the impact on his family, and how he pulled himself out of depression and became a leading journalist in author. Along the way he gets married (twice), has four kids, gets divorced (twice). This is both a study in tenacity and overcoming obstacles as well as a look back on the author's life. I haven't read his other books, although they sound interesting as well.Altogether it is well written. There are times where it drags along a bit and there are other times when it is very fast. But overall I'm glad to have read it.

I've used a lot of extension poles. This one is the easiest to use and lightest weight of all of them. well worth the price to be able to carry it easily, extend it fully, and not have the weight overwhelming.

I've bought several of these cameras for outdoor use.On the positive side, for the first year or so, they were fairly easy to install, the software works well, and i could easily incorporate them into my security system (I'm running Synology for that)The pan/tilt works quite nicely. Resolution is reasonable and images are reasonably clear.On the downside:Night resolution is fairly poor. If the area isn't lit you can't see a thing. I use a mix of IR and non-IR cameras to overcome thatBut the big issue:After roughly 2 years of use, 1 out of 5 of the cameras has completely failed. Everything it records is now purple and red, grainy and streaky. Basically useless.  2 other cameras are also starting to show the same signs.So I have a feeling that after two years of use, these fairly expensive cameras are all going to have to be replaced. Pretty crappy longevity.

Yet again, Michael Lewis delivers a fascinating book about the dirty side of Wall Street. In this book he explores super fast trading that is designed to take advantage of information flow, effectively altering the market by taking advantage of slightly different timings between different marketplaces. It is a fascinating technique, but one that ultimately shifts money into the hands of the traders with no positive impact the economy, economic stabilization, worth or anything else. Thus, it is another way in which certain firms in Wall Street manage to abscond with money while delivering anti-value and fragility. At the same time, it looks at the efforts of a company that established an exchange that eliminates many of the unfair advantages. Along the way it takes a special look at how creepy many of the large Wall Street firms are.Although personally I would have enjoyed a bit more technical exploration of what was going on, altogether it is fascinating and fast paced. Another great book.

This book explores the US interactions in Afghanistan, and most importantly, the complex relationship between Pakistan and Afghanistan. It takes a look at our war in Afghanistan, with a view from Afghans living through it. It explores the effectiveness of our bombing campaigns, counterinsurgency campaigns, surge, and nation building, and explores hard questions about what they really meant and how well they were executed. It looks at the politics of the Taliban revival, the ineffectiveness of Karzai (but with a balanced view at why he was an interesting choice as a leader), and the endless interactions of the Pakistani ISI in trying to control and influence Afghanistan. Much of what the book explores is how Pakistan, while taking huge amounts of money from the US, was at the same time sponsoring the Taliban and anti-American terrorism. Not a pretty picture.The book is fascinating, well written, well researched, and very informative. The only downside is that it errs on the side of the Afghani villagers... it may be interesting to balance out the view with the perspective of Restrepo or interviews that look at the war from the perspective of the allied troops.Well worth reading... an important book.

This is a fantastic book that looks at extinction. The book takes a series of extinct or endangered animals and takes a look at their history, and uses those stories as a backdrop to explore the history of fossil science and what we have learned about past extinctions. Thus the book covers modern science, modern ecology, past ecosystems, and science history, all while maintaining a fast pace human touch that makes the book quite interesting. The book explores how man, especially with our massive destruction of climate and ecosystems, is triggering the next major extinction. One of the fascinating chapters takes a look at ocean acidity as explored by highly acidic ocean vents, and uses that as a predictor of the near future as the ocean continues to absorb CO2. It is not a pretty picture.Excellent approachable science and a very important topic. A fantastic book and a must read.

I bought this camera specifically for use at the beach and underwater. Having said that, I also used it as a general point and shoot camera. Primarily I use a DSLR, and using a point and shoot takes a bit getting used to. It certainly is no replacement, but it is also excellent at what it does.The camera is small, light, and easily fits in your pocket. I took it in hot tubs, swimming pools, beaches, the ocean, and scuba diving, and it was great not to worry about whether it could take the beating. In short, unlike my DSLR, where i'm very careful of moisture, temperature range and dirt, with this thing I took it every where.The camera has a broad range of electronic modes that are quite impressive -- a portrait mode that detects when people smile and takes photos then; a pet mode that knows when the pets face is visible; fireworks mode; automatic mode and many others. Although some of these are somewhat gimmicky, they actually work, and given that there isn't a real burst speed with the camera, they are quite useful. For example, consider smile mode. On a nice DSLR you can take 10 photos in a second, so you can usually get a range of smiles. With a point and shoot you really do need to choose your photo carefully and the mode works, which i thought was quite cool.I didn't find the HDR mode to be super useful, but i probably need to experiment with it more. Still, the HDR mode operates from a single click and is very easy to set up...much easier than what i have to do with my DSLR.I had some troubles with the panoramic mode. While it is way cooler than the mode on an iPhone, in that it supports horizontal and vertical panoramas and 180s and 360s, i did find it was a bit finicky, especially with verticals and 360s. There the failure rate was fairly high, where the camera would sometimes end the sequence before the panorama was complete.For battery life, i found the camera worked fine. I turned on GPS (supposed to drain the battery) and WiFi and found i could get 1.5 days of fairly heavy use ... say a few hundred photos. I'm sure the life is much longer if i turned off the GPS, but I generally download and charge overnight so i didn't see this as a big deal. The camera doesn't come with a charger where you pull the battery out and charge separately. I'm sure there are chargers that do that, but again, for my use case it didn't really matter. (By contrast, with my other camera i keep a stash of batteries ready)Charging and downloading involves opening up the sealed compartment. This is fairly easy to do. The camera comes with a brush for cleaning, which i wish i had brought with me, since i covered the thing with salt and sand on a regular basis. Still, it was easy to clean and i always got a good seal.Color tones, resolution were all excellent. I didn't figure out if there is an easy no-flash mode (i'm terrible at reading instructions) or if there is an easy way to adjust ISO.For night shooting i didn't have a tripod so i can't say much about its low light handling.For underwater shooting it was excellent and a blast to use. I've read reviews of the earlier model that said the display was useless underwater but i didn't find it so at all. In a pool without goggles, sure, you can't see the display. But you can't see anything.I took it scuba diving down to 45', and found the display to be crisp, easy to see, and very easy to use. I also loved the depth measurements (not sure if iPhoto stores them or not :( ) which was quite fun for scuba diving, and more convenient than looking at the tank meters. While there were some issues with shake in lower light conditions, most of the photos came out extremely well, and I didn't find there to be significant color problems. The brighter colored fish turned out quite well, and shots in murkier water turned out the way you would expect. Still, it was super easy to use, convenient to go to movie mode, and easy to take stills while actively filming movies. You can also easily zoom in and out, take photos, take movies etc one handed while under water and swimming, which is quite convenient. I used the underwater strap (separate purchase) which worked out great.Downloading is fast and easy, and most of the features are fairly intuitive. For example, the zoom lever is used when filming and also when previewing images.The wifi mode is kind of cool.The key thing is that you need to select the camera's wifi network from your iPhone network selections.. .then run the app. (Not exactly documented anywhere). Once i did that, it worked well and you can see from the camera lens on your phone, take pictures, download them, etc. I suppose that is pretty good for voyeur mode or fancy selfies... i tend to download and post from the computer so it wasnt too convincing for me, but if you primarily operate from your phone it should be quite convenient.Altogether, outside of quirkiness with the panorama modes it worked great.I tried the shake mode a few times but never got the hang of that so didn't bother.I still use my DSLR as my go to camera, but i'll definitely bring this with me at all times as well, and it is a heck of a lot more convenient for general use.Impressive camera, and quite fun for underwater use. Very glad i got it.

This book takes a look at highly priced contemporary art -- who makes it, what it costs, how it is sold, and some of the insane oddities of paying millions for a work that isn't even created by the artist. I found the first part of the book -- which focuses more on the artists and the art and some of the paradoxes about it to be quite interesting. For example, if a Brillo Box was created in a factory for an exhibit of works that mimic'd Andy Warhol's Brillo Box, but Warhol never made it,or saw it, or new about it, but it was in a Warhol show, is it worth millions or is it just a Brillo box? If an artist makes a show that is a video of them having sex with a client, and being paid for the video as an art work, is it a master work or is it just essentially prostitution?The second half of the book, which focuses more on the mechanics of auction houses, pricing guarantee models, and after markets I found a lot less interesting.Hence, i found the book altogether to be mixed... some inspiration and interesting stories, and some rather dull analysis of auction house funding.

I heard the author speak on NPR, and found his stories fascinating, but the book didn't have that same sense as hearing it spoken. While it paints a very interesting portrait of life in West Virginia, told in a swirling shotgun style, I didn't walk away with any of the characters resonating strongly for me. This is, of course, a purely personal view. I suppose I tend to like a bit less experimental style of fiction, and as such was a mismatch for me. Certainly, it was a fun, fast read with a lot of amusing episodes, but it wasn't as strong as I had hoped for.

I approached this book with very high expectations, and perhaps that is why i came away from it disappointed. The book does an excellent job looking into the life of the author, a black woman who grew up in a poor fractured family in the deep south. As such it is an interesting exploration of the complexities and difficulties women like her face, as well as a elegy of sort for family and friends that she lost. Here, for me, the book becomes trickier, in that while I felt great empathy it was hard to feel sympathy. By this I mean, one can look at the people who died in her life, or the overall societal situation, as one of oppression -- southern white culture has put down the black man, doesn't provide education, and as a result the people portrayed in the book resort to dropping out, being unemployed, using and selling drugs as a way to cope. Or, one could look at it as a tragic cultural norm where some, such as the author, are able to focus on education and make their way out of the cycle of poverty. While the book makes all of the individuals very personal, and paints those that would often be painted as dregs of society as having good hearts, at the same time, as an outsider who has watched many people come to this country with nothing and end up in very different situations, their actions seem very self destructive, in contrast to how the author's grandmothers and mother is portrayed. Early in the book the author comments that people would say "they got him" and she asks, who is the "they". I would have liked a bit more follow up on that question. Now, I am not a black southerner, so obviously I don't know what it is like and my viewpoint is thus different, but I really would have been interested in more exploration of what to do about the situation and more examination of some of the root causes. I am not suggesting by any means that it is easy to get out of the situations described in the book, but at the same time, i am not sure that as a society we should excuse the results, and more perspective on that in the concluding chapter would have made the book stronger.

This is a fascinating and engaging book. The premise of the book is that there are just too many people on the planet for sustainability. The author explores this from many angles, primarily by looking at many different cultures and how they are either increasing or decreasing their populations and the impacts that has on the planet. The book is particularly gripping because of the human approach that it takes to this important and unfortunately daunting problem -- instead of simply approaching the facts (we are way over populated and we are consuming too many resources and this is destroying the environment upon which we depend) -- the author interviews facilities in many different cultures. For example, the book begins by looking at the high birth rates among the ultra-orthodox in Israel and the Palestinians, and looks at why they have such a high birth rate, what sustains it culturally, and the impact it has on this very small area of land. He looks at how couples in Italy feel about children, and how the political and economic situation impacts their decisions. He looks at changes in farming and urban planning practices, impact of religion, the impact of the one child rule in China, and many other issues in exploring the environmental and cultural impacts of birth rate.I don't want to spoil the book by revealing too much.. but for me it was a book that I couldn't put down. It is very well written, engaging, and fascinating throughout, and a book that i have recommended many others to read. Really, a must read for anyone concerned about the environment.

This book takes an evolutionary look at the human body, using that as a way to cast light on a variety of modern ailments. The book starts by looking broadly at human evolution, and how we moved from Chimpanzees to the upright creatures we are today, tracing changes in bone structure, posture, brain size and diet among other issues. He then moves from that to look at various issue afflicting us today based on what he terms cultural evolution. In particular, what did the shift from hunter gatherer society to farm based society do, and then more importantly, what was the impact of post-industrial revolution life. In short, suppose you take a creature evolved to be an active hunter gatherer with a particular diet, and you sit the person in a chair for most of the day, reading a computer screen, embed them in a system surround by hormone disrupting chemicals and other goo, and feed them high sugar processed food... and voila, we have diabetes, cancer, obesity, insomnia and much more. The book describes why, from an evolutionary basis, we have all of these issues, and suggests as well cures... basically involving having a diet and exercise pattern more in keeping with our evolution.Altogether, a very interesting book. At times it is a bit long or a tad repetitive, so i would have preferred if it could have been reduced a bit to be more succinct. But, you will learn a lot reading it.

This book takes an in depth look at the lives of a handful of vets who return from Iraq and Afghanistan with PTSD and TBI, and how that has impacted them and their families. This book doesn't attempt to look at vets at large, nor does it try to address the social or political implications of our war policies. It simply looks at the tragic side effects of war on a handful of individuals, who return home broken by either mental trauma from the death and destruction they have seen, or from side effects of brain injuries and physical injuries. These vets return to a system that doesn't understand or support their needs or those of their families. While it doesn't lay blame, it does show the difficulties of coping with the various physical and mental injuries, loss of loved ones, high rates of suicide and much more.The strength of the book lies in the compassion with which it treats the vets and their families, the brutal honesty with which it explores the issues, and the depth of involvement into what the lives are like. It provides a much needed view point to some of the personal costs of war. Altogether, gripping, well written, emotionally heavy and a very worthwhile read.

A fun and somewhat gonzo story about a drop out NJ teen who becomes a top art forger, making millions in the process... It's a fun story, well written, and a quite fast read. The book covers the author's fairly dramatic life style, from dropping out of high school, meeting up with a bunch of emerging (and quite famous artists), hanging out with the emerging gay scene in NYC,  and becoming an amazing forger. It is quite fun learning how easily he was able to fool all of the major auction houses (Christies, Sotheby's, et al) as well as ply his trade in forging famous artists. I particularly enjoyed the technical details of what he was doing, but would have liked a bit more about how he pulled off creating paintings so quickly. The book skates over parts of the artists own life .. and maybe should have delved in a bit more... but overall quite fun and certainly makes you think twice about the art market. As a painter myself, i found it particularly fun...

At first I didn't think I would like this book. After all, it is a story of a widowed mother who was abandoned by her mother at an early age and then who decides to have her elderly mother move in with her. Not exactly typical guy fare, especially as I often read history or science books. But, once I settled in tot he book I found it extremely interesting and moving. The author digs into her mother's life, her life, and her daughter's life, and how their upbringings and relationships have shaped and tortured them. I don't want to spoil the book, but suffice it to say that the book is filled with tortured and tragic lives, early deaths, alcoholism, affairs, and lots of drama and conflict, as well as resolution, healing and love. It is raw at times and always emotionally honest, and made me think a lot about a variety of people I have known, which at the end of the day, was part of what I liked the most -- the story brings you in enough that you are not only interested in the lives of those discussed, but you extend beyond those lives into your own.Good stuff, and for me, surprisingly enjoyable.

This is an interesting book that focuses on changes to war as the world changes -- in particular it looks at changes in battles that will occur as populations increase and become more concentrated, move towards the coasts, and become more connected. The book looks at a variety of fascinating case studies -- ambushes in Iraq and Afghanistan, the Black Hawk Down episode in Mogadishu, the attack in Bombay, battles in Kingstown, and many more. These case studies are the best part of the book, which, at other times, might be a tad academic for the average reader. But the case studies ... quite fascinating. The author looks at what causes some of these attacks, the tactics used, and how they are altered by the various shifting factors mentioned. I found the discussion of the attack in Bombay particularly interesting, especially with how the attackers used media and social media to stay one step ahead of the police and counter terrorism units. The picture painted isn't particularly pleasant, and as resource patterns shift and coastlines of poor countries are impacted by climate change, the expected chaos is formidable.Very interesting thoughts and observations, although occasionally slow.

I really enjoyed this book. It covers a fascinating period in China's history, when it opened up to the West, and before the Revolution. Ruled by isolationist emperors with a rigid power structure, this book traces the rise in power of one of the emperor's many concubines. Initially a low concubine, she is elevated when she becomes the mother of his first (and only surviving) son. This in turn eventually leads to a coup in which she assumes power. Often vilified in history, this book tells the inside story, and reveals the many struggles Cixi overcame, and the fascinating reforms that she lead. It is filled with history, intrigue (with numerous plots and attacks from the inside, Western countries, Japan) and the tricky paths that she navigated and she helped steer China into modernity, while still ruling more or less within the traditional gender defines.The book is beautifully written, elaborately researched, and has enough twists and turns of history to keep you turning the pages. It is one of those books that you will not want to let go until you finish. Great great history book and one of the most interesting history books I have read about China.

This book focuses on the role of women in Hitler's killing machinery. It profiles several German women who were caught up in the war -- nurses, secretaries, wives and others -- and looks at what they did before the war, how they became involved, what they did during the war, and what they did after. Some of the women were indirectly involved in the Holocaust and others were active participants.There are a number of interesting perspectives in this book, in that it is focused on women who were involved in the war, an often uncovered topic. It looks at the shifts in women's roles in German society after World War I, and how they got involved with the war, and hypothesizes that a very large number of women were directly involved in the happenings of the Holocaust.With the exception of a few chapters (most notably the one wondering about women's psychologies), the book was quite interesting -- both in terms of the changes in society that altered women's roles, the activities of the various profiled women during the war, and how they were almost all let off the hook after the war. Each of these areas is colored by gender and gender relationships.An interesting book about the war and a very different perspective.I would have liked a few chapters cut and a lot more chapters added, but certainly worth reading.

Great gloves for the price. They are quite lightweight and provide for terrific flexibility. Great for keeping hands a little cleaner and offering very basic protection. These are lightweight jersey and as I use them, they are largely disposable. They serve a great purpose for light duty use around the home, garage and yard.

Good Shimano quality. Really does eliminate chain slap and the ride is very quiet. The only reason I did not give it a 5 star rating is due to the added stiffness in shifting. Moving up the cassette (from small ring to larger rings) the added tension makes the pressure required on the shift lever a bit stiffer. Not so much that I would go back to the old style shifter. Once you get used to it the added effort just becomes second nature, but still noticeable when the shadow plus is disengaged or if you ride another bike without this feature. Still, I would recommend this derailleur, the pluses by far outweigh the one slight negative.

Had it connected to my regulated  municipal  household water supply and it failed within 30 days. When I got it I thought it was a nice hose, heavy brass fittings and it worked very well for 28 days. Per instructions, I did not leave it in the sun and I did not leave it pressurized, I always bled off the pressure when I was done watering. Turned it on today and something inside failed and water gushed out all over the hose.The idea is a good one however this hose is not, it is a miserable failure and completely unreliable. I am embarrassed that I missed all of the negative reviews not I am writing one. It is BAD.

Wish there was  a ZERO rating I could rate these. Just for your information take any remaining bags you have left and go into a dark room with a flashlight. With lights off place the flashlight inside your bags and turn it on, you may be amazed, I was. Full of holes or the coating was so thin you can easily see light through the bags. It was like looking at stars in the sky at night.My bags came folded and the majority of the holes were in the creases where the bags were folded. Run ! Pay a little more and get a better quality bag, your food is worth it and the bugs will not like you (or your food)
Love this feel good contemporary Christian music. I also love the message.
Love this feel good contemporary Christian music.
Got to love old time rock and roll, Mo-Town and Smokey. It's just feel good music and words you can sing along with.

I really like it and I have now purchased 3 of these. They are quite economical and take up little space yet can do a large job (see pictures including a large 12 inch sauce pan). Easy to operate and extremely fast, so far they doo all that the manufacturer said they will do. I am quite pleased. I can store when not needed and even take out side in good weather and use in conjunction with my BBQ.I have had to get used to cooking so quickly, this is not like an electric hot plate, this is real induction cooking. You can cook 2 ways one by setting and monitoring the temperature or, two by setting an a specified level that will not be temperature sensative, great for searing. There are built in safety provisions such as auto shut down after 70 minutesYou must have proper cookware, check your pans with a magnet. If the magnet sticks they should be ok, if the magnet does not stick you will need new pans. My Wolfgang Puck pans were copper-clad and did not work so I purchased some great Duxtop cookware (pictured beneath the cook tops)..

Quality tongs. The ring at the top acts as a hanger and it is also the release to open the tongs and/or lock them in the closed position for storage. Simply slide the ring up or down, I like this positive lock/unlock feature I don't have to rely on position and gravity to activate the opening or closing.Silicone coating is quite substantial and will not scratch my new induction cookware. I recommend them.

The rack appears to be well built and seems that it would accomplish it's intended purpose however it arrived with no hardware whatsoever. I could not assemble the rack. I read reviews that state it does not come with wall mounting screws, that is fine I planned on using my own. In this case there were none of the required 14 screws to attach the seven cross bars.I have ordered another and will see if it arrives complete. If it does and it performs as it should I will revisit this review and adjust my score.

I have been looking for a good old heavy cotton t-shirt, Eureka, I have found one. I ordered only one so I could experience the weight and quality first hand. I was not disappointed, the quality is good and the fabric is heavy.The label states "assembled in El Salvador of a U.S.A. fabric". As I stated, the quality is good and the American textile (cotton) is definitely better and heavier than any you will find in the average box store.The size runs a little large. I ordered a large and it looks like an extra large but that is ok. The shirt is 100 per cent cotton and will shrink. After one washing my large fits better, one or two more washes and it will be exactly as I wish. Bottom line; it is heavy, it runs large, it will shrink, I love it and I ordered more.

Heard it on the radio and had to have it. I am 66 years old and I love this sound, Britt has a great voice. Add in a bit of Hip-Hop and there is a winning combination.Mix this Upbeat Sound with a Great Message and you have some real feel good music. You can turn it up!

I use this light to back light items. For example I have this one setting on the floor behind my contemporary gas burning "wood stove". Pointing straight up, this provides interesting lighting on the stone wall behind the stove, makes an awesome mood or night light. The light swivels and can be aimed in most any position.The only draw back for me was the inexpensive in-line "on/off" switch that is close to the light. I improvised and have another way to operate the light without needing to bend and reach behind the stove.

Sizes appear to be accurate and the fit is snug enough so it does not move around or slide down. Good protection and does not restrict movement. I use for mountain biking and I recommend them. The only issue is that they make your elbow sweat but that would happen with any protective gear. They do breathe well but you will get warm.Appears to be quality materials and well made.

It is indeed easy to apply and it is easy to remove. I highly recommend micro-fiber cloths for best results. It is pretty cool that you can spray it on all your exterior plastic and there is no white (wax) residue. This works well on metal, chromed plastic and black plastic. Makes waxing your car much easier when you do not have to be so careful not to get on the plastic.I am old school and still like the good old fashioned paste wax but this works and saves a ton of time. I can wax my wife's full size SUV including bumpers and all plastic trim in one hour.Good price when you buy the 6 pack.
Really good, fast and easy to fix just heat some water and add the mix. Nice texture and the taste was much better than expected. Long shelf life, will buy more for sure.
Realistic looking gag gift. It's a pile of poo minus the smell, looks real, fooled some, what more can I offer.

We purchased this space heater to take the chill off the bedroom where we put the little granddaughter down for naps. The heater does the job nicely. It is completely quiet and appears to have ample capacity to heat a good size area especially if used in conjunction with a ceiling fan.There is that "new heater" smell but is easily overcome by using it a few times first preferably outside on the patio. We start the heater on high settings to hasten the warm up and the radiator easily maintains room temp at lower settings. There is no fan to blow or circulate air but the radiated heat is sufficient for a bedroom space.Appears to be well built and sturdy, no apparent danger of tipping over etc. I am quite pleased with this product.

I like the logo and the colors but that is where the like ends. This one was not quite as thin as some but, for me, it is too  thin. I ordered several Christian shirts and ended up sending 3 of them back. All of the shirts were made in Haiti or Honduras and several were quite thin and/or had large "old man" necks. All in all, it is too expensive and is not high quality, I will keep looking for a good quality, heavy cotton or cotton blend T-shirt.
So far it is a good mountain bike pedal, light but strong, good bearings. The aggressive surface makes it grippy.

A great everyday kitchen paring knife. Appears to be very good quality, very sharp and the handle has a good ergonomic feel. I recommend the matching steak knife set Victorinox 48792 Cutlery 6-Piece Steak Knife Set as a very good and quite inexpensive companion.

Just everyday kitchenware, appears to be good quality, quite sharp and has a nice ergonomic feel. I don't think you can beat them for the price, also I highly recommend the matching paring knifeVictorinox Swiss Classic 4-Inch Paring Knife, Spear TipThe paring knife has the same handle and good ergonomic feel and says "Swiss Made" on the handle, is very sharp and I believe it too is a very good value for the price.

It is all about relationship and it appears that TobyMac gets it. Terrific contemporary pop Christian music, you can turn this one up. Hope you have a good system that allows you to appreciate the richness.If Amazon would allow a one word review it would be..."get this album because it is more awesomer than the rest."
Works really well with the LG 840G, fits nicely and the material has a great feel. Protects my phone and still allows for full functionality of all buttons etc.

Good storage solution for the price. I looked at others that were quite a bit more expensive however this one does the job. Arrived quickly and the pieces just slide together, no tools required and about one minute to assemble.I tried it as a free standing unit and found what other reviewers noticed, that it is not stable on its own. Once I placed it squarely against the wall and screwed the top into the wall (see close up picture) with the screw that was provided, the unit is stable enough.Easily holds two bikes, note the supporting arms are adjustable to accommodate a variety of bicycle frame configurations. The bike on top has a straight cross bar so the support arms are parallel. The bike on the bottom has a dropped cross bar so the support arms are adjusted to facilitate this bike.The rack is made somewhere else so don't expect heavy materials or close tolerances for a tight fit. However this rack serves its purpose and keeps the bikes securely once anchored to the wall. I would purchase again for an inexpensive solution.

Great OEM quality and fit. Replaced my GMC starter several months ago and have not experienced any problems. The Amazon application chart was right on and the starter was a perfect fit. No shims were needed, starts quickly, minimal noise and does not draw excessive voltage.

Just roll it on like paint. It is a little thicker than paint, very black and will stain if not careful. Use the same precautions as you did with the textured coating, i.e., gloves, throw-away roller, use paint brush to "dab" into corners.

Really nice product. I was skeptical at first but after reading reviews I tried it out and I am happy that I did. The finished product indeed looks professional and appears to be durable and good quality. Pictures posted.Read the instructions, take your time, use gloves and old clothes and place something under the container to catch drips and for sure have great ventilation! The can is difficult to open, well-sealed for shipping I suppose, just keep working around the rim and eventually it will surrender. It took me several minutes to open the can.Comes with a pad to rough up surfaces, 1 paint brush, 1 roller handle and 2 roller pads, you need two coats. The roller handle is really cheap but it gets the job done and it is a throwaway. I completed my job within 24 hours allowing drying time for the first coat. I did a diamond-plate flatbed, about 38 square feet, with 2 coats and still have about one half gallon remaining. It appears there should be plenty for a standard bed pick-up including sides and tailgate.I used painters blue tape for edges but that did not work well on the diamond-plate, the liquid carrier ran underneath. For the final coat I used duct tape to obtain the crisp line I wanted and it worked. I rolled it on directly out of the can, I left a paint stir-stick in the can and as I worked I stirred the coating each time I dipped the roller in. The consistency appears to be just right I did not need to thin it out, stirs easily and is rich with texture (see close up of finish on diamond-plate.)Dab product in corners with paint brush, don't try to paint in normal fashion, when using the roller do not press down, it just thins out the application, get the roller well coated (mind the drips) and just move it across the area to coat.The first coat looked good however appeared to be a bit thin but the second application really did the trick, I now have a nice looking and thick application. I allowed the first coat to cure overnight about 16 hours, instructions state that the second coat needs to be applied within 24 hours so it will adhere to the first coat.I recommend for the do-it-yourselfer.
Semi-hard case fits my Nuvi 255W nicely. Sturdy zipper closure insures the device does not slip out. There is no extra room however for a wall charger, you can squeeze in the car charger however.

I have used TrakPhone's for years this is my 4th phone. I have always got good signal service and great customer service. The only reason I have been through 4 phones is because I upgrade as new and better features become available.I am not a heavy user so the annual plan with triple minutes serves me well. I have never run out of minutes, I just buy minutes once a year, they roll over unused minutes for you. My cell phone bill averages about 7 dollars per month. For me this is the only way to go.

Complete junk, difficult to work with, creases are difficult to get out. It is like trying to place cling wrap on your window and then trying to get it smooth so everything is not distorted.The Amazon label indicates that I purchased this item, I did but I am returning it tomorrow.Look for dot matrix shades they are much more user friendly and not so difficult to unstick from it's self.

AWESOME !!!!!!! Turn up the sound. I am an old guy and tend to be a bit on the traditional side but I like rock and roll so I thought I would give this a try and I am extremely pleased that I did. The best Star Spangled Banner rock version ever, I love it.Well done Madison Rising.

I purchased 2 of the 24 Gallon size, one to use as an emergency medical supply container and one to utilize as a portable survival (bug out) box. I found that the 24 gallon size is plenty large enough for each of my intended uses, I kept my items limited to what was most basic and necessary and I still have room for some additional items.I am pleased that I got the 24 gallon size for my purposes because even when they are packed I can still lift them and they are easily transportable, I would think a larger size container that was packed may be too heavy to handle without help.I have posted some pictures, they have hard plastic handles that snap into position and they have a place for you to lock then. Sturdy enough construction and appear to be rugged and durable.

I got this to tie down my mountain bike I needed to replace a pair of very old Dorcy motorcycle hold downs. The motorcycle hold downs had a large hook that went over the handle bars and if not placed properly they would damage the shifters so I tried something new.I use these straps (there are 2 in the package) along with soft tie extensions available from Amazon (Keeper 5729 16" Soft Tie Extension Tie-Down, 800 lbs. 2500 lbs. break strength 4 Pk.) and now I have several options to secure the bike.The straps are well made and work well each is 6 feet long and would be useful for many tie down applications. I posted a few pictures.
Shipped very quickly and arrived in perfect condition. It is a quality product and the application was easy and flawless. I have posted some photos, I recommend.

I would have given a 5 star rating had the product not taken 12 days to get to me. I read previous reviews and learned that the installation instructions are printed on the inside of an otherwise plan cardboard box so I was careful to open to get the instructions.The instructions are very generic and are not specific to your vehicle, there are some diagrams but are very difficult to see and are crowded and not clear. However it is pretty easy to install these things they snap on at the top and the bottom, there is a metal band that acts as a retaining spring. I found that if you have a small flat blade screwdriver you can pop that band off and you are ready for install.On the mounting ball or stud where you are going to snap the new strut onto I apply a tiny bit of white Lithium grease for ease of installation.These struts were a little shorter than the factory struts (2002 Trailblazer) but they work flawlessly. I recommend then just do not expect clear installation instructions or, in this case, fast shipping.

These are surprising nice ammo cans for plastic. They are quite sturdy and seem to be reinforced in the right places for strength and durability. They seal nicely with a large latch that will accommodate 2 pad locks (see posted pictures.)I took photos as I loaded these two boxes to demonstrate the generous size I am not sure what order the photos will appear but I started in each box with 200 rounds of .223, 100 rounds of 38 Special, 50 rounds of 12 Gage, 1,100 rounds of 22LR, 150 rounds of 380 and 100 rounds of 9 MM. Later I added to each box an additional 50 rounds of 38 Special and 50 rounds of 380.Altogether each box contains 1800 rounds of ammo all in original packaging and I believe there is still room for another 200 rounds. I would not be surprised to get 2,000 packaged rounds in each box.Now for the real test, do you dare to pick it up by the plastic handle? Yes, the boxes and the handles are quite sound and lift the weight handily, I had no issues with the abilities of the handle vs. weight.The boxes have small tabs on the top so they are stackable and do not slide around. The top has a small "O" ring seal and the manufacture states they are water resistant, I do not think they are waterproof. However these will serve me just fine for keeping my ammo dry stored in the house, shop or cellar or in a tent in the field.For the price and with Super Saver Shipping I believe they are a good deal especially with the cost of steel ammo cans.

I really like this ottoman and the price was good. The ottoman is comfortable and quite functional and has ample storage. My difficulty in reviewing this otherwise quality product lies with the fit and finish (see photo's I posted.)The stitched seams do not match and the top is not properly aligned with the base and hinges are exposed. All of this does not keep this from being a good and functional piece of furniture, they are just cosmetic.I thought that I would give 3 stars but the functionality, comfort and supple materials raised my rating to a 4. Had there been more attention to fit and finish this would definitely be a 5.

Received these in March 2012 and the expiration date was February, 2015, so I got nearly a 3 year shelf life.The chicken is good quality and is flavorful. Great for chicken tacos, burritos and chicken salad. Quick and easy, I rinse the contents.There is over 60 grams of protein in each can (10 grams per serving and the serving size is 2 ounces) this is one reason for selecting this product.
