I keep a year supply of food on hand and these fit in exceptionally well with my food storage and rotation efforts.I also ordered the Swanson canned chicken and was very pleased with that product however the Tyson is a larger can, a better price and has less sodium (200 grams vs. 270 grams)I like both products and recommend both however I will be purchasing the Tyson over the Swanson just because of the value. Both taste good and appear to be quality products.

Received these in March 2012 and the expiration date was August 2013, so I got nearly a year and a half recommended shelf life.The chicken is good quality and is flavorful. Great for chicken tacos, burritos and chicken salad. Quick and easy, I rinse the contents.There is nearly 50 grams (10 grams per serving and the serving size is 2 ounces) of protein in each can which is one reason for selecting this product. I keep a year supply of food on hand and these fit in nicely with my food storage and rotation efforts.I also ordered the Tyson canned chicken and was very pleased to note the Tyson arrived at the same time and has a February 2015 recommended shelf life. NOTE: The seller graciously provided me with a sample of this product and asked me to write a review.My job required me to listen to streaming broadcasts and write articles about them, so I've been on the lookout for a good, reliable set of wireless headphones that I could wear so I wouldn't be chained to my desk or risk missing out on important content during the day. So, I've tried out several of them that are available on Amazon. For my purposes, the Otium Wireless Bluetooth Headphones work well, but those whose primary concern is music quality may be more demanding.The headphones are actually a pair of earplugs that are angled to fit into the ear better. For me, they fit quite well and did not fall off or dislodge in normal walking around, bending over, etc. The headphones come with two alternate-sized pairs of ear buds as well. The headphones themselves are black, with an approximately two-foot long yellow cable connecting them. When wearing them, the bottom of the cable was about midway down my chest.The package also includes a mini-USB charging cable that is less than six inches long. This small cable may make recharging the cable inconvenient depending on your power source, but the headphones work with other USB charging cables as well. One earphone has a tiny LED that turns color from red to blue to indicate the headphones are fully charged. The charging cable connects to one earphone while the controls are on the other earphone.The Otium Headphones have two fairly large control buttons, both of which are easy to access while the earphone is in your ear, and which are far enough away from each other that you shouldn't accidentally push the wrong button once you learn their locations.. The buttons are also colored yellow to contrast with the black earpiece. The power button is on the bottom of the earphone, while the volume button is on the side.It takes about 1.5-2 hours to charge the headphones, according the the instructions. According to the specs, the power should last 4-5 hours while in use, but the longest I've used it is about 3 hours at one time. You turn the power on or off by depressing the power button until the voice says "power on" or "off." Pairing and connecting is very fast and virtually automatic if you've set the Bluetooth on your phone or computer to seek new devices. The volume button has a considerable range from virtually mute to blasting your ears, so everyone should be able to find the volume level they want the first time they use the earphones.Although I don't use the headphones with a cellphone, according to the specs, you can answer, hang up, or reject calls by pushing the power button once or twice (the headphones alert you of an incoming call). The power button also allows you to play or pause music while the volume button allows you to advance or go back through the channels of music.Overall, I was quite pleased with the operation of the Otium Headphones. They had a decent but not great range; I was able to go 25 feet or so away without losing the signal, and if I walked further away in the building, the headphones could easily reacquire the signal when I came back in range. The sound quality of voices was very good; I could clearly distinguish what was being said. The only problem I noticed, which was not a problem for me personally considering how I use the headphones, was the quality of the music playback when I listened to some music videos on Youtube. The music quality was okay, but not the most dynamic in the world, with a slightly hollow sound. The bottom line is that they are perfectly acceptable for use while running or working out, but I wouldn't want to use them in my living room to listen to my best CD's.For use as advertised as a set of sports/workout headphones, the Otium Headphones should satisfy most people unless they are very particular about the quality of the music reception through the headphones. They are also competitively priced and user friendly. The only other possible drawback is the very short charging cable. Certainly they met my needs and I would definitely recommend them for use in an office setting as well as for a set of wireless workout headphones.

Bernie Madoff's gargantuan Ponzi scheme is the stuff as dreams are made on, specifically the dreams of fiction writers who leaped at the idea of using variations on Madoff's chicanery as plot vehicles. Morris Fenris has done just that in "Maximum Redemption," a breezy novella about a con artist who puts Madoff to shame. However, Fenris' story becomes just a bit too preposterous from time to time.Maxwell Sheppard is the new Madoff, a crooked financier who stole over $100 billion but got caught because he didn't pull up stakes quite in time. He's now one of the most hated men in America but is surviving in prison thanks to his ability to use some of the money that he squirreled away to grease the wheels. Sheppard is not a total sleazeball, though, as his new cellmate, an undercover FBI agent soon discovers. He made sure that every person he conned could afford to lose the money. So, he's quite hurt when he discovers that a group of ordinary people in a small Iowa town stand to lose their homes because of his scam. Max is even more upset when he figures out that a crooked businessman used Sheppard's plan as cover to perpetrate a swindle of his own. So, he makes a deal with the FBI to turn over the bulk of his missing money if they will let him go to Iowa to try to set things right."Maximum Redemption" is light easy reading; most people will probably go through it one sitting. Max is an engaging sort of guy, and he has an easy going rapport with Wilson, the FBI agent who posed as his cellmate. It's not quite Nick Nolte and Eddie Murphy in "48 Hours" but the byplay between the two of them is good. If anything, the 90-page-long  "Maximum Redemption" feels like it's a few chapters too short. It takes half the book for Max and WIlson to arrive in Iowa. What follows is a whirlwind of activity as they talk to bank officials, affected homeowners, and the crooked businessman. This material could easily have formed the basis for a top notch financial thriller, but Fenris rushes through it all in just a few pages.I also had a problem with the sheer implausibility of the magnituted of Max's scam. Fenris blithely notes that Max stole about $100 billion and still had at least $70 billion of that total. Those amounts are approximately five times the amount Madoff took. Further, the FBI learns that Max had the money hidden away in the form of bearer bonds. However, bearer bonds have not been issued since the early 1980's, and there simply aren't that many of them still in circulation so that someone could buy up that many of them without being the transactions being recognized. I realize that all thrillers (and indeed much of the rest of fiction) require a certain degree of suspension of disbelief, but I would have thought an author writing about financial chicanery on this scale would have done a bit more research on the subject or scaled back the size of the scam.Overall, "Maximum Redemption" seems more like a well-written, fairly detailed outline for a thriller than the thriller itself. The less people think about it, the better it reads, because there seems to be a fair amount of the story missing in the sketchily written second half, and there are nagging plot implausibilities along the way. Fenris could also have used some better copy editing; there are some nagging grammatical errors along the way (using "Calvary" instead of "cavalry"). "Maximum Redemption" is acceptable lightweight entertainment, but it could have been considerably better.

NOTE: The seller graciously provided me with a sample of this product and asked me to write a review.Living in a condominium in which we share a building with three other units, one directly beneath us, has given me a healthy respect for fire, smoke, and carbon monoxide hazards, especially those coming from other parts of our building. So when the Mudder people asked me to review one of their CO alarm detectors, I was more than happy to do so.The Mudder Carbon Monoxide Alarm Detector is a small, easy to use, and easy to install detector. The unit is white and looks like a hockey puck, measuring about four inches in diameter and 1.5 inches thick. The unit comes with a removable back plate that can be mounted on a wall or ceiling (screws and plastic inserts included) and runs on three AA batteries (not included) that are inserted on the back of the detector. Once the batteries are in place, you place the detector on the back plate and give it a half twist to lock it in place.The Mudder CO Alarm Detector has a blue LED display that indicates the exact CO level in parts per million (PPM). The LED lights up automatically if the alarm is triggered, or you can push the test button to get a reading (it's been 000 each time we've tried it). The unit has two small lights. A green light flashes every 30 seconds or so to indicate the detector is working, and a red light will flash if the batteries are low (the unit will also chirp intermittently if that happens) or the unit is malfunctioning.To test the alarm, you just hold the button down for five seconds or so. The alarm will emit a burst of four beeps immediately and then again five seconds later. It's loud enough to be heard from an adjacent room, but if you live in a large house, for a number of reasons, it's a good idea to have more than one detector. The detector has another good feature, a memory alarm feature. If the alarm goes off for any reason while you're not at home, the detector will display a warning signal and keep a record of the maximum CO level recorded. This allows you to investigate and find out why the alarm went off.The Mudder Detector has a fairly detailed instruction manual with advice on where to install detectors and how many detectors to use, the significance of various CO levels, symptoms of CO poisoning, and other helpful information. Unfortunately, the manual was obviously translated into English from a foreign language (the detector is made in China), so some of the instructions are a bit difficult to understand. The company sells three different detectors on the same Amazon page at different prices and with different features. The unit I was sent was the Classic version. I don't know how that compares with other models.I find it a bit difficult to assign a rating to this detector for the simple reason that unless and until we have an actual alarm it will be difficult to know how well it works. I am impressed with the setup and testing and willing to use it in my house (it's already in its permanent location), but I hope I'll never have to find out for real just how well it works. Because there's that inherent uncertainty, and because the instruction manual leaves a bit to be desired in terms of comprehensibility, I'm giving the Mudder CO Detector a four-star rating. However, the Mudder Detector is a definite keeper.

NOTE: The seller graciously provided me with a sample of this product and requested that I write a review.With workspace at a premium in my office, I'm interested in avoiding as many wires and as much clutter as possible, and I felt that one solution would be a wireless mouse for the work laptop. So, when the TeckNet people asked me to test out their mouse, I thought it could definitely come in handy at the office. It has certainly exceeded my expectations, especially considering the usual sale price under $10.The TeckNet Pro Wireless Mouse is stylish and well designed to fit the hand. It's also fairly small, measuring about 4.5" long by 3" wide at the widest point. It runs on two AAA batteries (not supplied). The bottom and sides of the mouse are black, with the left side grip a rubberized pad with holes in it for better traction. The top of the mouse comes in four different colors at virtually the same price (black, blue, purple, red). The mouse I was sent was red.The mouse includes a dongle receiver that plugs into an open USB slot on the computer. One good bonus feature about the TeckNet mouse is that is has a slot on its underside for storing the dongle. Dongles, including this one, are usually very small and very easy to lose or misplace if they are ever disconnected from the computer for any reason, and the storage slot on the mouse makes it almost impossible to lose the TeckNet dongle. When I plugged it in and turned on the mouse (an on-off switch on the underside), the computer recognized the mouse in less that a minute and it's been smooth sailing every since.The TeckNet mouse supposedly has some energy saving features (the Amazon page claims 18-24 month battery life) including three different power saving levels leading up to a sleep mode. I can't verify that exactly, but it does seem to go into a sleep mode when not in use for a while, but it responds instantly to the push of a button. As for buttons, the mouse has five of them. In addition to the standard three buttons on the top, there are forward and back buttons in the left side depression where I can press them easily with my thumb to scroll backwards and forwards through Internet pages. The mouse also has an adjustable DPI switch right below the wheel on the top of the mouse. For those who don't know, changing the DPI changes the sensitivity of the mouse, in other words, how much the cursor moves in response to physically moving the mouse. Users can adjust the DPI level to their particular liking by clicking on the DPI switch.I have found the Tecknet mouse to be very responsive as I've used it so far. I've used it on two surfaces, the wood-like desktop at my office and the mousepad at home, and it works well on both of them. It also is very good at highlighting large amounts of text for copying or moving without hanging up, and it does a good job of precisely capturing a few characters as well, to provide a link to one particular word, for example.This TeckNet Mouse appears to be a newer and slightly smaller version of a similar Tecknet Mouse that's one of the best sellers on Amazon. I don't know enough about the two mouses (and I've never used the older mouse) to know how they might differ, but I can predict that this mouse is also going to become quite popular as users discover it. The new TeckNet Mouse works very well and has an impressive array of features for a wireless mouse selling under $10. The Tecknet Pro is a definite winner.

According to his Amazon biography, Michael Monhollon, author of "Trial by Ambush," teaches business law at a university. His legal experience is evident in the two brief courtroom scenes in the book, which, not coincidentally are the best written sections of the book. Unfortunately, the remainder of "Trial by Ambush" reads like a cross between "Nancy Drew" and "Letters to Penthouse Magazine," except that the level of actual detection and mystery is far greater in a typical Nancy Drew novel."Trial by Ambush" is the first in a series of "courtroom thrillers" featuring Robin Starling, an associate at a prestigious Richmond, VA, law firm. By the end of the first chapter in the book, it was apparent to me that Monhollon had fallen into the trap that catches a lot of male mystery/thriller writers with attractive female protagonists. Namely, the main character and everyone with whom she comes in contact has to be obsessed with sex. Robin is bothered by her unsatisfactory sex life while at the same time, every male character in the book practically drools over her and every other female character. Within that first chapter alone, the male lawyers at her firm do enough outrageous things to subject themselves to about a half dozen different sexual harassment lawsuits.Robin brings on a lot of the grief herself. She has a bad habit of finding reasons to take her clothes off in public and parade around in her underwear or less in front of perfect strangers. In one scene, in order to search a witness' apartment for evidence, she tries to break into an upstairs balcony window and winds up ripping her dress and taking it off so she can give a couple of contractors below an eyeful of an attorney in underwear. I've read a number of Grisham books, not to mention Perry Mason, Philip Marlowe, and Lew Archer novels, and never once did those guys have to strip down to their tightie whities in order to get into an apartment.I'm sure Monhollon didn't intend these episodes to be serious, but if his idea of humor is an attractive woman repeatedly having to strip in front of strangers, then something is very off about this novel and the author's idea of a joke. Nor is "Trial by Ambush" redeemed by an entertaining thriller plot. The story involves an old college friend of Robin's telling her that the former classmate's employer has been cooking the corporate books. Naturally, the woman soon turns up dead, and Robin tries to get the goods on the company.For most of "Trial by Ambush," Robin is either being chased and attacked by corporate goons or trying to break into the homes and offices of the company's officers where she can get in fights with them and hope they will say or do something to incriminate themselves and the company. And that's it, for 300 monotonous pages, with one fight followed by another. Monhollon's description of the chases and action are reasonably competent, but they grow tiring rather quickly.The only time that "Trial by Ambush" shows any signs of life are in the two courtroom sequences, which, combined take up less than 10% of the book. Ironically, one of those sequences involves a summary judgment hearing, a proceeding about which most non-lawyers are completely unfamiliar (as they probably are with the term "summary judgment" itself). Further, it's a case that has nothing to do with the plot of the book. The second sequence involves a preliminary hearing for Robin's boyfriend, a fellow attorney at Robin's firm, who is arrested for the whistleblower's murder. It's not exactly something you'd see on TV, but Robin adapts a most unusual (and clever) line of defense for the accused.I'm giving "Trial by Ambush" two stars because Monhollon has some writing talent and he can write an entertaining courtroom scene. Unfortunately, for a "courtroom thriller," those scenes are few and far between, while the rest of the book seems to have emerged from the fantasies of a high school student who's just discovered internet porn. I'm certainly no prude, and I don't mind the spiciest of sex scenes if they have a relation to the story, but in "Trial by Ambush," the story is all sex and sophomoric fight sequences.  Monhollon should stick to his area of expertise, the legal arena, and leave the sex and violence to those who know how to integrate them into a story. "Trial by Ambush" should be disbarred.

NOTE: The author graciously gave me a copy of this book and asked me to write a review.Author Stefania Mattana takes readers to the Italian countryside along with her hero, former Scotland Yard detective Chase Williams, in an entertaining mystery novella "into the Killer Sphere." After having left the police force in his homeland under strained circumstances, Chase is now working for an import/export firm in the small city of Tursenia, somewhere in the Apennine Mountains. Tursenia, like Jessica Cabot's hometown of Cabot Cove, seems to have an inordinately high number of strange murders, and Chase's boyhood friend Angelo, who's now an inspector with the Tursenian police deaprtment, calls Chase in to consult on difficult cases.The case in "Killer Sphere" is certainly strange. A wealthy man is found dead in his home, apparently crushed under a chandelier. However, after inspecting the crime scene, Chase figures out the man was actually conked on the head earlier, after which the killer cut the chandelier loose to fall on the corpse. There are quite a few potential suspects: a number of the deceased's relatives were in the vicinity when the murder occurred.Even though the novella is only 80 pages long, author Mattana takes her time in telling the story. Interrogations go on for a while as Chase allows the various witnesses to expound their theories on the case. But, although the pace is leisurely, the story doesn't feel padded. Each interview and encounter advances the case along, and readers will easily get caught up by Mattana's story-telling style. The solution to the case is rather ingenious, and Mattana does a good job of planting the clues as she goes.While Mattana plays the usual mystery writer's game with readers to challenge them to figure out whodunit, she's also playing an intriguing game regarding her main character. Chase is a man of mystery himself with an interesting backstory about his relationship with his own father and how he came to Tursenia in the first place, but Mattana chooses to reveal only bits and pieces. We do get a few good anecdotes, such as Chase's struggle with the local bureaucracy to avoid parking tickets for his car, all of which serve to make him a character about whom we're interested to learn more."Into the Killer Sphere" is an amusing light read whose main attractions are the lead character and the author's ability to weave the Italian setting into the story. The detection in the book is a mix of keen observation, scientific analysis and offbeat discussions on topics like whether a particular killing is a "man's" or a "woman's" type of crime. Some of the transitions between scenes are a bit awkward, as is an occasional sentence (which may result from the author's not being a native English speaker herself). By the end of the story however, readers will definitely want to read more about Chase Williams and his new Tursenian home.

NOTE: The seller graciously provided me with a sample of this product and asked me to write a review.The Karmick Luxury Hot/Cold Eye Mask is a lavender scented sack that's designed to be placed over the eyes when resting. I agreed to check it out because my wife often has headaches and troubles falling asleep, so I thought this mask might help. While it's good looking and easy to apply, neither my wife nor eye were able to use it when warm for more than a few seconds due to the overpowering lavender smell.The mask is actually a sack with a lot of grains inside that slide around easily. It's royal blue in color and measures about 9" x 3.5." It's made of satin or a material that feels like satin. When placed over the eyes, the Karmick mask extends about an inch past the edge of each eye socket, and the grainy material molds itself to the contours of a person's face to block out light nearly completely.The mask can be applied either hot or cold. When i put the mask in the freezer for several hours, it was cool when applied to the skin but not cold enough to burn. The seller recommends microwaving for 30 seconds to heat it up, but that got it a bit too hot for our tastes, so i cut that to 25 seconds so it would be warm.According to the seller, the mask is filled with natural lavender and flax seed. We have used the mask hot, cold, and at room temperature. When cold, the mask is rather comfortable and soothing with the lavender smell not too strong. However, at room temperature or especially when heated, the lavender smell is quite overpowering and has remained so after several uses. My wife doesn't have a very good sense of smell, but even she had to remove the mask after a minute or so. When warmed up, I found the lavender smell overwhelming and was unable to keep it on my face for more than a few seconds.It's possible that the lavender smell may fade with time and become more bearable. However, we put the mask aside for two weeks after our initial unfortunate experience and found the smell to be just as strong when we reapplied the mask. It's a pleasant lavender smell... from about five feet away, but not when it's less than five inches from my nose. In this case, the nose knows best, not to use the Karmick mask.

NOTE: The seller graciously provided me with a sample of this product and asked me to write a review.My wife is a very organized person and has about a million jars, bowls, covered dishes, plastic boxes, and other containers in our kitchen and spare room in which she stores things that go in the refrigerator and in the workshop. And, considering that some of these containers are opaque and sit in the refrigerator for months, it's hard to tell at a glance what's inside. So, when the Kicty people offered me a chance to review their reusable Chalkboard Labels, I thought they would be a lot of help for her, and I was right.Although Kicty sells these labels with various numbers of labels per package, the package they sent me contained 72 black labels, six on a sheet, on 12 different sheets. The package also contains a liquid white chalk pen with a reversible tip, one end sharp and the other end more rounded. All the labels are the same decorative pattern, measuring about 3" x 2" each.The labels are easy to peel off and stick to any reasonably smooth surface. Once applied, they can be removed and re-attached multiple times without leaving any adhesive gunk on the surface, but they won't fall off on their own. The labels are fairly thin, but they are also fairly durable; most people will use a fingernail to dislodge them which might crinkle them a bit, but they can be smoothed over without damaging the corners. They also won't tear under normal stress, such as yanking them off a container too hard.You can write on the labels with any chalk pen or good old fashioned chalk. When dry, the chalk won't rub off easily, but if you use a damp paper towel or cloth, the chalk ink comes right off. You will still be able to see the dark impression of the letters on the label unless you use a bit of elbow grease to rub it out thoroughly.My only problem with the labels, other than the lack of variety of patterns, was with the ink pen itself. It has to be primed before using, which requires shaking it, and then pushing down on the tip until the tip fills with ink. Anyone who has worked with this type of pen before will know what to do, but a novice may well be disappointed at not being able to uncap the pen and write on the labels immediately. Anyone reading the description on the Amazon page or some of the more detailed reviews similarly will learn how to prime the pen, but it would be more advisable to put some instructions either on the pen itself or in the package (the package does indicate the pen is reversible but not how to start the ink flowing).Overall, the Kicty labels are easy to use and apply and reuse, and they don't fall off either in at room temperature or in a refrigerator. While  there's no variety in the pattern offered, the package of 72 labels represents very good value for the price. And, frankly, there's a fun factor involved in using these chalk labels rather than post-it notes or taping pieces of paper to a covered dish. You can chalk these up as a good value.

When I was a college student, the governor of Georgia was Lester Maddox, well known for being a man of action. Right or wrong, good or bad, Lester would go after whatever he perceived as the evils threatening the people of Georgia. One of his most highly publicized foes was an entire town, Ludowici, GA, which had established a well earned reputation as being one of the country's worst speed traps, located on US 301, the main route from the Northeast to Florida. Eventually, Lester actually put up large billboards at the city limits warning motorists of the dangers to their wallet they faced in the town and kept state troopers on duty to protect the signs from being vandalized by the locals fearful of losing the town's main source of revenue.For most people however, Ludowici won't ring any bells, but Joey Ledford, who was an Atlanta Journal editor and columnist for over 20 years, remembers Ludowici very well and has made the town the thinly fictionalized subject of his novel "Speed Trap." The novel is set in the south Georgia town of Astoria, the Ludowici stand-in, and set in the late 1950's, the heyday of the real Ludowici. As a time capsule of the era in the State of Georgia and a description of the massive amount of illegal activities going on, Ledford's work is excellent. However, as an actual novel with supposedly real characters, "Speed Trap" leaves a bit to be desired.Most of the first half of Ledford's book describes life in Astoria. In addition to the local police just waiting to pounce on and ticket unsuspecting tourists passing through, the town had other sources of revenue. A downtown stop light was controlled by a lookout in a nearby hotel who could change it from green to red in an instant. Local gas stations doubled as crooked gambling joints, luring tourists into futilely trying their luck at rigged games. And, if they didn't watch carefully, their cars could mysteriously develop engine trouble shortly after leaving the station. Also, a couple of nearby brothels catered to other needs of the tourists.In the midst of all this, the Georgia governor (unlike Maddox, this governor is quite a womanizer) decides to take on the county boss, Earl Griffin. Unlike Ludowici, however, Griffin's stooges on the local police department go a lot farther in terms of illegal activity, including rape and murder. So, the governor dispatches a straight-arrow state trooper, Cal Bocock, to Astoria to try to get the goods on Griffin and his crooked cops. What ensues is a battle that grows increasingly violent.The second half of "Speed Trap" is less of a fictionalization of Ludowici and more of a typical B-movie redneck sheriff melodrama with highly stereotyped characters. Bocock is practically a Dudley Do-Right, while the villains seem to have come straight off the set of "Deliverance." The only interesting characters in the book are the rascally governor (a Burt Reynolds type) and the "Three Musketeers," the tweenage children of the three local cops, who seem to have wandered into this book from a better, coming-of-age one. The concluding chapters of "Speed Trap" are still escapist fun to read, but not as interesting as the more factual opening.Joey Ledford has obviously done his research and, when he sticks close to the actual story of what went on in Ludowici, "Speed Trap" is fascinating reading, so much so that I wish he had scrapped his melodramatic fictional plot entirely and written a non-fiction book on the actual town. The action that wraps up the book isn't too bad, but his main characters leave a bit to be desired, and Cal Bocock in particular is simply too good to be true. Still, "Speed Trap" is an entertaining reminder of of what life was like in the not-too-bygone days in rural Georgia.

NOTE: The seller graciously provided me with a sample of this product and asked me to write a review.The Atalanta Durable Weekly Wall Planner is a perfect example of the phrase "caveat emptor," or more specifically that potential product buyers on Amazon need to look very carefully at the entire product description rather than rely merely on the title and large picture that accompanies the product on its page. I freely confess that when the Atalanta people asked me to review this product, I glanced at the picture and title without looking all that closely at the description and assumed there would be sending me an actual chalkboard suitable for use as a weekly planner. I was wrong, as, I suspect, some customers who buy the product will be. And, to make matters worse, this product is really of very limited use for any purpose.The "Wall Planner" isn't a wall planner and it isn't a chalkboard. It's eight very thin vinyl sheets with a sticky back side (plus a liquid chalk pen). The sheets measure just under 8" x 12" each. To use the sheets, you peel them away from the thicker white backing to which they are attached and apply them to a wall or other hard surface. It's very important that the surface be smooth; attaching it to a spackled paint wall leads to bumps and possibly tearing the vinyl. One of the pictures on the Amazon page depicts one of these sheets attached to a brick wall, something which would lead to the sheet matching the contour of the bricks with their mortar valleys in between, not a suitable surface to write on or something aesthetically pleasing to look at. Even on a smooth surface, you're likely to get air bubbles and wrinkles when applying the sheet. Plus, if you're like me, it might take several tries to get the sheet perfectly vertical, especially if you're trying to line up multiple sheets to form a large writing surface.Whether you're just trying to straighten the sheets out or you want to relocate a sheet in a different location or other room, trying to remove a sheet and re-apply it is quite difficult. The result is like trying to remove any sticky object like adhesive or duct tape; the vinyl doesn't come off smoothly and instead scrunches together because the sheet is so thin, making it difficult to separate. Then, when it's reapplied to another hard surface, it's even more difficult to smooth out without wrinkles. Frankly, the one time I tried to do so, the result wasn't anything I would want on display in my office or anywhere in my home where people could see it.On a positive note, the Atalanta Chalkboard is easy to write on. It's black (not the gray shown on the Amazon page), and most color chalk show up well. Even when dry, the chalk comes off quickly and easily with a damp cloth. So, if you can apply a decal smoothly and successfully on a surface, you will be able to write on it repeatedly. And, when I did remove it, it didn't damage the wall or leave any residue, so the wall was in considerably better shape than the decal itself.I just don't see this product as being very useful, and calling it a wall planner is like calling a blank canvas the Mona Lisa because you theoretically might be able to paint Da Vinci's masterpiece on that canvas if you had the talent. I doubt most people will be able to assemble something that looks as professional as the planner in the picture on the Amazon page and will instead have decals that are somewhat misaligned, with ridges and air bubbles and that look even worse if a vinyl decal has to be removed and reapplied for any reason. In addition, several of the sheets I received got damaged somewhat in shipping so they were already wrinkled when I got them. Knowing what I know now, if I want to use one of these sheets on a wall, I would simply leave the decal attached to its backing (which makes it thicker and sturdier) and merely tape it up on a wall with the backing still attached.Ironically, the Atalanta "Chalkboard," which isn't a chalkboard or a blackboard, is categorized as such on Amazon and is listed alongside other actual chalkboards selling for comparable prices that actually can be used as weekly planners. And even people looking for wall decals will probably want something that's easier to apply and re-apply. I appreciate the Atalanta people sending me a sample of their product, but this is one planner that really needed some better planning.

There's good news and bad news for those who pick up a copy of Nick Poole's "Dirty Cop," expecting to read a story about a tough but crooked policeman. The good news is that Poole has included a second story, this one a horror story entitled "The Murderess," along with "Dirty Cop," so readers actually get two stories for the price of one. The bad news is that Poole has included a second story, so readers are subjected to two examples of bad writing instead of one.The title story, "Dirty Cop," is the worse of the two, although it's probably somewhat of a hair-splitting distinction.  The title character is a tough guy named Mark who, in the opening scene in the story, catches some robbers bare handed. However, in interrogating their leader, he hits the man too hard and the robber dies, prompting Mark to make it look like the robber was actually killed by Mafiosi angry at his invading their turf.  Naturally, this doesn't sit too well with the local Don, whose uneasy truce with the cops goes by the books. This leads to an escalating sequence of violence, somewhere in the midst of which Mark manages to fall in love with the daughter of one of the mobsters.The only good thing about "Dirty Cop" is that the story is relatively short. It's filled with spelling and grammatical errors, as well as awkward phrasings and extremely long paragraphs. The characters are uninteresting and unbelievable. The author apparently has no knowledge of forensics or police procedure at all. The story is extremely choppy and rushed. All in all, the writing seems on the level of a not-very-talented middle school student who spends all his time watching reruns of "Law and Order."  Reading this story is the equivalent of listening to an hour of fingernails running over a chalkboard."The Murderess" is a slight improvement if only because the typesetting on the Kindle edition has wider spacing between the lines and the paragraphs are shorter. Plus, the story itself isn't bad, and, if it were written by a competent.author might have been decent. Unfortunately, Poole displays the same lack of familiarity and comfort with the English language here as he does in "Dirty Cop."Five college girls go off on a winter skiing trip to a family cabin near a rather creepy small town. Unfortunately, while on the way to go skiing, they decide to cross a frozen lake. Now there are four. The story fast forwards five years, and the four remaining girls decide to go back to the same cabin to pay tribute to their dead friend. If the first trip was bad, this one turns out to be much, much worse.Poole's writing is somewhat improved here, at least technically. "The Murderess" has fewer spelling and grammar errors than "Dirty Cop." However, even though Poole spends more time with the characters, they still are ill formed and uninteresting, serving mainly as targets for some very bad things that eventually befall them. I don't expect characters in horror stories to make intelligent decisions, but it's difficult in this story even to figure out what they're doing. If "Dirty Cop" appeared to have been written by a talentless middle school student, "The Murderess" reads like a story written by an unpolished high school student. With better editing and a couple more drafts, it might have made a decent story.This is my first exposure to Nick Poole's work, and I got this book free as a promotion. I did note however, that he normally charges $2.99 for this and several other of his books that appear to be about the same length (40-50 pages). Plus, based on the reviews of his other books I've read, it appears that he includes "The Murderess" as a bonus in other books as well. Three dollars is somewhat high to pay for less than fifty pages of well-written material. It is completely ridiculous for writing that is at best high school level with one story that seems to pop up in multiple locations to pad the length of what would otherwise be an even more ridiculously short work.On a rating scale, I would give "Dirty Cop" one star and "The Murderess" a generous two stars. However, combine the two and the result is still pretty much of a mess, and a considerably overpriced one at that.The only thing that's dirty about "Dirty Cop" will be the words readers will mutter under their breaths if they pay money for it.

NOTE: The seller graciously provided me with a sample of this product and requested me to write a review.The Enpassion Bike Mount Holder Cradle is a flexible lightweight cell phone mount that will securely attach cell phones to bike handlebars and similar tube shaped structures. It's easy to set up and seems to be able to adjust enough to secure even the largest current iPhone or Galaxy phone.Enpassion sells three versions of this cradle, a yellow and black version and two black models. The black models differ in how they attach to the handlebar. The model I received has a ratchet strap to attach it. The cradle comes in two pieces. The ratchet strap is held in place by a large nut that easily screws on or off to allow users to secure the handlebar as tight as necessary and easily unscrew it again to loosen. When it was tight, I was unable to move the cradle with normal force.The grip includes a back brace upon which the mounting bracket is secured by means of four tabs that fit into slots on the bracket. The bracket easily snaps into place and can't be dislodged in any normal bumping and jolting the cradle might receive. The back brace also includes an elastic band that can be wrapped around the phone for additional security. Once attached, the bracket can rotate 360 degrees to allow viewing when attached to any handlebar. It also tilts from side to side approximately 45 degrees in either direction.The mounting bracket itself measures approximately 2 1/2 x 4 inches with a grip on the bottom and one on either side. The user simply puts the phone on the bracket which depresses a button on the bracket causing the side grips to snap shut. The side grips can extend wide enough to accommodate a large phone. There are two tabs on the side of the bracket that when pressed cause the side grips to loosen. The bottom grip is manually adjustable up or down or from side to side and once in the desired location can be screwed shut using a knob on the back.The first time I tried to install the mount, it took me less than five minutes from getting it out of the box to having it installed and a phone attached. The instructions on the side of the box are simple and fairly intuitive. Once in place, I could rotate or tilt the cradle around to allow use of the phone in a wide variety of positions.The only concern I had with the cradle was in regard to long term durability. It is rather lightweight, and I'm not sure how the side grips will hold up if they snap in and out frequently over a period of a few weeks or months. In addition, although I don't think it's very likely the mount could come loose from the handlebars or that an attached phone could come loose under normal use, I'm not sure how durable it would be if mounted on a bike whose handlebars hit the ground in a fall (admittedly, the cell phone itself might well break under those circumstances). Of course, not wanting to break the cradle, I didn't put it to the test of applying excessive amounts of force or knocking a bike over.All in all, I think the ease of setup and use of the Enpassion Bike Mount Cradle, combined with its flexibility, versatility, and secure grip make it a very good product for those who want easy availability of a phone during outdoor activities. The cradle's all plastic construction might mean that it's not as durable as a similar metallic device, but at a cost of around $20, it's a very good value for those who have the want or need for this type of product.

I get occasional notices about free books available from Amazon for the Kindle, and I have to admit that sometimes I will get one based solely on the title. Such was the case with Nick Cato's "The Last Porno Theater." Frankly, I didn't know what to expect, but I almost certainly didn't expect what I actually got. Part noirish drama, part sensationalism, and a large part some type of wild fantasy, the book mixes some things with which I was somewhat familiar and others that go way, way beyond.The year is 1989, and Herschell Schwartzbaum, narrator of "Porno," is fighting a seemingly losing battle to keep the family business going. Once one of many porn theaters in Times Square, Herschell's theater is now a last outpost for the sex trade on Times Square, as a combination of home video and urban gentrification have been gradually shutting down the competition. Herschell inherited the theater from his dad, and he struggles to make ends meet and keep paying his only two employees. Then, his concessionaire Marge disappears one day and, to make matters worse, Herschell discovers that the theater is literally changing right before his eyes. I wouldn't dream of giving away just what's going on, but it's something that Herschell is not prepared for and that threatens to shut him down.  And to make matters still worse, some busybodies from the mayor's office show up with their own ideas of shutting him down through bureaucratic red tape."The Last Porno Theater" is actually a novella, slightly under 100 pages, but in those pages, Cato engages his fantasies and allows them to go completely wild. By the time the story ends, readers will feel they've been experiencing an R-rated version of a "Godzilla" movie. To be frank, I'm not sure how author Cato intended this material to be taken. It's certainly not scary or suspenseful or exciting. And it wan't all that funny, especially when it got out of hand. Fortunately, the book's fairly short length helps here, as Cato has to resolve the storyline rather quickly. And when he does, the last couple of pages again get back to his more realistic, enjoyable style of writing.That more hardnosed style makes the first half of the book extremely enjoyable. Cato, through his narrator Herschell, is a realist when it comes to the type of "entertainment" that the theater is peddling. But he affords it a certain type of dignity and the passing of the lifestyle a certain melancholy sadness that makes Herschell's struggles to keep going quite interesting reading. Frankly, I would have preferred a more realistic story on the same theme without the fantastic elements. But what I did get more than compensated for some of the silliness in the second half of the story.Although I'm not a New Yorker, I did spend time there and got to see a bit of Times Square in its "heyday."  On balance, the city is better off without the tawdriness. However, eliminating the tawdry also means eliminating a bit of the city's character and, as seen through Herschell's eyes in this story, the livelihoods of some of its residents as well. Cato managed to create a sense of loss and nostalgia in this story through his apt descriptions and insight into Herschell's personality. I realize that the book's subject matter is not everyone's cup of tea. The story itself isn't pornographic, but it's not Disney either. For those who have any interest at all in this type of material, "The Last Porno Theater" is certainly well worth reading and almost undoubtedly not what you might expect.

Jeff Bennington is a published Amazon author who has written a number of horror books. I don't know how good a writer he is, but, based on this self-help guide innocently entitled "Reader Giveaways," he's a worthy successor to P.T. Barnum. His book isn't in any sense a guidebook; it's merely a rather slickly disguised attempt to attract people to his website.Bennington's promotion for his "book" on the Amazon page states that it is "a simple and informative guide that explains how easy it is for YOU to win [various valuable prizes] with just a few clicks on your digital device." Strictly speaking, he's correct. I looked at the advertising and the content of the "book" itself and I didn't see anything that appeared to me to be factually incorrect. However, like P.T. Barnum and his famous egress sign, it's misleading as all get out. At least, Bennington doesn't charge for this book, but there's an old saying: you get what you pay for.While readers might believe from reading the blurb that they're getting a guidebook to finding various giveaways and contests (and there are a lot of giveaways on the Internet and books and services on how to find them), what they are really getting is a sales pitch designed to get them to go to Bennington's web site and subscribe to his newsletter. The site promotes Amazon books by a variety of different authors. Bennington obviously is an Amazon affiliate (as am I) and will make money if someone winds up buying a book through his website (as do I). While on Bennington's site, readers can find and enter various giveaways for real prizes.The previous paragraph pretty much sums up all the valuable content in the 20 pages or so of Bennington's "book." He adds a good bit of fluff about himself and the internet and a list of prizes and winners (first name and last initial only, i.e., John D.) However, remove all the fluff and misdirection, and what's left could be summed up in a short e-mail. But, instead of sending the e-mail out to lots of people and hoping to get a response, he's trying to to take a shortcut and and let the readers come to him via this guidebook. In all fairness, he does include links to four other giveaway sites that don't appear to be affiliated with him, but that's the extent of actual content in "Reader Giveaways," four links buried at the end of 20 pages.Bennington apparently has been rather successful in promoting "Reader Giveaways": it ranks in the top ten in a couple of Amazon categories.  I have to say that on some level I admire Bennington's skill in wording this guidebook carefully enough to avoid legal difficulties and out-and-out misstatements. However, as far as this being a "guide," as it's described on the Amazon page, the only thing it guides people to is Bennington's website through some less-than-forthright promotion. It's hucksterism pure and simple, the ethics of which are at best open to question.When I review books on Amazon, I try to give potential readers a good idea of what they are getting to let them make up their minds. To that end, I'm specifically avoiding mentioning the name of Bennington's website here. If you are interested in learning more about his site and the giveaways it contains, by all means get this "guide" (it's free). However, if you are actually interested in finding details about giveaway sites in general, then look elsewhere. The only thing "Reader Giveaways" will guide people to is one particular website. Amazon is already riddled with worthless "guidebooks" whose only real effect is to guide readers' money into the author's pocket. "Reader Giveaways" is nothing more than an admittedly slicker variation on this too prevalent theme.

NOTE: One of the authors graciously provided me with a copy of this book and asked me to write a review.Historical fiction is a tough genre to master because an author has to walk a literary tightrope between historical accuracy and an interesting story line. Too often, authors pay lip service to the era and setting and just plunk down modern day characters dressed up in costume. Although I'm not an expert on pre-Revolutionary War America, I get the feel that Evan Ronan and Nathanael Green did their homework before writing "Language of the Bear," a tale set in that era. Unfortunately, at times they stray too far in the other direction and let the setting get in the way of their story.The setting is Pennsylvania, a few years before the Revolutionary War begins. A renegade Englishman named Azariah is assembling an army somewhere out in the wilderness and recruiting anyone who will join him: whites, Indians (using the historical term) and escaped slaves. His goal apparently is to set up his own independent state and his army is getting powerful enough to wreak havoc on anyone who gets in his way.To stop Azariah, the local British commander sends one of his officers, Lieutenant Hugh Pike, accompanied by an Oneida Indian guide, Wolf Tongue. Pike isn't given very clear guidance about how he's supposed to accomplish his mission, so he essentially spends over half the book wandering around the wilderness getting in one scrap after another with a variety of rough characters. Nor is Pike some sort of backwoods James Bond... he's just a well meaning, reasonably intelligent officer with a sense of honor that gets in the way of his accomplishing his mission for a while. His insistence on behaving like a gentleman (intending to give Azariah the chance to fight a duel) doesn't help him much. Fortunately, he's got Wolf Tongue, who is a skilled fighter and outdoorsman to help. The authors write well, and their descriptions of life in those days are quite good. Rest assured that "Language of the Bear" is not one of those "novels" in which we get a dozen pages at a time on how farming or blacksmithing was done in those days. Instead, the authors work what descriptions they have fairly seamlessly into their story. The most interesting sections are the plentiful battle scenes. Warfare was quite different then, because, although soldiers were armed, neither the pistols nor the muskets were capable of repeated fire, so once a soldier fired a shot, he was helpless until he reloaded his weapon, a laborious process. Thus, an enemy armed with a sword, tomahawk, or even a pair of fists could do considerable damage. Individual fights thus became far more a battle of tactics than quick draw. And, the battles were much smaller, often pitting Pike and Wolf Tongue against three or four enemies. The biggest battle involves about 80 troops on each side.The weakness of "Language of the Bear" is the overall story line and what goes on between the battle scenes. The plot isn't all that focused, seeming more like a crosscountry trail hike than an organized attempt to pull off a military mission. Pike and Wolf Tongue have some good exchanges of the mismatched-allies-who-bicker-then-bond variety, but I never really got into the characters. Here, the authors' attempts to have them act "authentically" rendered them a bit too foreign (Pike's insistence on dueling Azariah is a plot strand that never feels right). In addition, Azariah, who by all rights should be a charismatically evil figure, is little more than a plot device. Indeed, almost every character in the book except for the two main characters, is cardboard thin.The authors apparently intend "Language of the Bear" as the first in a series, and their ability to write compelling action sequences gives it promise (there's also an exciting scene involving the main characters in a roaring river). However, I hope that, freed of the need to spend as much time developing the main characters, they can work on creating a more compelling story line and supporting characters. "Language of the Bear" is worthwhile reading, hence the three-star rating, but as is,it's a book that will soon tempt readers to flip through a number of pages to get to the next section of "the good stuff."

I enjoy word games and puzzles, but I sometimes find it hard to find one for the Kindle that's pitched at the right level of difficulty. Some require you to be a professor of linguistics (or get lots of hints) to solve, while others are about as difficult as spelling cat having been spotted the "c" and the "a." "Seven Little Words" is the rarity, a game whose puzzles generally require some thought to finish, but can usually be solved in five minutes or so.As its title implies, each puzzle requires players to identify seven words given crossword style clues. The answers are all contained in a 4 x 5 grid underneath the clues. Each box in the grid contains two to four letters. Assemble the letters in the right way and they form a word that's the answer to a clue. So, if a clue is "something you read (4 letters)" and two of the boxes are "bo" and "ok," the player can assemble them to form the word "book." As players identify each word, the boxes forming that word are removed from the grid and, with fewer remaining boxes from which to choose, the remaining words become easier to solve.The game itself is free and players get two sets of 50 puzzles to start. In addition, the designer, Blue Ox, publishes a new free puzzle every day. Players have access to the last three daily puzzles, in case they miss a day. Thus, without ever paying a cent, a player can play at least one puzzle a day forever. In addition, the game has a hints feature. Players get 15 hints for free but can buy unlimited additional hints for $2.99. I honsestly don't know what type of hints they have since I've played the game for six months and never had to use one.Although the basic game is free, players can buy additional sets of puzzles. The base price is $0.99 for 50 additional puzzles, although they offer some bulk discounts and some premium packs that cost more. Many of the premium packs are arranged by difficulty level, so players can buy anything from very easy to "impossible" puzzles. The standard puzzles (and the daily puzzles) typically vary in difficulty from one to the next, with few that are either extremely easy or extremely difficult. Players can also buy packs containing former daily puzzles."7 Little Words" is a great game for those who like word puzzles. It requires both vocabulary and word recognition skills. The free daily game feature ensures that players will keep it on their devices to get the app equivalent of the daily crossword puzzle. The only quibble I have, not enough to deduct a star (I'd rate it 4 1/2 stars if I could) is the fact that players can't play the game without knowing the number of letters in each answer. I'd rather try to figure the puzzles out on my own for a more challenging game, but I don't have that option. The free game provides 100 puzzles, but most people will wind up buying additional puzzle packs (players can get free bonus packs for buying certain numbers of additional packs). People may differ whether 50 additional puzzles for a dollar is good value (a good player could get through all but the most difficult packs in about three hours or less), but there's no question that the free portion of  "7 Little Words" is one of the best word puzzle games available for the Kindle, regardless of cost.

All room escape games are pretty much the same, and "Escape from Work" from MobiGrow although well made, is about as generic as they come. Although the general rules and object of these various games are quite similar, each developer approaches the game a bit differently. MobiGrow has a number of good features in the game, but still, solving some of these puzzles is a matter of guesswork and brute force as much as logic."Escape from Work" has 15 levels, each of which requires solving a half dozen or so minipuzzles along the way. A player must solve each level before advancing to the next. Each puzzle can be solved by either using the objects the player has found at that level or figuring out codes or combination locks based on clues found on that level. MobiGrow makes solving the puzzle a bit easier by removing objects automatically from a player's inventory once they are used. So, for example, if a player finds a knife and using it to cut something open, the knife is automatically removed from inventory (unless it's still needed for some reason). Less clutter in the inventory makes guessing the next step in the puzzle easier.There is no real storyline to "Escape from Work." When a player begins the game, an onscreen avatar informs him or her that the game is actually an app designed to help people discover the jobs for which they are best suited (thus the "work" in the title). Apparently, solving a level indicates an aptitude for that job. To be frank, I honestly couldn't figure out what most of the jobs were supposed to be, not that I really cared. The explanation has no bearing on game play whatsoever."Escape from Work" has no internal hints feature; however, the game has links at each level to a YouTube video walkthrough of that level so that players with internet connectivity can get as many hints as they need. MobiGrow provides additional help for beginning players to get through the game's first level in the form of the aforementioned avatar at the bottom of the screen. In addition to explaining the game's title, the avatar "talks" to players, suggesting that they look in particular parts of the screen to find and use the objects needed to solve that first level. With this help, beginners can learn pretty much all they need to play this type of game in less than ten minutes.The graphics are quite clean, and it's easy to spot the objects players will need to solve each puzzle. When players click on an area of any level in which they can find objects or solve some of the puzzles, the game zooms in so players can see a closeup of the area. Each level has 3-6 or so of these closeup areas that can be found pretty much by random clicking on different parts of the viewscreen.My biggest quibble with the game is that randomness factor in solving the puzzles. Some of them pretty much depend on assembling the right number of smaller objects the player finds into larger ones, then applying that larger object on the right spot of the viewscreen in order to progress. Some of these processes are logical (combining a spear and a spear gun to make an entire weapon then placing it in a location where it can "catch" an object in an otherwise inaccessible area). However, others are not, so it's pretty much a matter of trying everything the player can think of combining, by trial and error, then randomly clicking locations on the viewscreen until something "works." This rather crude approach was effective in letting me finish the game, but it lessened the feeling of accomplishment.With 15 levels for $1.99 at normal game pricing (I got it as a FAOTD), "Escape from Work" seems to me to be a bit short in terms of gameplay for the money. There are a number of free apps available on Amazon that have almost the same number of levels. Depending upon players' familiarity with this type of game, most levels can be solved in 10-20 minutes, although, obviously, less experienced players will take longer. Unfortunately, the game doesn't have a save feature, so if a player quits during the middle of a level, he or she will normally have to start that level over again when resuming the game.All in all, "Escape from Work" is a reasonably challenging room escape game. Beginners to this type of game may want to try out some of the many free room escape games first before paying their $1.99 to see if they like the genre. More experienced players may also want to consider the dozens of other options available that offer longer and sometimes more interesting gameplay for the same or less money. For those who like room escape games and don't mind spending $1.99 for a game this length, however, they will get some decent entertainment, at least, as long as the game lasts.

The difference between good horror and mediocre horror isn't necessarily originality, because, let's face it, there are few original ideas for horror stories nowadays. It's how the stories are told. That's why, when youngsters gather around the campfire late at night, the familiar tales of crazed killers and urban legends can still evoke chills, even though the listeners have heard them year after year. It's all in the way the story unfolds. And, based on my first experience with Jeff Menapace, he knows how to tell a story."The Straw Man and a Murder" will sound quite familiar to any reader who has even a nodding acquaintance with horror. Not only that, but the readers can guess pretty much what's going to happen from the first page. A young boy, Thomas Bowen, lives with his father on a farm. The boy's mother ran off with another man, and Thomas' drunken, abusive dad blames him and takes out his frustration on the boy by means of some rather vicious beatings. Thomas' only "friend" is the scarecrow in the field, for whom he draws pictures of a happier family that doesn't include his father.I won't spoil what happens in "Straw Man," but it's not tough to guess, especially given the story's title. But knowing what's going to happen and seeing how it transpires are two different things, and Menapace is a gifted writer who is quite good at describing brutality and savagery. He takes his time here, first showing just how hellish Thomas' life with his abusive father is. Menapace's language isn't excessively explicit, but he describes some rather coarse brutality heaped on poor Thomas. And, he is patient as he does so, allowing readers' anger to build. And then, things change. Again, Menapace takes his time in describing what happens. Overall, the story has a measured pace to it, with the author allowing his morality play to run its course. And he finishes the story with a flourish, a clever play on words that puts a highly enjoyable exclamation mark on the goings on."Straw Man" actually plays out somewhat like an episode from a television horror anthology, and, indeed, there are a number of similarities between this story and a classic episode of Boris Karloff's "Thriller" that also involved a scarecrow, a nasty person, and a secluded farmhouse. Of course, freed of the censorship restraints that held back a 1960's TV program, Menapace can fashion a considerably more gruesome tale here, and he does."The Straw Man and a Murder" is the rare story that seemed to me to be exactly the right length. It took a fairly straightforward story and told it without padding or attempts at explanation of how some things in it were possible while, at the same time, describing events in full as they unfold. It's the type of story that could easily have been told around the campfire. Fortunately, readers here can choose to do so in the more reassuring light of day.

NOTE: The author graciously gave me a copy of this book and asked me to write a review.Some authors, especially authors of series, offer their readers pretty much the same thing from one book to the next in terms of characters, style, and storyline. James Ross, however, is a fan of golf, so it's fitting that his Prairie Woods series is like the fictional golf course near St. Louis where some of the action in his books takes place. For, just as the course differs from hole to hole, so too do Ross's books vary widely. His latest, "Shari's Shot," can be described in golfing terms as a hole in which he hits a couple of excellent approach shots and then misses a short birdie putt.The best club in Ross's bag is the title character, Shari Daniels-Donnelly, the sexpot wife of adoring real estate tycoon Tyler Cy. Shari seemingly has it all, but Tyler Cy is not much in the looks department, so Shari decides she wants out of her marriage, so she can pursue new male companionship more openly than she has in the past. Surprisingly, Tyler Cy, although upset, still proves to be a nice guy and very understanding of Shari's whims. Since Tyler Cy cancelled their membership at a swanky country club, Shari takes up golfing residence at Prairie Winds, where she meets up with Ross's cast of clubhouse regulars, including club pro J Dub and his pals, guys with names like Pork Chop and YouWho."Shari's Shot" has a plot, several of them actually, but it takes author Ross quite a while to get around to them. Eventually (about halfway into the book), there's a murder of an ex-boyfriend of Shari's, and she becomes a suspect. And, while that's going on (and the legal maneuvers surrounding her divorce are going on), Shari wins a chance at a million dollars (the titular "Shot") in a promotional contest, if she can do well in a practice round prior to a major tournament that's a fictionalized version of the Masters.Despite its rather leisurely pace, "Shari's Shot" is entertaining, especially in the earlier sections that focus on Shari's varied misadventures. Ross has created a colorful antiheroine here, a bullheaded, somewhat dim, extremely arrogant, completely spoiled woman who makes life miserable for Tyler Cy and the host of poor waiters, hotel staff, drivers, and anyone else who has to deal with her. She and hubby Tyler Cy are quite well developed characters, and seeing her pitch her fits (and Tyler Cy cleaning up after) makes for an enjoyable first half of the book.The fact that Shari is such a major force of nature in this book means that J Dub and the regulars at the country club are largely absent and relegated to essentially bit roles even when Ross is writing about them. For those who have read Ross's other books, this may or may not be welcome news. I did appreciate it, since I've never found these characters to be as interesting or funny as the author seems to ("Shot" is the third Prairie Winds book I've read). Ross's golf talk is considerably more interesting, and Shari's big round takes up a small but exciting and quite descriptive portion of the book. Also taking up a small but rather graphic portion of the book are Ross's sex scenes, less noticeable than in his other books but still possibly disconcerting for those who don't care for that type of material.I found most of "Shari's Shot" to be breezy, light, often funny reading, even once the murder investigation kicks in (with a couple of investigators who would give Barney Fife a run for his money). However, Ross has a few major missteps late in the book that lowered its rating from four stars to three in my view. First, although he makes a point to rail on about the injustices of the legal system, especially as it leads up to the murder trial, his portrayal of criminal investigations and the law are badly flawed. Second, and even more annoying, Ross attempts a "trick" ending to the book. I like surprise endings as much as anyone, and if an author has legitimately tricked me (as in the classic ending for "The Sixth Sense"), I admire that. But here, the ending flatly contradicts certain events that are described earlier in the book. This represents either sloppy writing or simply not playing fair with the reader. In either case, "Shari's Shot" ends on a sour note.All in all, I did like "Shari's Shot" enough to recommend it, with the reservations noted above. Ross has the ability to create entertaining characters and scenes and tell colorful anecdotes. However, sometimes he loses his way in his books, as he did towards the end of this one. An old golf saying goes "You drive for show but you putt for dough." Similarly, it's the ending of a book that often shapes a reader's overall opinion, and "Shari's Shot" ends on a weak note. As a mystery/thriller (as it's characterized on Amazon), "Shari's Shot" is a bit slipshod. Fortunately, the book reads much better, especially in the earlier sections, as a light character piece. Shari is a force of nature who is as much fun to be around on the written page as she would be excruciating to have to be around in real life.

NOTE: The seller graciously provided me with a sample of this product and requested that I write a review.With the advent of RFID chip technology in credit cards, the idea of a blocking device like the Protectif Blocking Sleeve to keep prying applications from hacking the data on them is a good one. However, for a non-technologically oriented person like myself, reviewing this product presents a major problem. Since the only purpose of these sleeves is to prevent people from stealing data, the only way I can conclusively know one way or the other whether they work is the hard way... namely if I get hacked, they don't work. And since I've never had my credit card data stolen, the mere fact that they aren't hacked in a few months of using the sleeves may just mean that, like the majority of people, I've been fortunate. So, I tried to come up with a test and I did conduct an admittedly imprecise one. However, based on the results, I would be very hesitant to use these sleeves, and I can't recommend them.The package Protectif sells contains ten credit card sized sleeves and two passport sleeves. The sleeves are white, with a shiny silvery inside surface. The cardboard substance they are made of is about as thick and resistant to bending as a standard business card. When bent, the sleeve can easily become permanently creased or wrinkled The credit card sleeve measures 2 1/4" x 3 1/2" with a small half moon hollow at the top. The passport sleeve measures about 4" x 5 1/2". In each case, I had difficulty bowing the sleeve to fit a card or passport inside, and once inside, the contents were a very snug fit. I'm frankly not sure how well the credit card sleeve will hold up to repeatedly removing and inserting a card over a period of time. Both sleeves had the Protectif name and logo that identified the product as an RFID blocking sleeve. I'm not sure how wise an idea it is to advertise that you've got something inside the sleeve about which you have security concerns.I was able to test the sleeves by putting an ID tag that admits me to a basement gym in my office building inside the credit card sleeve. This tag is about the size of a quarter. Unfortunately, when I put the tag in a sleeve and held the top of the sleeve together as tightly as I could, the tag opened the door at just about the same distance away (1-2") from the sensor pad as it does without a sleeve. I also have a metallic card case that's supposed to be RF blocking. When I put the tag inside that case, it would not open the door, even when I touched the sensor pad with the case.I then tried a second experiment. We have a car that operates on a Smart Key, and this time I put the Smart Key inside the passport sleeve and brought it to within about a foot or so of the door. The Smart Key worked perfectly to unlock the door as though the sleeve wasn't there. Again, this is the same distance away as the key without any shielding opens the door. Admittedly, the Smart Key was too large for me to put in my metal case, so I couldn't make a comparison. But I opened the car door with the Smart Key in the passport sleeve without a problem on two occasions. Plus, the second time I tried this, it was raining, and the passport sleeve got a bit wet. It's now badly wrinkled at the top, despite being exposed to the rain for less than ten seconds.All in all, although I appreciate the seller asking me to review these sleeves, I was quite disappointed. If I paid for this product, I would definitely have asked for a refund. Based on the testing I've done, the sleeves don't appear to work. Further, based on the somewhat limited handling and use made of these sleeves, they don't appear to be sturdily constructed enough to hold up under repeated use, especially not the daily use a credit or debit card might necessitate. The Protectif blocking sleeve certainly doesn't appear to be accurately named.

After passing up opportunities to buy Brink for the thousandth time, I finally bit the bullet and got this game courtesy of Amazon for a really cheap price. (wasn't even 3 dollars with shipping included)Prior to getting this game, I heard mixed opinions about this game and didn't know what to make of it. Now that I have it. I'll review it.Here's my review-Graphics-You'd think with the Virtual Texture Technology advertised for this game it would at least be a good looking game. Sadly, Brink is either too dark or it's textures are popping in constantly. At times, I'd take a look at the ground and it has no texture whatsoever. Even after installing this game to my hard drive, I was unable to see any improvement other than a slight difference in load times.Brink does have a consistent frame rate which maintains a smooth 60fps, only slightly dropping at times; but nothing noticeable.The color scheme in this game is slightly on the cartoonish side featuring pastel-esque palettes rather than the more conventional gritty tone.The maps are pretty big but the level design in this game doesn't bring anything new to the table. In fact, I was looking forward to some parkour when I noticed, I rarely even thought of using any other than perhaps getting the drop on an enemy from above.The characters look pretty good; but are cartoonish. Characters were reminiscent of RAGE (Xbox 360, PS3, Bethesda) with their cartoonish appearance. Big heads, oddly shaped body types and oversized feet are the norm, however, it's not that apparent being that you once you play Brink, the game's pace is fast and you'll often be trying to spot enemy AI which are uninspired. (red suits or clones)Nothing impressive here and really this may be the worst looking Bethesda game to date.Score- 6/10Sound-The sound is actually good in Brink. When you shoot a shotgun or a rifle or perhaps a handgun, it actually sounds like the weapon. (Especially the handgun and shotgun) The dialogue is interesting as well featuring a slew of different accents. (my favorite being the Carribean/Jamaican)In this department, I actually haven't one complaint being that the sound is satisfying.Score- 10/10Gameplay-This is where Brink has it's problems. But before I get into the Campaign, let me start off by saying you'll get the most fun out of multiplayer. Multiplayer can be played online against Humans and Bots or Offline against Bots. In either form of multiplayer, you're given options to tweak gameplay such as choosing objective based gameplay or all out TDM style gameplay. But in any event, Brink is teamwork oriented meaning that you're not going to get far trying to be John Rambo unless the difficulty is turned way down. The Bots have good aim and are good enough to play against if you can't get online. Also, against bots you'll earn rewards such as new weapons, skins, clothing, gear and perks.All in all and again, this is where you'll get the most enjoyment.Then you have the campaign...which is just endless spawning and objective based combat. In fact, the story's fairly weak and it plays nearly identical to multiplayer (and you're also granted rewards, the only difference is that the campaign is where you'll earn most of the achievements. (even though offline multiplayer or online mp earns them as well, just not the same achievements)The game's control is something that bugs me a little. Afterall, mapping "run" to one of the bumper buttons instead of the left analog stick when pressed in is weird. There's even two different runs in the game. If you press in the left analog stick and move, you'll move a little faster, but it seems more like a jog than a run and finally, when you press one of the bumper buttons for run, you move much faster like a real run.Aiming is a bit on the weird side also. Anyone whose played Section 8 for Xbox 360 can relate to aiming at an enemy and killing them much faster rather than hip fire. In Brink, hip fire does nearly any damage unless you're super close and even then you can still take a dirt nap courtesy of AI/online well placed shots from a shotgun or rifle.In any event, I also have a slight quirk with aiming in this game being that it feels strange. Even with sensitivity tuned, Brink gives me too much of a Killzone feeling. (not quite as bad but close) Aiming is a little on the sluggish side.Brink also brings some decent ideas to the plate that could've been better if these concepts were worked on.
