They've held up well through their first couple of cold-water machine washes (color has remained bright; they don't seem to shrink) and have now survived a trip to Black Rock Desert, which speaks well of their quality.These are thinner than my previous leg warmers, which I made from recycled wool sweater arms, so they're a sound option for most classes, though I plan to continue using the thick wool leg warmers on really cold winter days.My only complaint is that these get pretty fuzzy with use and will probably pill.  That's not the end of the world, though.It's hard to say how these will endure over the long run, but I'm quite satisfied with them at the price I paid.
This song has been covered many times by many artists, but it's hard to beat Nina Simone's smoking, dynamic delivery.  Her performance is a classic, and it deserves to be.

Update first!I brought these to Burning Man this year.  Once I broke them out, I pretty much never wore anything else.  They wipe clean, they held up beautifully in the alkaline dust, and they looked great.  Everyone loved them.I expected to need arch supports with them, but forgot to bring them.  My feet held up all right, though they were sometimes very sore at the end of the day.  I wouldn't want to wear these (or any other high-heeled shoe) on a daily basis year round, but for one week a year, they're fine.On colder nights in the desert, I very much appreciated the extra width so I could wear extra-thick socks.  Walking was no problem even in uneven footing or pockets of deep dust.  Being 2" taller than usual didn't hurt, either!  ;)They also came in handy as part of the most ridiculous post-modern gladiator costume ever conceived, but that's neither here nor there.I liked these so much that I think I'm going to order a second pair for clubbing.  I left my original pair in our camp's year-round storage so I won't have to schlep them back and forth to the desert.BTW, for travel, wrapping the buckles in plastic wrap did the job beautifully.  I carried these shoes in my small carry-on bag along with a bunch of other random stuff, and they came through in perfect shape.Back to the original review:Full disclosure: I'm a guy, a dancer with the attendant high arches/flexible feet going on, and not a regular wearer of high-heeled shoes, chunky or otherwise.  Thus, your mileage may vary significantly.Onward!  I bought these to wear with costumes and so forth, and I've never really owned anything similar, so I don't have much direct basis for comparison in terms of comfort and so forth.  That said, I'll do my best.Appearance and Materials:These are simply really cute shoes.  They look quite a bit better than I expected them to, in fact.The color of the plastic stuff the shoes are made from is quite a bit darker than you might guess based on the picture, but as another reviewer mentioned, that's actually a good thing -- the shoes look great, and the sparkly stuff (which is safely contained inside the plastic) really shines.The buckles do, as often mentioned, seem pretty cheesy.  Considering that these shoes cost me fourteen bucks through Prime, I really can't complain about that.  A previous reviewer posted an effective fix; I plan to employ that if the buckles give up the ghost.  Also, if you're traveling with them packed, you might want to wrap some plastic wrap around the buckles to prevent them from snagging on things.Be warned that the shoes might smell weird (mine did!) when they first arrive (ironically, mine are stamped "Natural Breeze" on the inside of the foot bed -- "I do not think that word means what you think that it means...").  Let them breathe for a couple of days, and the smell will dissipate.Fit, Comfort, and Arch Support (or Complete Lack Thereof):I wear a European size 40 - 41, so I ordered a US 10, and the fore-aft fit is spot on.I was also pleased with the width, which is pretty good (in addition to being weird, my feet are narrow).  I could use one more hole on the strap for barefoot wear or with really thin socks; with normal to thick socks, these would be about perfect.I thought the plastic footbed would feel weird, but to be honest, I pretty much forgot about it after the first few minutes.  I wore these around my house for several hours the day they arrived, then again the next day; they definitely behave as you might expect plastic shoes to behave when you accidentally dump water in them, but they're really basically pretty comfortable.That said, unless you have really flat feet, do not expect these shoes to come anywhere near your arches.  If you've got high arches, expect to feel contact at the heelbone and the balls of your feet and basically nowhere else.  It may wind up looking a bit odd, but I'm definitely going to wear these with arch supports in them.  I'd rather look a little weird than risk screwing up my feet.As it stands, I can wear them fairly comfortably for a couple hours, then not terribly uncomfortably for a couple more, but eventually my feet start to hurt.  I have pretty strong feet, so that's probably worth noting, but the closest thing I've worn in terms of heel-to-toe ratio has been a pair Iron Age work wellingtons with pretty substantial heels.  That said, those were the most comfortable boots I ever owned, so that might also be worth noting.Oh: walking in these is also no big deal.  I expected to feel like I was going to fall over and kill myself, especially going down the stairs, but I didn't feel that way at all.  Even if you tend, as I do, to a mid-foot stride, you'll probably be fine in these shoes.  Performance may vary on uneven surfaces, though.  I'll find out next week.So there you have it.  Overall, I'm quite pleased with these shoes -- they look nice, seem pretty well-made, and aren't horribly uncomfortable.  Flimsy buckles and lack of arch support can be compensated for as needed.I'll try to get a picture added ASAP, maybe with socks on so you don't have to look at my snaggly toenails.

I was very pleasantly surprised by these.  I didn't expect much, but the price was right, so I figured I'd give them a try.  In fact, the quality of both materials and workmanship seems really solid.  The nylon parts are not paper-thin, but in fact quite substantial; the mesh, too, looks like it's going to hold up to a lot of use.  Zippers open and close easily (which is saying something, because for all my apparent dexterity, I am severely zipper-impaired).The sizes are about perfect -- I can fit all three in my rolling carry-on (which, to be fair, is close to the size limit for carry-on luggage).It's nice to be able to keep all my stuff organized, particularly when I'm traveling with a bunch of ballet stuff and costume stuff and also trying to shove some normal clothes in somewhere.Little handles on the sides make it easy to grab whichever packing cube you want and sling it onto the nearest flat surface for ease of access.I look forward to no longer having to dig under my street-swear t-shirts to get my tights out, or what have you: ballet stuff gets its own compartment; street wear another one; underwear and other small miscellany the third.  These would also be handy for organizing off-season clothing items.  I will almost certainly order more -- come to think of it, I wouldn't mind a couple of the small ones for my everyday dance bag.This first set of packing cubes is going to Burning Man with me.  Antarctica or the moon might be a better the harshest tests of a piece of luggage, but Black Rock Desert isn't far behind.  I'll report back on how things shake out when we return.

One of my ballet teachers frequently uses Plumpton's West End To Broadway in class.  Mr. Plumpton plays with accuracy, expression, and no small measure of wit, providing a river of music on which ballet class flows along swimmingly (okay, well, we swim better on some days than on others).  Meanwhile, we all get a boost from the familiar showtunes -- I just about died the first time "Good Morning, Baltimore" came rolling out of the music system.  Sometimes I find myself quietly singing along during easy combinations.If you're looking for some music that will inject some fresh air into your ballet class or daily practice, West End to Broadway might be just what you need.

This is a nice road-bike mirror, but near in mind that the included plastic clamp is not large enough for some modern road bars even if you mount it under the wraps.It can, however, be swapped out for a larger clamp (the hard part is finding the right size).With a clamp that would fit more bars, this would be a solid four or five star mirror (I'm unsure only because durability is definitely a factor in commuter gear, and I haven't had mine mounted long enough to assess that).  As it stands, if you're willing to kludge a little, it's a good buy for the price.

I must concur with many previous reviewers — there's a distinct trade-off between form and function, here, but Fit & Fresh Cool Coolers are a good solution for the right applications.Fit & Fresh's Cool Coolers are perfectly sized to include in a sandwich box or cram into a tight lunch pack, but because of their small size and the high ratio of surface area to interior, they do thaw faster than many "ice brick" products.  That's worth considering when you're packing your food.That said, I am still quite happy with them.  My husband, a physical therapist who specializes in clients with intellectual and developmental disabilities, travels quite a bit on some days to meet his clients at their day centers.  His lunches may sit in a hot car for most of the day, so keeping them cold is a priority.  I pack his lunches in a well-insulated soft-sided baby bottle cooler (Childress brand, from Amazon — I bought it specifically to use as a lunch box because of its shape and excellent insulation); he puts one of these cooler bricks in before he leaves in the morning.He likes hot  lunches, so any leftovers presumably are still warm when he puts them back in the bag.A single Cool Cooler brick will be thawed but still cold when he returns home; leftovers, too, will be cold.  That suggests better staying power than I'd expect.In short, I wouldn't rely on one of these to cool food in an uninsulated bag all day, though I imagine you can increase cooling time by adding more Cool Coolers, if you have room.  They are not quite as effective as thicker ice bricks.However, they fit nicely into tight spaces where rocket bricks don't and will keep food at a safe temperature inside an insulated bag for several hours.  They also don't take up much space in the freezer, which is nice.

If you're an amateur dancer, a balletomane, or even if you just enjoy a good, witty non-fiction book, do yourself a favor and read Stephen Manes' _Where Snowflakes Dance and Swear._  Through Manes' fresh, wide-open eyes, you'll get a good look at the day-to-day life of one of the United States' premier ballet companies, and to a lesser extent into the inner workings of ballet itself.  While this is, in a sense, a very serious examination of the world of ballet, it's laced with Manes' wit (as the title suggests) and never bogs down under its own weight.Very good read -- well worth the price, and deserves a spot in any balletomane's bookshelf.

For what it's worth, I'm a guy, but mens' unitards are generally ridiculously expensive.  Since I wasn't actually sure I wanted to commit to the whole unitard concept, I figured I'd try this one first.As a general rule, I like it.  It's soft and supple.I wasn't thrilled about the cotton content -- I was worried it would get waterlogged in class -- but my concerns were unfounded.  It turns out that Eurotard's tank unitard wicks surprisingly well.That may be a function of the fact that it's pretty thin.  It's not quite "dude, I can see your dance belt" thin, but I did have my concerns at first.  I'm still not sure it's 100% opaque, and as a result I always wear something over it outside the studio, but this is definitely my go-to garment for warm days in class right now.The trade-off for the lightness of this unitard is that it doesn't offer much in the way of compression or support: of all the dancewear I own, it is the least supportive (though also the least restrictive, and that's saying something when you're talking about an entire industry devoted to making the least-restrictive garments possible).I've now washed my unitard a bazillion times (seriously, I've worn it 2 - 3 times per week since I got it, washing it on cold/gentle and tumble drying it on low, since it arrived), and it's holding up well.  That's a big point in favor of Eurotard's workmanship.Overall, a good buy for the price.

My big, lazy cat is surprisingly okay with this.  To be fair, he's pretty easygoing, but I think the design leads to less resistance than a standard harness would.I used the increasing-exposure approach -- popped the harness on for a few minutes while cuddling the cat, then took it off; popped it on again for a bit longer and let him wander in the living room (he seemed unsure at first, but got himself sorted soon enough); then increased the duration a little at a time.  Now he's content to wander around with the harness on.Initial setup is a wee bit complicated, but once you've got your cat fitted and the harness is adjusted, putting it on is no big deal.  Escape might be possible for a determined feline, but I'm not sure anything can actually contain a cat that really wants out.This is a great option for a people-oriented indoor cat who wants to get outside, explore a bit, and get some exercise (or who wants to get outside and explore a bit, and whose person wants him or her to get some exercise).  It's not perfect, but it's pretty good.

I never expected to be writing a non-dance specific underwear review, but I guess there's a first time for everything!  Then again, I was a little hesitant to order 8 pairs of _anything_ this essential.  If this review helps someone else feel secure in making a purchase, then I can ride off into the sunset knowing that I've left the world a better place.I ordered these recently enough that Amazon still thinks they haven't been delivered yet (ha!), but they got here way ahead of schedule, and I'm glad they did (though, obviously, that means I can't say much about long-term durability right now).Personally, I'm a fan of minimalist underwear.  Simply put, for an active guy, it just plain gets in the way less often than the full-coverage kind.  My goal is to put my underwear on in the morning and forget about it all day.  The ideal pair brings to the table no bunching, no chafing, no sagging, and definitely no squeezing.SiikWorld's Ice Silk Thong Low Rise passes all those tests.  It just works.  It's comfortable and functional (and comes in a bunch of colors, though I would have been just as satisfied with an all-black set or, really, anything except all white or all beige).At 5'8" and 156 pounds, I wear an American mens' size 32 in trousers; here, the Asian L -- equivalent to a US medium -- is a very nice fit.  It would probably do equally well for someone who wears a size 34.  If you're smaller than a size 32, I'd order the next size down; bigger than a 34, you might be able to wear the Asian L/US M, but I'm not sure.  My "fits as expected" rating reflects the sellers' sizing instructions.The waistband has a comfortable, fleecy terry backing and offers enough grip to stay where it needs to, but not so much that you feel like you've got an angry python wrapped around your waist.  The remainder of the fabric is silky, supple, and supportive -- though maybe not quite "I'd use these in place of a dance belt while dancing the Le Corsaire variation" supportive.Quality and workmanship seem pretty solid.  Should I discover any early unraveling or anything like that, I'll definitely check back in -- but right now, I expect these to last a good, long time.  (They'd better, because I just replaced half my underwear drawer with them!)  All eight pair passed my quick quality-control check.Definitely recommend these for anyone who leans towards the minimal-underwear approach but isn't quite into the idea of going commando.One more random bit: each pair comes packaged in its own little zipper pouch.  That could come in handy for travel, or you could repurpose the pouches -- they might be perfect for containing the millions of micro-USB cords that are slowly multiplying in every home in the developed world.I've included a photo to provide a sense of the various colors included in the package.  Not shown is the black with red waistband and trim.

Instant, painless sync with my Galaxy Note 8 tablet.  Nice action, if just a touch uneven, on the keys; also sounds nice (note: if you're looking for a silent keyboard that won't disturb your roommate or partner at night, keep looking).  Quick, responsive typing.Quite a few useful function keys -- you can turn the brightness up and down, for example, without having to touch the screen; the F1 button lets you tab through open apps much as you would with Alt+Tab on a Windows machine.  You can even long-press a key to access accented characters (Windows could learn a thing or two there!).Small enough to be portable; big enough to be useful.  This will be traveling with me quite a lot, I suspect.  It will go to Burning Man inside a gallon-size zipper bag.  It will definitely be traveling back and forth to school/work, where it will help me get meaningful work done without dragging along my 4-pound notebook PC.There are a few key combinations that this keyboard interprets a little strangely.  I'm not entirely sure yet what they are; I've just noticed some interesting responses (apparently there's a keyboard shortcut for changing the system language, for example, that corresponds to something I do automatically a lot on regular keyboards; I type really fast, so it might take me a while to figure out what's actually triggering these things).I rather like the idea that I can also sync this to my phone or my laptop (where it can work as a YouTube remote if I'm feeling really lazy!) -- that's a lot of use packed into this inexpensive little package.So far, this keyboard meets all expectations, given its price-point.

Quick to inflate (really only about 20 breaths!) and quick to deflate; easily as comfortable as my bed at home; packs light and small.  I've camped in sub-freezing weather with this pad -- sure, an insulated pad would probably have meant it took less time for my bag to warm up when I headed to bed, but with a heat-reflecting blanket tucked into my bag (between bag and liner), I was fine.Ultra-light backpackers and bikepackers may find it worth their while to pay a little more for something that packs even smaller, but for most of us, this mattress is just about perfect.  I wouldn't even hesitate to use it for a guest bed in a pinch!Edit: I realized some physical stats might be useful, here.  I am male, 5'8", just shy of 160 pounds, athletic (dancer and cyclist), fairly low body fat, with plenty of projecting bony spots that can create uncomfortable pressure points (but not, sadly, julienne carrots) in seconds.  No pressure points at all with this mattress!  The ribbed design does a fantastic job preventing themI'm also a restless sleeper.  With my old mattress, I had to shove it inside my bag to keep from rolling off -- and, ost of the time I still woke up every couple of hours throughout the night with the pad on top of me, or beside me, halfway out of the bag, or whatever.  I put Klymit's Static X under my slippery-sided mummy bag instead of in it, squirmed like a caterpillar in my sleep all night as is my wont, and woke up in the morning feeling refreshed and still on the mattress.  That, right there, is nothing short of a miracle.
Did a great job charging my Note II phone for a good month or so.  Then I stepped on it while avoiding my cat and broke the tip.  Totally my fault, will definitely order again.

Update: Today I hit an unseen patch of gravel while riding my bike back from ballet class and went down hard.  My tablet in its Fintie case was in the lightweight, totally-unpadded backpack I use as a dance bag.  It clearly took a hit; there's a gouge in the front flap of the case -- but the tablet is perfectly fine.  I'm typing his review on it thanks to my Fintie case.Edit: Still going strong, still no problems with the magnets.  Seems pretty durable.  Folded stand only really works in one position (the other works only on some surfaces), which is a tad annoying; on the other hand, the viewing-angle of the position in which it *does* work (seen in the main product picture) is great for many settings.  I won't be looking for another case any time soon, though I might buy a second one of these in another color, just for fun.I'm pleasantly surprised with this little case.  I failed to notice that it had magnetic features when I ordered, so I was deeply skeptical at first (magnets are notorious for killing the digitized on Galaxy Notes)  -- but the magnets seem to be well-places and sufficiently low-powered to prevent damage.  The case fits snugly and folds into a useful stand.  It's light enough that it doesn't make the tablet feel unwieldy.I could care less about the auto-wake/sleep feature, and I would rather have a tab-and-slot or similar mechanism for keeping the case closed (because I'm still a bit paranoid about the magnets), but overall I'm satisfied.  We'll see how this little case holds up over time.

This is a great little tablet at a great price.  I bought it to replace a first-generation Acer Iconia a500, and I'm glad I did.  It's lighter, faster, and overall a more effective tool for a student on the go.  The slightly smaller size (8" versus 10") had turned out to be an asset instead of a detriment.In fact, the size is really nice - just right for reading or watching documentaries (because I'm a giant nerd).  The Iconia was a little too big for my hands (and much heavier).The display, meanwhile, is beautiful and crisp, great for playing games.My only quibble is that the battery life isn't awesome (note: the battery came almost fully  charged and ready to rock!).  That's a trade-off I'm willing to accept for the excellent on - screen writing functionality that the Note family provides.  An aluminum body would also have been nice for durability, but that's nothing a good protective case won't take care of.One caveat: My particular Note 8.0 came with a couple of small scratches on the screen.  That's no big deal for me - with a Tech Armor screen guard in place, they're not even visible.They don't seem to affect the function of the device in any way, and I consider minor cosmetic scratches entirely acceptable in a refurbished tablet at this price point.I'm noting this for those who might be really lucky about the appearance of their devices -- for me, this tablet is a tool (okay, and a toy!), not a fashion statement.

You remember that swingset that you (or the kid down the street, or your elementary school, or whatever) had when you were little?You will when you're rolling out your dough with this roller!  It sounds exactly like a swingset.  At least, mine does.That said, it definitely gets the job done -- rolls the dough out nice and flat without sticking.The verdict: Inexpensive.  Doesn't stick.  Great for making bread, cookies, and other things that need to be flattened.  Not great for surprising the family or roomates with baked goods (at least not the part of the family that lives with you!).  A little food-safe lubricating stuff could probably eliminate the squeak.Recommended.

I actually was surprised with the quality of these shadows! L'Oreal has made a creamy eye shadow palette with a decent mix of matte and shimmery pink, gray, and brown based colors (I think this palette definitely has more of a "cool" tone to it than "warm" so buy accordingly to your skin tone). I do want to be clear, though- without a decent primer (I used Urban Decay's Primer Potion in Eden) these colors are not as pigmented as expected (especially the light pink ones- numbers 1 and 8) and need to be reapplied occasionally or applied over and over again to reach desired pigment. Without using a primer, the colors all blend together and wear off and you won't get the defined look that is so popular these days.The colors in this palette are numbered 1 through 10 from left to right. I think it would have been amazing if L'Oreal had named these colors! It would have added more of a "higher end" department/makeup store feel. For the price and quality, I believe that this is a decent mid range palette for those starting out and not wanting to spend over twice as much on other palettes that are available.The brush that is included with this palette is not too bad. One end is soft and decent for adding all over color and the angled sponge end is useful to blend out the corners for a dramatic look with the darker shades.I mostly liked the packaging... the palette opens up completely flat which is nice to hold and the half length mirror is great! I didn't like that I had to really stick my nail in between the clasp to open the palette. Doing this chips my nail polish and I would rather just pull the two sides open like my other palettes.All in all, this is a great palette for beginners or for mixing with higher end colors to achieve your desired looks. I think the variety of colors in this palette is decent and will compliment most cool skin tones. Just start naming your colors, L'Oreal and you'll be on your way!

I recently gave this game a try on a camping trip with my mother and father-in-law and my biologist husband and everyone had a blast! This game has everything you need to play with many animal cards, the game board, and wooden marker cubes for marking your guess and score.The card box obstructs the view of the bottom half of the card where all the information is. Players take turns betting on where in world the animal lives, how much it weighs, how tall or long it is, and how long its tail is(if it even has one). Players earn points by betting correctly or betting adjacently(next to) correct weights, lengths or locations.My father-in-law who is a retired engineer really enjoyed guessing at the weights and lengths and did very well in those areas and my husband was surprised at how many of the animals he had never heard of. Even though we all had different knowledge about the animals the game was very close until the end and competitive and fun for all players

This truly is a soothing oral rinse that is gentle and effective. I have recently begun whitening my teeth and this can be very painful for me as I already have sensitive teeth and thin enamel. I noticed that after using this oral rinse 2 times per day as directed, I didn't feel the usual pain from hot and cold foods after whitening. I was very pleased with this!I should note that one thing that confused me was the actual uses for this product. Printed in the "About the Product" section listed on Amazon, it reads, "Dentist recommended for post-whitening use and to help relive sensitivity associated with tooth whitening." The bottle reads, "Dentist recommended for post whitening use", however on the side of the bottle it reads, "Does not relieve or treat sensitive teeth, oral pain or gum disease". These statements tend to contradict each other. Does it help with sensitivity or not? All I can say is that I did notice a different (an improvement) in how sensitive my teeth were after whitening.This rinse has a mild feel and flavor. When swishing it around in my mouth for 1 minute (as directed) I did not taste a flavor at all! It was cool and refreshing but very gentle and non evasive. It wasn't until I spit it out that I could taste the pleasant flavor. This rinse is alcohol free so there is absolutely no burning!As others have posted, I too noticed the soothing effect from this rinse when I had cut some skin on my soft palate from eating crusty french bread. I used this rinse after noticing the discomfort and within a few minutes, felt much better.Overall, this is a very mild, pleasant, and soothing oral rinse. The 16oz bottle size is convenient to store (not too big) and just the right amount to try this product out consistently. I also appreciate that this produce is Vegan and Kosher and is all natural, containing zero artificial flavors or colors.Would recommend!

I received this case shortly after I had upgraded my old phone to a new Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge.The color of this case is called "Ice" but as you can see from the picture I have uploaded, it is totally clear. I have the white S6 phone so the white from my phone is what shows through.This case is much thicker than the more attractive (but less functional) case I had bought with my phone. This case adds a nice amount of protection to the back, sides, and corners of this phone. If you are familiar with the S6, you will notice that the sides of the phone are curved. This makes it hard for this phone to be fully protected as the long vertical sides are exposed if tipped on an angle. I appreciate that this case comes up as far as it can on those sides without compromising the function of the phone.I love how the buttons on the phone are quite raised and prominent. They are easy to find and have a nice "click" sound when pressed. The other feature that I really like is the ridged back which allows for an amazing grip! The style of the S6 Edge makes it difficult to hold and text with one hand,  however, the ridged back makes it much easier to do so.The microphone plug, charging plug, and speaker are all easily accessible and have excellent sized openings (see pictures). The camera and flash/heartbeat sensor are adequately protected and can still be used without taking off the case.Overall, I am very pleased with this case. It has an industrial look to it but as a girl, I still find it attractive and don't mind compromising a bit for style to have better protection :)

This 17-ounce size is great for a single drink or having water to sip on throughout the day. I use this bottle at work and like the way it looks and feels. The bottle and cap feel durable. I also like the thick rim where you put your lips.The Lid is spring loaded and the button to open it is easy to press. The switch and lever mechanism really require that the lid be pushed back down into its place, you can't just flip it shut and expect it to latch. The lid also makes 2 snaps when you close it and when I first used this bottle I kept thinking it was closed securely when it was not.

These are highly pigmented, long lasting, large sized lip liners for a terrific price! I am obsessed with the variety of colors in this 12 piece set :) They vary from dark browns, deep purples, bright reds, matte nudes, to hot pinks! I've included pictures to show how pigmented these colors are. As a makeup lover, I have a multitude of lip sticks, glosses, and stains and it can be expensive to buy individual lip liners to match all the colors. This set achieves that for the price of 2 drugstore lip liners! These are also full size pencils! Longer than typical liners. The tips are fine but are easily buildable for thicker lines. The quality of the color is excellent, very creamy and easy to apply and sharpen. These last about as long as my lipsticks do and I didn't notice any irratation or breakouts after wearing. Their main ingredients are listed as: carnauba wax, bees wax, ceresin, cocoa and shea butters, octyldodecanol, isopropyl myristate, diethylhexylcyclohexane, butylparaben, and BHT. These are listed as "made in China".Overall I am extremely pleased with the quality and feel of the pigments, the variety of colors, and the size of the pencils. A must have for makeup lovers!

This pencil sharpener works great and is perfect for my crowded desk at work!This top feeding pencil sharpener has no problem putting a nice point on the school pencils I use at work. It has an auto-stop mechanism that won't allow you to sharpen beyond a nice point, saving pencil length.I like most the small footprint of this sharpener. It takes up about as much space as a coffee mug or water bottle, so it is perfect for my already full desk. The batteries have not shown any signs of slowing down after about 30 sharpened pencils, but I will update this review when I need to change them

This small ball works great for fetch with a small dog! This is my third year of buying Audubon calenders but my first ever,  World of Trees calendar! I have never been disappointed! The format is similar to their other calendars if you are familiar. Each month of this calendar displays a beautiful tree from around the world. At the bottom of the page is a paragraph that describes the area (geographical location, climate, wildlife, facts about the trees, etc.) and also includes a cute picture of wildlife that may live nearby. The calendar itself is very functional. It is a nice large/standard size and the date squares are large enough to write in. All major Holidays (USA, Canada, Europe) are included. I am very pleased with this calendar. I don't know how I'll ever buy anything else!

I am not very impressed with this particular brand.  Some of these off brand concealar palettes are usually not too bad however this particular palette is the worst that I've tried. The concealers are very oily and are minimally pigmented (if you don't rub your finger in the pot like crazy- see picture). I found that it barely added any real coverage and actually made the lines on my face more visible! (Again, see picture- my fingerprints really stand out). If you try and use a brush to apply, all of the lighter colors go on clear and oily and are not very buildable without completely drying out (I know, the opposite of oily but they completely dried out on my skin). The consistency is very cheap and difficult to deal with.  This was a waste of money and I am sadly disappointed :( Beware!

I bought this book for my husband for Christmas. We've been together for almost 15 years and I thought this would be a cute way to remind him of all the things that I love about him. When he opened it, I was genuinely surprised at how touched he was. He couldn't put it down and has revisited it several times since then. There are 50 pages that allow you to personalize sweet sayings to your loved one. There are no rules with this book, and the instructions support that. Sometimes I added extra words or extended a sentence. However you use the book, it is guaranteed to make someone feel good and loved :) I also found it refreshing to really think about and meditate on all of the things that make my husband great and why I love his so much. You really can't go wrong with this book. Enjoy!

I am really impressed with the design and ease of use of this fruit and vegetable slicer. The title, however is a little deceiving. It is not a "2-in1 ... cutter". You actually get the apple slicer piece that is attached and then you get the lattice slicer separately. You have to remove one piece to use the other. The only other issue I had with this slicer is storing that additional piece safely as it does not attach to the slicer when not in use. I had originally placed it in the side of my cooking drawer. On Christmas Eve when I was looking for my turkey thermometer in that same drawer, I noticed that my pinky finger was bleeding like crazy. It took me a good minute to realize that I had accidentally sliced my finger on the lattice cutting piece and didn't even notice! I recommend storing the extra piece in a place that is out of the way, perhaps even in a separate container for everyone's safety.When using the fruit slicer for piecing up apples, I noticed that this cutter went through my large honeycrisp like butter! It was easy to remove the core and easy to clean. I also liked that the handles on this slicer are flatter compared to similar tools. This makes it less awkward to store. The vegetable slicer worked extremely well on potatoes. Overall this is an inexpensive and handy tool to have in your kitchen. Again, please be careful with how sharp this item is!! ;)

First off, I love the 8 different prints that you receive with this order (3 of each, total of 24 cards). They work out to be very economical! These cards are made from 100% recycled paper and you know what's even more awesome? They are made in the USA! Don't you just love when you can really feel good about a purchase? ;) Besides the adorable designs, the cards are blank inside, leaving room to write your own message. All of the cards do say "Merry Christmas" on the outside so these might not be best when sending to friends or family of different religious backgrounds. The only reason these cards lost one star for me was the fact that they are really small... about 4.8 in by 3.3 in. You can barely fit a gift card in these little envelopes! I suggest that these just be used to send a happy message for the Holidays and you'd be better off buying a standard sized card to send photos or gift cards in.I would definitely recommend these cards as a cute and economical way to wish others well this Holiday season!

I purchased my Fitbit earlier this year (February 2014) and was really excited to use it! I wore it everyday for several weeks and loved the fact that it counted my steps, monitored my sleep patterns, and allowed me to connect to friends through their online community. After about 3 months, I did notice that my band was starting to tear, especially where I would bend it to place the Fitbit back in after charging. This was unfortunate and I decided to purchase some replacement bands. I didn't mind doing this since I love that I now have a variety of colors instead of just the Slate. I never took the band off! I showered in it, swam in it, I checked it throughout the day to see how I was doing toward my goals. I really enjoyed it.Unfortunately, in June of 2014, I broke my wrist in a hiking accident. I needed surgery and was unable to wear or use my Fitbit for about 3 months. When I went to use it again, it had trouble holding a charge and eventually just died. I finally just got around to contacting customer service. Within hours, I received a reply email from a Fitbit representative who offered some suggestions/troubleshooting ideas. When that didn't work, I was asked to send a screen shot of my purchase (order confirmation) of the Fitbit that I purchased from here, at http://amazon.com. I just received a confirmation email that they have shipped my replacement Fitbit and that I do not need to send them my broken one. This was remedied in less than 5 hours, on a Sunday, for a Fitbit that I purchased 10 months ago. I was very happy with how well customer service handled this although, I see a lot of reviewers here reporting that they did not have such a great experience. I suggest you email them again. It couldn't hurt! I'm thinking there is a year warranty on these things so don't give up!I gave the Fitbit 4 stars because:1. If you wear it everyday, in the shower, etc. the bands really wear out.2. I wish this model had a heart rate monitor and was able to differentiate between walking on level ground and climbing stairs (I see there are some newer models that do these things).3. The size -is- a little bulky for women with smaller wrists but I appreciate the medium and large bands included.4. It is not -that- accurate... I think I get a couple hundred steps in doing my makeup in the morning (which of course is not correct ;)5. It died within a year.I love this Fitbit because:1. It makes fitness fun and I enjoy connecting with my friends online and comparing activity levels. (Also easily connects with MyFitnessPal)2. I like the different colored bands that can be purchased separately to match my various outfits.3. It is waterproof for showers, sweat, and swimming.4. It is easy to clean and take care of. The app is great and the online dashboard is easy to use as well.5. I actually was really impressed with my recent customer service experience.All in all, I would recommend this produce to friends and family members. There are some reported hiccups with these things not being able to last a long time but I'm willing to give it another chance. We'll see how I feel if my replacement breaks down... lol. Wish me luck!

I was very pleased with this Z-Vibe. I was worried that getting the plastic handle would mean that the quality would be less than the metal ones but I liked the lightweight feel of this one and the ease of cleaning it. This model has a nice bumpy feel to the handle that helps with grip. This is a great tool for SLPs to use with children with oral motor difficulties (low muscle tone, sensory issues) as well as for bringing awareness to the articulators for children with childhood apraxia of speech or other severe articulation impairments. This is a great product and there are many interchangeable tips that can be bought and used with this handle. A must have for SLPs!

I am very pleased with the SMS In-Ear Biosport Biometric Earbuds! These earbuds need the RunKeeper app for best results (available for GooglePlay and the iTunes app store). If you have an Android, set up is really easy. You literally download the app, make an account (through Facebook, Google+, or with email), and plug in the headphones to your phone! I was pleased to find that these earbuds come with 3 different interchangeable sizes (small, medium, and large). I also found these earbuds to fit quite comfortably in the ear. In addition, you will receive a nice pouch to keep your headphones in as well as the extra buds.Once you have downloaded the Runkeeper app, it will default to "GPS" settings. This is easy to change if you are going to be working out indoors or on a treadmill. When you click "activity", there are two options at the top of the page, "GPS Mode" and "Stopwatch Mode". If you have not changed the position of the slider from microphone mode to heart rate mode, the little heart icon in the app will have a "!" sign on it. Simply move the slider to the hear rate monitor position and click "Begin (workout)". You are informed that your "activity has started" by a very serious voice from the app. Your heart rate is now listed underneath the stopwatch and will fluctuate based on your activity level. When you pause or stop the workout, the voice will also inform you of this. I think this is handy in case the buttons are pressed accidentally in your pocket. When you have completed a workout you can adjust the distance and calorie burn, make notes, share to various social media sites, and add workout reminders.I liked the fact that when my phone rang during my workout, I just slid the slider back to the microphone position. Unfortunately, the heart rate monitor stops and you still have to manually pause your workout or else the timer will continue counting. I also liked that in the RunKeeper app there is a music note that once you click it, will automatically connect to your music library. When you move the slider the microphone position, the music and heart rate monitor pause, and once you move it back, they both begin to work again.All in all, these are great fitting earbuds with decent sound quality. I was happy to use these when working out instead of regular earbuds and really appreciated the heart rate monitor feature and ease of use of the RunKeeper app for Android.

My cat LOVES this Kong Kickaroo!!I couldn't even get this cat toy out of the package before my 7 year old Bengal cat, Gibson, grabbed the package and got to "kicking". I am so thankful to have found this toy :) My Gibbs usually grabs hold of paper towel rolls or pencils and goes to town, kicking and scratching away. It wasn't until I saw him grab one of my Husky's dog toys, that I thought I needed to look for something for Gibson to kick. After searching, I found this Kong cat toy and he absolutely loves it. I think the Tiger pattern looks a lot better in real life than in the pictures. It is a great sized toy for the price and the furry black tail at the end of the toy is very soft. Gibson couldn't wait until Christmas for this present! A must have for active cats that love to grab hold and kick!

3 1/2 starsThis hair dryer has some great qualities and could easily have earned 5 stars if it weren't for the most awkward button positions ever!What I love about this hair dryer is that it has an incredibly quiet sound during use. The low setting, which is what I use all over my hair to help it dry before using a round brush, is so quiet, I can still hear my husband talking to me from the room over! This is a big positive. I also like that the cord is retractable and easy to store without getting tangled in with other cords from my flat iron or curling irons. My final positive and feature that I really like is that the nozzle where the air comes out of is quite narrow and concentrates on the area I want to dry without blowing the rest of my hair all over the place!Now for what made this dryer lose 1.5 stars: the buttons. This hair dryer uses two "slide" buttons. One for "cool", "warm", and "hot"  levels and one for "off", "low", and "high" levels. 1. I wish these buttons were reversed. I use the "low" and "high" levels every time I dry my hair and these buttons are located on the most bottom part of the handle. This means that it is almost impossible to slide the button on to dry my hair without using two hands. As you may already know, most women use one hand to hold the dryer, and one hand to hold a brush. This is a hard task with this dryer. I know that this is also a new dryer but I find the slider buttons to be extremely hard to slide up and down. I am hoping with use they become less stiff.  2. I wish the "off" button was in the middle of the "low" and "high" options. It adds an extra step when I go from "high" to turning it off. The dryer has to go through the "low" setting first and when you're fumbling with the buttons already, it makes this seem like an unnecessary extra step.All in all, I enjoy the sound and weight of this hair dryer as well as its drying capabilities. The major cons are that the buttons most used are located in a very awkward position that makes drying my hair more laborsome than it should be.

This door sweep was easy to install on our back door that separates our garage from a landing to our basement. It fits a 36 inch door perfectly and sticks firmly in place.Our whole family noticed how much warmer the landing was immediately. I am impressed with this effective and inexpensive solution

This is the first entry in the 4-part series, which teamed up two of my favorite authors, Kendra Elliot and Melinda Leigh.On Her Father's Grave finds former LAPD cop Stevie Taylor returning home to her small-town roots in Solitude, OR.  Stevie followed her beloved father's footsteps into law enforcement.  Her father, the chief of police in Solitude, has passed away suddenly.  Stevie decides to move back to Solitude and join the police force there.Stevie's family is very well-known in the small town. Besides her late father's position, her brother, James, is the town's mayor.  Her younger sister, Carly, is a social worker who is married to Seth Harding, an investigator.Her father's second-in-command, Roy, decides that the top job isn't for him.  Instead, experienced officer Zane Duncan takes over as chief.  Zane has lived in Solitude for over 5 years now, but still feels like an outsider in the small town.Stevie and Zane are immediately thrown into an investigation when a teen dies after taking a new street drug.  Zane is taken with Stevie, but Stevie is still healing from breaking up with her ex-boyfriend, a fellow officer in LA.  She's not sure that she ever wants to date another cop.It's no surprise that the characters are well-thought out, given the two authors who worked on the series.  Stevie is strong and smart without being hard-edged.  Zane is kind and patient, realizing that Stevie has a lot of healing to do.  The story ends too soon, leaving you wanting more.Having grown up in a very small town myself, I appreciated the following moments:*  Small Town Rule #2: Reputations are made in five seconds and stick for twenty years. Or more.*  "You know you're from a small town if you call the wrong number and you know the person you called," stated Bruce.Highly recommend. Angela Risner 2014. This was a freebie for Kindle users last month.  It's the first novel by Robert Dugoni I've read.Tracy Crosswhite said goodbye to her younger sister, Sarah, one day, not realizing it would be for the last time.  Though Sarah's body has never been found, Edmund House was convicted of her murder and sent to prison.  However, Tracy, a chemistry-teacher-turned-cop has been unable to accept that verdict and continued to investigate her sister's case.There's a couple of things I want to talk about that involve spoilers, so I'm going to say....SPOILER ALERT!I thought that the majority of the characters were believable.  You could feel Tracy's angst as she wanted to make sure that she had done everything possible for her sister, as she blamed herself for letting Sarah drive home alone that day.  I also thought that the way Sarah's disappearance affected the family for years to come was very realistic.  Tracy became engaged to ex-husband, Ben, the night of Sarah's disappearance.  Tracy's parents let their anger center on Ben as the cause of Tracy not looking after her sister that day.  Even though Tracy married Ben, their marriage fell apart as Tracy was obsessed with investigating Sarah's case.Dugoni also did a good job of throwing red herrings out there.  I was pleasantly surprised to be, well, surprised, at the end.Highly recommend.© Angela Risner 2014. This rug is soft, but insubstantial.  It feels very thin and cheaply made.  I would rather go to a store like TJ Maxx and pick out a bathroom rug there.  I would pay about the same but receive a larger, thicker product.  I'm almost afraid to put this one in the washer, as I fear it will shred.  Thankfully, the cat likes it.  It's hers now.Would not buy.

I was interested in this type of light therapy for two reasons:1.  I suffer from Seasonal Affective Disorder and we're headed into fall/winter.2.  I am ADD.  I take my stimulants, but I'm trying to reduce my dependency on multiple doses per day.The light itself feels well made.  I thought that it said it had a rechargeable battery, but the one I received has to be plugged in to work.Does the light wake me up when I start to lose my concentration?Yes, it does.  But I think that has to do with the color of the light itself and how it mimics the affect of our devices' screens.  I'm sure you've seen the articles that discuss how the light from your laptop, tablet and/or smartphone keeps you awake.  Here's an excerpt from an app that I use on my laptop to help combat that:******Blue Light Affects Sleep (and here's why)We know that night-time exposure to blue light keeps people up late. We believe that f.lux adjusts colors in a way that greatly reduces the stimulating effects of blue light at night.To understand the effects of f.lux on sleep, we've spoken with some researchers, and we've read a whole lot of papers.The science that explains why blue light keeps you up was begun many years ago in the study of bird migration, and it continued in humans with the discovery of a new photoreceptor in the eye, called Melanopsin. Many are familiar with the "rods and cones" that provide our visual capabilities, but it was only about 15 years ago that retinal ganglion cells containing melanopsin, which are sensitive to a narrow band of blue light in the 460-480nm range, were discovered, and their unique effect on sleep was investigated.The experimental research suggests that an average person reading on a tablet for a couple hours before bed may find that their sleep is delayed by about an hour. Clearly, the details are complicated, but that's why we get to cite so many very interesting papers.******So, really, if you're in front of your computer, you shouldn't need this light to help you stay awake.  It's hard to say whether or not it's an effective treatment for SAD until I've had it for longer.  Until then, i would be cautious about purchasing this item.

Full disclosure: I received an ARC of this book in exchange for an honest review.I happened across Paul Kearns' name while doing some research on consulting in the learning field. Kearns wrote a series of articles, "From Trainer to Learning Consultant," back in 2004. Those articles formed the basis for his new book, Organizational Learning & Development - From an Evidence Base.If you've been in the learning and development field for more than a few years, you know that the hardest part of the job is trying to demonstrate your value to the organization for whom you're working. Whether you're an instructional designer, trainer or both, you typically show up on the books as an expense. When the business hits a rough spot and has to make cuts, you are usually considered to be the most expendable.To be honest, most of us found ourselves in this profession by accident; we were Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) or super-users. Because we performed our jobs so effectively, we were tasked with training new people (even our own bosses.) I was doing instructional design before I knew that's what it was called. When I was thinking about graduate school, instructional design programs were few and far between.It took years before I learned that I didn't have to say yes to every request for training, that training was not always the answer (because the question was one of performance management and training can't answer that question.) It's only been in the last decade that the learning and development field has started to think about their role in the business as a partner, rather than a "necessary evil" (as one of my managers said to her team in order to get them to come to training.)In 2006, the authors of The Six Disciplines of Breakthrough Learning (known as the 6Ds) challenged the learning and development world to only provide learning that aligned with your company's objectives. Training for training's sake was no longer the rule; the only acceptable form of learning would improve an employee's job performance, which would ultimately improve the performance of the business.The 6Ds is a great step in the right direction. However, speaking from experience, it can't work unless the organization itself is at a certain point of maturity. Unfortunately, the 6Ds does not address this. Kearns' book does.Kearns applies his previously developed HR Maturity Scale to learning. There are six stages of maturity on a scale from reactive (where training requests are "reacted" to and there is no curriculum mapping or conscious design of learning) to strategic (where learning is a natural part of the business process and the organization becomes a whole system.)For a business to truly evolve into a learning organization, it must be honest with itself about where it is on the Maturity Scale. To move up the maturity scale, everyone must be rowing the boat in the same direction.Kearns also takes on Kirkpatrick's Four Levels of Evaluation. He correctly states that they do not hold the training department accountable to any business objective; instead, they simply evaluate the trainer as a facilitator. Using the Plan, Do, Check, Act (PDCA) model instead to establish a baseline measurement or evidence base makes much more sense.This book is the best blueprint we have to move learning and development into full-fledged business partners with permanent seats at the table. If we can follow the principles in this book, L&D will no longer have to fight to stay relevant and prove its value.I have pages and pages of notes marked, but here are some favorite moments:• ...it marks the shift away from focusing on training, which is always an input, to learning, which is an output.• Professionals are always focused on business impact; amateur trainers are satisfied with their training activity.• Evaluation is not just about measuring success; it will equally expose training failure.• Traditional processes for performance review and development planning tend to suffer from a common condition - the culture does not allow for difficult conversations to be held in an open, honest, transparent and grown-up way.• Performance management works best in mature organizations, with Stage 4 being the minimum goal, where performance management is perceived as less of a big stick and more of a positive reinforcement of valuable behavior.• Learning should be encouraged to happen naturally and organically; it should not be designed as intervention, nor viewed as such.• Education means looking at how somebody else made a fire. Training means you have to know how to make a fire, not just describe the process. Applied learning means you make a fire.Highly recommend. (And should be required reading for all L&D folks.)© Angela Risner 2014. Knife is balanced well, where the blade connects to the handle.  Very nice edge.  Strictly for slicing, as it states - would not work for chopping or mincing.  Won't act as a chef's knife, as it isn't made for that.

I don't know why, but I've ended up in tears during the last two Murnane books.  I guess that's a good sign, in that the writing is really connecting with me.Katwalk follows Katrina as she attempts to break out of her mundane life by moving to New York City.  Katrina has always played by the rules; they've never been HER rules, however.  Her parents have always told her what to do, what to study, where to live.  She became an accountant and has been with the same company since her college graduation.  Her best friend, Deb, convinced her that they needed to break out of the rut by saving up enough money to quit their jobs and move to New York City for a few months.  Unfortunately for Katrina, Deb ends up with a better offer from her current job and decides to stay.  That leaves Katrina with the decision to head to the Big Apple alone or stay in her safe life. She opts for the adventure.  Katrina becomes "Kat" to her new friends in NYC and begins to explore the city.Murnane paints NYC in both dark and light colors.  People are either so desperately unhappy that they spend their evenings in bars and having affairs or they are...wait, it's mostly dark.  Sure, Katrina's neighbors befriend her right away and she isn't ever mugged or robbed, but most of the people in the book are really unhappy with their lives as they are.  They wish they could do something other than the 9-5 grind.Overall, though, I still liked it.  It wasn't sappy, but more realistic about the choices that we all feel forced in to making - the jobs we take because of the money, not because they will feed our souls or our passions.Some favorite moments:•  “I think a lot people do that, especially straight-A high-school students.” “Do what?” “Put their heads down , study to get a degree, get a degree to get a job, get a job to get a paycheck, get a paycheck to buy a house. Everything’s focused on the next step, and before they know it, they’ve spent all their best years always aiming for the future and never really enjoying the present.”•  "In your life, it shouldn’t matter what anyone else is doing , or what anyone else thinks. You are the only person keeping score of your life. All that should matter to you is what is important to you. If you make major life choices based on what other people expect from you, or what will earn the approval of others, you’ll never be happy.”•  “Mom, Dad , I know it’s not going to be easy, that it’s going to be quite hard, in fact. But this is something I want to do, something that will make me happy. I’ve spent too many years living a life that makes other people happy. All that did was make me miserable, and I just can’t do it anymore.” Recommend.© Angela Risner 2014. Officially, the character of Maxine (Max) Revere is introduced in this Kindle single, but I read Notorious first.  The single is a great appetizer, though this particular story has nothing to do with the events in Notorious, the full-length novel that is published after this.Max Revere is an investigative reporter whose former college classmate is after her to become the star of a new TV journalism show (think On the Case with Paula Zahn.)  Max hates the idea and tries to say no.  Meanwhile, she is interested in the case of missing college student.  Frustrated with the students who were with the boy when he went missing, she pushes the local police department as well as the college to find the truth.Great character and definitely an interesting read.© Angela Risner 2014. I'm so glad that Allison Brennan has introduced a new character, Maxine (Max) Revere.  I actually think that this was one of Brennan's best books to date.This book follows Max, an investigative reporter, as she returns to her hometown to attend the funeral of a former high school friend.  Max's life has been turned upside down many times:  1.  Her mother abandoned her as a child.  2.  Her best friend was murdered while the girls were still in high school.  3.  Her college roommate was abducted and is presumed dead, though the body has never been found.  Max's wealthy family, including the grandmother who raised her, would like nothing more than to have their lives kept out of the press and for Max to let sleeping dogs lie.  However, Max wants to uncover the truth, no matter the cost to her family's reputation.I have enjoyed Brennan's Lucy Kincaid books, but they are becoming increasingly difficult to swallow.  I like that Max's character is, as she puts it, not restricted by having to adhere to the law in the way that law enforcement does when investigating a case.  Max doesn't have to worry about the chain of custody for evidence, etc.  She is able to go places the cops can't.I look forward to future books about Max Revere.Highly recommend.© Angela Risner 2014. I was very excited to read this book, as I completely agree with the premise:  That kids today are over-scheduled, over-managed and over-protected.  Many parents, with great intentions, have managed to turn their kids into people who feel that they are entitled to things without earning them - such as respect, job titles, fabulous homes or apartments, etc.I see my friends post updates on Facebook that they're helping their kids with their homework or running their kids to soccer then to track then to this or that.  And I think, when does your child have time to be a kid and when do you have time to do anything else?  I think I asked my parents for help on homework maybe once or twice (and the internet didn't exist when I was in school.)  And after-school activities ended by 6pm, if not earlier.I will say, though, that the issue does not lie only with the parents.  We have a ridiculous education system in which you are judged by standardized tests.  Tell me the last time life through something at you in the form of a standardized test ?  Did you use your No. 2 pencil to fix your marriage ?  Was your job saved when you demonstrated that you could fill in a Scantron?However, the book itself was not that enjoyable to read.  The writing wanders a great deal and seems to stray from a point often.  I am never a fan of writing just to fill space.  While I do enjoy conversational style writing, I don't enjoy pages and pages of rambling on when you could have finished it in a couple of paragraphs.As Mr. McCullough is an English teacher, I know he loves words.  A great turn of phrase is something magical.  But the writing in this book seldom reaches that point.  It's like being stuck in traffic not far from your destination or foreplay that doesn't go anywhere.In the end, while I agreed with some of his statements, I felt as though this book needed a much better editor to keep it on point.  It became more of a stream of consciousness and I found myself putting it aside more often than not.Cannot recommend.

I have been working from home for a few months now and conference call time is increasing.  I finally decided to look for a headset that would mirror one that I've used before at work, which meant one that had the flexible boom mike.  This one fit the budget and gets the job done.  It paired instantly with my Samsung Galaxy Note 3.  Folks say that they can hear and understand me just fine.Recommend.

As an instructional designer and facilitator, there are times I need to put together portfolios and participant guides into three-ring binders.  This electric 3-hole punch makes that so much easier. I ordered this for my husband and, at the time, the only size option for Vine reviewers was medium.  My husband is 6'1 and about 185. Purchased this product coming in with high expectations. My verdict after two weeks of continuous usage? It's excellent for plumping but beware, do not get any on the skin around your mouth as it will become red and irritated.

I was looking for cartridges for my Canon printer and I am happy i found this one. I love the packaging and it works great. Awesome quality for the price. I will definitely keep buying more. Highly recommended!

I can't believe I found these tubes and needles for that low of a price.  Usually people ask for way more and they are a bad quality. I took it out of the box, made an unfortunate decision to use one of my existing micro USB chargers and broke the phone.It would not begin to charge-I used the micro USB included with the phone and now the phone only flashes like it is thinking about charging. I was never able to turn it on. I will update once I am able to work through a solution with the mfg.

We used this as a trundle-with only slats as a support. It is comfortable and easily supports most. I think someone over 230 would not feel enough support. (Only 4 stars because of the weight limit)It is a standard twin-deep pocket sheets are too big.The mattress shipped in a bag-I wish I could roll it back up to store!!The mattress has more cushion than an air mattress. We purchased as a infrequent use mattress because of the price but we are impressed with the quality and would buy again to replace one of our kids twins in the future.

Sorry folks but I love that it is not wireless!  I have several children and Duracell has definitely become part of our monthly budget.  :(This was a perfect gift or our 10yr old girl. The controller is LED lit and they can change to their mood.  Super cool!There are a few upgrades from the controller that comes with the XBox One, mulit-functional wheels that let them reassign the buttons to accommodate their dexterity to their game play.  The joysticks are quite responsive and you still have the "rumble" motors that vibrate during game play.It is great quality, awesomely customizable-great gift for your young gamer.

Better to describe as a water circulating bowl. I have cats and my vet recommended a fountain to encourage cats to drink more often.This bowl circulates water under the waterline vs having any type of falling/splashing water available in most fountains.The kitty's are not inspired to drink from this bowl.The bowl is large, holds enough water for more than a few days in a 3 cat household. Unfortunately, more than we need. I have to dump water to clean the bowl long before its empty. Very easy to clean-much fewer pieces to clean and dishwasher safe. I really liked the idea of fun colors.

The only reason for four stars is the inaccessible fountain filter.This is a great size, we are a multi at family and all are able to come forth and happily drink! The cord is long so I have flexibility on where this fountain is placed.We have it in full speed and it creates a nice water bubbly sound-kinda pleasant:)The fountain stays surprisingly Ick (that water bowl slime that seems to grow around the bowl under the waterline) free. I'm sad to say the filter that it comes with is the only filter I can find. I don't see where I can buy more. The filter is what make this a differentiator from the other fountains avail. You could get creative, as I will with cutting up sponges to help keep the Ick away until I find the filters!The resivoir with the bowl makes it need to be filled every 2-3 days in my 3 cat household.

Quality is here.  This bag is excellent for someone that needs to protect small equipment.  The bag is "tight" and the many small compartments give you the security that your gear is protected. This bag feels kind of like a lap top bag, with the amount of padded sides and pockets. Seams and zippers are great quality.  It will carry weight comfortably, the straps are wide and well padded.This is a great bag but is limited in its use, thus the 4 stars.  This is meant for a specific purpose.  This cannot double as an overnight bag-afternoon trekker or other opportunities one would have for a backpack.The pack is firm in its shape which is good from the protection aspect, but limited in its capacity.I included a photo.  This is the bag on a 5'7" woman, you can see its size and how is rides on the the back

I've never owned a dust collector before, but after using this one, I'm sorry I didn't pick one up sooner.  My shop has never been cleaner.This thing is a beast.  I'm a fairly large dude, and moving the box around when it first arrived was a bit of a challenge.  Assembly wasn't too difficult at all, and took me about 45 minutes total (I was taking my time, as well). Everything about this unit is made very well.  As heavy as the motor is, moving and maneuvering the unit around once it's assembled is absolutely easy - it's like pushing a shopping cart.This also has the added benefit of letting me move it around my smallish shop.  I don't have to install ducting in my shop because I can just move the dust collector to where it needs to be, when it needs to be there.  It *is* a bit loud, though - about as loud as a shop vac.  That said, the suction this thing has is considerable.  Make sure you don't accidentally get the ducting near small or lightweight parts, because it will suck it up in a second.I've been using it for a while now, and I have to say, I can't imagine not having a dust collector.  If you're thinking about getting a dust collector, I'd highly recommend this one.  It's made very well and works like a champ.

Typically when you sign up for broadband access through your cable provider, they want you to rent a modem from them, which ends up being a huge scam.  Buy this modem / router combo, and it'll pay for itself in about a year.As soon as I had this modem activated, I noticed an immediate boost in speed (from 80 Mps to 120 Mps - I tested this through speedtest.net, just so you know). I'm sure there is a long and lengthy technical explanation as to why this occurred, but the only thing I cared about was a faster connection, and it was *very noticeable*.I also set up the guest network for my kids' friends who come into the house and want to connect.  The parental controls are good, but not great.  Also, this modem has crazy coverage - we have a *very* large house (5k+ square feet), and the signal is very strong in all corners of the house.If you're renting a modem, stop it.  Stop it right now.  Get this one, save yourself some cash and get a performance boost at the same time.

This is an outstanding solution for a solo performer, or someone who wants an all-around PA solution.  We use this for a PA system for music and announcements during tennis matches, and it works *wonderfully*.  The number of input and EQ options for this speaker make it super-flexible and we'll be using this for pretty much any function or gathering we have in the future.I don't think I would necessarily recommend this for use as a bluetooth speaker only - there are other way cheaper solutions for that on Amazon.  This is much more of a PA system, and while it's definitely loud, it doesn't really carry the sound quality of a Bose or Sennheiser. It's more of a blunt instrument than a scalpel in that regard.If there was anything that really hung me up, it would be the app integration.  You need to download the free Mackie app in order to really unlock the more powerful options of the system.  That said, once you have it downloaded and you've connected the speaker, it is *ridiculously* easy to control every aspect of the PA system, right from your phone or device.It isn’t built to be everything to everyone, but if you're looking for a really flexible PA or small performance speaker, this is an amazing solution.

Trust the quality on this! We have become professionals at replacing sink faucets and this is definitely a simple drop, tighten and go.Our sink is black mat composite and the chrome on this really pops! I haven't had any trouble with water spots, it wipes sparkly easily.We have had a Delta with similar features in our RV and the touch-clean spray holes have been so helpful with the varieties of water we run through that system, the jets are soft rubber that allows you to just wipe and all jets function flawlessly, no odd hard water buildup.The hose is ample to pull out and rinse all areas of our over-sized sink.The only bummer is that the post is a bit misleading, though it is clear in the product details, this is not a touch sensor faucet, even though the video does show that as a feature on a similar faucet in the Essa line.It is great quality, easy to install with elegant clean design.

Our little girl is waiting for her shot to become a backup dancer. This was right up her ally.The game was easy to play, though they modified the rules often as they played round after round. They played it in the game room, I don't need to tell you that if you aren't playing no amount of volume control is going to let you love the sounds this thing makes.The plastic felt a fit fragile but, we are in our 10th hour of play and the unit has been stepped on and held up.Most of the twister dance games have a place to lock in the sold separately "tracker" that can monitor and calculate body movement encouraging kids to play more and be celebrated. One more thing she "needs".:)It's been a nice add to our sleepover game collection.

Resounding hooray!To note, the Millennium Falcon case is a bit larger than 11in in diameter, a really nice size for a play set.Easy to open for little hands, and stays closed keeping the figures/accessories locked in side.There are a few small pieces-like the torpedoes that shoot from the cannon, we bagged them up until we are ready for them later, removing them didn't hinder play.We love that it is old school imagination, no lights, sounds or batteries! The trap door and secret compartment were a bit hit.My Star Wars aficionado approved of the small details, making it a fun piece for a collector.The C-3PO was not included, so we will be searching for that next!

The polka dots definitely bring your personality to the party! I am a big fan of potlucks & having a simple crock that I can take to the office, church or a neighbors house is a bonus.It does not look cheapy-the removable ceramic pot inside is nice quality and easy to clean.It has done a nice job simmering my chili, melting the my cheese dip and keeping my bbq meatballs warm.The cord is just a bit longer than 2ft and the metal heating pot does get hot to the touch like most crocks. Not negatives, just the nature of the beast.

This thing is pretty awesome once you've got it up and running.  We don't have a lot of power outages in Phoenix, but I'm *that guy* who likes to be prepared, and I used the excuse that we could take this camping to get the wife's buy-in (it was reluctant, to say the least).That said, here are some things to be aware of:When I unboxed the generator, it was apparent it had seen some hard times in transit.  The styrofoam was crushed all over, and one of the circuit reset buttons had been broken (a dot of superglue fixed that).  The packaging isn't really designed to withstand the weight of a generator, so it was impressive nothing else was broken (UPS is awesome).The assembly directions didn't include the need to bolt on a bottom support bracket.  No big deal - it was two bolts - but it probably should have been mentioned in the directions.  The biggest problem I found was that I was missing 2 c-clips to keep the tires on.  Again, not a big deal for me, as I have these in my shop, but they're kind of a specialty thing, and if you don't have a hardware store nearby, you could be waiting for Honda to send you replacements.In the box, this thing is *heavy*.  I'm not a small dude, and I had to put some effort into getting it off the front patio and into the house.  If this might be a problem for you, you might want to make sure you're home when the delivery guy shows so you can have him bring it in for you.The good stuff:It started on the first pull (!).  For anyone who's tried to start a lawnmower that's been sitting a while, this is one of those amazeballs things you can't believe happened. Also, for a generator, it's not really loud.  I mean, it's a gas engine, so it's not whisper-quiet or anything, but it's not difficult to have a conversation around it, either.The power it puts out is *substantial*.  It has 4 plugs on it, and you can run a large number of things.  I was able to run an industrial grinder and a miter saw at the same time (it didn't like it when I added a shop vac to the mix, however).  If this is backup or recreational generator for you, you'll have no problems with powering the things you want/need to.After getting it assembled, I was really surprised at how well it performed.  If you're looking for a really solid generator, I'd highly recommend this one.

3 AA batteries (not incl), 6 screws, 8 stickers and 8 minutes and you have a winner!Nice little play set, only 7 pieces to pop/screw on.  It is nearly 24' from top of the flag pole to base.Her favorite thing about the set is that it came with 2 princesses (Belle and Cinderella) and their corresponding prince's, though the Beast is in human form. There is a wheeled carriage, bed, sofa and dinner table...enough pieces for long time play but not too many that they will be strung everywhere. Plus all the Little People toys work together.It plays a snip of the Beauty and the Beast theme song, along with a few words from Belle and a bit of Bibbidi-Bobbidi Boo when you spin the dance floor.  There is also a button that plays 5 phrases and 5 regal trumpets, randomized when pressed.There is a high-low-off button for the sounds.  (YAY!)Age shows 1 1/2yrs to 5 years and everything is intuitive and easy for the toddler and still has enough elements to keep the 5year old engaged.

If you love your Swiffer, then you may like this. It is your favorite dry Swiffer with a low powered vac.Pros: rechargeable, fits the Swiffer dry pads (my Swiffer wet pads could wrap around too!), light weight, easy maneuveringCons: very low suction (took 3 passes to pick up kitty litter), it was loud with no additional features for the moneySwiffer is king of the quick daily tidy, I just couldn't validate the extra spend-you can get a small stick vac with considerably more options and significantly more power for nearly the same price. I did not find the vac in this to be worth the reduction of cleaning tools in the closet.To note! There was a slight reduction of that annoying line of dust that is left when you have finished Swiffer-ing the floor. :)

I regularly use C4 for my pre-workout, and even though I've tried other brands, I keep coming back to C4 because of it's effectiveness.This version of the pre-workout is good, not great - depending on what you're looking for.
