Excellent scale. Easy to use, light weight, compact and uses AA batteries (included). Takes the stress away from wondering if you've packed too much in your luggage. A must for anyone wanting to avoid those exorbitant weight overage fees the airlines charge. Easily converts from lbs to kg.

A bit pricey but a great sunblock for sports. Dries quickly after application, isn't sticky at all and best of all stays put!!!. I also love their noncomedogenic sunblock for the face.  Due to the high price I would only recommend this sunblock for sport related activities.  If your simply going to the beach/swimming then a regular high spf Neutrogena works just as well.

Pros-includes two smooth barrels (1 inch clip and clip less)easy to switch out barrels1 inch clip barrel holds hair nice and tightmultiple heat settingsproduces nice spiral curls or beachy waveslight weightend of both barrels has nice plastic piece to hold on toogood value for what your gettingsits off counter to prevent table burnCons-no heat protection glove for the clip less barrel (this would have been especially helpful if you need to change barrels quickly)end of both barrels has nice plastic piece to hold on too (can snag if you slide hair out instead of unwinding)

I've had this vacuum for several months now and I am impressed with its capabilities considering the lower price.  Suction is excellent.  It tackled my thick rugs to hard wood floors easily.  On board hose and extension are handy and fit neatly/securely on machine. Maneuverability is good.  Its not exactly light weight but its not the heaviest either.  My only gripe is the bagless container. I don't like touching the clip on the bottom of the container whilst opening it, should be push button.  But at this price point, can't  complain.  Overall a good machine for the price. Recommended.

I don't know what it is about the combination of Regency Rakes and Christmas but it's simply divine. Perhaps it's that I love to see historical bad boys reformed during the most magical time of year.  Or its perhaps it's that I love reading about all that warm wonderful holiday spirit.  Or perhaps it's really for the mistletoe scenes (ok, I admit it! ;)).  Luckliy, you get all three in Christmas at Rakehell Manor. On one hand there is Hugo, the elusive and secretive Lord living in the scandalously dubbed Rakehell Manor.  What exactly is going on in there? What of all the whispers and rumors of shocking behavior and... orgies? On the other hand, there is Prue, the sensible and highly capable companion, able to handle any situation thrown at her with aplomb.  But will she be able to handle being forced to take refuge at the Manor? What will she think of the goings on in there? Will she uncover the secrets of the mysterious Lord? Would she even dare to?It's wonderful to see these two characters slowly open up to each other healing their wounded hearts. And the back drop of the impending holidays couldn't have set the scene any better.I read it in one sitting, couldn't put it down. Hanbury has a particular talent for creating heart melting scenes and this book has several of them. Its worth reading simply for the log house scene.*sigh*Highly recommended.My absolute favorites by Hanbury-Ice AngelThe Paradise Will

Omron makes great blood pressure monitors. This is our 3rd one. I love how readings are accurate and easy to make. But I'm not sure all the "extra's" are needed for our purposes. I think the lower models are just as good and worth looking into if someone is on the fence to spend the extra money.

Not as good as the original.  I found this carrier to be just as sturdy and comfortable as the original by not as easy getting the baby in and out.  The mechanism is different.  Perhaps we are just used to the original by I find this one more difficult to deal with especially when taking out a sleeping 8 month old. Too much jostling in my opinion.  And couldn't the designers at BabyBjorn come up with some other patterns and colors?

I really like this shampoo, a little goes a long way for my super long bleach highlighted blonde hair. It left my hair clean but not stripped.  It has a very slightly oily feeling ( which I liked) while cleansing and almost feels as if you are not completely rinsing out the product.  Because of this, my hair was left hydrated (preferred) and not raw squeaky clean (here comes the straw).  I also felt that I didn't need to use a super damage remedy conditioner afterwards. Good product for me.I agree with others that I would not recommend this Fekkai shampoo to anyone with thin to normal hair.  Its best for dry hair types.

I have been using Fekkai Glossing Conditioner on and off for many years. Up until recently it has been doing a very fine job of keeping my very long highlighted blonde hair silky and smooth.  Unfortunately the formula has changed with the packaging.  What used to be a decently thick conditioner has turned into a thin watery mess.  I wound up using far too much product to get my hair coated and I don't believe the results were the same.  As far as I am concerned, for my type of hair, the cost is just not worth it for me.  I will be on the hunt at **Maxx for any of the old bottles.I would recommend this product to anyone with above shoulder length, thinner hair.  A nice light weight conditioner with no buildup.

I wasn't entirely sure about this odd looking teardrop shaped iron until I used it.  Surprised it worked so well. The wand produced some very nice beach style waves on my long hair (see photos).  And the curls only got better looking (more relaxed) as the day wore on.I think there is a lot of confusion about how to use an iron without a clip, so I tried to explain that visually with a photo in the images section.****You are NOT supposed to touch wand/iron with your gloved hand, let alone hold it there. The glove is meant to protect hand from an ACCIDENTAL touch. Look at the photo on the side of the box and please read the instructions. Also, nowhere on the box or in the instructions does it state that there are multiple heat settings but rather interchangeable barrels you can purchase.Here's what I think of the teardrop wand.PRO-creates very nice beach style waves-great for long hair-easy to use after you get the hang of it-barrel can be removed and replaced with other shape (conical etc)-inexpensive compared to other brands-smooth barrel-swivel cord-barrel rest prevents counter surface damageCON-only one heat setting (410)-you have to buy the other barrels (couldn't Remington just include them?)-not for shorter hair lengths, hair would wind up sticking out in kinky anglesRecommended for longer hair lengths seeking easy beach waves.

This is the second pair of these gloves that I have purchased for my 10yr soccer goalie son. One pair lasted him an entire travel season (granted, at the end they were, to put it mildly, disgusting).  I use the goalie glove soap one these to keep them lasting longer. The finger guards are the reason I purchased them. Prevents injury but also limits mobility. Its a trade off he is willing to live with until he gets older and better.Recommended
Nice little compact device. Easy set up right out of the box. I just connect it to my receiver, turn on the blue tooth on my phone and stream my music through the surround sound.

I've had the curl secret for over a year. While it does an excellent job of achieving a certain type of curl, it doesn't  necessarily  replace a curling iron.PRO-achieves a consist curl on both sides or your head-easy to use once you get the hang of it (great for anyone who struggles with using an iron)-the absolute best part of the this iron is that hair is heated on BOTH sides so curls LAST LONG! Sometimes days with minor touch ups!-multiple heat settings allows a variety of curl coil (tight or loose)-Perfect for above the shoulder length hair.CON-really only makes one type of curl, either loose of tight depending on how long you hold it (vs. an iron where you can alternate direction, thickness etc)-takes waaaay longer than an iron because you can only curl VERY small sections of hair at a time-HEAVY! If you have a lot of hair be prepared for an arm workout!-tangles hair. No matter how many times I have curled my hair over the year, I ALWAYS tangle (at least one piece of) my hair.  Its probably because I'm frustrated by how long it takes so I take sections that are too wide into the machine.-tangles (getting hair stuck in machine) hurts a lot! Its one of those OW!!! "Get this thing off my hair!" moments. Its a mad rush to reverse and unplug before permanent damage happens.-the longer the hair, the more likely it tangles-price. You can get the same look with a curling iron for much less moneyOverall I would recommend the curl secret for anyone with above the shoulder length hair and/or anyone who has trouble using a curling iron.*see my curl secret photo for long hair in customer images

I felt like I was entering the twilight zone reading this book. Everything seemed the same but yet everything was different. What the hell has been happening to the last several books? Where's the drama, the camaraderie and the dam action?!?! I felt like the whole book was compartmentalized into Wrath/Beth, Assail/Sola, Trez/Serena and Xcor/Layla.  Barely anyone else was mentioned or interacted with. So unlike the beginning books of this series.My proof that we are in the Twilight Zone-1- NO lessers (Come on, there are more letters in the alphabet to use! What about a Mr. S, Mr. M, or Mr. P?) Miss the Omega.2- Band of B's - Xcor just decides, yup, I'm going to put the whole "overthrow the king" thing on the back burner while I go shopping for some new duds to impress my "pregnant by another dude" pseudo girlfriend.  So the big scary (oh I'm shaking in my boots thinking about the creepy lip) leader is shopping at Macy's?!?!? Huh. Wonder if he bought Tommy Hilfiger or Ralph Lauren. And where the hell is Qhuinn?!?!?3- No Shellans. Hello? Was Beth the only one in this book? Blink and you miss the slight mention of the others. They used to be so prominent in previous books. Everyone worked together like a FAMILY. They ate together, they played together, they laughed together, they worked out together etc.  The whole family life seems to be crumbling.  I miss the mundane. It was so endearing. I want to read about them hanging out and watching movies, playing billiards and other stuff.4- Finish what you started. Way too many new characters with unresolved issues. Am I supposed to forget about Murdher and Lassiter while Assail, Xcor, Trez and iAm come into the picture? I want to invest time into a character and CARE about them. I don't want drips and drops here and there.5- Lacks depth and information. For example -Shadow -OK so Trez and iAm are shadows or whatever Ward calls them. Well, what about them? What can or cannot they do specifically? Who and Where are their people? What are their rituals/customs? How are integrated into the Vampire community? I felt like this was a huge missed opportunity.  Remember all the details about sympaths in the previous books? Well, what about the shadows?And those things are just off the top of my head!Sigh. OK, I finished my vent and I probably would not have been as harsh if I hand't recently re-read my favorite parts of previous books. I didn't completely dislike the book.  There are certainly parts of it that I enjoyed (Wrath/Beth) but the rest was just unremarkable and uninspiring to say the least. Nothing close to what Ward is capable of and thats the problem.  Spectacular this is not.  Praying to the Scribe Virgin the next one is better.

I'm all for all natural products and am willing to pay extra to purchase them over synthetics, but I'm torn with this burn relief gel. It works as advertised (relieved my pinkish mild shoulder burn) but I didn't care for the brownish gel. It left stains on my white clothing and bedding. I waited 20 minutes after applying and the gel seemed to be completely absorbed but still stains. Perhaps I applied too much? Not sure, but when in pain, I like to put a nice layer of burn relief on.  The texture of the gel is weird too. Its more of a slimy gel verses  gels that I'm used to (if that makes any sense).  I'll still keep looking.

I used 3 pumps on my damp hair after washing and didn't notice any difference in my hair when it dried.  I guess I was expecting some softness and manageability, but I got nada. I'm better off sticking to oils.

I like this restorative oil. I use 3-4 pumps on my damp (post washing) mid-back length highlighted blonde hair.  My hair is rather thick and absorbs the oil well.  Afterwards I allow my hair to air dry.  The result is nice soft manageable hair.  I never use oils on my hair when it is dry, the result is usually greasy looking.I think you have to be careful about the amount you use though. Its very easy to wind up with an oily looking head. I would only recommend this to people with thicker hair.  Any other type of hair might get severely weighed down.For anyone interested in trying hair oils, at this price point, its worth a try.For highlighted or bleached hair I highly recommend my absolute favorite Kerastase Elixir Ultime.  Worth every penny.
I like this cover.  Its nice, thin, and unobtrusive. It fits my iPad perfectly, while covering all four corners. Recommended!

I didn't see the difference between using this and any other regular type conditioner for dry hair. It did condition my hair but did not leave it as soft and manageable as I would have liked without adding a leave-in conditioner.  I feel, for my type of long blonde highlighted hair, there are far superior products.I like to rotate amongst  several products like Aussie 3 Minute Miracle.  Just about any Pantene or Loreal deep conditioner works well too.  And for those who don't mind the $, Keratase and Loreal Professional line make some excellent conditioners.

I would give this book 10 stars if I could.  Seriously, I think it's that good.  I won't spoil it for anyone but there is a clever twist in the book which separates it from the average bluestocking/libertine romance, but this is not what blew me over.  The yearning to absolute anguish the hero( Ian ) and heroine (Corinna) go through in this book is remarkable, particularly the last gut wrenching quarter of the book.  Neither of these two believe their love is reciprocated, so they stay silent about it.  Every meeting thereafter is an emotional roller coaster till the end.  I absolutely loved that.Reminded me very much of Judith McNaught's emotional writing style.**Coincidentally, I read the author's note at the end and she mentioned that Truly Madly Yours (one of my favorite contemporary romances) was one of her inspirations for the My Lady, My Lord.  I highly recommend this book if you enjoyed Gibson's book.

In general, I like Toni&Guy Shampoo and Conditioner.  Used together it left my long bleach blonde hair soft and manageable.  The smell is pleasant and not overpowering.  The shampoo produces a nice lather and the conditioner is light but effective.  The only drawback, and this is a big one, are the ingredients.  I am by no means criticizing anyone who uses products with sulfates, TEA, parabens, and all those other nasty chemicals we keep hearing about.  Heck, I probably have a dozen or more products with those ingredients in my bathroom right now.  But I figure with this higher price point more natural ingredients could have been substituted.  If I'm spending more money, I want to see better quality ingredients.

In general, I like Toni&Guy Shampoo and Conditioner.  Used together it left my long bleach blonde hair soft and manageable.  The smell is pleasant and not overpowering.  The shampoo produces a nice lather and the conditioner is light but effective.  The only drawback, and this is a big one, are the ingredients.  I am by no means criticizing anyone who uses products with sulfates, TEA, parabens, and all those other nasty chemicals we keep hearing about.  Heck, I probably have a dozen or more products with those ingredients in my bathroom right now.  But I figure with this higher price point more natural ingredients could have been substituted.  If I'm spending more money, I want to see better quality ingredients.

Prequel: American Mail-Order BridesBy: Kirsten Osbourne4/5 starsThis is a very short prequel setting the scene for a series of mail-order bride books, written by multiple authors. There will be 1 book per state and the authors are set to release one per day starting 11/19/2015 until all have been released.A group of women work at a factory and when it suspiciously burns to the ground some women have no job options and no choices of places to live & ways to make money. But the former manager felt a sense of belonging and caretaking over these women, and she needed help for herself. She finds an ad for mail-order brides and decides that is her only option and may very well be the only & best option for most of these women.

The Wrath of Cain (Syndicate #1)By: Kathy Coopmans3/5 starsCain & Calla were star-crossed lovers. Their fathers hated each other and thus they weren’t allowed to spend time with each other, let alone date one another. Instead, they were forced to hide their relationship and sneak around. But at 18 years old, they thought that their parents would have to acknowledge their relationship if they were married, so they eloped. To say that their parents were less than happy is an understatement.After Cain goes to tell his father & step-mother, Calla shows up later only to find him in bed with another woman. She is devastated & heartbroken. She ends up leaving and going to college & law school out of country. We didn’t get to see any of these intermittent years, they were only briefly described. Then six years later she returns to Cain to have him sign divorce papers, but it doesn’t go as planned.There are betrayals, there is danger there is hot sex and intrigue. There is some loathing and love. Feelings and emotions are all over the place and at times, cause whiplash.I loved the premise of this book, but sadly, it missed the mark. I wished there was more time for us to see the relationship between Cain & Calla to develop when they were just high schoolers. I wanted to see the love blossom & grow between them. But I didn’t, so I didn’t really feel their soul-deep connection. Therefore, I didn’t really care for how quickly and easily she fell right back in with Cain & without much discussion. It was like, insta-love, insta-forgiveness, insta-now & insta-future. I just didn’t feel their love or connection.

Crave (Bayonet Scars #5.5)By: JC Emery4/5 starsElle Phillips has long since had a difficult, strained and sometimes estranged relationship with her father, Chief, a now deceased member of the Forsaken Motorcycle Club. Her only real connection to Forsaken was mainly through Grady as they had been friends with benefits for years. Grady was 10+ years older than Elle and also her father’s best friend. At first this also made me wonder if she had daddy issues, which she actually did. But once Grady hooked up with Holly, Elle was dropped faster than he even had a thought.Diesel has had a long crush on Elle and always believed that she deserved better than Grady ever treated her and more than he ever offered her. Diesel wants Elle, but has never crossed any line with her because of her connection with Grady. But he ends up keeping tabs on Elle for Grady and thus getting to know her a little better.Elle is a private detective and when she gets a case that also involves club business she knows that she can’t talk to anyone in the club about her newest assignment. But Diesel is determined to stick with her. He doesn’t know her assignment either, but will never leave her high and dry.What I didn’t like about this novella was the insta-love. There wasn’t time for their relationship to develop and thus deeper feelings. I think that it could have been done better had the author shown us the getting to know each other period and all the times that Diesel spent checking in on her. But those weren’t expounded upon, only his last visit.There are some crazy revelations and I can hardly wait for the next book because the personal drama in that one should be ramped up!

Vow (Bayonet Scars #4.5)By: JC Emery4/5 starsVow is about Ryan & Alex and moving forward with their relationship. Ryan wants a more permanent union between the two of them. Ryan wants the stability & the permanence of marriage. He’s continually been pushing Alex for marriage, but she continues to push back, saying she’s not ready.Alex is cautious of making a lasting commitment because of how she grew up and how women were viewed within the mafia life. She wants to be an equal partner in her marriage, like her birth mom Ruby is with Jim. She doesn’t want to just be a possession or someone who requires constant protection. Her life right now is in extreme danger, so she spends her days at Ruby & Jim’s home, living with Ryan and under protection at all times.While this novella was supposed to show a more loving side of Ryan and have him not be such a jerk, I don’t think this novella did that. He still had his straight up jerkwad tendencies, thoughts & word vomit. But it did show that he’s willing to compromise for Alex and not just bully her into doing what he wants. This novella is like all the books in this series, in that it overlaps in timeframe

Vow (Bayonet Scars #4.5)By: JC Emery4/5 starsI bought and read this novella as part of the box set, Where Souls Spoil.Vow is about Ryan & Alex and moving forward with their relationship. Ryan wants a more permanent union between the two of them. Ryan wants the stability & the permanence of marriage. He’s continually been pushing Alex for marriage, but she continues to push back, saying she’s not ready.Alex is cautious of making a lasting commitment because of how she grew up and how women were viewed within the mafia life. She wants to be an equal partner in her marriage, like her birth mom Ruby is with Jim. She doesn’t want to just be a possession or someone who requires constant protection. Her life right now is in extreme danger, so she spends her days at Ruby & Jim’s home, living with Ryan and under protection at all times.While this novella was supposed to show a more loving side of Ryan and have him not be such a jerk, I don’t think this novella did that. He still had his straight up jerkwad tendencies, thoughts & word vomit. But it did show that he’s willing to compromise for Alex and not just bully her into doing what he wants. This novella is like all the books in this series, in that it overlaps in timeframe

Simple Ride: Hellions MC (Hellions Ride #6)By: Chelsea Camaron3/5 starsWhen Boomer left the military he was a broken man. He has a bit of survivor’s guilt from his service, couple that with PTSD and Boomer has his share of problems. He joined the Hellions after returning home and knowing Shooter and wanting to belong to a family. Therefore, he seems to mainly be a loner.Purple Pu$$y Pamela is a barfly, someone that is just there to provide a good time to the club members. She has secrets that she’s never shared with anyone in order to keep herself & her loved ones safe. But these are the types of problems that should have been brought to the club for everyone’s safety.Boomer thinks that he & Pam have developed a deeper connection over the last year and he wants more. But Pam is running and won’t allow herself anything else. This of course causes friction between the two of them and jacks up whatever type of relationship that was building.There was just too much that went way too fast. The book wasn’t fleshed out, there was more showing instead of telling and felt very rushed. I didn’t have the time to feel any connection between Boomer & Pam. Then the amount of time that it took them to actually come together also didn’t flow well. The book just ended abruptly after they had barely gotten together.One RideForever RideMerciless RideEternal RideInnocent RideSimple Ride

Reaper’s Fall (Reaper’s MC #5)By: Joanna Wylde5/5 starsPainter and Melanie have had a rocky, up and down history. Painter has been a member of the Reaper’s MC for years, ever since he was released from prison the first time. He’s been a jerk from the time that he first played a bigger part of a book. During the book Devil’s Game, he led Em on for a while and when he finally got his patch, instead of going for her, he went for the club girls, which drove Em into the arms of Hunter, a Devil’s Jacks member. Then in book 4, Reaper’s Stand, Painter followed London for Picnic and also hung out with Melanie to keep her occupied while she was also living at Picnic’s. We learned a lot more about Painter & Melanie during Puck’s book, book 1 of the Silver Valley series. This book occurs almost within the same time frame as Puck’s book.The book starts from when Painter gets out of prison with Puck and being back in Idaho. But he has his doubts about Melanie. She is just too pure and innocent for him and the life he has lived and will continue to live as a member of the Reaper’s MC. But the connection they had was too much for either one to deny and though Painter tries to stay away, he and Melanie spend time together which develops into something more and then something deeper than that. But of course something goes sideways, causing a separation.Melanie loves Painter and has for years. She wrote to him throughout the 5 years while he was in prison with Puck. So she wants to start a relationship with him right away. She spends time pining over Painter’s avoidance. But when they start something, she’s ecstatic for the entire time, until things get a little too real, and their circumstances change. Melanie makes decisions about her life and the future and does what she has to in order to get through it all. But when Painter re-enters her life, she doesn’t have room for him.Now, many readers had a total, full-on hate relationship with Painter, because he does have a tendency to say things & act like a jerk. Even though I did get mad at him, I never went full-on hater because I never thought he was absolutely terrible. I did want more story after Painter & Mel actually got together, but that’s just a personal preference.We did get a bonus epilogue in this book, which is a teaser for the next Reaper’s book to be released, Reaper’s Fire.

Slut (Twin Duo #2)By: Jettie Woodruff5/5 starsThe cliffhanger at the end of book 1, Suit, made it hard for me to focus on other books. I kept coming back to it and hashing things over in my head about it. I talked it over with a group of friends and we all had theories and if someone had a different theory, then it started the discussion all over again.I feel that if I review this book like I normally review, that it will spoil it. And this is definitely a book that you need to read and discover the truths for yourself. I absolutely loved this book and stayed up super late to finish it, because I just had to know what happened!Gabby still has no memory, and she tries to figure out more of what her life was about. You’ll love Paxton, then hate him, understand him and not understand anything about him and then love him again. Their daughters are still as adorable as ever, who will make you laugh and make you think deeply.So many things were answered, and a couple new questions arose. I really didn’t want this book to end, I wanted more! And Jettie announced via Facebook that there will be a follow-up novella around Christmas time, so it may include the holiday time for the Pierce family as well.*I was provided an Advanced Copy in exchange for an honest review.

Coup De Grâce (Code 11-KDP SWAT #7)By: Lani Lynn Vale4/5 starsMichael is known as Saint to the SWAT officers because of his caring & ability to take care of the people that they rescue, especially the children. But Michael also holds himself a part from the team because he fights different demons. Michael actually went to college to follow the family footsteps into the medical field before he became a Navy Seal, where he became great friends with Nico & Bennett and Foster & Miller.Nikki Pena is Nico’s younger sister, and has been attracted to Michael for years. Previously they had a relationship, but that went belly-up for reasons unknown to all their friends and the readers. Well, we finally figure it out and it turns out to be a poorly worded argument/reason and an ensuing misunderstanding between the characters. Nikki is a nurse in the hospital where quite a few of the heroines of this series and the Freebirds series work.The personal, familial & work drama was all intriguing. But the past drama between Michael & Nikki seemed to be resolved way too easily and almost immediately once they resume actually speaking to each other, which happens early in the book. It just seemed like it was glossed over and for me that seemed to cheapen their valid argument when they went their separate ways. I just felt like I needed more communication between them than just a few lines and they jump back into a relationship like nothing ever happened.

Beyond Her Words (Corrupt Chaos MC #1)By: Bink Cummings5/5 starsMagdalene has had a rough life for the last 10 years. She’s been on her own without any living family or friends. She’s always been a bit different having been raised by her grandmother in rural Kansas on a small plot of land. She grew up gardening, raising some small animals and falling in love with the boy next door and learning all about vehicle mechanics & restoration. But for the last 10 years, Magdalene has lived in just as many one-horse towns, working odd jobs, living and even dating, before moving on again. But on her last trip, a storm forces her to pull over, which turned into a much longer stay than just pumping some gas.Lachlan is a firefighter and brother in the Corrupt Chaos MC and to top it all off, he’s Scottish! Bink does provide some common translations for how Lachlan pronounces some words and speaks. This wasn’t hard for me to read, and I found myself reading with an accent. Lachlan is a wonderful father, loyal to the core and a gentle giant. Though, he does have the ability to be a jerk at times, as well. That does seem to come from his inability to understand women, and possibly because of the way he was raised, since most everyone around him seems to know that he can be a total jerk.Both Magdalene & Lachlan suffer from doubts and insecurities that have built up over the years that have also caused scars. Slowly but surely, they begin to open up and show feelings. For the first time in years, Magdalene opens up to the possibility of having real friends and Lachlan has to confront his fears so that he can move forward.The supporting characters were so fleshed out that I really felt like I knew them all. I was almost just as invested in their side stories as I am about Lachlan & Magdalene’s. I’m looking forward to more in this series, I’m very intrigued!! I wasn’t ready for the book to end and I’m also sad that Lachlan isn’t a real man out there, but will remain a great book boyfriend!The writing style is similar to Bink MC Chronicles series, but she has really grown as an author and I think this book really shows it.*I was provided with an Advanced Copy in exchange for an honest review.

Tequila NightsBy: Melissa Jane5/5 starsThis is Melissa Jane’s first foray into contemporary romance and I think she nailed it. I loved her dark cartel series and was excited to hear that she had something different in the works. She had nothing to be concerned about switching up the genres for this book. I fell in love with the characters and their friends.Josie is a college art student and somewhat of a natural klutz a condition that is exacerbated when she’s nervous. She’s chasing not only her dream but also her mother’s. Her mother was a gifted art student, who later developed Alzheimer’s and died early. Josie is following her advice to paint the world beautiful, while also following her love of art.Leo is a perfect gentleman who also likes to get down and dirty. He’s a genuinely nice guy, a man who knows how to treat a woman, who is sensual and has a love of life in general. He is a giver and a pleaser, but all alpha in his wants, needs and Josie seems to pull that side of him to the surface even more than usual.Leo & Josie are a passionate couple who found each other by chance, had an attraction and developed a relationship even with a pending separation headed their way. I love the way they are together and though everything happens quickly, it doesn’t feel like insta-love at all. I was thoroughly intrigued by the side characters as well. Since this is a stand-alone, I was glad that Melissa Jane also wrapped up the side characters stories and didn’t leave me hanging.*I was provided with an Advanced Copy in exchange for an honest review.

Blood & LoyaltiesBy: Ryan Michele4/5 starsThe Lambardoni family runs a large enterprise that spans all across the United States. Catarina Lambardoni, the only daughter, amongst her brothers, to the underboss of the family, grew up knowing about the type of business her family was a part of. Though she can’t be involved in the family business, because of her gender, it doesn’t mean that she hasn’t picked up things along the way. Her brothers made sure that she could use a gun well and knew how to protect herself. However, they are so protective over her that she doesn’t always get the chance to use her self-defense skills or date any good men. Her brothers scare men off or dissuade them from even trying to date her. She needs someone who isn’t afraid to stand up to her family.Jag Maratelli works for the Lambardoni family and is the consigliere. But he’s not well known around the area since he runs the family distribution business in California. When he sees Catarina for the first time he is taken by her beauty & ferocity. He wants to know her better and in more ways than one. However, this is something that could cause tension since she is family, he won’t be in town long term and she won’t move to California. Despite everything that works against them, they get close to each other and form a relationship.But past sins of fathers come back to haunt the young couple. This causes a physical separation since Jag has to find the men causing problems. More things happen which puts more time between them and now, emotional separation. Their road back to each other may not be easy, but it is something that will happen.I liked this book, but it felt like it was missing something compared to Ryan’s Ravage MC series. There were some parts that seemed like they were added, just to create a little bit of drama, that didn’t seem to go with the storyline. But I liked it well enough and will most likely read the rest of this series.

Calm & Storm (Night Horde SoCal #6)By: Susan Fanetti5/5 starsThis is the epic conclusion to not only the Night Horde SoCal series but I believe to the Night Horde series all together. There will be a standalone book for Nolan (Havoc & Corey’s son) that will still be about the Horde, but will not be the start of a series.Ronin is a bit older, more than 50, and he’s always been the quiet one of the club. He’s never been into the all-night parties or crazy shenanigans. He joined the service at the age of 30 and joined club life late as well. He was just a prospect, for the Scorpions, during the Signal Bend series when they went to war with the Perros Cartel. But he’s a loyal man to his very core and even though he voted against getting in bed with La Zorra & her Cartel, he does everything that is needed & required of him. But he’s one of the few who still sticks with a “straight” job, even though he has more money than he needs and has no family. But he enjoys his stunt riding for TV and movie productions. While working, he happens to see the woman who broke his heart 25 years earlier. They are a bit awkward, but both seem to want to catch up.Lorraine aka Rainy felt like she had no choice but to walk away from Ronin when he left her to join the military & go to war. But so many years later, she still regrets it. She refers to Ronin as her ‘Great Lost Love.’ But that’s the thing about life; you can never go back and get the chance to redo anything, you can only move forward. Rainy did several of the things she had always dreamed of doing. She was married & has a son, became a chef & now owns a restaurant. So when she sees Ronin again after all these years, she just has to try to get to know him and see if there is anything there left to rekindle. But there has been so much time go by and water that has passed under the bridge, that they are almost 2 completely different people.The club is also dealing with burying some of the brothers in previous books and the need for more members & prospects in order to be there when the war goes down. In the last book, we learned La Zorra’s plans to “salt the earth” and essentially end the drug producing land & trade in Mexico. This was also information that the officers voted not to share with the whole club. Not all officers agreed, specifically Connor, and the tension between Connor & his dad, Hoosier is not only obvious, but almost in everyone’s face. This causes concern and some discontent within the club in general and Ronin. But he is loyal and trusts his officers. But the war is still coming to La Zorra, and thus, the SoCal Horde, so they all prepare.There are twists and turns to Ronin and Rainy’s story. She really made me mad and it was kind of difficult for me to like her, which did eventually happen, but not in the sense that I loved her character. Ronin was almost too Zen at times, but that was an admirable quality.There was club craziness, in which people were harmed, which was to be expected. Even losing a character/s would be par for the course. I loved seeing many of the Signal Bend characters at a couple points during this book. Isaac & Lilli, the two who started it all off are my favorite. But we also saw Showdown & Shannon, Badger, who is the Signal Bend President, Len & Natasha, and some of the younger guys like Nolan, Double A & Dom. Susan Fanetti knows how to write emotional, gut-wrenching scenes, love scenes, high-energy scenes & steamy, hot scenes. She always delivers. This book made me feel happy, sad, bitter, loving, bittersweet & hopeful. For me, Ronin & Rainy’s love story came in second to the club story and how Susan was going to tie everything up for this series. This book ends at 78% which is where the epilogue novella, Home & Safe, starts and ends at 100%.I can’t go into the description about the novella because that would give away a major plot point. But it brings everything full circle and wraps up both Night Horde series. I cried almost through whole chapters of the epilogue novella. Susan Fanetti draws out the emotion almost effortlessly.

Pretty in Ink (Bodies Ink & Steel #2)By: Scott Hildreth5/5 starsI love Stevie & have since she was introduced in book 1, Blurred Lines. She’s a foul-mouthed Kansas transplant from San Diego, California. She’s openly stated that she only dates bikers. But her choice of men in the past hasn’t been good. She’s unfortunately attracted the men who are financially dependent upon her or who use her as a punching bag. She’s loud, in your face and no apologies are given. She’s fully sleeved and a tattoo artist at Blurred Lines and has been a tattoo artist for years.Asher Wilson has lived in the Midwest his entire life. He’s wealthy in his own right as a day trader. As an only child, his parents were overprotective so he was homeschooled, mostly by a caregiver, who also provided him with almost the only love that he felt. They only wanted the best for him, but the thing he felt like he missed out on was love shown & given to him by his parents and having friends. His parents seem to base his and their own self-worth off of his financial statements and his success.Wilson & Stevie meet by chance at a grocery store and though Stevie tries her best to snark her way out of a conversation with him. But they end up talking, since Wilson wasn’t deterred. He asked her on a date, and though he wasn’t what she always thought was her type, she decided to give him a chance.Stevie learns to love herself and that she is worth all the showering of attention that Wilson pays her. She starts to blossom as a human and woman learning to trust again with him. In turn, Stevie gives a new meaning to Wilson’s life. It’s not all work, money, working out and business. She revives his spirit and teaches him about living his life. They may have some doubts and times when they are down, but with hard work, those don’t last.Wilson is truly a gentleman and damn near Prince Charming. I love the guy and hope that every woman out there finds her Wilson. A good thing to remember, is taking chances often bring the greatest rewards.

Blood of Eve (Trilogy of Eve #2)By: Pam Godwin5/5 starsAt the end of the first book, Eve, her three guardians, Roark, Michio & Lakota aka Jesse and the 2 guardsmen, Georges & Tallis, all return to the Blue Ridge Mountains to the other 3 Lakota. They are 2 years into the apocalypse, with the virus that turns men into aphid monsters, turns women into nymphs and has killed all the children. But they are also returning with answers & possibly a solution to the problem, an antidote to the virus, Evie’s blood.In all of the testing and with some experimentation, they have learned that Evie’s blood causes the aphids to explode, but is able to cure the nymphs, bringing them back to human life. After a brief resting period, the group sets out searching for nymphs to heal. They traverse much of the United States looking for nymphs, because women are needed to start repopulating. And Evie is still refusing to have any more children. It is necessary to heal as many nymphs as possible. But they face more challenges than just the aphids, running out of ammo and keeping safe from other, probably dangerous survivors and surviving the wilds themselves. The aphids are no longer just mindless monsters, they are evolving.They all learn more about each other during this time. Finally, we know why Jesse won’t allow himself to be physically involved with Evie and his visions. Jesse desperately wishes to have a deeper relationship with Evie, but holds back. Michio is also hiding secrets, some that are about him and some that are about Evie. Michio is still the slightly jealous and possessive man in love with Evie. Roark is still deeply loyal, protective and in love with Evie. Roark is still laid back and easy going about sharing Evie with the other guardians. His views on his priesthood celibacy are evolving, and it is so HOT! All of the sexual encounters are off the charts!There are twists and turns, and plot lines that make you just wonder WTF is going on?! This entire book is just as well mapped-out and planned as the first book. I’m in awe of how Pam Godwin’s mind worked this entire storyline out. The amount of time that she must have spent researching and then making sure everything worked out damn near perfectly, had to have been in the hundreds range. But Pam delivers with this novel in a HUGE way!!There were definite sad parts, heart stopping points, funny & sarcastically funny conversations, but most of all, there is hope. There is hope for the future, for humankind and for the group. It may have been a bittersweet ending, but I was filled with so much hope and love. I’m excited for the final book. I know Pam has a couple other books in the works before finishing up this series, but I have no doubt that it’ll be worth the wait and every bit as epic as the first 2 books.*I received an advanced copy in exchange for an honest review, but I also bought my own copy.

Chasing Claire (Hell’s Saints MC #2)By: Paula Marinaro4/5 starsClaire Winston is Raine’s (h from book 1) younger sister, who is a recovering drug addict. In the first book, we realize that Claire is more vulnerable & not as mentally strong as her sister. But during her time recovering at the lake house, she & Reno started spending more time with each other and were getting along well. But something happened and they both went their separate ways. In this book, we learn what it was that caused them to separate.Reno is Dolly’s son & nephew to Prosper, the Crownsmount chapter, Hell’s Saints President. At first, he didn’t really care for Raine and the way everyone bent over backwards to help her out. But at first sight of Claire, he knew she was different than he expected and he not only wanted her, but wanted to be with her.They both let their own insecurities get in the way and then they let their hurt feelings get in the way. When Claire tried to go back and explain, Reno had already been to hurt & pissed off to listen. That’s when he went to the West Coast for club business and spent some time out there. But the pull to be with Claire eventually hit him and he just had to get home to be with her. But he was epically stupid, but in the end, it only kind of mattered to her, which I felt was not true to Claire’s personality or if it was, it made her lust-driven or she has a low self-worth.There is club drama and some personal drama, which all goes with the flow. I am intrigued by Reno’s mom, Dolly and her possibilities in the future, and also I hope that Glory and Jules eventually get their own book.I did get annoyed with Claire in this book. She still had so much insecurity and feelings of inadequacy so late in the book that it just got to where it was tedious and made me roll my eyes. By that time, I just wanted the book to be over.

Taming Crow (Hell’s Saints MC #3)By: Paula Marinaro4/5 starsI have loved Crow since book 1, when he befriended Raine and took a shot with her. But at the same time I was also mad at him for hiding that he was married, even if it was a marriage that he wanted out of. I felt sad for him when he lost Raine because he truly did love her as well and those feelings never went away, even as he watched her life morph into dreams of happiness when she married his MC brother Diego, and had a daughter with him. In book 2, Crow knew that he had to make a change and went Nomad, where he didn’t have a home charter and was on the road all the time, doing the work the club needed done. Crow decided to do that to take time to clear his mind and hopefully gain peace of mind and heart.Melissa is a single mother, widowed when her Air Force pilot husband died in a crash while on tour in the Middle East. She lives with her young son, Jett, and is a massage therapist. Her life is simple & quiet, until she meets her new landlord, Crow. While her entire world was orderly & tidy, having Crow around just has her about to combust with all the differences that are driving her haywire. But she can also see how good he is to her son & how her son responds to having a strong male influence in his life.There isn’t much club drama, though I think that it could be boiling in the background. This book is more about the personal lives of Crow & Melissa. But I didn’t like all of this. Crow never talked to Melissa about the club and its importance in his life. While Melissa told him her life story, he never opened up and told her about his. So even though they were supposed to be falling for each other and in love, I didn’t always feel their connection. It also took them a long time to have the getting together conversation and to actually become a couple. The epilogue jumped in time, and to me the whole ending felt rushed.We did get to see some of the Crownsmount club members & their families a couple different times throughout the book, Jules probably the most. Then we also got to meet several of the club members from the Hell’s Saints chapter that was just an hour away from Crow’s house. I don’t know if the author is planning a spin-off series, but I wouldn’t mind a Charity-Tommy book, but who knows. I’m still hoping that Glory and Jules get their book.At the end of the book, I kind of felt lost, like I didn’t know where the characters were going from the end of the book and where the author is taking the storyline. Granted, this book was billed as being able to be read as a standalone (and it can) but I don’t know what Crow & Melissa’s plans are for the future or where this series is going.

Full Circle (Rockin’ Country #3)By: Laramie Briscoe4/5 starsThis is the final part of Garrett & Hannah’s story. They are married and have made the best of their situation of being located in California and Tennessee. Hannah had also already decided to take at least a year off from her grueling schedule, seeing as she has been going non-stop for six years. She also took the time so she could spend it with her husband, while his band finished recording their new record and then going on a world tour.Hannah had some disagreements with Shell, her best friend and manager, mostly about the time being taken off and how much time she was spending with her husband, instead of her career. But they get things ironed out and Shell is happy to try something new and just for herself, for the first time in her adult life.Other than some issues with the paparazzi, life is going pretty well for the newlyweds. They are enjoying their time on the road together. Some nights they perform their song together and of course they both upload photos to their Instagram social media accounts.Jared & Shell have a little bit bigger parts in this book and we see more behind both of them. We see some of the bad and some of the good and a lot of the apprehension. But things are somewhat up in the air for them. They will be getting their own book. Though those probably will be something that I will skip, as these books were all good, but not stand out enough that I want to continue on with the series.

Cassie (Mitchell Healy #7)By: Jennifer Foor3/5 starsOk, so I may be the exception to the rule in my review of this book. I don’t generally give spoilers, but there will be some at the bottom of the review to explain my rating.Cassie Healy is 22 and has a boyfriend that her parents disapprove of. She still lives at home, even though she works and pays her parents rent, they still feel like they can tell her what to do and who to see, which she absolutely hates.Cassie feels the only way that she can be with her boyfriend, Brant, is if they run away together. So they head to Las Vegas to get out from under her family and to start a new life there. Brant hasn’t exactly been truthful about his new job and their living arrangements. Cassie has a hard time accepting that this is her new life and that Brant has gotten them both into some criminal scheme. She’s ashamed, but she loves Brant and just can’t give up on him yet, plus she’s also too embarrassed to call home & return to her family.Cassie has issues accepting her new reality. Unfortunately, in order to deal with this, she seeks the help of drugs. Cassie ends up changing into a person she never thought she’d be, doing things that would be unacceptable to her if she was clean & sober.Her life changes when FBI Agent Logan Campbell enters the picture. At first she doesn’t believe that it’s for the better, but with time spent off drugs, she realizes that some changes are for the best. She still feels like she can’t face her parents because of the things she said to her mother and by being completely wrong about her boyfriend when her family was right.**Spoilers**I felt that some of this book process was rushed for Jennifer Foor. I loved the Mitchell series and have just been so-so about the Mitchell-Healy series, but I love the characters & I will follow this series. But there were quite a few grammar mistakes (a few are generally to be expected) and there were storyline mistakes. For example, one of the characters would do something and then a few pages later, they would just start doing what they had previously just finished. Then there were huge jumps in time after Cassie was rescued by Logan. There was one day that was shown at his house and then in the next paragraph, it was three weeks later and they were leaving on a cross country car trip. Then there was a reminiscing about things they did or that happened while living at his house. There were too many moments that were just told, almost as an afterthought to make something in the present standout, instead of shown. The last is a personal preference: They ended their little whirlwind at 91% so I didn’t get the love feeling when they made up. Then the book skips to 6 months later & ended. I like to see the time after a couple makes up, to actually be in a relationship and see them working it out. Especially after the huge split comes so late in the book, I just didn’t feel their relationship.

Rockin’ Country series box setBy: Laramie Briscoe3/5 starsThis box set only includes book 1 Only the Beginning, book 1.5 One Day at a Time & book 2 The Price of Love. The third book, Full Circle, must be bought separately. This is not a full box set, which is why I rated this 3 stars when I rated the individual books 4 stars. I don't know if authors do this to make more money or to drum up new readers before the final book. But IMO, a box set, means a final, finished product.This series focuses on Hannah “Harmony” Stewart and Garrett “Reaper” Thompson. Both are famous musicians in their respective musical genres. Hannah is a solo country music artist and Garrett is the lead singer of the rock band Black Friday.They work together to figure out how to make a relationship work while they are both busy producing albums and touring and how to deal with the paparazzi drumming up false stories about either and both of them. They have to deal with jealous exes and record companies. They have to deal with being based in California & Nashville and being separated by the physical distance of not only their homes & recording studios, but also while on tour.But when a couple is committed to each other, they’ll do anything to make it all work out. The final book, Full Circle is the last in Garrett & Harmony’s story, but there is more coming from the side characters.

The Price of Love (Rockin’ Love #2)By: Laramie Briscoe4/5 starsWhen Hannah & Garrett got married they didn’t leave behind Harmony & Reaper, their onstage personas. They still have separate obligations to their record companies and what their futures will entail. They aren’t ready for the physical separation that will occur when they have to both get back to work, but that time is near.They are both recording new albums and of course a new album means a new tour. But Hannah has never exercised the clause in her contract that allows her to take some time off. But now, Hannah is ready for a break and even more so since she is a newlywed.They are both under pressure from their record companies about their sound & songs for their new albums. There is more than a little friction from Hannah’s record company about a certain song they want her to duet on with another country artist. Of course there are the paparazzi and trying to spin pictures and news stories, which of course bothers both of them.This book centers around the length of time that Hannah is touring and a countdown until they can be together again. There were some fights they had and disagreements that sometimes seemed a little forced, like the author was trying to force a confrontation. I did find Hannah a little whiny at times during this book as well. We do get a bigger look into Jared & Shell’s relationship as well.I bought and read this book as part of the Rockin’ Country box set.

One Day at a Time (Rockin’ Country #1.5)By: Laramie Briscoe4/5 starsAt the end of their respective tours Hannah & Garrett just didn’t want to be apart from each other. So Hannah flew back to California with Garrett and had her parents check on her house in Nashville, with plans to spend more time with them towards the end of her break.Now, they have more time to spend together and without the grueling schedule of concerts and travel. Now they have time to breathe, to relax, to get to know each other and just take life one day at a time.But they also have more problems with the paparazzi and false news stories. Both Garrett & Shell are worried the Hannah may relapse into bulimia if isn’t able to deal with those stories. She still seems fragile, but she does want to get better and trust in the love between them.I bought and read this as part of the Rockin’ Country box set.

Only the Beginning (Rockin’ Country #1)By: Laramie Briscoe4/5 starsHannah “Harmony” Stewart is at the top of her game in the country music world. She puts out new albums & tours every year. She’s one of the most popular country music stars with all the fame that comes with it. She lives in the public eye through her tours, all the promotions and her social media. But by and large, she doesn’t get attacked by the paparazzi in Nashville. She has always been a fan of the rock band, Black Friday. She sees them perform at an awards show and then takes a picture on the red carpet with the Lead Singer, Garrett “Reaper” Thompson for the press. That’s just the opening they need & the rest is pretty much history.Garrett “Reaper” Thompson is looking for a change. He’s tired of the constant on the go, the lonely life with just his bandmates and groupies and being hounded by the paparazzi. But after meeting the sweet country star, Harmony, and they hit it off, he starts to feel rejuvenated. He and Hannah make plans and put in the effort of seeing each other even though they are both on tour.  They call, text, FaceTime and use social media, mainly Instagram, to stay connected.But there are problems with their situation, which include Harmony’s crappy ex-boyfriend, trust issues with the availability of groupies and the distance that separates them. They can’t wait for the end of their tours so that they can get to know each other better. But when that time ends, they have a decision to make about their futures and where they will go from there.I bought and read this book as part of the Rockin' Country box set.

Dead of Eve (Trilogy of Eve #1)By: Pam Godwin5/5 starsI’ve been a fan of Pam Godwin’s for a couple years, when I first read her second book, Beneath the Burn and was hooked. Dead of Eve was her debut novel, but not my usual reading genre, in the apocalyptic/paranormal/sci-fi romance. I finally read it and it absolutely DOES NOT read like a debut novel. This book was well-thought out, plotted and executed meticulously.The book starts out in the middle of an outbreak of some sort that has caused countless deaths and that transforms humans into a new type of species called aphids. Aphids are humans that were bitten or contracted the virus and turn into bug/insect/human hybrids that have lost all their human qualities like being able to think or feel but still walk upright. They are kind of like zombies, but not. I almost see them like the alien on the movie Alien Vs. Predator.Evie is our heroine and is the last human woman alive, at least that she or her husband Joel know of. Joel has trained Evie in hand-to-hand combat, weaponry and survival. They have lost their children to the virus and have been focused on survival ever since. But they eventually have to leave the safe haven of their home because of the aphids. This sets them on a course that will change their lives forever.As it turns out, there is a phenomenon with Evie and why she is the only woman to have not contracted the virus and has appears to have some “extra” abilities when it comes to fighting off the aphids. Not only does Evie have to watch out for and protect herself from aphids, but also human men. Some of those men are desperate to have a woman since there are none. Some also don’t trust her because she is a woman and women were originally the ones to carry the virus & then bite & infect men. She does take time to heal and meets a few trustworthy people along her road.Her travels are driven by gut instinct and visions of her dead children. While she is reluctant to follow them, they have never steered her wrong. She picks up guardians along the way who believe in her, trust her and want to be there with and for her, who are willing to lay down their lives to protect her.There are sad, happy, devastating, funny and sexy times in this book. It is hard to slip this book into just one genre. It’s post-apocalyptic, paranormal, sci-fi, horror and romance. Some may think it odd to put this in the romance category, but there is lust, romance & love. Thankfully this book didn’t end on a cliffhanger, though it easily could have, but leaves you at a resting moment & wanting more of this story. The sequel, Blood of Eve, will be released 10/29/2015, with the third book slated for late 2016/early 2017.

Home Free (Heaven Hill #8)By: Laramie Briscoe3/5 starsCharity grew up as the stripper’s daughter and thus, was always looked down upon in not only high school, but their entire town. There was no way for her to live that down when everyone wanted to hold it against her and throw it in her face. In order to make something of herself, she had to leave town, go to college and make a successful life. It broke her heart leaving Drew, her high school sweetheart, at home, but it was at his insistence that she left Kentucky to go to college. She became an attorney in North Carolina and has been working ever since.Drew became a member of the Heaven Hill Motorcycle Club and a mechanic so that he could work at his dad’s/the club’s auto shop, Walker’s Wheels. It broke his heart and left him devastated, but he knew that it was best for Charity to leave and go make something of herself that way she could rise above just being the stripper’s daughter. It was hard for him to do it, but he would do anything for Charity that was in her best interest.But when Charity got the call from Meredith Blackfoot to come home because she was needed, Charity came home immediately. She opened her own practice and her best friend Mandy, also Drew’s twin sister, who is a paralegal, came to work for her. Charity is helping Meredith with pro-bono legal work at the women’s shelter, CRISIS. Of course, Drew finds out when he stops by to drop off for Mandy. When Drew & Charity see each other, it’s like no time has passed and they strike up a conversation and set up a time to get together.Charity & Drew have a couple disagreements, but nothing else will get in their way. There is some drama with the CRISIS center that involves several of the club members, Charity & Mandy and some of the clients at CRISIS. But other than that, the club doesn’t play much of a role.While this book was well-written, it just missed the mark. It fell flat. We didn’t learn about much of anything that happened or went on during the 10 years that Charity was gone. I think that it would have worked out better to see some of those years, so that we got a sense of how sad they were instead of just being told about it. Also, there were no discussions between Drew and Charity about what happened, how they changed and grew and how they stayed the same. There was none of that; they just jumped back into the deep end. They had 2 stupid little arguments that were ridiculous and felt like forced conflict. Also, the club didn’t play any real role in this book, just some small protection work and detective work. I was really looking forward to this book, but it fell flat. I am intrigued by Mandy’s book, and hopefully there will be more to it than just 10 years of missed feelings & no real tension to the book.

Rest & Trust (Night Horde SoCal #5)By: Susan Fanetti5/5 starsSherlock is the intelligence officer for the Night Horde SoCal who isn’t like all the other guys in the club. He’s not been the most physical or intimidating guy, definitely not part of the muscle of the. He’s the brains. With his hacking ability and ability to check things out, verify & search backgrounds of people, he is invaluable to the club. He’s always been somewhat quiet, more of a thinker and not just all about partying, though he does his fair share of that. He’s has a steady friends-with-benefits, who is a single mother, but who also keeps Sherlock on the outside.Sadie is a recovering, high-functioning addict with almost a year clean and sober. She’s not a junkie, because she always held herself to the highest standard possible so that no one knew what was actually happening in her life. She went to school, got the grades, graduated, got a good, high paying job and no one knew that she was high on Oxy or Heroin the entire time. Until one day, she had a very public meltdown at work. Now her job is different, she goes to meetings, has a sponsor and is working at getting involved in things, just to keep herself busy.They meet when Sadie needs rescued and Sherlock just happens to be there & bails her out of trouble. Then he feels responsible for her & helps take care of her. But they both feel for each other and are intrigued by the possibilities even with the 13 year age gap. They have similar interests in gaming & computers which Sherlock has never found in a woman or even close friends. Bart is the only one who understands his computer “geek-dom” but Bart has a family to spend his free time with.We also get to some of the Missouri Night Horde in this book, which always makes me happy & giddy. We saw Badger, Showdown, Nolan, & Dom. Also during this book’s timeline, both Isaac & Len are released from prison, but are on parole, so they don’t make appearances at either rally. I don’t know if we’ll see any of the Missouri Night Horde in the next book, but I hope so!I absolutely love Fanetti’s writing style and ability. I’ve never been disappointed, and I’ve read all 19 of her books. She can pull emotions from me and shock me, but also leave me with a feeling of being able to move forward. I was really sad learning that this is the second to the last book in this series. I’m still hoping that there will be more books for the entire Night Horde family in spinoffs for Nolan, Havoc’s adopted son, & maybe Dom in Signal Bend. I like to see how the kids of my several of my all-time favorite characters are growing and maturing & their lives. Even though it is nearing the end, it sure doesn’t feel like it should be, but I have no doubt that Susan Fanetti will blow it out of the water.

Bound by Temptation (Born in the Blood Mafia #4)By: Cora Reilly4/5 starsLiliana Scuderi watched both of her sisters be married off for political reasons to brothers in the New York mafia, so she hopes that she can marry for love. She has been infatuated with Aria’s bodyguard, Romero, since the first day she met him. That hasn’t changed and she really feels like she possibly loves him. But she knows that her father will take some convincing to allow her to marry “just a soldier.” However, she refuses to give up hope.Romero has always put his duty to the famiglia first and has never wavered. He’s ignored Lily’s flirtatious behavior for years and has never wavered. But as Lily has grown older and matured into a woman, he can’t deny her beauty or her spirit. They become closer than ever and have even crossed a few lines. He wants to be with Lily also, but it’ll take Aria and Luca speaking to the girls’ father to allow Romero & Lily to marry.But when they find out that Lily’s father has arranged a marriage with a man more than twice her age, their hearts are broken and most all of their hope is lost. Once a marriage is arranged, if the arrangement is cancelled, the cancelling party loses face and respect for backing out. No amount of pleading convinces her father to back out of the marriage.Aria and Gianna both want to rescue Lily from this arranged marriage, as does Romero, forcibly if necessary, but that will cause a war between the Chicago & New York mafias. And while Aria and Gianna are more than willing to take that chance, Romero doesn’t know if he can break his vow to Luca & the mafia. Lily also doesn’t want to cause war because that will put her sisters & their husbands, Romero & possibly her younger brother in danger. They all have to make the decision of whether or not love is worth risking a war.There were several grammatical errors, and then there were also errors with word usage. For example, a capo in the Italian mafia is a captain, not a boss. The boss is called boss or the Don. Finally, the author did get the Italian word famiglia instead of the Spanish word familia.

Bound by Hatred (Born in the Blood Mafia #3)By: Cora Reilly3/5 starsWe first met Gianna Scuderi and Matteo Vitiello in book one, when their older siblings were engaged & later married. We also found out in that book that they were engaged, though we didn’t learn of Matteo’s reasoning until this book. During book 2, we learned that Gianna had run away while visiting Aria in New York and that both families were pissed and that Matteo would hunt her down. This book does go back and show several of those scenes from Gianna and Matteo’s POVs. This was the first book in the series that had dual POV & I really liked that.Matteo was bound and determined to find Gianna and marry her, even though she had run away, been found with another man, lost her reputation as a virtuous woman and her value as a bride. Matteo thought that he could possibly work Gianna out of his system, but he found that to be false, as he kept only wanting her more. But he also couldn’t trust Gianna not to run again and had to take preventative measures.Luca treated Gianna pretty bad, but he lost face as the boss and in his ability to control his area. He was also upset with Aria because she helped her sister and in doing so, betrayed him. This caused them tension and I also think that’s probably why Aria wasn’t able to stick up for Gianna as much as we thought she probably would.This book could have been so much more. I was looking forward to reading Gianna’s book, but this one just missed the mark for me. Gianna was strong enough willed to run away from the mafia in search of a life of her own and for the chance to find and marry for love. That was a great concept, but personally, I didn’t feel like Matteo & Gianna had built a connection by the end of the book.There were several grammatical errors, and then there were also errors with word usage. For example, a capo in the Italian mafia is a captain, not a boss. The boss is called boss or the Don. Also, in Italian, it’s famiglia because Spanish is familia. There were also some small & some big storyline inconsistencies. Some of the inconsistencies could have just been when the author forgot to write the in between/descriptive paragraphs or sentences.*Spoilers*I think it would have helped had Matteo told Gianna the real reason that he asked his dad to arrange their marriage. Gianna may have shown a little thankfulness & gratitude when she found out that Matteo saved her from a worse fate. Also, clear at 84-87%, Gianna was still debating about leaving Matteo & actually did take some steps to run away from him, even after she admitted to herself that she was in love with him. Seriously at that point, Matteo deserved someone who would fight for him as hard as he fought for her.

Bound by Duty (Born in the Blood Mafia #2)By: Cora Reilly5/5 starsDante Cavallaro is the Boss of the Chicago Outfit mafia, who lost his wife to cancer about 4 years ago. However, he was left without an heir and it is expected of him to remarry & have a son who can take over the mafia when he retires or dies. But Dante truly loved his first wife and hasn’t gotten over her death, but knows that he looks weak in the eyes of his men for not remarrying and is now willing to at least do that much. He has the choice of any woman he wants, but has to take his position into consideration of who would be an acceptable choice for the new head of the family.Valentina is also a widow with no children. She was married to Antonio, her childhood friend, for years. But their marriage was a sham, a cover-up, a beard. Antonio was gay and if that had ever been found out, men in the mafia would have killed him for it. So Valentina agreed to marry him, in order to protect him. She had naively thought that perhaps they could make their relationship into a real one, that she could have kids, a marriage & a life with Antonio. But they never consummated their marriage; and when Antonio died she was still of a marriageable age. Although her virginity will raise questions with her new husband, secrets can’t hurt a dead man.As the Boss, Dante truly had his choice of any woman to marry, because most all parents want their daughter to be married to the Boss, giving them an elevation of status within the mafia. Many people can’t figure why 36 year old Dante chose an older (24 year old!) widow, instead of an 18 year old virgin. Even Valentina isn’t sure why she was chosen, but she will do her duty & marry Dante.Dante is known to be cold in all his business dealings and with the men under him in the mafia. Valentina hopes that he won’t be that way towards her and that she can finally have a true marriage with all the marital benefits. But she’s in for shock and confusion on her second wedding night that ends up being unconsummated, yet again. Valentina begins to think that it is something that is just wrong with her.There were some grammatical errors, and then there were also errors with words. For example, a capo in the Italian mafia is a captain, not a boss. The boss is called boss or the Don. Also, in Italian, it’s famiglia because Spanish is familia.

Bound by Honor (Born in Blood Mafia #1)By: Cora Reilly5/5 starsDaughters born into the mob are married off to other mob men in a way to strengthen political alliances or to move up one’s family position within the organization and sometimes, they marry as part of a peace agreement. The boys are given free rein on pre-marital sex while girls are forced to remain pure & chaste, generally achieved by constant bodyguards, attending private girls’ school, not being allowed to be alone in a man’s company and having very few freedoms. Girls who aren’t virgins on their wedding nights can be cause for major problems. For some of the men, the only worth their daughters have is to be arranged into an advantageous marriage, since sons are the only ones who can join the mob & take over for their fathers. Women also know that their husband will most likely keep mistresses for most of their lives.When a truce was needed between the Chicago mob and the New York mob, Aria Scuderi becomes engaged to Luca “The Vice” Vitiello when she is just 15, in order to secure peace between the two mob families. Shortly after her 18th birthday, she is wed & immediately moves to New York City with her new husband. Though she is fearful, Aria knows that she has to do her duty to keep the Chicago mob safe, thus saving the lives of her siblings. One piece of advice that she was given, in order to survive her marriage with no familial support system, was to make Luca fall in love with her. For if he loved her, he would desire her, he may not take a mistress, he would be more apt to take her advice and would want to protect her out of love & devotion instead of “just because she’s his wife.” In short, a reciprocated love would make the arranged marriage more bearable to her.Though Luca is greatly feared and a killer, there is a tenderness that is bestowed solely for Aria. He waited for 3 years to have her and after seeing the woman she has become, he wants her. But he’s not used to the reserved woman that Aria is. Luca is used to the easy come, easy go floozies and regular women that he sleeps with. He realizes that he needs to ease his young wife into the completely foreign sexual world. He also comes to realize that his feelings run deeper for her than he ever imagined and that he may be falling for his wife.Just because the two Italian mobs from Chicago & New York City have a truce doesn’t mean that they free from trouble. The Russian Bratva is still a huge problem for both families and their troubles are far from over.There were some grammatical errors, and then there were also errors with words. For example, a capo in the Italian mafia is a captain, not a boss. The boss is called boss or the Don. Also, in Italian, it’s famiglia because Spanish is familia.

Even with the few problems it has, Splatoon is an extremely fun online multiplayer game. With "weapons" to cater to a variety of playing styles, no gamer will feel alienated, and it lacks pervasive violence, making it one of the few shooters that can be enjoyed even by young kids. The graphics are beautiful and high-def, the music is fun, and the character design is cheeky and clever. I've played this game every day since purchase, and still enjoy it, partially because Nintendo keeps adding new content and events called "Splatfest" where you choose a side (Dogs V. Cats, Waterslides V. Coasters) and duke it out with the other team.Downsides: no local online multiplayer mode (I'd like to go online with my husband instead of having to take turns), and the two-player "dojo" mode is not fun. This is not a 1v1 game, and that mode feels slapped on just so they could write "local two-player mode" on the box. There also is no option (yet) to create teams for online play (you can play with friends, but it's randomized so they might be on the other team), I suppose because Nintendo wants to hypothetically prevent organized teams from pubstomping random teams and ruining the fun for everyone. Another thing lacking in this game that every other team-based shooter has is microphones, though I know Nintendo is hardcore against mics because we have to protect little Timmy and all... but a solution would be to have mics automatically disabled and only accessible through parental settings. Ultimately, the downsides don't really make me dislike this game. It's so fun, I can overlook them, and I do know, in theory, why Nintendo doesn't do mics or teams... they don't want folks getting too crazy or competitive and ruin the game for their target demographic.

Great, long-lasting color with a pretty silly grape tylenol flavor/smell. Love this stuff. It lasts forever and looks really nice. The flavor is ridiculous, but I like it, to be honest. Great lip stain, and a much better price point than anything from Sephora. It's also a jelly-like consistency rather than watery, so I feel more comfortable having it in my purse.

This printer worked beautifully for about a year, and then the printheads would no longer dock properly in the service station where the waste ink pads etc go. I took it to a shop and found out that there is something wrong with the service station sensors and that I would have to replace the entire thing, totaling around $300. Even if I replace that part, because the printheads haven't been docked properly for about a month, I'd have to replace them as well, since they're dried up and unuseable. Because this printer is barely out of warranty, there is NOTHING Epson will do for me, despite the fact that the reason the printer fouled up in the first place was due to a manufacturing error that didn't come to light until now. I loved this printer...LOVED it, but I just can't afford to spend hundreds of dollars repairing something that I can replace for less money. If you go with an Epson, be sure to purchase the extra warranty or you'll be crying over your expensive brick a year later.
Awesome! I lose my keys in my house constantly. I could have been late for work looking for keys that had ended up in the bottom of the clothes hamper, but not anymore!
