This review is written for those accustomed to older-generation or single-large-inner-sack daypacks (with possibly several outer pockets), and are unaware of features of modern multi-inner-compartments daypacks.This Thule daypack’s inner large sack is divided into two.  One compartment includes 3 small-items-storage compartments, for better organization.  The second compartment is padded so as to hold and protect a laptop and tablet.  Daypack’s shell is made of water-resistant material, and the second compartment’s access zipper is further rain-protected.  The stored laptop and tablet will survive a drizzle, possibly a brief rainfall, and possibly a drop.Thule’s outer shell has two side, open-top elastic pockets, and a middle, adjustable size, open-top pocket.  These are useful for water bottles, and other larger items that can be easily-reached. Additionally the outer has a middle 5” x 7.5” x 1.5” (max) zippered container constructed of a firm-flexible-plastic.  This container is designed for carrying fragiles such as eyelasses, earbuds, and other miniature electronics.  Thule’s ad describes this container as “Crushproof”, meaning the plastic will bounce back after crushing—realistically, the fragiles will be crushed.Appearance--looks great!  Good also for bicycling, it was lightweight, and sufficiently small for easier balance.  25 year warranty and looks durable as well.The tech bag feature I’m still looking for is “shrinking-capable”, to meet changing plane baggage regulations.  I’d issue a 10 star for that.  :)

My prior setup consisted of an older Epson all-in-one printer with single, multi-color cartridge, HP personal B&W laserjet, and Epson precision scanner .  What I hated about my prior all-in-one were:  one color of inkjet's cartridge would run out before other colors--requiring entire cartridge replacement, scanning was cumbersome requiring individual pages’ babysitting feeding, and small and cryptic LED menu display.  I also used the HP B&W laserjet because even while all-in-one was printing mostly in black, one of its multi-color cartridge's coloring would soon quickly run out, and replacement cartridges are expensive (particularly when one factors in purchasing transaction time and re-installation time).  And using 3 devices took up extra storage space.This Epson ET-4500 ink tanks filled easily.  Is this network-shareable printer also easy to set up?  Unfortunately, the scanner portion did not sync with its cloud storage, necessitating a tech support call.  Epson’s support was available at 9:15PM, Central Time!  And the tech support person solved this, though it took 45 minutes.  Apparently, a rare problem.  I’m impressed with Epson’s tech support hours.  Afterwards, scanner worked well--without baby sitting during multipage feeds.  The scanned images were automatically forwarded from the cloud to my email.As for printing quality, for B&W my HP Laserjet’s resolution is slightly sharper.  Epson's coloring is muted on plain paper.  Nevertheless, having plentiful and inexpensive color made a difference in my printing life--things I never printed before in color are now in better explanatory color. I don't do photo quality printing, so will try high quality inkjet paper later.As for speed, personal HP connected via USB is significantly faster on the First page only of each of the Word files I sent.  The Epson has a 5 to 10 second pause before printing first page, but afterwards it is faster than my personal HP printer.  It's unclear to me as to whether the delay is due to the Bluetooth vs. USB, or the inkjet vs. laserjet.ET-4500’s LED display menu is far larger and more intuitive than my prior Epson All-in-One.  One network connection problem occurred, but I simply rebooted the Epson to restore.5 stars because this ET-4500 solves what I previously hated about inkjets listed above and has inexpensive color printing.  Multipage automated scanning worked, inks can be changed individually rather than buying an entire cartridge, LED easier to understand, saves space.Basically, if user is willing to accept muted color with economical inking—excellent choice.  If want only B&W—other printers print crisper.11/13/15-- having used this nearly three months of light usage-- nearly flawless operations.

This is a funny book.  It’s about how to increase market share, using very-brief, case-studies of large corporations, and deriving 8 growth precepts. About 80% of content feels like these case studies are authors’ customers or prospective customers, and authors are overly effusive with praise.I’ve read about 140 pages, skimmed remainder, and learned little.  The 8 precepts are business ideas the reader likely already read before—in summary, Innovate, Build Customer Advocates, Welcome Customers’ Criticisms, Aesthetic Appearances Matter, Transform Employees, Ramp Up Relationships, Take Giant Leaps, and Handle Schisms in Relationships.Guess you already knew about these precepts too?  One can simply read these precepts’ explanations (which constitute 5% of the book), and understand 85% of the book.  The 140 pages I read has ZERO teaching on how Time Limitations affect creating branding experiences, and it is these time limitations that is challenging to accomplish branding effects for not-wealthy companies.Can a reader really benefit from learning in the mini-case studies, which constitute 80% of this book?  First consider authors’ biased interpretation of what the entrepreneur did.  Then, consider, that the entrepreneur’s temperament, thought processes, and circumstances are likely very different from the reader’s.  For example, Armand Hammer of Occidental Oil had an effusively praise biography book.  His ex-public relations agent then wrote “Dr. Hammer and Mr. Hyde, the Dark Side of Power:  the Real Armand Hammer.” Rocket feels like the first, unrealistic biography case studies.Book’s first case study is of Lee Wexner of Victoria Secret, and its precept is-- “Don’t Ask Your Customers What They Want (Because They Don’t Know Till You Show Them)”.  Reader probably have already heard this precept from stories about Steve Jobs and Henry Ford.  80% of this chapter simply praises Lee Wexner’s ingenuity and business savvy.  But will becoming aware these Wexner’s  traits transfer his skills to you?  Unclear.Most branding experts I’ve met tend to redefine terminology to fit other business disciplines under an umbrella of branding, and authors, as B2C branding experts, here do similarly.  For example, Wexler’s ingenuity in “somewhat franchising” international operations is written as financial high returns of his branding prowess.  Huh?  How did the meaning of branding suddenly encroach into financial structuring of franchising, as to mean same?  And aren’t many international operations structured similar to “somewhat franchising”—where is Wexler’s praised branding genius?  Similarly, endless praise and redefined terminology for the several case studies I read.This book is mostly suitable for very large companies only.  The principles are suitable for any company, but book doesn’t tell how unwealthy companies can create the Time and Money to then implement these—which is more valuable information.And the “take aways” and other advice given—these are mostly platitudes you’ve already heard before.  Additionally, the action steps and even the precepts are lightweight.  60% excessive praise, 30% reinforcement of commonly-known business principles, 10% I learned something new.Reader’s time is probably spent better reading something else.  But if you want sugary reinforcement of precepts you already know, the writing style of this book is excellent.

Haven't  played many classical guitars before.  Very well crafted instrument.  Compared to the classical guitars in the $400 to $600 range I tried at Guitar Center, I thought this guitar sounded better.

I like Avery labels, been using these for years.  Easy to peel off even after years of storage.  Sticks on well.  Pen writes well.These labels average 4 cents a label at 8/15/2015 Amazon prices.  Is the 4 cents a label a good value?  If reader is new to Avery printing, it is necessary to visit Avery’s website, as these labels are integrated with Avery’s printing software.  The website offers an online label-designer, mail-merger, and printer software with 484 full-color design templates for this label.  Enhanced features include bar and QC code production, sequential numbering, PC, Mac, or tablet software versions.  Live support too, and 50+ how-to videos on Youtube.However, competitive, same size same quantity labels are 2 cents a label, sometimes less.  How is Avery cost justified?If user likes Avery’s numerous design template, software capabilities, and the easy to peel off feature and user prints occasionally and prefers occasional tech support, then a 5 star.  However, if label-software skillful user regularly prints hundreds to thousands of labels, Avery is then more expensive.5 stars for the occasional label users who wants colorful designs, ease of use, or tech support.

Easy to bend wiring, reinforced tag hole.  Most other tags with wires appear to be sold in quantities of 1,000 averaging 5 cents a tag.  With Avery and Amazon, these at quantity 100 average 7 cents a tag, and this smaller quantity and lesser total cost is better for me.  A good consumer, rather than industrial shipper, product.

If you’re looking for a commercial vacuum cleaner that is powerful, quiet, simple to operate, stores vertically compactly, looks professional, has inexpensive replacement bags, and HEPA capabilities, this fits the bill.  Even my elderly housewife-occupation mom thinks highly of this vacuum cleaner.Office environments are usually less cluttered than residential, and if this vacuum performs in my cluttered, dust-mite-infested-carpet apartment, it will excel in less-cluttered offices.  My current daily carpet vacuuming regimen to reduce dust mites allergens is such a drag.  How does Hoover upright compare to my other vacuums?My Kenmore HEPA upright vacuum is noisy, not that powerful, and didn’t resolve my allergies that well; not in the same class as this Hoover (but then Kenmore had cost slightly less).  My Electrolux HEPA canister vacuum had the highest rated consumer reports ratings, at the time of its purchase, and cost more and overall performs excellently.  I additionally used several HEPA robotics vacuum cleaners, including Roomba, LG, and otherOne weakness with canister vacuum was the dragging-it-around process.  The vacuum head is at one location and it was inconvenient having to drag the canister around, dodging the cluttered obstructions.  Weaknesses with the robotics vacuum included the amount of environment setup time (moving the furniture around), the robotics vacuum still needed monitoring time, and its small dust bin necessitated constant bin cleaning.For open space vacuuming, which constitute 95% of vacuuming, this Hoover is faster and more enjoyable.  Not only is the Hoover light in weight, but also its wheels are higher quality than my Kenmore’s.  Additionally, I believe Hoover’s underside brushes help propel the vacuum and does not resist much when pulled backwards.  The result is very lightweight feel, smooth operations, and speed.  Most importantly, because Hoover is powerful, I don’t need to repeatedly vacuum same spot over and over.In the remaining 5% of vacuuming surface, both the robotics and the canister were better.  The robotics could operate with clearance of about 4 inches, and the canister’s head, about 2 inches.  Hoover’s arm can be lowered so that it works with a height clearance of about 11 inches high.  This means, the canister and robotics would work better under sofas, beds, kitchen cabinets space, etc., where the Hoover cannot reach.  Also, the canister came with 4 vacuum suction heads, for better reach.As for HEPA efficiency, even with the highly rated Electrolux, I still noticed some vacuum dust blow out.  With the robotics, I set up the environment (which takes time), and don’t walk into the room until 30 minutes later.  But robotics required monitoring, so I was still exposed to some dust blow out, whenever I went into the room being vacuumed.  I doubt that the Hoover’s HEPA protection will be as good as these, but my initial impression is that its overall HEPA dust protection is very good.Hoover’s HEPA replacement bags are also far less costly than the robotics replacement dust bin filters and Electrolux bags’.Overall, Hoover is superior for 95% of the environment, but because it lacks different size vacuum heads and has a higher height clearance requirement, Hoover can’t do the other 5%.  But 95% may be good enough for commercial environments, and then bring in a canister every 10th time or so.Even my elderly, slightly disabled mom likes this.  5 star for commercial.  5 star for 95% of residential as well.

What I’m looking for, in addition to securing guitar tightly, is rapid exchange of guitar straps--to move a strap with lock from one guitar to another rapidly, and to rapidly change straps on a single guitar.Each of the two Superlocks in this set consists of a large-button for the strap, washer, a small-button with screw to be drilled into the guitar.To exchange straps, one uses fingernails, or easier a hex wrench, to remove the large button hugging the first strap; then push in 2nd strap and screw back in the large button.  This is nearly the same speed of exchange as changing a strap on a guitar without strap locks.However, it appears one cannot purchase separately the small screw-in-guitar buttons, such that a single strap with a large button can be attached to several guitars' small buttons.  The strap change process here would be very quick-- maybe under 15 seconds.  And it should be cheap-- one large-small button set is $15, each extra small-button, is for perhaps, $4.  Total cost for 2 extra small buttons and one set would be $23.  Instead, it is necessary to purchase 3 separate button sets, each for $15-- $45 instead of $23.If all you’re planning to use one strap for one guitar, this is a 5 star.  If you prefer a single strap onto several guitars, this is a 3 star.

My Belkin products have usually worked well, and my iPad is happy.  My complaint is this cable’s 7/18/2015 Amazon price is $20 and prior models Belkin MiFi cables had mediocre reviewers’ ratings.  Other manufacturers’ MFi certified cables cost 30% to 40% less and have excellent Amazon reviewers’ ratings.Belkin is a much larger manufacturer than many of its competitors, and Belkin’s economy of scale should produce less costly cables.  But, not so currently.  Price is relative to the person though.  4 star for a functional cable without bells and whistle features.  2 star for high price.  Just a cable with a small chip.I would pay more for a dependable cable, as these are frequently weak points.  It works fine, and I like its colors selection.  4 star overall.

Below is a comparison between this Hohner and a Fender dreadnought guitar that cost twice as much.The Fender does sound slightly better, but was frustrating for a beginner.  Fender came with strings gauge and height that hurt my fingertips, so paid extra $50 for luthier to replace and lower strings.  But strings separation remained tight, cramping my B7 chord.  Each time I contacted Fender or its dealers regarding warranty coverage on strings separation distance, I got a run-around.This Hohner looks like a computer-machine-precision-cut instrument--a mechanical rather than craftsman look.  Still looks great!  My fingertips hurt far less with the Hohner.  Strings height was ideal for me straight of the box.  Strings tension and height makes a BIG difference for the beginner players' fingertips and desire to practice.Haven't had to thoroughly test Hohner's electronics yet.  Some preliminary thoughts-- Hohner's microphone and preamp has an equalizer, which makes a big difference on my acoustic-amp-modeling feature of my electric guitar-amp.Considering that the Fender cost more than twice as much and yet still required adjustments, I am very happy with the Hohner, which additionally came with a decent bag.

Maybe I simply don't understand these....Compared to my regular thumb picks, e.g. Dunlop, Bumblebee simply doesn't have the robust sound that the Dunlop can provide.Compared to my regular fingerheld picks, Bumblebee has far too much flex.  Sounds weak and harder to control.I like that the height is adjustable, but this was a minor advantage.  There are some situations where I want both fingerpickin and lead guitar work.  This can work.

This product needs far more explanatory information for the western consumer.  Just what exactly does the box’s benefit labeling “supports cognitive function and brain health” mean?It’s troublesome and difficult to isolate the body effects of a nutraceutical as this.  Here’s my experience.  When I first ate these, I developed excessive saliva, and a slight upset stomach.  Coincidence?  Maybe it was something else new I ate?  Acid reflux?  When used again, the excessive saliva and acid reflux recurred, so my guess is likely due to these capsules.Researching WebMD, I learned two of its three active ingredients are known to cause an upset stomach.  And its product box labeling fine-print labeling suggests eating these “preferably” with meals.I did experience a calming effect—a more serene mind that enables me to think more clearly, as one might expect from a nutraceutical designed for the head chakra.  But, simultaneously, I felt lethargic.  Serene, but less motivation to be active.  Again, it’s difficult to determine whether the pills caused both or not.Overall, eating these is like taking an over-the-counter pill without warning labeling and uncertain of its benefits.

The gigging guitarist usually already has a repair kit, that’s likely customized (e.g., don’t need all the extra Allen wrenches and has a better string winder) and more compact.  Most guitarists already have ready access to the tools in this kit.  Essentially, then, the kit serves as a convenient guitar-only tools set.The tools are sufficient for the job, not high quality, but will get the job done.  Current Amazon price is $30; I think this kit is worth it, not much more.A four star for doing what it’s suppose to do.  Not a 5 star because nothing special.  A good gift item.

I’m going to get rid of my other sleeping-bag pads.  These prior pads were usually bulky, taking up backpack and storage space.  And my prior air-filled pads took time and many deep breaths to inflate.Klymit stuffs into a bag about the size of two to three pairs of compressed fluffy men’s socks, and weighs less.  This bag can tie onto backpack’s outside loops, leaving extra carrying space.  Then in under two minutes of unpacking and puffing, pad was sufficiently inflated.  With practice, I can probably set it up with just the right pressure in about 90 seconds.Sleeps good.  At first, I was concerned that my body would press against the ground, as I move and turn, but this was not issue when Klymit is fully inflated.How will it withstand pebbles and thorns that puncture?  I don’t know yet, but a rubber patch and glue are thoughtfully enclosed as a separate pouch inside Klymit’s bag.Saves a lot of backpack bulk, weight, and easier to store too.  5 star.

This review is written for those new to microphone varieties.  I had learned about microphones while recording singing—and there are many types of microphones, with genre names such as handheld dynamic, studio hanging condensers, electret condensers (found in lapel-worn and other tiny mics).  A mic that records more challenging singing well will excel at speech recordings.From a technology perspective, it is very difficult to capture actual sound.  So, except for enormously expensive mics, mics add coloring to recordings (and aural aesthetics then are affected by the coloring).  Room acoustic conditions are also difficult to control.  My past electret condensers and low end mics sounded bad, and past mic-receiving-recording software were cumbersome.  Sennheiser proved capable and easy on speech recordings.This Sennnheiser's installation and usability is nearly truly plug and play, straight from the packing box to recording on my iPad2.  One of its two included software, Apogee MetaRecorder, wasn’t found at the Appstore, but was readily available at Apogee’s website.  Nearly frustration free installation and setup.This mic with iPad Air 2 and Metarecorder record-then-plays my singing better than it actually is.  How so?  Removed bass undertones and has algorithm that smooth out the tenor sounds.  A rougher vocal sound becomes almost smooth and good enough to add to a music recording tract.Did it capture subtleties in vocal tones?  Yes and no.  Human speech comprehension occurs more in the tenor range.  In telephony technology, this is known as the intelligible part of speech.  Sennheiser captured this intelligible tenor and its subtleties very well, but did not capture the bass undertones.  For example, in its recording of my electric guitar, the guitar’s bass strings (5th and 6th strings) diminished in volume significantly, as compared to 1st through 4th strings.The bass part of the voice is important for building excitement, motivation, undertones, and other things, but it usually isn’t valuable for recreating intelligible speech wording.  For intelligible speech and tenor portions of singing, this Sennheiser delivered crisp, clear, smooth recordings.  To give a further idea, based on inferred quality reflected by higher pricing….  For intelligible-tenor-speech, as good as my high-end $200 street price dynamic mic, not as good as a low-end $500 large diaphragm condenser mic.  Far superior to the terrible electret condenser mics found in $75 digital voice recorders or most dynamic mics under $100 street price.Also comes with a tiny wind screen for windy conditions.The second included software, Apogee Maestro, appears to be a limited version of the Apogee Maestro, as described on Apogee’s website.  Its limited features include volume control and capabilities reducing hiss, rumble, and overload.  No other equalizer-mixer functions.  This is good enough, as equalization is unnecessary for this type of talk recording.At $200, Sennheiser is an expensive tiny-size condenser mic.  But it seems sturdy enough to be easily portable and makes the voice sound sooo good.  Given its advertised objective (crisp, clear, intelligible speech recording)—a 5 star.

I wanted to try aromatherapy to see if it helps with sinus problems and initially thought this smelled like lavender soap.  Yuck.  But, I kept it near the desk and occasionally took a whiff.  Cool!  This is somewhat addictive for a compulsive person.  Why eat an extra cookie when I’m bored?  Whiff of this lavender as a distraction instead.  Lavender smell is reputed to be soothing, and it does slightly calm my hyperactivity.  But I doubt it helps with my sinus problems.  What I really need is a spicy lavender mix to open up my nostrils, spice up my sinuses, and calm me down simultaneously. :)  Please email notify me when such is invented.  :)However, if you’re looking for a soothing aromatherapy smell, take it from a hyperactive Attention Deficit Disorder as me—this works.  Breathe in …. Oooomm. :)  Good luck!
Own lots of percussion but never a cabasa.  Nice sound, quality.  I would purchase thisagain

Let’s compare to my prior hard plastic spatula with metal stem.  Yes, only a metal stem, as its plastic handle became unglued, hardly a problem likely to occur this unibody DII spatula.My favorite pan has 3 inch tall, sides, at about a 55 degrees steep angle.  I can bend DII’s spatula and its handle’s angle to this 55 degrees angle, such that DII spatula moves around the pan perfectly.  And whereas, I thought a hard plastic spatula would pick up the food better, I found DII’s soft silicon smoothly goes under foods and provides minor adhesion to ensure the food stays spatula on while moving the food from pan to dish.  Less worry about dropping a rolling hot dog from a hard plastic spatula.Also, Dii Silicon soft handles feel much better than any of the hard-surface handles of my other cookware.  Though this comparison isn’t really fair, because this Dii is new and my prior spatula is old, still in many ways Dii is easily superior.And my prior wooden spoon that slightly scrapes pan’s non-stick surfaces—it doesn’t take the dishwasher well.  Dii’s spoon is easily washable.For approximately $5 per cookware utensil, I like these because they are bendable, easily pick up foods with some adhesion, and feels softer to hold and more heat resistant too.

According to the book The Sinus Cure, written by a ENT MD, while using Neti pots, "blow backs" can occur, and if one has a sinus infection, the blown back bacteria can reinfect.  If you have a deviated septum, it is almost certain this will blow back while in usage.  Instructions should have warned about this.My pot leaked constantly.Additionally,Instructions need a magnifying glass to read.Instructions are also confusingly intermingled with instructions for at least 10 other products,  Font type for all this is maybe size 5, sometimes 3.Also,read on web on how to make this yourself, for far less money.  This is a simple product that wants a premium price and wants user to replace Neti pot regularly, buy their salt mixture, etc.

This is an easy to read book on business leadership and management principles, and authors claim these three-- Priorities, Who, and Relationships—constitute core principles of a successful company.  Book explains the principles’ essentials, and reader is then asked to complete a 30 questions survey, deriving a Power score which reflects the quality of business organization.Of course, the real world is more complicated than answers to 30 survey questions.  But the authors do make a good point in that these 30 questions are valuable and that their results can be used to derive a single Power score which is easy to understand.  (Though seems I read in the Economist there was also a similar single number finance metric that became a major cause of the financial meltdown due to overuse).Some companies will drink this Koolaid (principles) and run faster than Bugs Bunny.  But then, to compare fairly, might diligently practicing others' leadership management principles also speed success?Priorities have to be set for businesses, Work assigned to the correct working member, Relationship maintained for the working members-- that's basically what this book says.  The term "Power Score" is hyperbole.This book serves as a good starter for anyone new to leadership-management literatures.

Very clever design.  Having the user supply the bucket significantly saved this product’s shipping, packaging, and storage costs.I only occasionally need a wet/dry vacuum, and wouldn’t spend over $60 for one.  This unit is under $35!  Within 10 days of its arrival, a 2 gallon container in my refrigerator leaked, leaving puddles in refrig and on floor.  My prior solution would have been sponge and a bucket.  Using this wet vac was three to five times faster and less annoying as well!  Next, to tackle my parents’ garage—vacuum will be small, but I don’t clean garages but once every 3 years.Excellent as a low price, wet-dry vacuum, with limitations in power, short suction tube, and only a 90 days warranty.  Yet, nearly a perfect solution for occasional users--low price, saves space, valuable occasionally.User’s guide recommends specific buckets, but I couldn’t find any of the recommended buckets at Lowe’s.  The $3 five gallon Lowe’s branded bucket worked just fine.  Saves space because this head vac stores in only a one foot cube box. Good value!

Versatype’s marketing literatures claims it operates in 4 modes; I think it’s actually 5 modes. 1. Typing mode is comparable to a laptop computer.  If you’ve ever used a netbook laptop, it’s similar.  2. The reading mode is holding with one hand and tapping with other hand’s finger, similar to iPad’s normal usage, except that the Versatype-iPad combination is, of course, much heavier.  3. Viewing/stand mode is a V angled view of the screen, with the keyboard acting as base to support the angled screen.  4. Protection mode means Versatype is performing as a strong protection cover (4 feet drop protection!)  These four modes are described in its marketing literatures.My claimed fifth useful mode is a rotated screen viewing mode, as shown in this review’s photo.  For example, a support consultant and I were talking across a bar table at the Apple Store.  I could rotate the screen diagonal to the keyboard resting on the table.  Both of us can then more easily see the screen, while I’m typing.  This rotation is very useful when multiple people are working together.  Works well upto 25 degrees diagonally—beyond that some of keys are blocked off.I’ve used numerous tablet covers.  This Targus-iPad combination does all ergonomics my prior pad covers did, is tough-cover protection, has a keyboard for laptop usage, and rotates for even better shared viewing.Downside—heavier than other covers.I didn’t use Apple tablets much because they’re slower in usage than Windows PCs.  This Targus-iPad2 combination is the first product that changes my mind on Apple tablets.

The book, the Yeast Connection written by a MD, describes how antibiotics killed good bacteria in the gastro-intestinal tract, resulting in damaged gastro-intestinal flora, causing illnesses.  These Therabreath’s probotics for the mouth claims to restore damaged bacterial flora in the mouth, resulting in healthier teeth, gums, ear, nose, and throat; and claims improves bad breath, respiratory problems (colds,flus), sore throat, ear ache, etc.At about $1.45 each tablet, these are expensive probiotics.  Will it do as it claims?  Other than improving bad breath, Therabreath’s brief 8 days per month treatment seems too short for users to determine its effectiveness for the longer time cycles of above illnesses.  And at $1.45 each tablet, each tablet is more expensive than a yogurt cup, which has far more good bacteria, though possibly not same type.Did it work for me?  I didn’t fall ill or develop bad breath while taking this—so no news might be good preventative news here.  Insufficient value for me to buy these regularly, except when after antibiotics treatment.  During antibiotics treatment, I eat yogurt after antibiotic pills and add these during and after antibiotics, for two months.  Therabreath recommends to eat these starting 2 weeks after antibiotics use.  But I’m hoping these bacteria live long enough to prevent possible yeast issues.  And after antibiotics, I would use yogurt and these for perhaps a couple of months afterwards.Therabreath came packaged in a box sealed with messy plain tape strip, and tablets are unmarked.  Perfect product for tampering?  Service is very good—company quickly answered my questions and sent another package.Overall, expensive probiotic probably useful after antibiotics usage.  4 stars.7-19-15  Restarting Therabreath 3 weeks after extensive antibiotics.  The antibiotics didn't seem to affect my mouth, but I ate lots of yogurt during and afterwards.7-24-15  I noticed little benefits.  May work, but I don't know.  Rating to 1 star for high price.

Usually, aligning a single picture onto a wall is already troublesome.  Yet, it’s easy to rearrange multiples of these tiles.  For example, I initially set 3 tiles vertically staggered—staggering 3 looked awful.  Easy to solve—remove tile’s adhesive to the wall, which comes right off without any damage to the wall, and rearrange!  This 3 piece tile set comes with only 4 adhesive strips—I recommend purchasing far more for best trial and error artistic placements.Less than 40 tile designs are available for purchase.  Has 2 specialty designs—a height riser for tile’s 3D effects and a blank version for attaching custom photos and artwork.The instructions advises using alcohol to prep-clean the wall.  When I did such, the alcohol removed part of my badly-painted apartment’s paint.  Also, there were no warnings that the tiles contained medium strengths magnets, which may possibly damage magnetic media.  Inadequate instructions.Overall—these tiles’ advantage is that they are easy to rearrange without renailing and creating additional wall holes.  Disadvantages are if one already knows precisely where to put wall artworks, these tiles are pricey solutions, as inexpensive nailing and having a wider variety of designs are more valuable.
I'll never trust BestBuy or Sharp again.  My prior microwave (Panasonic?) lasted close to 10 years.  This one-- 4 months past the warranty period of 1 year.

When I think of NOLO, I think of dry laymen law books.  Didn’t expect this to be a practical book for selling, but indeed it is.  Titled “Essentials” guide to selling a house, these essentials include preparing, pricing, advertising, maintaining, transacting, and people selecting (agents for example) aspects of house selling.  And such topics' essential components are clearly explained in short wording.  5 star because I love short, clear, practical books.

This is an intermediate level video editing software (possibly top tier level in consumer grade video editing).  This is a review of VideoStudio's training for novices, such as I.Being a long-established software, VideoStudio has sufficient numbers of online training tutorial videos, and includes a complimentary 45 days usage of third-party, professionally-produced video lessons.  After the 45 days, this third party lessons are approximately $6 a month.  Corel online additionally provides free training on specific VideoStudio features.  Because this is an intermediate level product, it has a training curve in order to become productive, but given the training opportunities above and that the software is fairly intuitive, if one is focused, I’m sure he or she will quickly find this software useful.Installation was a little faulty on my Windows 8.1 computer, but 80% of all software I’ve added to Windows 8.1 were a little faulty.I’m not capable enough with this software to give it a 5 star; don’t see anything wrong with it yet, so 4 star.

Using its versatile cable, this power pack can charge using microUSB (in many to most portables) and Lightning (in Apple portables).  And it can charge two devices simultaneously, provided one is micro-USB and other is Lightning.  Has a battery charge level meter.  2 1/2" x 4 1/2 " X 1/2" and built solid, with many metallic parts. Its charge cable is conveniently integrated into the unit.Is it worth $99 (5/1/2015)?  Price is relative, so if one wants to carry only 1 battery, an Apple, and a micro-USB device, this versatile, higher power capacity battery does the job.  But, smaller batteries are priced as low as $10, and prices are likely to drop.  If I was carrying 3 devices or even 2 micro-USB products or 2 Apple Lightning products, wouldn't it be better to have two or three smaller size chargers for a price total of under $35?  5 star for the right person with both Apple and microUSB.  Pricey for my taste.

I've used all kinds of dodgeballs, and this does feel better.However, the standard red and blue, same size play balls using possibly another material is, I suspect, far superior for storage.  I stored about 30 balls in an outdoor shed.  Unable to determine whether the sun got to the Mikasas and not as much to the others, but 80% of my Mikasas deteriorated over a period of about 18 months.  Large and small holes developed, entire cracks, over expansion increased size of ball, dirtied by some kind of organic rot too.  Nearly none of the standard red, blue balls deteriorated much.As mentioned, I am unable to determine accurately whether the sun managed to get to the Mikasa and not the others.  And both exterior material feel and look same.  But all my Mikasas were damaged in long term storage and none of the others.As for playing, the Mikasa look cooler.  But in performance (throwing and being hit), there only a slight difference.  I estimate 30% of the price of this ball is just to have "Official" stamp.All the dodgeballs I've used damage rapidly-- world Needs superior dodgeballs :)  So for short term use, Mikasa is simply slightly more expensive and looks cooler.  For long term use requiring storage, these Mikasas failed miserably.

This book’s final (10th) chapter has Brooks’s historical analysis of American character-values evolution, from about 1930 to 2014.  This history is useful to modern living and is the best I’ve read of this type, so this book deserves a 5 star.  I recommend skipping all prior chapters.Chapter 1 is Brooks’s opinions serving as an introduction.  Three fifths of chapters 2 through 6 are biographies focusing on character changes influenced by social conditions, moral language evolution, and children upbringing.  Brooks’s biographical writings are based on others’ writings, and I’m always suspicious of biographers who have never met the subject person, and in this case, there’s a further filtering of another author.The other two fifths of chapters 2 through 6 are David Brook’s commentaries using these biographies to elucidate some moral judgment he has on modern lifestyles.  Many are insightful, but I found it difficult to figure out what social and moral framework Brooks was coming from.  That is, Brooks would comment about some subject matter, but I found it difficult to figure out how he judged it that way--which principles or philosophical approach was he taking?Having been puzzled enough from chapters 1 to 6, I skipped chapters 7 to 9, and read 10, the final chapter.  Here, Brooks summarizes how Americans evolved starting in 1930s from a “realism tradition” that views a person as deeply flawed and inherently sinful--“crooked wood”—such that the person should strive to constantly improve his or her flaws.  To then evolve to currently a “romantic tradition” (Me-centric society, where a person regards his inner self as divine), meritocratic materialistic success (at disregard of inner well-being), and a third trait (difficult to find again this word in text, because I felt chapter 10’s subtitles needed re-editing)This book is written with the incorrect assumptions that readers are speed readers willing to uncritically and rapidly read first 9 chapters to arrive at Brooks’ valuable conclusions in chapter 10.  If you don’t have much time, read chapter 10, and then read remaining chapters as desired.

If private viewing is an important issue, then this is a capable screen protector with several limitations.  I have an Asus 15.6” touchscreen laptop-tablet, which can function either as an enormous tablet or a laptop, by flipping its screen 360 degrees.Installing Belkin was easy.  When the screen is in landscape position, sideways viewing is completely darkened, and vertical viewing is partially darkened.  For examples, with a large spreadsheet, document, PowerPoint, or movie in landscape positioned viewing, viewing from sides is significantly reduced .Here are some of the screen protector’s limitations:1. If I turn my laptop-tablet to profile view, the profile view’s horizontal sides are only partially darkened.2. Belkin's plastic adheres to the Asus glass creating many bubbles (similar to how water looks when squeezed between glass panes).  These bubbles are noticeable on white screen coloring, and less on other colors .3. Belkin's thickness causes a slit when Asus’s two halves close, allowing for small particles to fall into Asus's keyboard.Belkin has excellent clarity and comes with extra corner suction adhesives for easy re-installation.  I wasn’t able to test how many times these adhesives can be reused.For someone who regularly needs this privacy, Belkin is a 5 star.  If the Belkin happens to allow a laptop's halves to close tightly, this would be a 5 star.  If halves can’t close tightly, 4 stars.  For a laptop-tablet, this is a 3 star due to no privacy in profile view.
Tastes awful.  Not cheesy tasting at all. If I could sell mine remaining packages via Amazon, I would.

Pretty good sounding durm, for someone who knows how to play these well.I wasn't at all impressed after 10 minutes of trying this, so decided to sell this.  A buyer who knows how to play took it, and it sounded better than I ever experienced.  He understood how to make the wood sound better.Looks great!  Low maintenance, as contrasted with the leather of normal djembes.

Durable, easy to clean (not that I've needed to).I am 50ish adult (well experienced in reclining furnitures).  This is a terrific backrest wedge!  I just set it on the ground and recline on it.  Better than most reclining sofa-chairs!  A reclining sofa-chair may be comfortable, but most are not good for your posture and spinal alignment.  This is durable and better for spinal alignment.  Also, durable.  And costs a lot less than furniture and takes up less space.  I'm 6 feet and this works well.Downside:  Has a handle to facilitate carrying this.  I own two of these, and after 6 months usage, both handles are slowly falling apart.  Recommendation--don't carry this using the handles.
Dries quicker than other compression socks.  Very long.  I have long legs and felt this was long.

Strictly an amateur with limited knowledge of cookware.I wanted to make infused berry drinks, with more concentrated fruit flavor.  I use this Chinois to squeeze out berry juice, and then put the pulp into Primula's infuser element.  Tastes great.  Primula by itself would just turn into pulp.This chinois is huge (to me)!  Take a look at its dimensions before ordering.

I have a $400 street price Fender dreadnought using very light weight gauge strings, all of which sound disappointing.The easiest way to install is when replacing strings.  But, if strings are attached, I recommend first reviewing the installation video found at Planet Wave's website.  Installation of O-Port when strings are attached was easy.  Three of my bridge pins were on so tight that a puller couldn't pull these off.  Still, the O-Port fit through while with 3 strings attached.Sound produced is a lot brighter.  Finger picking w O-Port was definitely a brighter feel sound.  Chords using finger nails strumming--perhaps a more rounded sound, but lack character.  Chords using pick--sounds very good.  O-Port misses a slight amount of natural character in the sound (complexity in the sound).  I only tested very light weight gauge strings.I'm a Vine reviewer and receive music products for review for free, but having heard this, I would purchase.

This review is solely for ATT Uverse users, which (according to ATT) requires use of its freely supplied ATT router-modem.  Other ISPs, as Comcast, allows differing router and modems, so I would imagine Nighthawk perform better.  My question are: as Nighthawk has to interface with the Uverse modem, what kinds of configuration, incompatibility, and support issues might result, as ATT doesn't support Nighthawk?  How much faster is Nighthawk over ATT's modem-router?  What are the benefits and downsides of using Nighthawk over ATT's-supplied modem-router, in a large apartment?  This review is unconcerned with distance issues, a major reason most people acquire Nighthawk.  My review concerns are speed, dependability, and health.Nighthawk router is easy to install and fast on my AT&T Uverse 18mbps with Pace router-modem.  AT&T supplied and requires use of its Pace router-modem.  I attached Nighthawk to Pace's Ethernet port, to utilize Pace's modem.  Expected an installation nightmare since AT&T doesn't support Nighthawk, and Netgear also didn't provide good answers.  But following Nighthawk's easy instructions, amazingly, the Nighthawk worked straight out of the box!  I love computing equipment without headaches!Testing using speedtest.net, Nighthawk slowed to 9 mbps download, half of connected Pace modem's 18mbps.  But the Overall Speed of Nighthawk is significantly faster than Pace or using Clear (my prior ISP service).  I don't exactly know the technical details, but Youtube videos (including HD ones) and other web accesses are running much faster on Nighthawk than on Pace.  My guess is that the bottleneck was solved by the faster Nighthawk wifi connection.Also, I love Nighthawk's administrator's control panels.  Easy to understand--for once, I can do some complicated router settings myself.Nighthawk has some downsides:1. The attached Pace router-modem still emits a wifi signal and Nighthawk issues a 2.5ghz and a 5 ghz signal;  my body is now bathed by three wifi signals instead of one.2. Minor technical issues that appear to be resolvable with Netgear's tech support (which I haven't even needed to use)2a. My computer more frequently dropped the Internet signal, for reasons I don't understand.2b. Microsoft Office One Drive doesn't understand some portions of the web certificate in this Pace-Nighthawk attachment.3. A physical connection might work better in my single user environment.  90% of my computing usage is on a single desktop computer, and the remaining 10%--tablets and smartphones-- can go through the slower Pace.  Netgear's Ethernet Powerline 500 adapter, which connects from wall plugs, costs an average of $25.  My calculations suggest upto 3 Powerline users can be a more cost effective solution than a Nighthawk.  Beyond 3, it would be more expensive using Powerline 500s and there will be far more wireless devices in connection such that Nighthawk becomes more cost effective.In summary, Nighthawk is significantly faster than ATT Uverse's supplied Pace router-modem, Nighthawk installation is easy, and its administration module is easy to operate.  Negatives include Nighthawk's two unwanted wifi signals and a possibly superior solution with  Powerline 500 coupled-Pace for under 3 users.  4 stars for 3 or less active users on Uverse.  5 stars for more than 3 users on Uverse.  5 stars on ISPs that allow users to select and would need to buy modems and routers (whereas with Uverse, a free Pace is included).12-29-14  I've decided Nighthawk's extra wifi signals and Pace's singular wifi signal were just excessive for an apartment, and instead Ethernet cabled my Pace for my primary computer and disabled Nighthawk.  There may be some complicated way of turning off Pace's wifi signal to use the Netgear, but I would want the entire wireless transmission of any kind from Pace to be turned off. 4 stars for potential health reasons for anyone who has to sit or sleep nearby both routers.
The color is not yellow, but brown with lot of orange coloring.  Photo color is incorrect.Very nice strap though.

This is a good device; worked on my phone(s).  However, there’s little that’s exceptional about it, and it’s pricier than other 3000 mah devices.  Also, the specs here says 5v, 1 amp; whereas, many others say 5v, 1.5amps.  Has a preventing overloads feature—which is ways of maintaining 5v--but I think every competent external battery should have this.  4 stars.No battery power level indicator.  Does not come with an adapter for AC-plug to USB; when my computers hibernate, they do not USB charge.  It will be easy to forget that battery has not been recharged.  -1 star.

Four different size earpieces, to provide optimal fit.  Clever integration of heart beat monitoring, coaching recordings, music, and telephone.Basic installation using instructions booklet is simple.  If this works for your phone, congratulations.  If complications, online documentation is missing or confusing.  Notably, which and how many Jabra apps should be installed and what happens if pairing fails.Jabra Pulse's associated Dolby-sound app is available only for Android/IOS.  Unfortunately, my primary phone is Windows 8.1 Nokia.  The Nokia Bluetooth pairing went smoothly, but without the Dolby app, the sound is only crisp and lacking in bass and fullness.  Kindle Fire also lacks the Pulse-Dolby app.My secondary phone, Kyocera Hydro Vibe, a modern Android, loaded the Dolby app, but wouldn't pair using Bluetooth or NFC.  My older Android Samsung SPH-L300 phone also wouldn't pair.  Both of these phones are using small-carriers' access means, so it's too early to possibly fault Jabra.I couldn't find documentation online to help me diagnose these problems or even instructions advising which of the several additional Jabra apps to download.  The documentation's referred to instructional URL http://www.jabra.com/sportpulsewireless was blank.  And a link to "Important:  New headset firmware available.  Click here." was also blank.  The FAQ section provided many of the instructions needed, but FAQ is not the first place one would look for these.If I'm paying $200 for earbuds, I would expect its superior sound quality would be usable by my tablets as well.  My new Samsung Android tablet also didn't Bluetooth pair, and apparently the Jabra's Android app is only for smartphone.  -1 star.Also, no evidence of anti-noise cancellation.  -1 star.During the Thanksgiving holidays, Jabra's technical support understandably didn't answer my telephone calls.  Presently, a 3 star, because, to be fair to Jabra, the quality of the earbuds look great and suggests the problem is primarily in installation.  When their tech support returns, this evaluation continues.

This product has many capabilities.  Technically, WD My Passport (aka WDP) can be described as a multiuser file server, multi-media server, and wifi server, all in one handheld size unit.  Just 10 years ago, companies would hire a technician full time to provide these server capabilities.  Because WDP is a server, its primary usefulness is serve multiple Distant devices with services such as multi-user video streaming and other digital media transfer methods.In cases of individual-use, I view WDP as impractical for most individuals with an Internet connected PC.  Because:  1. Individual-use online cloud storage is free or inexpensive and getting faster constantly and also because 2. faster transfer is achieved from USB cable than from wifi.  Technically capable individuals can find use for WDP, but there are easier, inexpensive solutions available for most of us.  For examples, some have used this device together with a tablet for viewing movies.  Technically, it'll work, but practically, a small laptop (nowadays under $200) costs less total and be far more capable.  And some have used it for backup, and again, technically, it'll kind of work.  But WDP backs up only certain type of files and is likely far less capable than cloud based backup services, which would also cost a lot less.  (I guess if one has a lot of pirated movies and didn't want to be scrutinized by a cloud based storage, this will be practical.)If without Internet access, the WDP can create a wifi and centralized storage for mobile devices.  Still and video photographers with many mobile-originated files come to mind as finding WDP's SD card input and wifi accessibility useful.As a group-sharing device, I see the device as, instead, Practical. It can:  1. Serve as a video server streaming for upto 4 concurrent videos--four family members can watch 4 different videos.  2. Family photo albums can be posted at a single wifi accessible storage.  3. If a speaker wanted upto 8 people to look at something on their mobile devices, all 8 can access WDP, without Internet, e.g. on a field trip.  By group-sharing, I also mean multiple DISTANT devices.  If an individual lives in an apartment, impractical.  If single individual lives in 2 story house, some advantages over carrying a wired portable hard disk.WDP also can act as an Internet hotspot and a backup media server.  For example, using online automated backup, e.g. Carbonite, might be easier for a single individual, but a family of four might find using WDP's backup services to be more cost effective.Somethings WDP does not do well.  I did not find a Kindle app.  Lacks an iTunes server, which means audio files will be more difficult to share. My Windows 8's File History backup software did not recognize WDP as a backup storage device.Pluses:1. Price is right.  Based on photography magazine professional reviewers, this unit costs significantly less than comparable products.  (11/2014)2. Has SD card, faster Wifi, fast USB 3.0 inputs and retrieval methods.3. Has security measures for group use.4. Includes data backup software to backup other computers media files.5. An inexpensive multi-media server.As a single user, I find other solutions easier and more intuitive than WDP.  For multi-user applications, WDP is packed with value.  A four stars.

I once rented a decorated, furnished home from an ex-friend, and later learned she had expected its artistic duck-art bath mat would be decorative and never be used :).Grund's modern zig zag design mat looks great in my current plebian light blue, large tiled bathroom.  Not as cushy as my ex-friend's tightly woven duck mat; not as cushy as thick carpeting; nearly as cushy as a low piled carpeting with foam underneath--far more cushy than most bath mats.  The zig zag design can really draw attention away from plain tiles' and floor's blandness.Grund claims its mat's colors and anti-skid characteristics won't fade after hundreds of washes.  Most rugs in new condition work very well when new. Are Grund's long-term claim's believable?  Grund's base's surface is built tougher and of a different weave than bathroom mats I've seen, enabling for better long-term anti-skid and cushioning. Reviewers of other Grund mats have noted its colors last for years.  Being the world's largest manufacturer of bath mats, Grund's claims are likely to be more scrutinized and believable.And, my ex-friend's ducky mat was so thick that moisture would evaporate slowly.  Grund claims its polyacrylic fabric dries faster, reducing potential mold problems.So, if price isn't a concern, and you like this mat's design, it's a 5 star, because of its claims in durability of anti-skid, color stays, and soft-cushy comfort.  It's pricey though; if I was to personally buy this, I would rate it a 4 star due to high price.To my ex-friend and ex-landlord--this would have kept our friendship and your rent payments longer than your artistic ducky mat :).12-2014  Don't run a Roomba vacume over this.  Sucks up fibers quickly and messes up HEPA filtering.  Any kind of powerful vacume will suck up lots of fibers, so don't vacume.

According to several orthopedic surgeons (including professors) and a chiropractor I've spoken with:  joint pains are caused by numerous factors, including osteoarthritis.  Glucosamine-chondroitin treats only a percentage of the osteoarthritis sufferers.  How does one determine whether it does?  Try some, according to a medical professor.These physicians also say that Move Free's third ingredient, hyaluronic acid, must be injected into to the joint.  Noticeably, Move Joint's website claims that an unreferenced clinical study shows hyaluronic acid can be ingested.  Move Free's final "active" ingredient, "Uniflex" is just a bioflavonoid.  It's unclear whether Move Free is more effective than any other glucosamine-chondroitin combination.Does Move Free provide drug interaction information?  When I inquired regarding antiacid and a second common drug, Move Free's customer service replied with "ask your doctor".I dislike advertising misrepresentation, so will take off stars based on that:1. Broadening treatment claims by wording product is effective for many joint pains, instead of accurately saying glucosamine-chondroitin is useful for osteoarthritis--  -1 star.2. Weak supporting evidence for hyaluronic acid and Uniflex -1 star.3. Did not answer questions on drug interferences.  -1 star.Move Free is a try-it-and-see nutraceutical.  My knee felt better even after the first two pills (probably placebo effect), but I had been practicing better posture and walk for sometime, and, it's unclear whether Move Free is superior to any other glucosamine-chondroitin.Overall, 3 stars, mostly because of vague advertising information.1/11/14  So, here I was thinking that the glucosamine and chondroitin might help my likely arthritis.  Visited a orthopedic surgeon and took several Xrays.  Nope, didn't have arthritis.  My knee felt good taking this product, but it's not because it treats arthritis.  Minus another star.

One of the best back alignment devices I've ever tried, and I've tried lots.I had occasional backpain, and had to relearn how to adjust my posture.  This device really helps at the beginning of the relearning process.  Pushes against the lower back, so that the entire chest and spine align properly.I had purchased 3--because it looked like Koala might not be selling through retail, I had a chance to purchase at bargain price, and Koala was critical for me.  However, now, my posture is very good, and I intend to keep the one I used and sell the remaining two.
Very impressive tone.  I have several high end guitars in the street price of $900 to $1,500, and this Dean nearly matches these in playability and tone.

The quality was excellent.  However, the Youtube video I saw on this suggested it could produce more variations in sounds, like a conga.  I hadn't played a timba before.Anyhow, I have too many drums, wanted a portable conga, so will sell this.

I'd like to review Primula first as a normal infuser and second as a flavored-water maker.  Primula is potentially a great 5 star product, but it could use superior and multiple infusion cores (the cylindrical unit holding the fruits).  Still, Primula produced great tasting flavored water and is effective in reducing my sugar or diet soda intakes.First, as a normal infuser....  For a party or for very large families, it is one of the best designed consumer products I've experienced.  Features include:. A party-size liquid dispenser holding 2 gallons.  Most large dispensers tend to be wide; this is narrow and long.  Food and drinks at parties tend to be served in a linear line, and its narrowness takes up less space.. Dispenser and all accessories can be stored compactly using 5" width, 13" depth, and 16" height.. Fits and dispenses well inside the refrigerator as well as outside.. The base stand lifts the tap so that tall glasses will fit underneath easily.. Convenient chilling using coolant cores.. Convenient internal stirrerOverall, a well designed, large capacity infuser, yet compact in space requirement.Secondly, from the perspective of making tasty flavored water, instead of the infused water above:I'm a bit addicted to sodas and sugary flavored waters, but dislike sparkling waters with just a tint of flavoring.  I wish to create a healthier, custom drink without the excessive refined sugars of sodas and sugar waters, less sugary and less costly than juices, and with natural ingredients.Primula differs from the other infusers I've seen in that its infusion core can use a "muddler"--a small fruit-masher.  The infusion core has a porous screen to keep the "muddled" pulp and seeds within the screen.  1.5 gallons can top its porous screen --- making 1.5 gallons the minimal efficient volume for flavor infusion.I muddle-mashed soft fruits inside the infusion core.  Juices flowed out and subsequent water infusion drains pulp juices.  By using lots of fruit, a healthy, strong-flavored juicy drink (tasting like Sobe) without using any added sugar, can result.  For example, the infusion core can mash about 2/3 of a pineapple, and 1.5 gallons will then fully cover the infuser's porous screen.  Tastes OK--a bit diluted, not that great.  Using a second infusion core and an entire pineapple would have likely resulted in 1.5 gallons with more flavor.  3 cups of raspberry did an OK diluted job on 1.5 gallons; but if a second infusion core was used with 5 to 6 cups of raspberries--results would have tasted better.In addition to not coming with enough infusion cores, the infusion core doesn't appear durable for long-term strong grinding using a muddler.  And, once the fruit is pulverized, water has trouble infusing through.If you plan to make less than 1.5 gallons regularly, Primula has a 2.7 quart version.  If you're planning to make flavored water in bulk and store, please check how well fresh fruits' antioxidants might store.Overall, if you're wanting a standard infused drink, this large Primula is excellently designed--5 star.  If you want a stronger flavored drink, order several infusion cores (not yet available).  4 stars overall, because I happen to like stronger flavored drinks.11/24/14  Update.  I may not have cleaned the infusion element well, because mold is growing on its membrane.  This mold is difficult to remove.  I'll contact manufacturer to find out what to do.11/29/14  Manufacturer told me soak in warm water and scrub the membrane.  I tried this the first time, but it didn't remove all the mold.  Will contact manufacturer again.12/1/14  Always use a bottle brush to clean the infusion core.  Doesn't seem to damage it, and prevents mold.  Not well explained in the instructions.11/29/14  The membrane apparently can take hard scrubbing from a bottle brush.  Removed the mold I could see.  I feel though that Primula's instructions should have Highlighted how to remove the mold.

Power Tools can easily last 10 years.  Traditionally, power tools are sold at hardware stores, who can rapidly diagnose problems, sometimes fix,  usually rapidly exchange, and offer some tips.  Who helps Amazon buyers in diagnosis, returns, and service problems?  Does one have to pay shipping costs of $25 to $50 to return a tool under warranty or in need of post-warranty repairs?These DeWalt tools are truly a pleasure to use.  Well balanced, has features such as automatic LED lighting, feels sturdy, made of a plastic that claims can help reduce electrical shock (if one happens to hit a live wire, power), feels precision-made.  As an analogy, using common flashlights, DeWalt's powerful flashlight, at 20 volt, was even useful for me as a small searchlight.  DeWalt also manufacturers drill bits and accessories, so it's easy to buy add-ons.  For amateur tool users, as I, these features and easy-to-purchase accessories really help my user experience.  Using DeWalt magnetic drill tips (sold separately) and the well balanced drill, my amateurish drilling of wood screws nailed these straight on!Is the kit a true savings?  Adding up Amazon prices for the kit's individual components--$510 to $525--so, the kit at $400 (11/2014) is approximately a 25% savings.  Good deal, but not a steal.  During holiday buying season, I noticed the price dropped dramatically.My DeWalt arrived DOA.  Was the battery, charger, or drill bad?  DeWalt does not directly provide weekend telephone tech support, and its website's black coloring is difficult to read and content disorganized.  On Monday, instead of helping me diagnose, DeWalt's telephone support sent me to visit their Houston factory service center.  I had to drive 60 minutes to learn what malfunctioned, but DeWalt's local staff quickly diagnosed and immediately replaced the charger.  The local staff explained they can also repair and even rebuild certain tools.  I guess if an Amazon customer went in at not-busy times, they can also offer tips on how to use.DeWalt online and telephone service communications methods are not quite ready for online customers.  DeWalt's confusing website also listed a nearby service center that no longer serviced DeWalts.Had the battery charger or weekend telephone support worked, DeWalt would have received a 5 star because these tools are professional quality tools at a good price.  But, the battery charger was defective, weekend service was lacking, website was confusing, and I had to drive 60 minutes to resolve the defective battery charger.  So, a 3 star.  But it's nice to know there's a local service location (DeWalt claims to have more than local service centers than any other manufacturer), which ups its star rating for Amazon customers as me. +1 star.

Peltor Tactical 100 fits a bit snug around my head, but brand new, it is well centered around ears, has comfortable surround-ears cushioning, and the headband also has cushioning.  My regular non-electronic Peltor Optime 105 is 30db reduction, instead of the 22db with Tactical, and Optime has pillow-soft surround-ears cushioning, making Optime far more comfortable.  Thinner surround-ears cushioning as in Tactical's, tend to wear out fast, but by then, wearer might become accustomed to the snug fit, and Tactical should still work well.Tactical folds up very nicely--truly compact, about size of a very large grapefruit.  And Tactical cuts shocking gun blasts while enabling for clear speech hearing.  The speech hearing volume is adjustable in loudness, and can even slightly amplify.  Lots of hiss at higher volumes, but might this also be a use of pink noise sounds?It's not troublesome to take off the Optime to hear well, so Optime would be a good lower cost solution.  What is difficult to reinsert are foam earplugs, because they should be rolled and then inserted.  Also, Tactical is usually better safety, as one can easily hear others' speech.  $22 solution-- Optime.  $74 solutio--Tactical, for greater convenience and safety.

I see this Noco kit as mostly a wilderness outdoorsman, third world traveler, or emergencies product.  If one needs to carry more than 3 to 5 typical 10,000 mAH USB charge battery packs or needs to charge a 12V or 6V large battery, and can transport multiple 12.5 " x 6.5" solar panels, then this Noco kit is a good solution.  Useful for camping for several days, going to countries without electricity, and supplying post-hurricane or earthquake electricity.This 9 Watt power kit consisting of a Noco solar panel, a regulator-connector, and a battery-flashlight costs $157 (Amazon 10/2014), which is over 3 times the cost of current battery packs (10,000 mAH) plus one good $50 outdoorsman flashlight, and is also more bulky.  As most prospective users of this product probably already have a good flashlight, make that 5 times the cost of current battery packs.  Is it cost justified?First, the solar panel, which is the kit's essential product differentiator.  Panel is 12" inches by 6", folded up,  but more importantly, is less than 15 degrees bendable lengthwise and temperature resistant.  This bend is sufficient for inside a backpack, provided it is not stuffed.  Panel has many handles to secure onto the side of a backpack.I talked with Noco's excellent tech support, who said he personally tested the product 3 days in the snow and that the solar panel is also designed for the desert.  So, Noco can tolerate most temperatures.I didn't find out how rain proof the panel is, maybe someone else can find out?  Panel's cover is water repellant.Solar panels can be stacked together, meaning, if one is willing to buy and carry several, these can even charge up a car battery!Second component, a five inch long rechargeable-battery & flashlight combo capable of 5V USB input or output or 250 lumens.  250 lumens is bright enough for a night time-defense-weapon, and this flashlight is durable and claims to be waterproof.  However, its lithium ion battery lifespan is best only at moderate temperatures.Lastly, a regulator connector for USB connections.  Noco can also use optional other voltage connectors, enabling 12V and 6V outputs.Here, for example, is an ideal user.  Someone in the wilderness for many days, with a GPS and smartphone, a 6 or 12V electric motor (perhaps for car or boat battery), and USB and 12v connectors.  A serious mountain  climber.  On an island without electricity.  A solar power enthusiast who has a place to set the solar panel protected from the rain and from theft.Easy to use.  Tech support was very fast and professional.  The battery power switch needs to be turned off when charging (power LED off), and this is not stated in the manual.Other than the ideal type user and emergencies such as hurricanes, I believe there are superior solutions for the money for most people.  4 stars for the right users.  2 stars for most potential users.  5 stars for excellent tech support that was fast, and Noco appears to be strong enough of a company to stand behind its products well.  Overall, a 4 star.

I received a pre-release copy of this book for review.  At the time, there were 8 reviews, and this book averaged 3.5 stars, which is awful for a pre-release book.  Yet, the author has not sent a small army of boosters, as many other authors do, to boost this book's star ranking.  This says a lot about author's excellent integrity.This is a book on strategic marketing, usually of new products.  Its lessons will save a lot of heartache, money, and time.  I'm an inventive type who learned many of these lessons through the school of hard-knocks, wish had read this book earlier in my career, and learned still more valuable tips here.The book essentially says that the creative spirit who develops in-depth insights as to customers' needs and buying behaviors and designs products or service ideas, then must have these ideas subjected to rigorous economics analysis, asking questions on how to implement such ideas.  The impractical ideas need to be quickly discarded, so as to focus on the great ideas.As this sounds obvious, so why would a company hire an outside consultant for this?  Why?  Because it requires the creative to first view the problem differently and come up with several solutions, with these different views.  Then, the economics analysis, which are more methodical and described in this book, are applied on these ideas to determine which are practical and great.And, then there are the unicorns--the illusionary lovely horse that is wonderful to ponder on, and in real life, frequently carefully fed (use up resources).  This book gives guidelines on how to get rid of these unicorns, projects that probably are illusionary ROIs.At the time I'm reading this (10/2014), most of the reviewers state that the book is difficult to read.  That its language is somewhat convoluted.  I'd say instead the book is more intricately written, with the author describing many insights for each step of the above design-economic-analysis steps.  One can read this book and say its repetitive, or one can read this book and say it's filled with nuances on how to effectively apply the rules, which is my view.  Could be edited to be clearer though.I seem to recall 90% of new products fail.  The author here gives a few hard-won strategic marketing views of why this is so, so that success rates will be significantly higher.

I think these are a good product, better than other probiotics I've used except for one brand. The pearl delivery system is a smart one, and the company seems to care about quality. It concerns me a little that they are not refrigerated, because most quality probiotics seem to be. I can't say that I felt any difference after two weeks of taking them, but I was just getting off antibiotics and that may have affected things. The pearls are easy to swallow and not too large. This is a perfect scale. It's small enough to tuck away easily in the office, but large enough to accommodate most small and medium packages. It comes with a wall plug and can also run just off four AAA batteries. Since I'm using it in a home office and not a large shipping department, I just run it off the batteries. I've been using it for a month or so and haven't needed to change batteries yet. The scale has a range of 0.1 ounces to 110 pounds. I'm attaching a photo of a large copper mug holding pens sitting on the scale to give you an idea of how big it is.It measures in pounds ounces grams and kilograms. I've checked its gram and ounce weights against a very sensitive jewelry scale and it's very accurate. The digital read out has bright, crisp, large blue text and is very easy to read. Switching between pounds and kilograms is a matter of pressing a single button, unlike some scales which make it rather difficult to switch. The build quality seems excellent. In fact, it looks and feels like a much more expensive scale. The only thing I wish they would change is the sticker on the top of the scale, which tells you to remove the packing cardboard but then refuses to come off without solvent. You can see that in my photos too. However, that's a minor quibble that doesn't really affect my opinion of an excellent scale.If you're looking for a shipping scale that small enough to fit gracefully into the home office and can handle a wide range of weights, I wholeheartedly recommend this one.As a product tester I received this free or virtually so for evaluation and review. I was excited to try these, because I'm a jeweler and would be thrilled to find something I can recommend to clients who for various reasons may not want to be able to resize their too - large rings. I tested them out on a number of my rings, and unfortunately they did not really live up to expectations.The main problem is strength and durability. If you are using this on an expensive ring or one with sentimental value, and that ring is too loose, and the ring magic band fails… You can see how it's very easy to lose the ring. These bands are very thin, and one broke on me within a week. Not only are you risking losing your ring, but it would get expensive buying a new package of these every week.My other problem with these mainly pertains to fine jewelry. Such jewelry is all about the appearance of fine detail. While the ring sizing bands are very thin and inconspicuous, they do show especially on rings with very narrow bands. For casual wear that's fine, but it doesn't really go with an expensive ring.I gave these three stars rather than the lower readings that some other reviewers chose because I can see these being useful in one very specific situation. If you're getting engaged, and aren't completely certain of your fiancé's ring size, you could get a package of these to have in your back pocket in case the ring you present is not a perfect fit. This was my first time using Xylitol, but I'm a long-time liquid Stevia user so I was interested to compare the two natural non-sugar sweeteners. My test product was lemon iced tea, which I hot brew and can often consume a half-gallon a day of. I usually use stevia as a sweetener; stevia has a sort of aftertaste to it which the lemon masks, so out of curiosity I added the Xylitol and tasted it before adding lemon. It was a little disheartening to find out how much I had to use to get it mildly sweet; I tasted the crystals straight out of the bag and they aren't that concentrated in their sweetness - less so than sugar I think. I ended up using 10 tablespoons (yes, tablespoons) of this birch Xylitol to sweeten it, and I was going for mild sweet, not "southern sweet tea sweet."There wasn't any funny undertone or aftertaste that I could detect; it doesn't taste exactly like sugar, but it doesn't taste like something else either. It's a cool, light sweetness and leaves your tongue feeling cool. In other words, great for cold drinks. A huge appeal for me is the dental benefit; I have bad teeth, and drink tea constantly, so having that be beneficial would be lovely. Stevia (what I usually use) isn't sugar and doesn't cause decay, but Xylitol has the edge through helping avert it. The granules are clean-looking, distinct, and dissolve readily in liquid. I looked around on amazon and this product looks to be one of the best, because it's made in the USA, it's birch xylitol, and is non-GMO (some Xylitol is made from GMO corn). The only drawback, and it is rather a large one, is the fact that you have to use so much given that the stuff isn't cheap. I would suggest as large a bag as you can.As a product tester I received this free or virtually so for evaluation and review. This does NOT mean this is a fake review. This is a very unique towel - it has a few drawbacks, but it's also got some advantages over anything else. Somehow, it manages to go beyond just evaporative cooling. When I removed it from the package, when it was dry to the touch, it was also *cool* to the touch. I followed the instructions to wet it initially in warm water, and chilled it in the fridge. Wow was it ever a nice feeling in the 99-degree sun! Here are the plusses and minuses I've noted:GOOD* Somehow they've done what no other towel I've tried has done and boosted it beyond what I feel from normal evaporative cooling. It simply feels colder than anything else* Stays wet and cold for a *very* long time* Soft on the skinBAD* Dries stiff as a board. When you let it dry, be sure that's the shape you want it to remain in for storage.* When wet, the material it's made from is a little tender. It's a foamy cloth, and bits of the "foamy" are already missing after I've used it about 5 times. Be more careful of it than you would cloth. * Because it's not a porous material, I find that after a while it actually starts trapping heat against my skin after it builds up. This seems fixable by removing the towel and flapping it around in the air a bit to cool it off, or running it under cool water.Still a five-star product despite the disadvantages because it does what it's supposed to, and does so amazingly well. Throw it in the fridge before use and you'll be in heaven.As a product tester I received this free or virtually so for evaluation and review. This does NOT mean this is a fake review. Odd but very good and unique flashlight! It's a side light or standard flashlight depending on which button you press, and the side light makes a great reading light. I can't believe I didn't know about geraniol bug sprays until recently. A nice-smelling, non-toxic spray is sort of the holy grail, and it finally exists.  The bottle holds a fairly substantial 4oz without taking up too much room in your pack; a little goes a long way because it's very liquid and you can spread it on your skin.The active ingredient, geraniol, is a constituent of rose, citronella, and palmarosa essential oils, and also occurs in small quantities in geranium, lemon, and many other essential oils. The University of Florida developed and tested alternatives to pesticides for 17 years, and geraniol is what emerged at the head of the pack as a safe, effective insect repellant. It works against mosquitoes, flies, cockroaches, fire ants, fleas, gnats, ticks, and no-see-ums. This spray is very strong-smelling, and I think it smells wonderful; like a rose/citronella perfume blend. I don't find I have to cover all my skin with it to keep bugs at bay; it's strong enough that just a cursory application works. However, it does evaporate or wear off rather fast, so I had to re-apply it while working outdoors.As a product tester I received this free or virtually so for evaluation and review. There's no odor, so you don't feel like you're working out on a rubber tire.I've just gotten spoiled by mats that are even thicker, and found that this didn't cushion joints as well as I would like, and it's more prone to bunching up or shifting on the floor. This is not something it does *often* I'm just used to it not happening at all. It's a very nice mat, don't get me wrong. But I like them with a little more cushion, and with more weight to keep them from moving.As a product tester I received this free or virtually so for evaluation and review. This does NOT mean this is a fake review. I was not paid for my review, or given any incentive or reward for a positive review. If you don't believe me, click my profile and scroll down to see the poor reviews I've given bad products. My job is to give an honest opinion, not help the manufacturer. My remarks are sincere and my own.
