This is a contoured mask that doesn't touch your eyes, and is moulded around the nose to keep light out. It does a superior job blocking out almost all light. The materials and construction are good quality, and it's comfortable to wear. I actually prefer slightly softer materials and like a soft mask against my eyes, but my mom fell in love with it right away. She remarked several times on how comfortable it was, and she likes that it doesn't touch her eyes. So I think it's personal preference; this does a better job blocking out light than any mask I've tried, so if that's a priority this is the best choice.As a product tester I received this free or virtually so for evaluation and review. This does NOT mean this is a fake review. I was not paid for my review, or given any incentive or reward for a positive review. If you don't believe me, click my profile and scroll down to see the poor reviews I've given bad products. My job is to give an honest opinion, not help the manufacturer. My remarks are sincere and my own.

I'm a jeweler, and I have several scales, but this one is by far the best. It's not actually easy to get a scale that has all the specialized weights used by jewelers: carat, troy ounce, grain, and pennyweight are needed a lot more often than grams or standard ounces. Well, this scale has all of them. It was easy to calibrate, and weighs a tiny 3mm faceted gemstone (0.135ct) just as easily as 17 grams of gem rough. The read-out is easy to see and it's small enough not to take up too much room in your workspace.Tare is easily established, and batteries, calibration weights, and tweezers are included in a nice carrying case. It takes AAA batteries, which is kind of a nice feature because a lot of scales use harder to find "button" batteries. This is going to be my go-to scale from now on and I highly recommend it to fellow fine jewelers. Please note that if you are looking for something to weigh strands of beads, they probably won't fit; this is more the gems, precious metals, and gem rough sort of scale.As a product tester I received this free or virtually so for evaluation and review. This does NOT mean this is a fake review. I was not paid for my review, or given any incentive or reward for a positive review. If you don't believe me, click my profile and scroll down to see the poor reviews I've given bad products. My job is to give an honest opinion, not help the manufacturer. My remarks are sincere and my own.

We were in a coastal town near the docks a couple of days ago. Extreme fire danger, half the state's on fire, smoke so thick you can't drive with the windows down without your eyes stinging ....and I looked over and there was fire spreading through the grass. Bushes a few feet away, cars on the other side of the bushes, a narrow street and then a hillside covered with houses. Two guys were trying to stomp it out and failing to contain it, I ran over with my drink to dump on it and asked if they'd called 911 yet. "Why'd we do something like that?" was the genius of the year reply. The leading edge of the fire made me stop stomping and RUN a couple of times, and that was when my mom in the car reminded me we had this fire extinguisher. I grabbed it, asked her to call 911, then ran along the leading edge of the fire (did I mention it was windy too?) with this.It stopped the fire in its tracks everywhere along the perimeter that I was able to spray it, and with the grass burnt already behind the fire that meant it was effectively out everywhere I could spray it. Unfortunately the extinguisher ran out really fast, leaving 2/3 or so of the fire uncontained, but I'd stopped the leading edge that was spreading too fast, driven by the wind, for it to be stopped by anything but an extinguisher or a hose. It was still touch and go with lots of stomping and three bottles of water a lovely bypasser threw us, but we got it out. The fire department arrived and soaked everything that was still smoldering.While this alone was not enough to contain the fire, I am 100% certain it was the deciding factor. It absolutely would not have been contained without the fire department if I hadn't had this and used it, and the fire would have been large and destructive by the time they arrived. I'm converted to ALWAYS carrying a fire extinguisher in the car now (I actually bought this after my former car caught fire driving down the road ...having realized firsthand that your car can just burst into flames). Actually, I'm carrying two from now on.

Hair bits tend to fly in every direction when you use a shaver, and the little vacuum built into this one can't catch it all.  I'd guesstimate it catches about 80-90% though.  The receptacle isn't that large, and if you're trimming like four weeks of growth, you'll have to empty it a couple of times, particularly because the suction of the little fan deteriorates as hair builds up in the chamber.  Hair surprisingly stays in when held upside down with vacuum still on.  Razor cuts very cleanly with no tugging, make sure you keep it oiled.  Unit itself is fairly large and bulky, but with the lighter Li-ion battery it's about the same weight as my plug-in model.  Has the standard range of plastic clip-on guides.

The seat itself is great.  Shape has proven to be close to ideal, lid doesn't slam shut, lid and seat will stay up when lifted.The biggest design flaw is the light.  I don't know why it doesn't simply activate while the lid is up, that engineering is not difficult.  Instead you have to press a button in the back and then it stays on for 7 hours if you don't click it off again.  I guess they figure 7 hours is likely how much night is left?  But people are lazy and won't click it off, which drains the batteries.And then you have to change the batteries which for some reason requires you to remove the entire seat.  The battery compartment also isn't isolated well from the gross parts.  Even if you clean constantly, if you're potty training a boy, that area is going to get nasty.

I feel it has decent quality sound, some people have dinged it - my pair has pretty good range for such a low price.The controller only muted/unmuted on my Android (G3,5.1.1) phone when listening to Google Music.Despite the poofy ear cushions, they didn't block out much outside noise, which I guess can be a feature depending on what you're looking for.  Though usually if you're dealing with sweaty ears you want some isolation.Collapsibility is nice for traveling, cord is relatively tangle-free if you collapse and wrap around.

My son is 4 1/2, we are small people, and this is just larger enough that he'll be able to wear it for a while.  Fabric is very nice and durable.  These sport shirts are apparently what all the cool boys are wearing at the daycare...

Overall these are okay, but I think I prefer the kind that comes in a roll.  The size of these pre-cut rectangles wasn't appropriate length or width for any shelf or drawer of my fridge, so you end up needing to join two cuts together, which is sloppy and prone to rolling/folding when you slide items in.  The fold creases will come out if you soak them and dry.  I recommend cutting with a razor and straight edge ruler to guide it, using scissors the fabric tends to move and you don't get a clean straight cut.

Interesting design, I love how the smaller stones and metal circle to draw your attention in to the larger center gem that has a nice cut.  It's almost like a mesmerizing Beholder eye or vortex.  Sits nicely against the skin, just wide enough that it doesn't flop/spin around.

Really well done miniature Avengers set.  Quite surprised at the number of points of articulation, they are very movable and pose-able.  The only bad part is the capes on two figures are cloth and don't hold up to play.  Hard plastic capes wouldn't have been a bad alternative.  They probably could have ditched an Ultron in favor of War Machine or Quicksilver.  Packaging is kind of annoying as the arms of the characters are threaded through holes behind the plastic and elasticked in.

For a plastic low end paint sprayer, the PaintWIZ PW25000 does a really nice job.  Even if you've used a sprayer before I'd still suggest a few things before you get started:1. If you need to dilute per instructions, under-dilute first and see how it sprays; you can always dilute more, but you can't un-dilute easily.  Every model,unit, and paint varies in how it's going to come out.  I was surprised in the difference between a year-old can and a new can of the same paint.2. Once you get the dilution ratio set, mix up as much as you think you need for the job.  This way the ratio will be consistent for the whole job, and you won't be spending time mixing while your project is drying unevenly.3. Test out the sprayer on scrap first, get used to how it sprays horizontal vs vertical and with different flow rate before you attack your actual job.4. Really make sure you clean it out with detail when you're done.  Anything left in the spray apparatus to dry and cake on will make a huge negative impact the next time around.5.  Be very generous when taping off edges.  I usually tape newspaper or drop cloth to the trim instead of just the strip of tape.  Even if you're used to the spread of the spray, you may not be 100% careful and droplets can wander.  It's notoriously difficult to get paint off a popcorn ceiling or match the dirty white.  I've also killed off a portion of a shrub outside by getting too much paint on it when doing a fence.  Drop cloths, dead wind, and a face mask are your friends.

These really aren't anything special as far as insoles go.  Cushion is pretty much the same as the insole that's come in most of my shoes.  There's no additional arch support.  The odor difference may be noticeable for you if your current insole is more absorbent than the rubbery stuff these are made of.  (The chemical smell that these originally had, for me, faded after a few days wearing).  If you have cheap shoes from a bargain department store, these will probably be better; or if you need to replace a worn insole in an old pair.  Otherwise if you're looking to replace an insole to alleviate tiredness from standing all day, I'd seek a different product.

Passes the primary test I have for cookbooks: full color pictures of every dish.  Recipes are very diverse in ingredients and prep time.  Lots of good stuff in here you won't see in most other cookbooks, really helps to round out your collection.  Fair enough number of vegetarian recipes while also bringing superstars like homemade pastrami.  The author own a bakery and that seems evident from the awesome desserts.The only thing missing is a pronunciation guide for some of the dishes!

I also have a killawatt, which I feel gives you more accurate and customizable readings.  The Belkin, however, is extremely user-friendly.  You just input your electricity rate and plug something in.  Immediately you can get readings for how much is being used and a forecast for what that usage would accrue to in dollars over the course of a month or a year.  I'm not big into figuring out carbon offsets and/or "greenness", but it's a feature that may appeal to some.The separation of the outlet from the display is extremely handy, much better than the crouching over with a flashlight I need to do to read the killawatt.

Within a dystopic world, it's the typical "more than you bargained for" kind of story.  Characters left with few other options join a community that is very reminiscent of Stepford Wives where everything looks great at first and the rest of the book is spent showing you just how wrong that impression is.  The characters aren't fully developed, and I found the images I had in my head of the characters changed drastically a couple of times as they responded to situations inconsistently.  Overall, if you've liked Atwood's other dystopic novels, you'll probably like this one, though I enjoyed Handmaid's Tale a lot more.

The nautical blue one came in good condition, it's thin, but not ridiculously so.  Color seems a bit deeper in person than the photo.  Does well in the washer and dryer and hasn't bled or faded.  Fits my long table with the leaves in.  Very pleased.  Would recommend a table protector pad underneath.

It's a very pleasant black tea, has a little bit of something that gives it a smooth taste - I guess that assam component they talk about in the description.  It's not harsh to me at all, which means it lives up to its "breakfast" designation in my book.  I usually drink it black, but it goes very nicely with some milk because of that smooth character.  The leaves look like there's a lot of fannings and dust, but this still definitely drinks better than a generic Lipton bag.  Doesn't take a whole lot to brew a solid cup and each ounce lasts a respectable amount of time.I hadn't tried much if any Capital Teas before this one, but I think I will seek out more.

This is a clean professional looking planner.  The bigger size fits together better if you're carrying textbooks, the smaller planners always seemed to get crushed.  Being bigger it also allows it to be thinner, and it lays flat when open, very handy when you're jotting stuff down with only one hand free.  I almost think they should have made it an inch larger on each side so a normal sheet of paper could be kept between pages without the need to fold it.This is a Monday-Sunday week format with business hours from 7am-7pm.  That inked time frame is slightly restrictive, but having to use the extra "hot" space on the bottom isn't terrible.  I prefer this softer cream color rather than the stark white planner pages.

Anybody can produce a mediocre tool set made in China.  Ford probably should have gone "premium" and produced a high quality set in America to attach their name to.The set is fairly standard, I've owned two other very similar sets, and quality-wise this sits between cheap-brand-that-rusted-out and Craftsman.  The handles on the three left pliers are a good thickness.  The other sets I've had were much thinner and really dug into your hand after a while when applying lots of pressure.  These grips are more comfortable.

The form is done with metal and the wicker is fairly plasticky.  It's softer than the wicker furniture I have on the deck and has some give.  That's probably good as the dog is always nosing into it to get toys out, and my toddler has climbed in and out of it numerous times and it hasn't been damaged at all.  The medium size is really very large, we have a lot of dog toys and could probably have made due with the smaller one.  The leather straps look great, though every puppy I've ever owned has enjoyed chewing on leather.

LG G series are great phones.  I've had the 2, 3, and 4 now.  The G3 is a big upgrade over the G2, particularly in processor performance and both screen image and glass qualities.  The G4 isn't as much of an upgrade overall, except for one particular feature, and that's the cameras.  The main camera megapixels on the G3 are more than sufficient, but taking the same picture with both the G3 and the G4 shows that the G3 has more small artifacts, particularly in low light.  The G4 camera manual settings are also a huge plus, particularly when one of the G3 annoyances is an overbright flash, which among many other settings can be adjusted on the G4.  The front camera is an extraordinary upgrade over the G3, which was pitiful, but this may only be important to you if you're big into selfies.Other than the cameras though, you won't notice much performance difference if you settle for the G3.  There may not really be a need to settle for the G3, however, as almost right upon release there have been penny deals with contract for the G4.  The G3 and G4 are slightly bigger phones than the G2, but they fit in my hand fine and I've seen many little hands handle it fine though girl jeans less so.

(Assuming it is the finish..)  The misgivings I had at book one, that it was one point of view, very simple story structure, that all went away.  By this third book we have the typical Abercrombie shifting viewpoint giving you different perspectives on events, always adjusting what you thought was going on.  More of his great fight descriptions and sprinkled wry humor throughout.  I really recommend this series and author.

These are a very solid pair of shears.  The thick, rubberized handles are an upgrade over my other pair as I feel I can more comfortably exert more pressure when cutting denser foods.  They could improve upon them by making them a little more ergonomic, I get the typical soreness around the thumb after extended use.  Blade comes sharp and performs well, though a bit of a sawtooth close to the hinge would provide some utility.  Blade length is fine for most of my kitchen uses.

I tried this out first to see how bad it was.  It's bitter for sure, but I like bitter tastes in general, and was expecting it, so it didn't seem that much of a deterrent to me.  However, two weeks later it's still active on my thumbnail, despite dozens of handwashings and showers.  I occasionally accidentally touch it to my lips when I'm eating finger food, and not expecting it, it's so much worse.  I'm still going to resist using nail polish remover to see how long it can last.The kid, having the usual sweet tooth, really doesn't like it.  Despite agreeing to it the first time around, I think a reapplication will be either a fight or done by ninja dad while he's sleeping.

Works well, and for the most part is easy to apply if you're generous with the pre-wet.  Handy that it comes with razor and squeegee.  A two-person job solely for the one step of removing the backing.  The light shade does for sure make the glass appear darker, but it's not bad at all.  I would be hesitant to go to the medium or dark shade, as that would definitely be a tinted window look.A few caveats:-Try not to seam.  Start with a piece large enough for the entire window.  Even doing the overlap and slice through both layers method doesn't provide an exact lineup because the film is still shifting slightly.-You need a seriously dust free environment.  I had some almost microscopic width dog hair that was apparently floating around which leave a noticeable bump if they get under the film, and good luck getting a thin hair off a sticky film.-The felt squeegee is great, but no matter how meticulous you are with the laying of the film and the pushing out of bubbles, you will still see texture up close.

I've owned several Speck cases for various phones, and have never been disappointed.  This one is nice and slim and doesn't add too much bulk to the iPhone.  We've unfortunately dropped the phone several times already, even on the concrete garage floor no damage and very minimal scuffing of the case.Camera and buttons are all accessible with no interference from the shell.Comfortable in the hand texture-wise.My only real beef is the price.  It seems customers get bent over the barrel a bit when a new iPhone comes out.  An equivalent new-android phone case can be gotten for less than half the price, and tempered glass screen protectors are routinely under ten bucks.  The "layers of radial impact geometry" seems kind of gimmicky, when the other pure silicon Speck and off-brand cases I've owned have done as well of a job.

The features of PowerDVD 15 are pretty overwhelming.  I needed something to play bluray discs on Windows 8.1, I guess since the bluray format is proprietary Microsoft didn't want to pay to license it by default.  I tried the free VLC program but didn't find it as polished or user-friendly.  The direct YouTube thing seems like a weird feature when you can just open a browser.  I enjoy being able to bookmark spots for later reference and picking up where I leave off.  You need the Ultra version to get 3D support, though I've never been huge on 3D, I like it even less on the smaller screen.  Ultra will also play ISO files if you backup your discs to your home media server.Whatever upscaling of DVDs it does is fantastic, I'm not getting any blurring or pixelation, though your mileage may vary depending on your viewing device - I mainly use a fast refresh monitor for movies.  Plus there's support for 4K if decide to upgrade my monitor in the future.  5.1 surround seems to work well.I've heard older versions of PowerDVD were resource hogs, but I don't experience any of this.  It feels rather lightweight and the fans don't hit full speed when I'm watching movies.  You need to go at least with the Pro version for bluray, and the extra premium paid for Ultra seems worth it to me if you're already resigned to paying that much for Pro.  I don't recommend buying version 13 on the cheap, as 15 is too much of an upgrade feature-wise.

We apparently had an odd-sized cradle and it didn't fit quite right (check your measurements precisely before ordering, our sloped sides didn't help either), we ended up using the end bumpers from the crib for the sides of the cradle.  But then we ended up doing the opposite - in the crib my daughter would continually lose her pacifiers out of the corners where the crib bumpers didn't fully enclose; so we brought this cradle bumper back out, and it encloses those corners on the end of the crib she prefers to sleep in.  It's funny how it worked out.Seems to weather the washer/dryer cycles fine.

Overall a typically good backseat organizer.  The pockets are sized well, sippy cups fit in nicely, not too snug, not too deep.  The viewing pouch isn't really usable in my car, though it'd probably be better in my wife's CRV.  The brown/red design really stands out against the dark gray seat fabric, I didn't think I would care, but MONKEY.  The straps around the headrest and seat bottom are unobtrusive.

These are really delicious.  The beef ones are the best, super tender and flavorful.  The turkey and chicken are a bit tougher and don't hold as much flavor, but are still great.  The plain beef is probably my favorite.  Hoping they release more flavors.

Cardigan is a very deep color of navy.  Size medium/5-6 seems accurate - fits my four year old a bit loosely and should last another winter.  Not thin like you'd might expect from something this affordable.

This was deeply discounted when I picked it up, under ten dollars, and for that price does an amazing job.  The light is bright and even at dusk or in a shady basement you can easily see pet stains quite remarkably.  I'm excited the cat damage wasn't nearly as bad as I was imagining!  It's nice having peace of mind knowing precisely where problem areas are/were.

Really nice blend of scents.  I don't really pick up on everything they list, but it is slightly exotic.  It's also less floral/fruity without being too musky.  A spray-and-walk-through delivers a nice coating, doing the job without being overpowering.
The table saw mounted securely, and now creates a solid, stable table saw.
Little great granddaughters loved it.
I split the pack for two sets of great-grandkids to use with the scooters and Plasma cars. They loved them. They are light and safe, and so far have withstood the pummeling they get.

Denzel Washington, a new action hero. You'll never view him the same after this cool, hard nose Equalizer role. He makes the original Equalizer look like a wimp. A superb acting job, and totally believable. Great action movie, with really bad villains, who all get their come-uppings.

The DVD has excellent 5.1 sound, and the film is perfectly remastered  -- brilliant color, sharp images, even on an 80-inch TV, from beginning to end I couldn't have stopped watching, except if the house were on fire. The movie is fun to watch, Debbie Reynolds catches one up in the story from the moment the movie starts playing and she makes her presence known on screen.

I've been a sci-fi addict since my high-school years. (1950) I read all of the books, the pulp fiction, listened to Buck Roger's on the radio, as each new book, magazine, or movie came out, I had to see/read them. I've collected all of the films first on VHS, then on DVD, and finally on 3D BD. This addiction never slowed."Lucy" has to be milestone in science fiction. Beside being an exciting adventure story, terrific stunts, well filmed, superb editing, and excellent sound and scoring, it's a movie I'll watch a couple more times before I break out a fresh film. I've only seen it on DVD, but i would have loved to see it on the big screen. The science is accurate, the story, fascinating, with a convincing performance by Scarlett Johansson. Lucy will stand along with Capt. Kirk as a memorable character. Morgan Freeman, as usual, held the story together.

Tightly stretched canvas, solid gesso, and stapled on the back, a full stretch if you carry the painting over the edge. (No need for a frame when you do that.) All of my acrylic paintings are edge finished with part of the image or background, even the 2 x 4 feet x 1-inch pressed board paintings. I've won first places and sold many finished this way. Keep in mind that canvass this size is mostly for studies or parts of diptych, tetraptych, etc., painting.
Easy to assemble, and easy to fold up when not being played with. Three-year old great-granddaughter quickly got the hang of it. She loved it. Being three-wheeled, no balancing is required

My four-year old great granddaughter loves, and got right down to business as soon as it was opened, diving right in with the molds. One happy kid.The Kinetic Sand works as described. It is not messy, sticking together like it's supposed to.

My four-year old great granddaughter loves, and got right down to business as soon as it was opened. One happy kid.The Kinetic Sand works as described. It is not messy, sticking together like it's supposed to.
This is a pretty good towel ring. It is 90% plastic which is kind of depressing but it was easy to install and seems to be holding up well
Got a couple of these and they seem to be working great. They have a splitter if 3 sockets.

I saw some good reviews on this stuff so I figured I would try it. I use to drink those 5 hour energy's or those Costco brand knock offs. This is a lot cheaper though and it tastes better with no medicine flavor.The flavor of these kind of taste like those pink ice pops/Otter Pops. Those popsicles with the plastic sleeve on the outside and various colors. The pink one best matches the flavor of this energy shot.Highly recommend as a replacement to more expensive alternatives

This DOES get rid of pet stains but by doing so you will be replacing the smell with a VERY strong, almost suffocatingly strong, clean odor. If your bad smell really smells SUPER bad then this may be the way to go but your house will stink of a fresh sent that just screams "I covered up a pet smell!". I would recommend getting something that neutralizes odors instead of covering the scent.

Great trimmer. Very powerful. I got the 4AH battery model. It's unlikely that you will need the 6AH battery unless you have a ginormous lawn. I have 1/3 of an acre lot trim, with 5 mature large trees, a large shed, whole lot chain link fenced in, as well as going around the house. After doing all of that at full speed (there is low and high speed) I still have enough battery to do it again the next time. I charge the battery after every two trimmings.Another thing nice about this trimmer is its balance. At first I was bothered by how long it was but once you get used to it you realize that it's very well balanced. It's also built incredibly well.One problem I seem to be having, and thus minus 1 star, is that sometimes when I set the trimmer on low speed it seems to go at high speed anyways. So that's kind of weird but since it still gets the job done I want it to get down, I'm not to bothered. Highly recommend this trimmer.
I was forced to have this book for a class. The entire class is very subjective and so is the book.
this is just what I needed for a drain in my basement. It's very well made and thick plastic. Good purchase

I ordered two Frigidaire dehumidifiers before returning them and replacing them with this one. The new Frigidaire dehumidifiers suck air from the back and blow out the side. They also don't have a built in hose attachment. You have to attach an adapter (which could easily be lost) so that you can use a hose. The other thing was that the hose attachment was also on the side! You had to have the dehumidifier a foot and a half away from the wall which looks stupid if using in a finished basement.Now, this dehumidifier is great. This is what I expect from a dehumidifier. Sucks into the front and blows out the top. Perfect. I put it right up against my wall. The hose attachment is on the back so I could run a line through my wall. The filter is also great, you press it and it pops up and you rinse it and put it back. There is one thing that is annoying. If you do use it with the bucket instead of the hose, sometimes the water will drip AFTER you remove the bucket. The way to avoid this is to wait a few minutes after its full for it to completely drain into the bucket. Then this wont happen. No big deal though. The bucket also has a nice handle and if it ever breaks it is replaceable because it can be detached. The fan can be a little loud but they all are and this one is about average.Overall this is a great dehumidifer and works well. Honeywell makes great products and I haven't ever had a problem with their stuff.
Its spray paint and its black. Not sure what else to say except that it does what its suppose to and is actually the color it is suppose to be. Used it on metal and on wood and it worked just fine.

I am impressed with this level. Looks like its made really well and also seems to be quite accurate. It may not be precise but for every day house work its great. I actually used as a level when I built a wood frame for a wall. Worked perfect. Highly recommend.
I have bought a few triangle bulbs in different sizes and types. They all seem to work well and they haven't died yet so I can't really complain. These were no exception and work just fine.

I will rate this based on everything other then the actual use of the product. Seeing how I haven't used it and hopefully will never have to use it. The size of this is perfect for a nightstand drawer. This is where I keep mine. It seems to be well made and not likely to explode randomly. It also has a safety lock on it so my son won't blast his eyes out if you were to somehow get a hold of it. Overall, I think it will be a good thing to have just in case.

Works perfect with my DeWalt oscillating tool. Great for what I needed them for. Not as good as the actual DeWalt brand blades I am used to using but for the price they are definitely worth it if you only need to get a few jobs done with them. They will wear out faster then name brand ones though. Again, worth it for the price.

I got three of these and they work great for dimming lights. They are easy to install since you can use them on old ceilings. You just pop them into the hole you created and push the tabs out to keep it in. I don't recommend LED lights with these if you are going to be using them for dimming. LED's seem to flicker. Halogen seems to work best. Here is a picture of them where I installed them in my house.
Works great. Just what I needed. It is slightly bigger then 30" x 8" so make sure you measure your hole before hand.

This works great! Its easy to wire. Just attach black to black, white to white, and copper to copper. Be aware that you do NOT take it apart by pushing in the tabs on the back. You need to pull the rings off from around where the bulbs screw in. Then it will come apart and you can get to the wires. Also, the blue on the outside of it is a sticker to protect the chrome, it is not actually blue. Overall, this worked great for my bathroom and I haven't had a problem yet. I attached a picture as well so you can see that it works good.

No where in the description does it say that these suck air from the BACK of the unit, have the hose hole on the side, and have the exhaust on the other side. The manual says the unit must be 1.5 feet away from all walls. So you are just suppose to have a random dehumidifier sitting in the middle of your room? Sorry, but whoever decided this was better then the other dehumidifiers that suck air from front and blow out the top obviously wasn't thinking. Will be returning this units.

I got this lamp at a furniture store called home makers. The item was 129 dollars at the time which was kind of steep but it is definitely a nice lamp. You DO have to put it together yourself. This isn't very difficult. It's very sturdy and heavy if you put it together properly. At first I thought the light sockets were wiggly but then I found that there was a screw at the bottom of each socket to tighten them onto the base and that fixed that. There is NO dimmer unlike what it says on Amazon. I had already known this since it was on display when I bought it. It does have a switch that changes It to have 1 or 2 or all bulbs on at the same time. So this is pretty nice. The price on here is way to steep and Incould never justify buying a lamp for nearly 200 dollars. 129 dollars is even steep but we bought it anyways. Having two of them on night stands is very nice.
WOW awesome! These are VERY small and at the same time VERY loud! These are nice instead of having giant ones all over the house.
Works very well. Other people seem to be having some kind of buzzing noise in the fan but I don't. I put this into my Silverstone Raven case.
I love prime instant video!
Outstanding connection. Very happy. Put it into my grandpa's computer.
Its a HDD and its fast and works great. The end
Fixed my grandpa's wireless internet issues
Works great for the price. Got it for grandpa's computer and it was way better then his old CRT monitor
OUTSTANDING for the price. Very well made and solid. I am impressed.
Very protective
Love this show. Great acting and great story.
What?? its doesn't even come with the USB cable to hook it up to the computer. what the heck!
Its an HDMI cable and it works. nuff said

This book made me incredibly sad. My grandfather and my mother both died with Alzheimer's. My grandfather was a 'mean' Alzheimer's patient, very angry as he started losing his artistic abilities. He took his anger out on my mother unfortunately, and this was back in the 80's, and my mother did not understand that what grandpa was doing and saying was from the disease impacting his amygdala, which is the emotional part of the brain. My mom was a very sweet Alzheimer's patient, but it was hard to see her dwindle away to nothing.This book brought this all back up for me. I'm sure it touches the lives of other people who are dealing with this as well. And always, at the back of your mind, you worry that eventually the disease will possibly take your mind, or the mind of your loved ones still living.Genova tackles this topic from the person who is undergoing the loss of her mind, and the impact it has on her family. I thought the movie was quite good, but as usual, I feel the book encompassed more than could be done in the movie. Genova did a great job with the little things that people start forgetting, not just the usual keys and phones, but going blank when you know that you have the knowledge in your brain, but you simply cannot reach and grabbed that knowledge.I actually went into Neuroscience because of my grandfather's experience. I was lucky enough to work in both a lab on Alzheimer's and a Lab on HIV encephalitis. It opened my eyes to both the frustration that comes with trying to find something to work on these brain disorders from the point of view of the researchers, and having my mom go through Alzheimer's experiencing the frustration of not finding anything to help her personally (the medications are basically useless as of now). Because of my personal involvement in different sides of this story, I really appreciate Genova's writing of this book.I found the saddest part of the book to be the leaving of Alice's husband, because he couldn't bear to watch her deterioration. In my family, we don't do that. My grandmother took care of my grandfather until he ended up in the hospital where he died. She persisted through times of him getting up over and over in the night to bathe, because he thought he hadn't done it that day. And my father took such good care of my mother, taking her with him places to the point he neglected to take care of his own health and suffered a stroke. My father and mother died a month apart from each other...my mom was lost without him. So even though this is fiction, the fact the husband left to pursue his own opportunities struck me as extremely selfish...An excellent book...just very sad.

This book was a good read for medical history, but was not on the same level as other medical histories that I've read. It stalled in a couple of places, and I found that occasionally all the other extraneous information added not related to the story itself, would sometimes be confusing.I had no idea that transfusion was considered back in the 1600's. All it took was one arrogant physician, trying to push the envelope. And if you've been in medical school, you've seen a few of those. In this case, dealing with such an unknown (they did not know about the cell markers in blood at that point which would cause clotting reactions if people were given the wrong blood type). It's too bad that Jean-Baptise Denis couldn't see our use of blood today, and see how well his idea saves lives today. Now to be fair, he wasn't the first to try transfusion. That definitely belongs to the British. But he tried hard, in spite of religious and medical objections, to demonstrate the possibilities of transfusions. It boggles the mind to consider that if transfusions had been possible that far back (with continued research), the lives that could have been saved in all the wars.The research for this book probably wasn't easily done. Especially if you had to get rare material in French, from the courts and royal records kept almost 500 years ago. Apparently, the author, Tucker, knows French as well as English, so that explains a lot.This is a great book to read if you want to understand how far back medical research goes, and many of the obstacles that are put in the way of those who do research.

I finished this book a while ago, but forgot to write a review. It's been a while since I read a Jeffrey Deaver book. I like his writing, and the relationship between Rhymes and Sachs is one of the more interesting duos in fiction. They are both crippled in different ways, Rhyme from an unfortunate accident which left him a quadriplegic, and Sachs from arthritis. They are both very intense people.In this current novel, someone is setting 'booby traps' using the city's electrical grid. This is making for some very horrifying situations in which innocent people are getting fried in a variety of ways. Lincoln Rhymes and Sachs have to figure out whether this is an act of a disgruntled employee or a terroristic group first, while they try to find the physical evidence that will tell them how to get the guy or guys.As other reviewers have said, I get the feeling that Deaver is tired of his two protagonists, and so much of the writing seems repetitive and old. HIs writing is excellent as readers have come to expect from Deaver, but maybe he should do something new and different and get away from these protagonists, even if they are the source of his income!

I haven't been made this mad reading a book in a long, long time. I have been interested in bioethics since medical school. And I've always been worried about certain situations in which people that are often disenfranchised find themselves. I am especially talking about people with disabilities and the elderly. I am Deaf, so this area is of particular interest to me. I also have family members who died with Alzheimer's.I had heard and read about some of the problems that occurred down in New Orleans...but I had been wanting to read about specific instances of 'bad behavior' on the part of members of the medical profession. This book confirmed what I had heard/read. That doctors (and nurses) took it upon themselves to determine who was worthy of life. In this case, in this hospital...those lives were the elderly patients who were not even patients of the doctor who did the killing, and specifically, one patient who was obese. Sheri Fink did an incredible job of research, making sure that she didn't just tell one side of the story. She tries very hard to be fair to everyone, which is difficult in a book like this. She tries to leave it up to the reader as to how they feel about what happened at Memorial Hospital, and decide who is at fault.Believe me, there is  plenty of fault to go around. Whether it is the doctors who did not come forward and say 'You just can't do this', the corporation who decided to save money rather than update things like generators which would go under water with flooding, or the government, whose inadequate handling of the disaster made things very bad in the hospitals. But ultimately, the decision to 'euthanize' specific patients because it was too 'hard' to get them out of the hospital laid upon the doctors and the nurses that helped them. This all boils down to whose life is worthy of life. These medical personnel for whatever reason (it is really hard to determine what their reasoning for dealing with these patients that way) made an extremely bad decision. The ethicists said so, the other doctors said so, expert coroners said so. No one has the right to say when someone dies, and in this world where it is becoming all too prevalent to devalue people, my fear is that this type of situation is spreading. As Fink said, in Europe countries such as Belgium are already putting people to death, some of whom have very little wrong with them. Why, because some deem it easier to use resources for those who are 'worth more' to society.Anyone who is interested in bioethics needs to read this book. Especially those in medicine. Those in governmental positions who need to prepare prior to disasters, such as in places like San Francisco and Miami, who are hanging on the precipice of a disaster. What are they planning to do when an earthquake, or a tsunami hits. Have they prepared, or are they going to have these same things happen in their cities?

Warning. This is not an easy book to read. But it is a great book nevertheless. I enjoy science biographies where you actually need to have your phone with you in order to look things up. I've read other books about Feynman's work, but not a biography about his life. So this filled in a lot of blanks for me. But this wasn't a simple biography. Gleick took it upon himself to explain much of what Feynman was known for in physics, hence the need for dictionary, and Wikipedia, and other physic sources to be able to follow the book. What I liked about this biography besides the physics lessons, is that even though many works about Feynman discuss his humorous and intelligent sides, they don't discuss his problems in life, some of which he made. Everyone makes mistakes, and Feynman did too. I was surprised by how much original work Feynman did, but didn't rush to publish...so others were able to get ahead of him in several fields. That speaks a little to humility or insecurity on his part, which in science where it is publish or perish is kind of odd. Of course, odd would certainly describe Feynman, but for the most part it is a good odd. It did seem to me that his inability to obey the rules of polite society in the 50's and 60's ended up hurting him, more than it hurt others (though the women he 'used' may have disagreed).Like many in science, Feynman questioned everything. This can be both good and bad. It's great for getting new ideas in science, but when a person questions everything, that usually includes his self and his place in the world. It did sound like Feynman found some stability with his family later in his life. Even genius' need to connect with someone.A very good biography about a great man...even if he was fallible.
Beautifully made dress for little girls, definitely worth the cost.

It's been a while since I read a book on AIDS. I saw this book when I was getting other books on infectious disease, and put it aside for future reading. I had read "And the Band Played On" about 20 years ago, when I started working in a Lab on HIV. I knew so much had been found out concerning AIDS and where it came from. But much of this book was a surprise to me. I always felt that we didn't know the whole story about when AIDS actually started to infect the human race. The research that has been done in monkeys and apes, to determine the relationship between SIV which is simian immunodeficiency virus and HIV. Quammen provides a lot of background into what had previously been known and talked about. When I teach microbiology to my students I want to impress upon them the importance of knowing where these diseases come from. So many of the emerging diseases today are zoonoses, meaning they come from animals. Human invasion into habitats that used to rarely be seen by humans is introducing new viruses that some animals could live with, and others that were killers, no matter what the species.Quammen does a good job with the science. He obviously has a lot of practice in both the research and the writing. This book was incredibly interesting and definitely filled in gaps in my knowledge. I would recommend that readers be a bit familiar with AIDS before tackling this book. It assumes that the readers have a background in AIDS.
My grandson loved these shirts...and they are getting a lot of wear.

I enjoy for the most part writing by Alan Russell. I've read several of his books now, and he always has great plots in his mysteries. This was another good mystery, but was a very convoluted plot. It isn't always very clear what was happening, because the chapters would jump around quite a bit, using several third person voices. I don't mind this type of writing when you have a few people's voices...but when it goes to more than three voices, it tends to get a bit confusing at times, especially if you cannot see the tie-in between all these people. To tell you the truth, I got a little lost in this book a couple of times.The protagonist is a member of the paparazzo, a successful one, who unfortunately caused an accident that killed two very important celebrities. This accident weighs on Wells, the paparazzo, and leads him to rethink his career for a couple of years. Just when he gets back to taking photographs of celebrities again, two things occur that seem unrelated at first. He is approached by the CIA who uses knowledge of his accident to make him do jobs for them. Then on one of said 'jobs' he see a major actress attempt suicide, and he gets involved, and saves her life. Then everything starts unraveling with relentless force, and other people around both him and the actress are murdered. Wells needs to find out who is actually behind these deaths, and prevent his own death and the death of the actress with whom he has developed a relationship.One of the other problems I had with this book is a personal preference of mine. This book had a lot of salty language, more than any of Russell's books that I have read up til now. Lots of 'F' bombs. A couple I don't bother with. If the book has such language every few words, I don't finish the book. This wasn't like that, but it was more than I usually read. I know. Very prim of me. But I learned a long time ago that I don't really want that type of stuff crowding my mind, and those who speak like that have limited intelligence and language abilities. Because of my view on this, I will be a little loathe to get one of Russell's books again. I will try another one of his mysteries but if the language is like this, I probably won't read any more of his books. Which is too bad because he really is a good plotter.
Cute set of tiaras for little girls. Both the six year old and the nine year old immediately started playing with them...

Wow...two great books in a month! I didn't think I'd find another book comparable to The Emperor of All Maladies for a while. But I got very lucky and read Kean's book on the brain, and hit paydirt.I have 2 degrees in Neuroscience, and of course, read many, many textbooks while getting my degrees. I can honestly say that I don't think anyone has made this information on how the brain works, and the various things that can and do go wrong, as accessible as Kean has made it.Kean takes complicated information and he doesn't 'dumb' it down, he just presents it in an easily understood format, and with a significant amount of humor. He actually confirms my thinking that most textbooks are written for the peer group of the author, rather than to make concepts accessible to students. The book starts with cells and works up to the different lobes of the brain, and then continues on to the brain as a whole. In each section, Kean includes stories of people who undergo brain disorders, explaining how and why the brain is responding to trauma in this manner. Unlike in other textbooks or material that I've read concerning individuals with brain disorders, Kean doesn't deal with just the disorder, he deals with the person behind the disorder. One of the best sections in the book was on Phineas Gage, who accidentally blasted a tamping rod through his brain, in such a way that he caused damage to his emotional brain. Kean included more information on what happened to Gage than any other book I have read. Most other material simply repeats that this man went from being nice to being nasty, and Kean makes it clear that this simply isn't true. Gage managed to live another 12 years after his accident and for most of that time, was a working member of society.Kean deals with one of the biggest questions in neuroscience...that of where the physical presence of the brain ends, and where our 'mind' or consciousness and ego begin. With each little snippet of information, and studying people with brain disorders, we gain a little more insight into what makes each of us an individual. Writing such as Kean is doing on science topics make it so that everyone can know and understand the importance of the brain. Hopefully, when someone picks up a newspaper with information about the newest research in Alzheimer's or Parkinson's, they will be more likely to understand what is being discussed thanks to Kean's book.

I am going to say right upfront, this book is not written in the same great manner in which The Emperor of All Maladies was done. Bynum did a worthwhile presentation of tuberculosis. There was some history in it, some cases, a lot of medical information, just like there is in 'Maladies'. But it is presented way too dryly. And the author did not become intimately involved in her topic, which is what Mukherjee who wrote 'Maladies' did. He had a personal relationship with his cancer patients and it came across in his writing. There is no emotional involvement with this disease by the author, merely a recitation of facts that make up tuberculosis as an ailment.I'm not saying the book is not readable. Most of it was. At the end I was a little bored because it felt like the recitation of facts of how TB and AIDS are being handled today was worse than the other chapters prior to the final ones. And the thing is, I would have liked to read more personal histories about HIV/AIDS and TB, because I worked in an HIV lab for several years, and I'm from San Francisco.I think if people are going to write histories of diseases, they need to become a bit emotionally involved in their topic. Why are you writing this book? Merely to fill a gap in current knowledge? That's fine if you are writing to doctors and other medical personnel. But if you want to share information about a disease and how it impacts people for the public at large, you need to share stories, not just statistics.
Absolutely gorgeous dress for a little girl. Everyone who sees it loves it! Nicely made, more for summer, and maybe fall with a sweater.

I enjoyed this book on poisons. I read it for several reasons, one being that I teach microbiology, and often talk about bacterial and viral poisons, and I wanted more background. Unfortunately, like other reviewers have remarked, the book was not as consistent as it should have been. Lots of diverse stories, but they were all over the place...not in some type of logical order. This would have been a problem that a good publisher/editor could have corrected. The information and stories given captured the imagination, but with something like this that has a science background in it, you really need to have a good outline which puts everything in correct order. I definitely would have liked there to be a lot more science background on several of the topics. I love mixing history with science, as I find it to make things more interesting, and there was some of this going on in this book, but not enough to placate me.If a reader simply wants a lighter book for reading on poisons, this is fine. It doesn't require a vast intellect, and as many have previously stated, it's interesting.

This is now one of my all-time favorite books (not just medical books) that I have ever read. Dr. Mukherjee may be a cancer physician, but I really hope he continues to write, as his prose is such a beautiful thing, and his ability to explain scientific concepts in such a way as to make them totally accessible to the lay public. It's been so long since I read anything in the same class as this book. I had an absolutely awful time putting it down, even when I had classes to teach and grading to do. Usually I read several books at the same time, but this time, I read this book all the way through without bothering to look at anything else.Why did I pick this up? I've been teaching microbiology to nurses, and I knew that viruses often lead to cancer. I really wanted a better understanding of the science of how viruses can lead to cancer. I also had friends of my mom and dad who died with cancer back in the 1970's, especially breast cancer...and I wanted to know what, if anything has changed. I remember the declaration of the War on Cancer when I was a teenager, and it seems like we know significantly more thanks to genetics, but it also seems as if cancer has never given up holding the best 'hand'.Dr. Mukherjee did an incredibly job of intertwining the history of cancer with the ongoing story. Without the background half of what he explained would not have made such 'neat' sense. And the stories of his individual patients and those of other doctors, helps the reader remember the humanity behind this saga. I get the feeling Mukherjee is a great and caring doctor as well. And given the amount of death that must be seen in this field, it must be hard to keep that humanity without becoming cynical.I'm keeping this book...and will probably read it again.

Part of the reason I got the first book by Anne Perry is I had read a few of these years ago. I knew from previous experience that Perry wrote fairly decent mysteries, that were relatively clean because they happened in the far past. I have always loved good characterizations in my fictions. Perry does a more than adequate job in both characterizations and in doing the research to make the past come alive. I tend to want to read books in correct order that author's write them in because it helps you to learn about the characters as she/he meant you to learn about them.Perry's mysteries are not greatly complicated. This first one dealt with the meeting of inspector Pitt and Charlotte, who are the two protagonists in these stories. In spite of meeting due to a local series of murders, these two people are attracted to one another. Eventually the series of murders involves her own sister. This tragedy brings these two closer together, and Charlotte feels the need to get involved in solving her sister's murder. This puts her at high risk, and that of course, concerns Pitt.These are good books for light reading.

I'm not a big lover of mysteries and series that bring out a new book every Christmas. For one thing, it is hardly very Christmas to talk about murders. I like Russell's writing. He has a good sense of humor which you rarely see. This was a sweet story really. Nick Pappas, kind of a bad mood cop, who is in trouble with his place of work for some reason. In the meantime, he is asked by a friend to help with a problem in his mall. Apparently some robbers/thugs have been attacking shoppers on their way out of the mall. So they come up with the brainy idea of having Pappas serve as the mall Santa, to see if they can spy out who the culprits are.Pappas slowly gains some uninvited friends in the people he is hanging out with in the mall. He also learns to quit moping about his own problems, and learns what really counts. Not a deep book, but a quick and fun read, with lots of characterization and lots of humor.

I finished this book over a week ago, but wanted to have time to write a decent review. I've read some of Dugoni's legal procedurals and mysteries. So when I had this non-fiction account of an environmental legal case, I had no problems immediately clicking to get the book. It proved itself worthy of reading. I have read some other real cases of environmental pollution, and I teach environmental science and health occasionally. So this book was up my alley for several reasons. This case is about a man really, not a corporation or a company. Even though the guy set himself up as a corporation for a variety of reasons, it was really just him, and whoever he could pay to work for him. He was/is (since he is still alive I take it) was everything you don't want in a boss. Everything in his 'businesses' were for profit alone. He made no attempt to protect his workers, and he would close one business only to open another under a different name, in order to avoid responsibility. He declared bankruptcy several times, and this was his idea of doing business.What basically happened is this man sent unprotected workers into a tank that was full of cyanide, which is deadly. Since the book is about the investigation by various entities including the government. This was one of the first cases to go to court and be successfully sued for endangering the lives of the workers. The writing in this book was great, kept me on my toes until the very end, because it seemed as if the owner of the business with these dangerous tanks was going to get away with what boils down to attempted murder. I was thrilled that this guy ended up in prison for much longer than he thought he was going to get, but unfortunately due to his financial shenanigans, he has yet to pay the person he hurt the most (who was very badly hurt by the cyanide), any money. I feel bad for the injured young man and his family, because I'm sure they could use the money.Great and quick book to read...

I hadn't read a Charles Todd book for a while, and was in need of some 'light' reading. So I picked this one up. I always enjoy these books for the most part, but at Amazon.com before I bought the book, I saw a reader comment that the presence of Hamish in Detective Ian Rutledge's life is getting old. To an extent I agree with that reviewer, but not to the point where I don't think the book is worth reading. This plot device that Todd (mother and son writers) uses is actually quite unique in modern fiction, even if Shakespeare used it a bit. Now given, Todd is no Shakespeare, but I've read many books with significantly less characterization and less sensible plotting. Those two parts in novels are very important, at least to me. So I am more than willing to give these books a little leeway. People do not often totally overcome a mental illness (PTSD) in their lives...and back then in World War 1, there was little that could be done concerning what was called then 'shell-shock'. Therapy as it is known today was just beginning to be used, and there was little in the way of medication. So that ghost, Hamish, might be around for a while. Maybe once in a while they might make things a little less dark?Rutledge does manage to meet a new woman, someone who a bit clairvoyant. She recognizes his problems from the war, but does not delve into his private problems at first Rutledge seems to have a stalker, who at first is simply mysterious. But later the stalking becomes dangerous to life, and he has to figure out both an attempted murder of a police officer, as well as deal with this new private problem...

I like Alan Russell's psychological thrillers. Most of his writings are very well done with great characters in the books This book was no different. This was rather a dark read, about the son of a serial murderer. I didn't read the synopsis well before I grabbed this book. I had read some of Russell's other books and enjoyed them quite a lot. This book was definitely a little bit more 'deep' as well as dark, than some of his other books. This is due to the topic. Years ago, I got on a bit of a true crime kick, trying to understand the psychological underpinnings of serial murderers. Luckily it didn't last long. I didn't want to spend any more time on those type of people...it was a more of a curiosity thing on my part. But coming into this book which was fictional, it was obvious that Russell did some research on both how these criminals work, their psychology, and also into those people who may write about serial murderers. (Most of the books I read about serial murderers were from FBI profilers.)This book was rough for me to get through. It had a great premise...about what happens to the families that are left behind from a serial murderer. Many of them do have families, and like most people, I never stopped to think about those people.This book had two protagonists, the writer of the book about the original Shame serial killer, and his son, who had to deal with his fallout after he was put to death. The writer was the one person who survived Shame, and literally lived to tell the tale. But though Shame is dead, another group of women are being killed the same way as Shame had done, and they are being made to look like the son is the main suspect. The son asks for the writer's help in proving he is not the killer, and both of them end up in the sights of the murderer.This is a really good story. The language was rougher than I usually like my fiction, but then I'm probably a rarity as concerns this...

I finished reading this one a while ago, but I forgot to write a review for it. I used to get Discover Magazine. I think my parents bought it for me for a while as a gift. I enjoyed it immensely but I try not to put more 'paper' around the house for me to have to throw out. Anyway, the first articles I would always read Vital Signs. I teach nurses and pre-med students so these articles were a pull for me. But the writing and the compassion in these articles by active medical personnel make for outstanding reads. I really enjoy learning about uncommon or unusual medical cases. So I was thrilled to see that they had put these into a book format. I had missed not reading these on a monthly basis. Any person can learn a lot about medicine and the profession. Oftentimes, people jumped to judgement, even doctors do that. See a horse, and not recognize the 'zebra' in front of their face. My students are required to do case studies anyway, and this book is loaded with great ones, that make them think a bit. Broaden their critical thinking skills (and mine!).

When I was in med school for neuroscience, I took some classes on public health. That class started my love of case studies. Books like this one, are very good at teaching using case studies. Besides that, the stories are just plain fascinating. Meador has written other books that I enjoyed very much, so I knew I would enjoy his discussions of medical cases that were not the obvious. It helps that he is not only a physician, but finds the cases of others interesting as well. He writes in an intelligent way. And these books make it so clear, that physicians and nurses need to listen to their patients. It's easy to dismiss what people may say about their own health, but that often causes problems with their care. I had a good doctor who took the time to listen to his patients. When in medical school I saw too many physicians-to-be who thought all they had to do was use the technology available to them, without listening to their patients. And what happens if someday, we lose our power grids due to natural or manmade disaster? Will these guys be able to diagnose their patients then?This is an art that with all the technology we are quickly losing. Can doctors look at nail beds and eyes, and see the signs that are there for them to see? Books like this one help to emphasize the need for doctors and all medical personnel to get back to basics.

This book took me a while to get through. Not because the writing was bad. On the contrary, considering the sheer amount of military information that Tuchman had to deliver about the first month of World War I, the book was immensely readable. For some reason I'm fascinated by the fiasco that was WWI. I've been reading a variety of books from different viewpoints concerning the war. It isn't just the battles that I am interested in. I'm interested in the characters and personalities of the men (and some women) who led the world into this war, and those who led the armies.Tuchman's ability to paint pictures with words was significantly more helpful than the photographs were. I think one of the things that Tuchman made clear, was how old all the men were who were leading at this point. I think that was a huge part of the problem. These men were still stuck in the 19th century, with the old ways of doing battle. Technology advancements had brought in cars, planes, huge cannon like Big Bertha, and machine guns that mowed through men, like slicing soft cheese with a knife. These changes made the concepts of throwing massive numbers of men into battle with little or no protection not just archaic, but monstrous. Yet the old men from Germany, France, and England cared nothing for men as individuals...but only for national honor as they perceived it. This is what made this war so absolutely Ludacris.Tuchman gave a lot of information about these men, and what made them tick. She provided so much from personal letters from these men, as well as later information written or supplied by these men. A dry recitation of the battles would not have sufficed. Tuchman's ability to weave the stories of that month beginning WWI into a cohesive whole, that leaves the reader with more understanding about the 'whys' as well as the 'where' and the 'who'.I know there are flaws in this book that was written fifty years ago. That's going to happen when more information comes out over the years. And though some readers/researchers were bad-mouthing Tuchman about her slant concerning miscalculation driving the war, to an extent it was true. She was writing about the first month of the war, not what started the whole thing. Anyone who has read a lot of books about WWI knows about Sarajevo. Maybe Tuchman should have made it clearer that she assumed the readers entering into her book already knew about some of the factors that led up to the war. Sarajevo was certainly one, but it was merely the excuse for the whole thing, and there are other factors as or more important than Sarajevo.In any group of books that concentrate on a single topic, there are books that are so important to read to increase the understanding of the topic, that they cannot be overlooked. Tuchman's book on WWI is one of these. It is also one of the most enjoyable histories that I've read in a long time.

This was a great book on the Middle ages. Starr did his research for this one, and it showed in the book. I'm sure murder and mayhem happened quite a bit during medieval times. Death was more taken for granted, and less than a shock than it often is now. Between plagues, accidents, lack of food or health care...life was usually short and hard. It's amazing that lives were still lived, children were born, people were most definitely closer to the God, and even art was accomplished. I think if most of us were thrust back in that time period, we die from discouragement and desperation.The history in this tale actually made up a significant part of the reason I gave this four stars. I love history with anything. I use history in all my science classes to make the science more applicable and memorable. Good history in a mystery like this keeps my attention. I appreciate the research the author does. A young man who is not the inheritor of his father's estate, Hugh de Singleton, decides to become a surgeon. He starts his practice in Oxford, but comes to the attention of a local lord, who asks him to become involved when the skeleton of a woman is found in the castle's cess pit. First thing, is to find out who is missing from where. In a day, when forensics has not even been thought of yet, Hugh must use his powers of observation and deduction to figure out what ends up being not just one murder, but several.This is a highly enjoyable, and 'safe' book. What I mean by safe, is there isn't bad language in this book, or a lot of sex. I personally don't enjoy either of those in books all the time. If there is too much of either, I'm liable to put the book away. If that makes me a prude, so be it. I just choose not to clog up my mind with unnecessary crap.If that's your preference this looks like the series for you. Like I said, great history, good mystery makes for a fun mix.

This was such a sweet story. When I was growing up, and dealing with bullies because I was Deaf and going to a public school, I'd go to the library and load up on books. Many times they were fairy tales, myths, and fantasy. I've never lost that love of being taken by a book and dropped into another existence. This book did just that. The story of two sisters who are dealing with changes in their lives is something that many sisters go through, with simply growing up. In this case, one sister is becoming a beautiful mermaid, and if she doesn't reach the ocean in time, she will die.In the process of taking her sister to the ocean, the other sister, Clara, travels with her 'pretend brother'. They have numerous adventures involving a traveling circus, and striving to keep Maren, the mermaid, alive. I love their pet dragon, who seems to be a dog with wings. He's very loyal, and comes to the rescue when they need him to.The narrative nature of this story was a bit awkward, but the story and the characters made up for it. My only complaint was the constant negative attitude by Clara...she seems to have a big problem with hoping.Younger teens, and even pre-teens will enjoy this book. I certainly did...

Been reading more novels that are obviously for teenagers thanks to some of the books like The Hunger Games, which have proven so popular. This book had a great premise...a young girl finds out from her grandmother (who she has just met) that she has inherited the ability to travel in time. Her grandmother also has this ability. This girl, Kate, has already had inklings that something is different in her life, because she is seeing changes, and running into people at times when she seems to be having 'flashes' of insights. Not quite dreams, but before her grandmother explains them, Kate doesn't know what is going on. Eventually, one of the changes is Kate's mother and father disappear in the world she currently inhabits, due to changes being made in the past.Something happened to Kate and her family way back in the 1800s around the time of the World Fair in Chicago, that her grandmother wants Kate to go back and change what happened to save their family. But the Chicago Fair turned out to be dangerous for a lot of women due to the presence of a real man, named Holmes, turned a hotel into a serial murderer's playground.Good ideas, right. The problem is with the author. This was one of the most irregular books I've read for a while. There was almost no explanation before the author plunged us into Kate's strange world. The writing was uneven, and like one reviewer said, there was too much dialogue and not enough background or characterization. The Hunger Games were extremely well-written books. This book was not.I know she is writing for teens, but even teens should be exposed to the absolute best writing. Adolescents do not get enough of a good education in anything, including writing. So when they go to read these very popular teen fantasies, which I want them to do (I'm a professor), I want them to have the very best. I'm sure some teens will enjoy this book anyway. But the characterization was weak (I never got a picture in my mind of any of the characters), and the plot was jerky, and the dialogue was often annoying...I will not continue to read any of the other books from this series.

Russell is a new author for me. I read one of his later books, and decided to dive in and get this first book about Michael Gideon, and his great dog, Sirius (love the name for the dog). I have always had a very close relationship with my dogs, and I love reading about the relationship that exists between these two. I know that most cops who do K-9 work are unusually close to their animals, The need for not only respect but also trust is paramount to keeping both partners safe. Just recently in Pittsburgh, where I live, a beloved canine put himself at risk to keep his partner safe, and he paid for it with his life. Pittsburgh was devastated...not just his officer. Because of his death, special vests were bought to protect these beloved dogs.I love the way Russell writes. The books read too fast for me...I want them to keep going. Fire engulfs Michael's life. It not only burns him physically, but it also haunts his dreams. He cannot seem to leave behind the horrific incident where Michael caught a serial killer, but almost lost his partner, Sirius, in the process. When Michael finally comes back to work, he is placed in a special situation by the head of the police. He is to take on cases that require a different take. Even Michael isn't quite sure what he is supposed to be doing. But he gets a couple of cases that require finesse and a lot of heart, one concerning a baby who is left to die, and another where a young man is found on a running trail hanging from a crucifix. Michael and Sirius need to find the truth behind these cases, while still dealing with their own ongoing problems.An immensely readable book. I am looking forward to more books from this author! If I could give this book a half a star, it would be four and a half stars.

This turned out to be a very sweet book. My mother used to read Catherine Hyde's books, I think, so I was familiar with her name. The premise of the book almost floored me at the beginning, because her protagonist, August is taking the summer to travel in his RV with his dead son's ashes. The RV breaks down, and the man who is fixing his RV asks August to take his sons for the summer, out of the blue. The mechanic, Wes, is going into jail for 3 months, and needs someone to take his boys because he has no one else.As a mother, the thought of sending your kids with an unknown man is asking for trouble, and no one in their right mind would ask a stranger that! It took me a little while to get into the book, to even accept that anyone in this world would even consider that. Any good parent that is. But Wes obviously isn't the best parent, or he wouldn't be going to jail for another DUI.Once the story gets going, it is an incredible story of loss and gain, of learning to care about others, and of growing up and growing wiser. Hyde is a good writer. Her prose is straight-forward and honest. It's hard to remember sometimes that there are good people in the world, who try to do the right things...sometimes for the wrong reasons, but then it turns out to be right anyway. This book makes you stop and think about your choices in the world, and to put your priorities in the correct place. Many times when we do that we have a positive impact on others who we would normally not have come in contact with.An enjoyable book...I will probably look at her books more closely in the future.
This did not load...

I've seen that other reviewers had good things to say about this book, which is part of the reason I was incredibly disappointed in it. I enjoy a good historical novel occasionally. One reviewer compared the book to Caleb Carr's historical mysteries which I adored, and then to Eric Larson's histories which are not fiction...This author does not compare well to either of them. The language and the writing of this book did not compare well. He isn't of a sufficient literary bent or has the background needed for the excellent writing in the previous two authors. But I could have swallowed writing that was not the best, if the story and the characters were decent. I actually had to make myself finish the book, which for me is rare. I've read some on Nellie Bly and Emma Lazarus and I went to refresh some of my historical knowledge of these two. I'm sure the author did his research for this story. But it felt contrived, which historical fiction can do if not done right. But the biggest problem I had with the entire book was giving our current morals in 2015 to something that occurred in 1880s-1890s. I am not nave enough to believe that lesbians did not exist then, nor that there were not loose morals in the Victorian era. But, to have all the characters act the way we do currently is not in keeping with that strait-laced society. They were private back then, much more than we are now. And women did not flaunt differences as much as they do now.This is not a 'bad' book, and I'm sure some readers will enjoy it. But it played fast and loose with the time period and the mores of that time period, and for that reason I did not enjoy it.

I was very tempted to give this book 4 stars, instead of 5 like I did, mainly because of the 'stridency' of the author. I do not disagree with the author's point of view. In fact, as a rubella baby from the 1950's who managed to get measles, mumps, and other infectious diseases during the '60s which are not seen any more thanks to vaccines, and as a professor who teaches nurses and pre-med students, I have my own reasons for being horrified that the U.S. and other civilized countries are losing their 'herd immunity' due to people not vaccinating their children.I immediately knew how strongly the author felt concerning anti-vaccinators and the fake scientists who were spreading junk and bad science about the vaccines. The Title of the book, and some of the information concerning the book, did make it obvious what the book was going to be about, but the author was almost rabid in his opinions. I totally understood his impatience with these people who have ears, 'but do not hear' as the scriptures say. Normally, I try to avoid books that enter into a discussion that seems one-sided, but I wanted to read a book on this topic that provided all the necessary research, that Mr. Mnookin did. The amount of research that he included in this book from all areas involved in this current health crisis was phenomenal. I appreciated that he did all of the research and provided where that information came from.
