I'm planning on looking into some of the research farther.I get so frustrated sometimes with people who choose not to get their children vaccinated. I understand the worry that parents go through concerning autism. I had three children, and I got them all vaccinated because I didn't want them to go through what I did due to these diseases. I have 6 grandchildren, and I also have a nephew that is high-functioning Asperger's. But the doctors who started this, Wakefield and others, were not doing correct experimental and objective science. They went into their 'studies' already decided on their hypothesis, and you just don't do that. I worked in labs on Alzheimer's and HIV for 6 years. You do not decide what you are going to find in your work prior to doing the experiments. You certainly do not allow money to influence your findings, and this is what these doctors did. Wakefield and company should be ashamed of themselves, because of their greed, children throughout the world continue to die needlessly.Mnookin did express compassion for the parents of those children suffering from autism. I feel for them too. My sister's son is great, we love him a lot, and he's smart and a good kid. But his parents struggled all of his childhood to get him adequate medical care, and social learning. And we all worry about him. So I can't imagine what other parents are going through with children who are much worse off than my nephew. I understand the need parents have to find someone or something to blame for this autism crisis. But too many of them are being blind to the truth, and some of them are putting their children at increased risk of invasive medical care just to somehow prove their point. You do not put a child through a medical procedure such as drawing spinal fluid needlessly. I've been through that...it's extremely painful, and you only do it as an adult if you are trying to rule out something like cancer. I certainly would never put a child through it if you can avoid it.I'm Deaf due to rubella. We've gotten so far away from these diseases, that current parents have no idea what kind of damage they caused. I also have numerous autoimmune diseases from undergoing exposure to these viruses 'naturally'. I read inn Mnookin's book that parents and some doctors say natural exposure to measles, mumps and rubella is better than the vaccines. Are they nuts? I want to tell these people to talk to me and other rubella babies that have been through so much due to natural exposure to these diseases. Believe me, if they listened to me they wouldn't be in such a hurry to expose their kids!This is a necessary addition to the writings on the state of vaccination in the world. Hopefully, more people will read it and do the right thing by their children. Their kids will thank them for it.
I'm so addicted to this game. I love trivia, and I play this with my friends and family in between everything else. Loads of fun, and I learn a lot as well.

I actually finished reading this book quite a while ago. I just forgot to write a review. I really enjoy Dugoni's legal thrillers. He's an excellent writer, and I only gave him four stars instead of five because I preferred one of his other books to this one. David Sloane, a top-notch attorney, is recovering from the loss of his wife. In the midst of his work on previous cases, he comes across a very smart, attractive defending attorney who was against him on one of those cases. She quickly becomes involved in his life, almost too quickly. Then Sloane finds out that this woman is being targeted for her work in bringing down a drug trafficker who managed to kill her daughter. When a trafficker is found murdered, she becomes a suspect, and asks Sloane to represent her in court.Sloane seems to be a bit oblivious to this woman's agenda, but the people who work for him and even his step-son are growing wise to possible problems in the case, and in this woman's involvement in Sloane's life. Sloane is forced to separate his personal life from the case, and look at what is really going on before it is too late.Great summer read, very smart, with lots of intelligence.

This was a really poignant book, about a family that is falling apart. It's a legal thriller, and the author obviously knows what he is talking about. A 14-year old is found murdered, and at first, there seems to be no suspects. But then the police zone in on the son of the prosecutor who went to the same school as the victim. The victim apparently bullied the prosecutor's son, and the case seems to be circumstantial at first, but more disturbing information comes out as the case goes on.This book brings up several important topics. How would we handle it if family member's are charged with a crime? Can we be supportive and face reality, or will we be blind to possibilities?The ending I wasn't really prepared for. And I don't want to wreck other readers enjoyment of this book by telling any more than I already have. Needless to say, this was a very smart book that makes you stop and think about our justice system, and about what we know about our family members.

Ugh...I hate it when I am recommended books, and they turn out to be huge disappointments. First off, from the reviews that I read, I thought this was a mystery. I guess it will remain a mystery to me, because I got through 2/3rds of the book and deleted it from my Kindle. I absolutely hate books that are supposed to be one thing, and turn out to be really another genre. This tried to be a mystery and a romance, and it was boring the heck out of me about 1/4 of the way through. It wasn't particularly well-written. Then to top it off it decided to veer into a topic that I avoid at all costs. It started to be about child molestation.No thanks. I don't need to waste my mind or my time with that type of crap. I usually read about 4 books at a time. Three of them were nonfictions, biographies, or science...and I read fiction for enjoyment. That topic doesn't constitute enjoyment (or shouldn't), and certainly didn't provide anything I could learn from. I know this stuff exists, but I don't need to fill my mind with such things as that...nobody does.Definitely will not be reading her again! And will be a bit more careful about the 'reviews' in the future...

Oh boy...I love Ransom Riggs' books. They are so incredibly unusual. The cleverness of his plots and his pictures (black and white ones with a mystery about how he got or made them!)...just when you think that someone cannot come up with a totally different plot, someone like ransom comes along. Even though the protagonists in this story are children, the book is not for children. I'm sure that teenagers enjoy this book, but the writing is actually geared towards adults. Bring in a topic like World War II (which the children go back between earlier times and 1940), and most children and teens will be unfamiliar with this time period. I read all kinds of books, and when these books come up recommended to me, it's less teen-related, than it is fantasy.This second book by Riggs is just as well-written as his first book. Jacob, an American boy is helping the 'peculiar' children flee from the hollowgasts (monsters) and the wights (who are Peculiars that have changed to bad beings). Each of the children have a special ability, that makes them  peculiar. But in this book, Jacob is finding out more about himself as well as the other children. He doesn't want to recognize that he is special in ways as well. He only thinks he is helping the peculiars because they helped his grandfather, and needs to pay back that debt.I don't want to ruin anyone else's read by telling more about the plot line. As other reviewers have said, this book is dark and deep in some places. Somewhat along the lines of Tolkien's books, this book uses the war and the differences of the children to talked about ideas such as discrimination and the importance of being different. So this book should not be read by very young children, and this is a book that can be read and talked about with teens and others about the themes in it, and what they mean.Terrific read, and I'm going to have a hard time waiting for the next book in the series.

I went and got this second book from Dugoni, after I read My Sister's Grave. I actually enjoyed this book more than that one even though it was pretty good. Dugoni has a very crisp writing style which goes well with legal thrillers. In this book, his protagonist, David Sloane, is not involved in court. His 16-year stepson is acting out due to his mother's murder, so Sloane decides to take him on a Father-son camping outing with friends. They pick the wrong town to stop in before going to the woods. The son Jake, decides to pull a criminal stunt with the younger boy he is with, and gets them both arrested. This puts them into a system, where the judge quickly puts them into a rehabilitative program for boys, without providing them with lawyers or even a chance to talk to their parents/guardians. The program turns out to be less than rehabilitative, and more a place where boys are abused and used as slave labor. Sloane and his friend, whose son was also convicted in a illegal court situation, are determined to help their boys get out of this place at any means necessary. And since the court and the police are equally determined to retain these boys, this means Sloane must work undercover to prove the authorities in this town are up to no good.Many people will pass this story off as 'fiction', but unfortunately, this did happen in Eastern PA, where judges and lawyers conspired to put both young boys and girls into a private detention facility for kickbacks. These guys were caught and put behind bars for over 20 years, but not until they ruined the lives of many children and teenagers. So in this case, reality became fiction. I'm sure it isn't the first time something like this has happened in the U.S. But I can understand how frightened parents must be for their children when trapped in a situation like, let alone how the kids feel.If you enjoy thrillers, this is definitely a great book. The plot is excellent, and Dugoni does a better job in characterization than many of authors do who write books like this. The characters are more believable and three dimensional, than in many mysteries.

If I could have given this book another half a star, I would. It's been a while since I've read a mystery/procedural that I could really enjoyed as much as I did this one, Guardians of the Night. It was very refreshing to read a book about a cop whose constant companion is his German Shepherd. So there are actually two protagonists to this story, the cop Detective Michael Gideon, and his police dog, Sirius. They have a closer relationship with each other, than anyone else in Gideon's life. It's interesting to watch the author develop the 'personalities' of both the man and the dog. I thought it was great, because each dog has individual personalities, and the relationship p between a man and his dog are always different.In this book, a 'bum' sees what he perceives as an angel to be killed. Gideon is usually assigned to cases that are not run of the mill, and originally he is skeptical, but after he meets the homeless man...he feels there is more to the story. As he digs, first the homeless man is killed, and then he finds films from the area the 'angel' died in, and they all were filled with static at that specific time period. The farther Gideon digs, the more questions are raised. Someone had a hand in killing this 'angel', and they become irate that Gideon is digging into their business.My biggest complaint of this book, was the author did not totally resolve what the 'angel' was. It actually becomes part of the plot, and I understand that, but it kind of leaves the reader not totally satisfied. But for the most part, I really enjoyed this book. The writing was good, and Gideon and his dog make for a different and enjoyable duo. I will definitely pick up books about this duo in the future!

What a terrific biography! I read so much of Twain when I was taking literature the first time I went to college. We also had to read him in high school, but I don't think I appreciated him back then. I would suggest to literature teachers to recommend this biography to students who are studying him, because it really helped to understand his writings. Powers so easily entwined Twain's writings in this book, and all the letters he wrote to so many people really made a huge difference in understanding the man. Twain was a complicated guy. He was funny, irreverent, cynical, and in spite of all this, he was a man who was a wonderful husband. His relationships with other people besides his wife, were less easy to nail down. His daughters worshipped him, he had some good friends that thought the world of him, while he kind of took them for granted. He was absolutely terrible to his brother, who he thought was a wimp. Powers brings all of this information and insight into Twain/Clemens into such a readable whole book, that many times, I was loathe to put the thing down. I actually was grateful to getting sick, so I would have an opportunity to finish the whole book.Powers doesn't gloss over the bad things that Clemens did or said. But he really made it clear through the book how much the author thought and felt for this unusual man. Powers gives so much background that explains why Samuel Clemens was the kind of person he was...I really need to go back and read some of his writings over again, to understand his books from what I know now.Too bad he isn't here now. We could certainly use his humor and his honesty in our politics and our foolish preoccupation with 'celebrities'. Even though he was very much a celebrity in his time, and he enjoyed being one, I think he would make short shrift of our current world, and put many people back in their rightful place!

Hmmm...I have mixed feelings about this book. I can totally understand why teens love it. I have been reading quite a few books this year that were really for teens. Partly because I remember really good literature from when I was growing up that I read such as L'Engle's Wrinkle in Time, and I first read Lord of the Rings back as a teenager. I really enjoyed other books such as The Book Thief, and I read all of the Hunger Game books. Because I'm Deaf, I prefer to read books first before I see the movie, but my granddaughters wanted to see the movie, so I was actually reading the book at the same time as when I saw the movie. As per usual, I thought the book was slightly better than the movie, although they really took the dialogue right from the book. The book gave more to the imagination than the movie did.So what bothers me about the book? Part of it is the fact that I got a strong feeling the book was actually written with a movie in mind.. Books like the ones I mentioned above, stand well alone...they don't seem to be written for a movie. Even the Hunger Games, which we have all been seeing and hearing about for several years now (and the Harry POtter series), the writing is really good in these books. We will have to see what the future brings, but I think the books I've mentioned will continue to draw readers for years, while this book will not stand the test of time. The writing just isn't there in this book. It is not a great piece of literature. It was written to sell.That's kind of too bad, because the topic is one that should be explored. Children and teens are not supposed to die of cancer. But they do, and their stories should be told. But I don't like tear jerkers usually, I don't choose to read those along with my science, and history, and classics. I would probably recommend the book to teens to read if this is the kind of stuff they like, but it wouldn't be my first choice.

After seeing the last case of Poirot on PBS, I felt I had to read some of Agatha Christie's books on him. I'd read some of her other mysteries when I was young, but wanted to remind myself of her writing abilities. She was very good at writing clever mysteries. Her language is impeccable, as are her ideas or plots. In this book she introduced one of her most famous protagonists, Mr. Poirot. He is totally unique in English writing, not the usual good-looking man who is solving criminal cases in a hurry. Poirot doesn't hurry. He takes his time, and makes sure that everything is in place so he can nail the criminals responsible. Poirot has his companion, Captain Hastings, who is not quite as smart as he is. But Hastings is his wall that he can bounce his ideas off of.In this mystery, Hastings and Poirot are staying with a friend of Hastings, whose stepmother was just murdered. Poirot starts investigating, using his grey cells to determine who was capable of murdering this woman. Several people staying at Styles are possible culprits including her own stepsons, the wife of one of the son's, a young woman named Cynthia who seemed to be a companion of the older woman, and an unknown doctor who seems entirely too friendly with the wife. This first book starts while World War 1 is still raging, and Christie paints a picture of what life was in England during that period.Now that I've started with this book, and enjoyed her writing again, I think I will be getting more of her works. I love the ambiance of the books. A great way to spend a cold day...

I really enjoyed this book. I have a granddaughter a lot like this 17 year old girl, who is trying to make sense of her life. My granddaughter has a mother, but life hasn't been easy for her, like it hasn't been easy for Molly, the 17 year old. We all wish that our kids and grandkids would meet someone like this older woman, Vivian, who in spite of her age, had a similar hard time growing up which Molly could relate to.I knew about orphan trains, and I figured many children experienced horrors or difficult times. I'm sure there were stories such as this one. Both Molly and Vivian are vital protagonists to this story, and their story being entwined was beautiful. I think young people should be introduced to older people because they would be surprised at the stories they have to tell about their lives.My only complaint about this book, was the ending was bit too fast, and wrapped up in too neat a bow. It felt not quite right, even though Vivian is introduced to family members she thought she had lost. Other reviewers mentioned being left with wanting more. The book felt slightly unfinished to me.Otherwise it was a very good read with an interesting plot.

Collins books involving Katniss, have been a wonderful break from my usual reading of science and history. I enjoy a lot of genres, but these 'young adult' books have been so enjoyable because they were well-written and really made you think. I usually try to read books before I've seen the movies, and most of the time, I find the book is better than the movies. I thank heaven that the movies really have tried to stay true to the book, and also for the great computer skills of the people working on the films, that allow them to make the 'world' that surround Katniss. And they found a great person to play Katniss...I can't see anyone else playing that part.I've been thinking about this book since I finished it. I was talking to my teenage granddaughter about it, and my husband. These books are almost scary because of what I'm seeing about the world and politics in real life. Like Orwell, Collins is describing a world of the future, but some of that future is here, and I find that appalling. I know this book is being read at schools, and I hope that teachers bring up the fact that science fiction like this oftentimes comes true. A good percent of science fiction from people like Jules Verne and HG Wells, have already become 'real' in our lifetime. So books like these act as warnings of what will happen if we are not careful.Definitely worth the read...I read it in two days straight, even with grading finals!

I didn't like this as much as I thought I would. It sounds more like those Irish singers on PBS all the time, especially this one voice...and it is a little high frequency for my enjoyment. I prefer deeper voices...so this is a personal preferences. A lot of this sounded the same to me.
Beautiful music for the season. Much of this was choral, and it was exquisite. The 2 set CD makes for a lot of music.

Even though the whole series is great, this book wasn't quite as good as the other two of the series. It served to provide more filler for the story...and introduce us to new people who will be important later on. Katniss is unfortunately pulled back into another Capitol game because President Snow feels she is becoming too powerful, as a face of the discontent of the districts. Katniss tries to do the best she can to calm things down in fear that President Snow will take retribution on the people she cares about. But everything she does makes things worse.We learn more about people close to her in this book, and that is important to the third book. The new Games are just as atrocious as the first ones Katniss is in, but she gains some allies who seem to be intent on rescuing both her and Peeta rather than killing them. She doesn't quite understand why, but they help her to understand how the new Games are working.There is a lot more explaining in this book, and though it is exciting and necessary, it didn't have the drive of the other two books. But it's absolutely necessary to the story.I'm amazed at how close they made the movies to the books. It's certainly a bonus to have computer graphics that can mimic the imagination...

Such a beautiful book. That's two books on WWII that I've read this year that were historical fictions, that brought to life more about the German side of the story. We forget in blaming the Germans for the things that Hitler and his cronies did, that many Germans were simply caught up in a disaster, not of their making. And certainly the children were mislead by the adults, and had no choice in the matter. There were several threads in this story, about a young orphan with remarkable skills in electronics who is forced to perform for his country, despite his inclinations towards being good. He sees both the horror of war, and the brutality...and tries to block it out with his science. He also sees some beauty, in the ocean he eventually is introduced to, and a young blind girl who he meets very shortly.Another thread is about the young blind girl from France, who is forced with her father to leave their home in Paris. He is entrusted with a package from the museum he worked for, and is asked to protect. They flee to a small port in Southern France, where the girl meets an uncle who is damaged from WWI, and who becomes her protector when she loses her father.The stories of the people who surround these two protagonists, is a story seen in times of war...of loss, of redemption, of forgiveness, and of courage and empathy for others. Doerr writes in such a way to draw the stories together as a quilt or collage. HIs use of words is some of the most gorgeous prose I've read in a long time, especially writing about something that is so horrendous as WWII.I hope to read more from this author in the future...if you have the time, read this book.

Excellent book on the battle to conquer strept. We don't think a whole lot about strept now. When our kids get sick with this bug/microbe it usually causes a sore throat. This is what doctors test for. But in my grandmother's time, streptococcus of any kind could kill you. Streptococcus infections caused sepsis, wound infections, and if it traveled from the throat to the heart, it could cause rheumatic fever. I know about this because my grandmother ended up with it.The Germans were the first to find something that would work on streptococcus. Before antibiotics existed sulfa drugs were used. This is the story of the research done by Bayer and other companies in Germany to find something that would prevent the many deaths seen during war time from disease. For the most part, during both the Civil War and World War 1 (and the other small wars in between these years) more men died from disease, including gangrene and wound infections, than died from bullets. So the race was on among all countries including Great Britain, France, and Germany to find something that could cure men of disease, and get them back to the fronts. This of course, was of more concern than civilian deaths. Streptococcus was also known to cause puerperal fever in women who were delivering children. This was another huge concern for many doctors.This race to find a drug that would help prevent infections led to some of the typical fiascos seen in the science community. These men are very competitive, especially when other countries are known to be searching for the same thing. These competitions mean that mistakes will be made, usually someone's feelings will get hurt due to being ignored when awards are given, jealousy runs rampant, etc. All of those things happened here in this story.What's interesting isn't just the research done, and the men involved, but how short the use of sulfa drugs actually was. We still use some sulfa drugs, such as sulfonamide, but it is known that many of the antibiotics we currently use are causing resistance among bacteria. So it might come to the point we will need to use more sulfa drugs again in the future.Interesting story...

This was another decent mystery/police procedural by Jance. Beaumont is trying to figure out who killed a coach. The man left behind a pregnant wife, but it seems that he is not a perfect husband. Beau hates to think that his wife had something to do with his murder.One thing that separates Jance's books stand separate from many other series, is that the books can stand by themselves outside of the series. If you pick one up from the middle of the series you will still enjoy the book, and find out enough about the characters to have a good idea what type of people they are. I love Jance's character development. That's a major reason why I continue to read this series. Beau has been through a lot as far as personal life is concerned, but he has a great partner (who is constantly nagging him about what he eats), and he also has an inherited lawyer who has turned into a great friend. Jance always puts in more stories of their interaction with one another, as well as with the crime being solved, and it makes the books read very quickly.Good read.

This book was not what I expected, but it turned out to be a really good book. When I picked it up, I thought it was a book simply on tuberculosis and the spread of the disease, and the eventual cure. This book was about that, to an extent, but it was more on specific scientists involved in working on tuberculosis (Pasteur and Koch), and how scientists worked to find the thing causing tuberculosis. It was also about the mistakes scientists make, when blinded by other things such as ego and greed. This was a great history about the new fields of bacteriology, microbiology, and epidemiology. Even Conan Doyle makes an appearance in this history...people forget that Doyle was a physician first, before he became a well-known writer.I teach microbiology. Of course, both Koch and Pasteur are brought up in all my textbooks for the great work they both did. But I had never read about the competition between the two men, which helped to drive their work, but it also caused Koch to make huge mistakes in his research for a vaccine for tuberculosis. The research was impeccable, and the writing was good for such a dry subject. I'm always looking for more books like this to help make my classes more interesting. A little bit of history with the science, makes it go down easier, and much easier for my students to remember!

The din of spirited discussion during a case study in training is music to my ears. It means the participants are involved, energized and learning on their own while I am only showing them the way.The only problem is getting their attention to wrap up the exercise and dissolve the buzz group. Even though I'm told I sound like John Wayne, pilgrim, sometimes the din of voices become the same as a runaway beer wagon, and regaining control requires several waves and yodels.Enter my imitation, genuine, authentic, certified London Bobby Police Whistle, which I thought would alert my classes that there had been another Jack the Ripper murder and would be poorly received, wasn't. It actually worked for the first time yesterday and today. It wasn't so loud that they had to cover their ears, but it was loud enough to regain their attention without recurring screams.The whistle worked like a charm, and I highly recommend it for training.

I wish I could endorse this product, but as a city employee holding the civil service title of Administrative Staff Analyst, I cannot.The test that I took had topics that this book does not have e.g math and grammar which is likely to comprise approximately 20% of the test.The math is simply grammar school level of percents, fractions and decimals with questions that might require your knowledge of "please excuse my dear aunt sally." There will be some questions on quantitative analysis and budget with some percentiles thrown in.As far as grammar goes, any grammar book might help including Strunk and White's, "The Elements of Style."This study guide has no information on the in-basket exercise which is sure to perplex the most analytical mind. The in-basket exercise is likely to contain several pages of rules on which a number of questions will be based e.g. John Doe is an associate staff analyst with 265 hours of annual leave and 70 hours of accrued sick leave when he is deployed to Afghanistan in April 2013 and doesn't return until the end of May 2014. According to the rules, he accrued X days of annual leave per month according the rules of deployment, and Y number of sick leave hours per month as a Tier 4 employee. How many of each does he have at the end of June 2014? The distracters are very close and require scrutiny.  I recommend you try reading the question first, then look up the rule pertaining to the question, rather than spending the time reading all the rules before reading the questions, because that will be a time well wasted.This book offers a number of tests that require deduction, comprehension and general knowledge that will be beneficial to anyone taking a test. However, I believe the test-taker will be shocked to learn what the complexity of the questions on the actual test that are not in the book. As another reviewer noted, there is no explanation for what they list as the correct choices.Incidentally, I am currently training participants in a number of topics for the upcoming administrative analyst and staff analyst exams. I have also been doing this training for 20 years.As far as this book goes, take a pass.

Author Geri McArdle takes us through a 20-step training system model that is divided into 6 parts:1)  the business justification stage (a stage I have sadly never experienced);2) Analysis;3) Design;4) Development;5) Implementation and6) Evaluation.Each stage consists of a series of subsets or sub skills required to complete each stage successfully. In evaluation she focuses on Kirkpatrick's 3rd and 4th level of evaluation which are skill transfer to the workplace and results or return on investment. It ends up with a trainer's toolkit which consists of tips for the enterprising training consultant.Ms. McArdle also provides grids, sample letters, forms and most of all templates for the trainer to complete a lesson plan, the roadmap to conducting the training with some consistency.This book is not all-encompassing but it is certainly thorough, easy to read, and extremely well-organized.Consider this an excellent training resource from soup to nuts.Happy Veterans' Day!

Icebreaker, Networker, Team Builder, Task Tension Reducer, Relationship Tension Reducer, Personal Tension Reducer, or Focussing Activity.Studies have shown that capturing anyone's attention at the start of training or a presentation is critical to a trainer's or presenter's success at maintaining learner interest and motivation otherwise the audience will shift to the nearest Lotto winning fantasy for about 30 minutes before checking back in to see what they have missed. Pike and Solem offer 61 energizers to ensure that you maintain audience interest.What I found most appealing about this book is how it is structured. It starts off with a matrix that Pike is particularly fond of using in much of his writing: Icebreaker, Networker, Team Builder, Task Tension Reducer, Relationship Tension Reducer, Personal Tension Reducer, or Focusing Activity. Each page will have the name of the activity,  a box in the top right hand corner for each of these categories, and a check mark next to each if the energizer applies to that goal. They also list the length of the course it is appropriate for e.g. use only for a course that is at least three hours long or a day long, etc. It also lists the materials and procedures for carrying out the exercises.The authors are also mindful of the size of groups (ideally 5 to 7) to maintain maximum interaction between all members including how and when to rotate groups to reduce the influence of dominant members and heighten the participation of more introverted members. Relationship tension reducers will be particularly helpful when participants are not getting along.These activities place a great emphasis on learners being seated in groups rather than individual desks since interaction is paramount for these activities to take place. Many of the activities involve the use of name tents. No name tents and you can skip a number of pages.Books of such a limited "genre" usually come at a steep price compared to, say, non-fiction or biographies. so full price can be steep and disappointing to the experienced trainer, but worth the price many times over the training neophyte who has no mentor for the labyrinthine interactions of a training workshop.Just make sure you don't forget the name tents and make sure people are sitting in groups.

This is perhaps the most complete and comprehensive book any trainer will ever find on how to go about writing training programs since authors Dick and Carey wrote theirs more than 30 years ago . It contains charts and templates to guide the writer through the process. What the book doesn't provide is how to structure a lesson plan, and what Ms. Barbazette describes as conditions to learning outcomes or performance objectives, I see as criteria. Two, she lists a number of tasks in the Affective Domain of Learning (changing learners' attitudes)  that I find would be difficult if not impossible to measure. That said, she offers many more ideas in the instructional design process that I had not been aware of before reading this book.

I am always looking for new ways to spice up my training. Some of the activities in this book are useful and some I have already used in my years of experience. A number of them are impractical for the milieu in which I train e.g. I cannot see myself blowing up balloons for everyone and then asking them to tie the ball to their wrists with string.In the author's defense, each page has an energizer telling you what materials you need, how long it will take, etc. The opposite side of the page tells you the procedure and recommends questions to add during or after the exercise. I do wish that she had specific ones identified for opening activities and closing activities. If they were, they were not evident to me.I hope many more trainers will find this book useful and helpful.

The Trainer's Journey to Competence is one of the only books I have found that define competencies for facilitators, instructional designers, training coordinators and managers in a basic and advanced series. The book also has competencies for coaching and mentoring.  I submitted them for a new coaching and mentoring program where there were none, but sadly are still none. There are also evaluation sheets to measure progress or achievement. A CD includes all the templates in the book for those who buy the book new.Competencies are the new buzz word in business and organizations. Training is now being designed around the competencies that each title is expected to possess rather than just skills.The author's knowledge of training is extensive to say the least, and I have already found this to be one of my most useful books for competencies and competency-based instruction.I'm becoming quite a fan of her books.

One reviewer wrote that the book had a big font and the information found in the book could be found in an evening of googling, so I decided to buy it, and as I suspected I cannot substantiate his claims. With 25 years of training experience in all phases of ISD, this book is a treasure trove of information for me, and I have a M.S. in Training and Learning Technology.It is not entertaining but it is not meant to be. Ms. Barbazette's writing style is analytical but informative. Every event in facilitation is broken down and examined in detail with templates to enhance recall, intuition, and learning e.g. do you know when to conduct role play, how to conduct role play, or the variations of role play you can employ, or why you would use them? Did you know there were five types of case studies, because I didn't. (I assumed there were only three). Whether it's instructional strategies, asking and answering questions, how to facilitate vs. instruct or train, determining your facilitation style, the author provides you with a thorough understanding of each. The book comes with a CD that has the templates that you can add to your thumb drive. The book is complete with a glossary, index and bibliography.I take issue with only one thing in the book where Ms. Barbazette describes conditions of an objective as quantity, quality, sequence of actions, and speed (or time limitation). I treat these as criteria of an objective and would add accuracy as another possible criterion. The conditions or circumstances in which an objective is supposed to be achieved would be the resources such as equipment or tools,  given or denied. In some conditions noise, temperature, or weather would also be considered conditions e.g. flying under instrument flight rules.The training I love to conduct the most is Train-the-Trainer training, and there are a host of ideas I plan to use from this book for our topic in Facilitation Skills. (Of course full credit will be given to the author), just as I noticed that she acknowledges the contributions from others in her book.Whether you are a neophyte, journeyman or highly experienced in training, this book is a worthy reference.Any one chapter is a bargain.

We remember the first things we see and hear, the most repetitious, the most novel, and the last things we hear or see. This is obviously about the last things we remember, and it is just as important as the others so that it isn't forgotten in days, weeks or months when the training over.There are also four types of closers which the book illustrates for us: review, action planning, celebrations and motivations. Each closer has a box in the upper right hand corner that tells you with a check mark which one or more of the four applies. Each closer is at least one page and tells you the source of the closer, the objective, what class length for which it is appropriate, the appropriate group size, time needed, equipment needed and directions how to use it called process.The 50 closers are not all different. A few are built upon others which I understand but find mildly annoying. The one I like the least is "sayings." These are platitudes of inspiration, which I find lacking in inspiration. However, I plan on using a number of these the next time I conduct a two-week Train-the-Trainer program which I will also carry into retirement--my own version, of course.The book is also full of advice which I found most helpful e.g. the longer the training the longer should be the closing, and that reaction sheets should be passed out to the learners much earlier than at the end when people are usually ready to leave. They are less likely to make a concerted effort to provide meaningful feedback.This book was co-authored by Lynn Solem whom I never heard of before and Bob Pike whom I know of very well. (I will certainly recognize Solem's name from now on).The book should be helpful to trainers on any level. I subscribe to the notion that if you find only one thing in a book useful, it is worth the price, but this book offers much more than one.

Marketing is the art of getting people to buy what they don't need and make them think they do..Author David Zinczenko offers his readers a thorough examination of thousands of items found in supermarkets that are configured to dazzle the senses, mislead the shopper with false advertising, and make you buy more than you came in for. He even tells when is the best time to shop--evenings in mid week when the supermarket is less crowded, which translates to when you likely to be able to get in and out without being stuck and buy more of what you don't need.The book is divided into nine chapters: Anatomy of Supermarket, Your Save-Money Shopping Guide, The Produce Section, The Meat & Fish Counters, The Refrigerator Section, The Pantry Aisles, The Snacks and Sweets Aisle, The Freezer Section, and Drink This, not That. It also has a appetizing index that will lead you to the product, if not the brand you are looking for. Each page shows several brand name products on both sides of the page. Eat This is on the left, and Not This is on the right. There are cartoon balloons for each product explaining why you should eat it or leave it out of your basket. It's the top three ingredients that customers have to pay attention to because that is what the products contain the most of.Speaking of baskets, the supermarket has heaped upon us a number of smaller baskets knowing that the shopper is less likely to check the products he or she buys and more likely to add items that would never have been considered. Even putting produce first means the supermarket knows the consumer will spend more time which translates to spending more money in their establishment. Author, David Zinczenko recommends customers peruse that aisle last.The author pays particular attention to saturated fats, sugar, sodium, protein, and anything that is difficult to pronounce or sounds like Latin, so while Campbell's Select Harvest Healthy Request Chicken with Whole Grain Pasta might sound like a healthy request, it is only Campbell's requesting that you buy it. It has 410 milligrams of sodium and only 1% fiber coming from the whole grain pasta.If there's one thing you need to put in your food basket when you go shopping this book is a must.Buy this and digest every word.

Srixon makes golf balls you hate to lose; they are that good--and costs more when compared to many other brands. Naturally I jumped at the opportunity when Amazon Vine offered them and offered them in yellow. Srixon balls give me greater distance in my drives. They offer consistency. The soft feel is ideal for my club head speed which is about 80 miles per hour.Although yellow is the mark of an amateur, they are easier to follow and spot. Besides, I'm too on in years to really give a damn, and I enjoy watching the starter's reaction when they expect me to hit a dribbler and the ball goes flying long and high down the fairway.If you want a great golf ball, you cannot go wrong with Srixon.

To people outside training the 4C's can sound like oceans, diseases, or the Hi-C sugary drink, but to us the 4 C's is what the author Sharon Bowman claims we should use to ensure our learners actually learn from their training while making it interactive and exciting.Connections is the first "C" and it contains 15 opening activities that connect learners to the topic.(This is critical as it has been shown that we remember the first and last things more than anything else in between).In her second "C" concepts, she cites 20 strategies "to engage and involve learners" during the, and I won't say it, I won't--l-e-c-t-u-r-e. These strategies emphasize learner feedback and activity that is anything but sitting still or remaining silent. Ms. Bowman believes that if you must lecture, it should be kept to 15 minutes tops, and then making the learners active.Her third "C" is what separates training from education. (Education calls it lab). She calls it Concrete Practice. (She had to add this C for obvious reasons--"The Three C's and 1 P" doesn't sound quite as catchy). Ms. Bowman realizes as any training specialist does that without practice you only have a seminar, and that practice that is not aimed at accomplishing learner outcomes (objectives) is equally worthless. Here she offers 15 strategies for learners to practice and review what they have learned.The fourth "C" is conclusions and these include 15 strategies for participants to lead in their summaries, evaluations, and celebration activities.Training from the back of the room is just that--you might lead the training, but you make the training participant-centered. Making the learners active is what makes them learn.This book is practical, well-written and will have a high impact in any classroom, and I have seen the results having just trained a number of law enforcement officers to become instructors using these principles.  They are highly motivated and intent on using their new found skills in their classrooms.I recommend that you use these strategies in yours.

I did not know Sharon Bowman so I did not recognize her when she and I stood near the head of a very long line of trainers lined up according to our training experience, at Training Magazine's seminar in Orlando last year. After reading this book and her "Using Brain Science" book, I realized how much our experiences diverged and how much I still had to learn. Because of her books my learning curve went vertical.Ms. Bowman presents a number of activities to be used before training, during training, during breaks, as closing activities and for action plans. There are several variations to each activity to keep the learner attentive, interested, and most of all--learning. These strategies push the senses by making participants walk, making them talk, and making them write. What I found particularly useful and neglected by many trainers and instructors in my experience is to repeat the questions or exercises to ensure the learning sticks. Before this I never stood still but I realized that I had to make sure the learners didn't sit still.Recently, I revamped our Train-the-Trainer course by abandoning the ADDIE format of presenting topics and focusing on practice after each topic. I am still getting complimentary e-mails from participants who want to return for more. I will go into overdrive using even more of them this week from a workbook I created for internal use. Ms. Bowman knows we will use these exercises and only asks that we give credit to her. Her name and book titles are mentioned prominently as resources.If you want to improve your training skill, buy this book. Be a guide on the side rather than a sage on stage.

I have nothing but admiration for a man who is an amateur writer who does not back down from a challenge to writing a series of humorous essays made all the more novel because English is his second language. (Pardon me! The good doctor would inform me that it was his fourth language having grown up in Romania, moved to Israel, then to France to study medicine, and finally finishing his odyssey in Long Island.Being an anesthesiologist, he feels he doesn't get the recognition that he should get. No wonder, he's the one that passes the gas (in a medical sort of way.) As a result, no one remembers who he is. I think it should be a tipping situation, myself. So, he has resorted to writing two books, one with an excellent plot, and this one which lists his pet peeves of being recognized as Mrs. Neuschat's husband, lawn mowers going off all the time, and realtors dissembling about ocean views. (They're much better in the winter time, I'm sure).Look at the picture of the good doctor on his Amazon page, and you see an infectious smile and outlook on life that shows how deftly he can turn his complaints about things beyond his control into humorous little stories that made me laugh out loud. It also speaks to his intelligence and fluency despite the accent that must be impossible to pin down demographically.The only things Joe left out is people handing you your change with the coins sitting on top of the bills. Can't you give them to me separately as people used to do? Am I supposed to wrap them up in a ball and stuff them in my pocket? Nor did he mention the people who hand you your change as though they are giving you a present. Hey, it's money you owe me; it's not a gift! He didn't mention the tip jar that businesses put out even though you're getting up to get your order, and they didn't even bring it to your table. I guess the doc doesn't do much driving either or he might have complained about New York driving.Otherwise, read it and enjoy!Review no. 500.

My work colleague has definitely gotten my number. He knows I like things hot. (He also likes to watch me sweat, but that's another story).  This was one of the Christmas presents he gave me.I have put this on just about everything, a ham and cheese melt, sausage, scrambled eggs, chicken, roasted peppers, mussels, clams, calamari, and most importantly in a Bloody Mary.It is also low maintenance. It comes in a plastic bottle and doesn't need refrigeration. The lid opens by rotation similar to a plastic ketchup bottle.It is not terribly hot at 1,500 to 2,000 Scoville Units, but it enough to wet my scalp. I'm definitely going to buy more of this. Why?Because it's hotsy totsy!

Sometimes your enemy comes at you as a friend. The same is true with propaganda coming to you masquerading as journalism. Fox Nation, the Internet arm of Rupert Murdoch's vast news empire, provides the readers with a daily dose of propaganda in the guise of news.Author Mark Howard catalogues dozens of Fox Nation headlines showing in detail how Fox Nation blatantly lies to their readership, even citing sources that contradict their own headlines. One of my favorites is "NBC-WSJ poll: On economy Romney Opens Up Lead Over Obama." Even though Obama was in fact leading in 14 categories, even leading in fighting for fairness and strengthening the middle class, Fox Nation gave the impression that Romney was leading in overall economic improvement when he was only leading in "ideas for improving the economy by 6%. (We all know how that turned out)!Perhaps the most blatant of all was "Poll: Americans Not Buying Buffett Rule." In case you don't know, Warren Buffet has advocated for increased taxes on the wealthy. Fox Nation's claim here was that the public rejected it.  The poll they cited was from Fox News which found that "more voters think raising taxes on wealthy Americans will help rather than hurt the economy." In other words, the results of the poll actually refuted Fox Nation's headline!Thanks to authors like Mr. Howard, he keeps Fox Nation honest. (?) Make that he keeps their dishonesty in the spotlight. He continues monitoring Fox Nation with his website which I will mention in the comments section. This is a short book but well worth the time to read. He proves the old proverb--Don't believe everything you read. With Fox Nation, you should probably not believe everything you see either.Here is the truth about lies.Happy New Year!

A colleague mentioned that Midsummer's Night was her favorite, so I chucked at the thought of giving her a Duck Dynasty Chia Pet. I can now count on another year of cooperation from her.Midsummer Night smelled okay to me, but to her nostrils it was Nirvana. Yankee Candle offers great products especially at Christmas time, and in what seems like a hundred different scents. (How do they get ocean breeze in that jar anyway)?Maybe next Christmas I will surprise her with Yankee Candle Roast Turkey, Cranberry Sauce and Stuffing scent. (How do they get that in a candle anyway)?  I'm sure it will smell like she cooked all day in front of a cold oven.Happy New Year! (That would be Yankee Candle: Winter's Snowflake. (How did they capture that scent)?

I bought this for a colleague as a Christmas present after she complained that she has been on vacation and forgot to pack her pants. I was wondering about that. Then, she confessed that she only had blue jeans to wear. (Thank heavens).This little baby should keep her pants wrapped around her legs and bum for some time. It contains everything you might pack for a trip right down to your after shave and sunglasses.It comes in a pad with more sheets than for which I will probably ever need of and if I do that much travel, by that time I will have memorized what I need to pack. You just peel off each sheet after each packing and you are ready for the next foray. Don't forget to pack an unused one for your return home.Don't be caught with your pants down.

Politician is a dirty word in American English, and the unfolding story of what went on in Benghazi Libya on the night of September 11, 2012 brought the word to a new nadir in our language.After four Americans were killed that night including a U.S. Ambassador, the first time an American ambassador was slain in a number of years, the Republicans saw their opportunity to politicize to influence the upcoming national election that November. Although Mitt Romney and Barack Obama had agreed to halt personal attacks, this was irresistible for the Romney campaign who immediately charged that the president was weak on foreign policy and had made a statement that was tantamount to an apology for prior U.S. actions. This incorrect statement would come to back to haunt him in a debate with President Obama.Darrel Issa led the Republicans with charges of his own barely after convening an investigation with his oversight committee. Issa, a congressman who was often thought of as a man born out of wedlock started making accusations of presidential neglect, ambivalence and stonewalling. He began leaking information that intimated the administration had lied and was negligent. Issa would be severely embarrassed when a Democrat released the entire report which showed Issa had lied and his investigation had turned up nothing.The Fox News network, which claims to be fair and balanced and states 'we report you decide," went into high gear accusing the administration of being soft on terrorism and uninterested in finding out who were the culprits of the attack. Greta van Sustern, Sean Hannity, Steven Doocy, Brian Kilmeade and other Fox hosts interviewed a number of right wing nuts giving them full rein to their baseless suspicions and paranoia. Their attacks were enough to destroy the nomination of Susan Rice as the next Secretary of State, but it did nothing to hurt the re-election of Barack Obama.That left the Republicans with Plan B: go after Hillary Clinton, the odds-on front runner as the Democrats Party's nominee for President in 2016, and go after Hillary they did. Scheduled to appear before Congress, Secretary Clinton literally stumbled and received a bad concussion that turned into a blood clot behind her ear. The press, led by Fox of course, claimed that Ms. Clinton faked her fall to avoid the spotlight of a congressional investigation. The Secretary of State held her own.Resistant to public apathy the Republicans continued with Plans C and D, or accusations of a stand down order for military relief that never existed. Those with little to no knowledge of military operations or logistics insisted that a rescue operation could have been mounted despite sworn expert testimony to the contrary. Plan D was the critical cables that Republicans charged the now ex-Secretary of State knew an attack was imminent (she did not) and that requests for security upgrades were denied or ignored. This too was proven false. Even charges that whistleblowers were muzzled, that witnesses had not been interrogated, and our dead were left behind were proven false.What author David Brock showed here was the hypocrisy of Democrats and Republicans who stood together after the attack on 9/11 in New York and the Pentagon had morphed into a chasm of bitter political rivalry after Benghazi. He eloquently reveals what lengths politicians will resort to, to bear false witness against their neighbor. It is also said that New York is tough town, but Washington D. C. is a mean town, and Benghazi showed just how cruel and vicious politics can be to gain and maintain power.At this writing an article in the New York Times confirms what most of us suspected and Republicans denied. The attack was not well-planned or coordinated by al-Qaeda. It was a spontaneous reaction to a DVD that insulted the Islamic religion that went viral and inflamed the Muslim world. It was just as Susan Rice had said.Benghazi was and is a Republican hoax in search of a scandal..

This is a not so novel idea but a very helpful one unless you're the kind of citizen who enjoys reading entire federal bills after they are signed into law. I am not one of them and Ciaro Health Resources is betting that you aren't one of them either.These are quality, plastic-coated playing cards that offer information about Obamacare in four areas that correspond with the four suits: The spades give us the facts of Obamacare; the hearts are the patients' rights and protections; the clubs come under improving quality health care; the diamonds cover increasing access and lowering costs. In all four areas there is additional information about medicare, women's health, role of the IRS, young Americans, small businesses, the individual mandate, and much more.Each card has a cartoon that covers roughly the top third of the page. A subtitle in bold immediately follows, and that is followed by an easy-to-understand explanation of Obamacare e.g. The Ace of Spades reads in bold: Obamacare does NOT mean government taking over healthcare. It is followed by a short sentence and three bulleted items. It is like this on each card, even the Jokers, which describe the goals and where to call. There is also a blank playing card that has the all important phone numbers for: Small Business Health Options Program (SHOP), Early Retiree Reinsurance Program Center, and a Help Center for everyone else.The font looks like Universe or Calibri which are easier to read than Times Roman. It also shows me that a lot of thought went into the creation of this product.Even if you don't play cards, this deck provides useful information offering more than the average American probably knows and dispels the myths about Obamacare which have been widely reported and unfortunately widely trusted.It is information that is literally at your fingertips.Merry Christmas!

At least I was busy putting up the houses that would go around the base of the Christmas tree when this movie provided ample noise background which was better than quiet--I suppose.The movie is based on the much better book, as is usually the case. The film is bland, formula-ridden, with mediocre acting and miscasting that characterized this boring and unusually long film. I was saved by the frequent commercials showing Santa trying to get me to buy a Chevrolet. William Holden played the real-life Lt. Col. Frederick who later became a major-general in the army before retiring. The real life guy looked younger than Holden, was skinny with a pencil-thin mustache. Cliff Roberston played an Irish Canadian with a brooding air and an unconvincing brogue. Vince Edwards should have stuck to playing Dr. Ben Casey. Claude Aiken and Richard Jaekel are the usual suspects called upon to military roles.By formula ridden I mean every major character is paired up with someone they initially despise and end up becoming friends. One of each pair always dies by the end of the film. There also seems to be more Thompson submachine guns in this brigade then in the entire European Theater. They all seem to be capable of shooting from the hip and each Thompson has an endless supply of bullets without changing magazines. "Give'em hell!" "Let's go!" "Come on!" are thrilling, novel parts of the script too. Naturally,  the Germans have to lose every hand-to-hand combat encounter.Now for the mistakes which annoy me no end in military movies. It's kind of like watching someone's napkin sitting precariously on someone's knee wondering if they will find it before it falls to the floor. The Devil's Brigade was made up of a contingent from the U.S. Army, most "volunteers" from various stockades around the country, and a Canadian contingent which sent their very best. So during their "pass in review" we see the American flag, the Union Jack and Brigade's flag. Whoah! Rewind! The Union Jack? The Canadian flag at the time had a Union Jack in the upper left corner flanked by blue field with a crest on the blue, eh?. Where was that flag, eh? How can you build expensive sets and not pay for the right flag, eh?This deserves two buckets of coal.Now it's back to the Snow Village under the tree and the figurines. What a relief!

Next time you open a bag of Tyson Pork Chews and pop open a cold beverage, be sure you open up your electronic tablet to the video below. Take a deep chew and a swig as you watch pigs being thrown around, writhing on the floor, having their testicles pulled off, their eyes gouged out or their tails cut off with wire clippers.Tell us how much you enjoy your Tyson product then.And I'm certainly no vegan. I make it clear that I love some form of dead animal to eat. I just don't think they have to be tortured before they get to my plate. There has to be a better way, a more humane way than throwing a bowling ball at a pig or tossing them around.  Please consider before you buy your next Tyson product and ask yourself, would you treat an animal this way?

Perhaps I was born in the wrong era. I love 40's music and my favorite is Vera Lynn, especially "We'll Meet Again." Her voice resonates. It has range. It's strong and beautiful. No matter which song you listen to, you can't help but be enthralled with the voice of a woman who was still giving concerts in Amsterdam in 1985 at the age of 78. The Dutch still love her. (That's right-still). Dame Vera Lynn is still alive at age 97.Her songs were perhaps the most poignant during World War II. "We'll Meet Again" suggests the joy and tragedy of war as the words imply that the the serviceman will return to the joy and romance of true love or that true love will only be renewed in the afterlife if he didn't return. Her voice adds to the hope that the end of war brings, and the despair of it ending with loss and grief. Choruses are a frequent part of her songs. Choruses, especially in wartime, convey a sense of community, even if the songs are individual and romantic "from the time you say good-bye."Unfortunately, I don't think this is the VERY best of this artist. "I'll Be Seeing You" is not on this album, nor is "Lili Marlene," which was popular with the German as well as British troops. Nevertheless many more songs on this album are sure to relieve some stress and add some melancholy.

"The Bill of Rights in the Modern State" grabs you just by the titles of some of the chapters: "A Threat to Liberty," "Free Speech Now," or the "Politics of Distrust." Edited by Geoffrey R. Stone, Richard A. Epstein and Cass Sunstein, they have selected many essays that explore our bill of rights in depth I never thought possible. Here's an example from the chapter "Women's Wrongs":"Christianity has been a primary--in many women's lives the primary--force in shaping our acceptance of abuse. The central image of Christ on the cross as the savious of the world communicates the message that suffering is redemptive. If the best person who every lived gave his life for others, then, to be of value we should likewise sacrifice ourselves. Any sense that we have a right to care for our own needs is in conflict with being a faithful follower of Jesus. Our suiffering for others will save the world."Is it any wonder that women were not allowed to claim self-defense if they killed their abusive husbands when they were not in physical danger at the moment they did? Is it any wonder that women are still seeking to be treated as equal citizens under the law?The authors often cite Supreme Court cases analyzing their conclusions and their precedents as they also examine social reality, religious principles, legal foundations and how they have meshed or morphed into our perceptions and legal processes.This is not light reading. It is also a reference book that might be pulled off the shelf many times over the years. Mine is already inundated with different color tabs and extensive highlighting of passages. Believe it or not, I feel this was written for the layman to give us a deeper understandng of American Jurisprudence.It will probably be more than you expect.

I find the idea of organizational development fascinating, finding out what is wrong, or finding out how to maximize office efficiency. It's like a puzzle without all the pieces, and you must make up the pieces in your head. Unfortunately, I didn't find this book fascinating, revealing, helpful or giving me any pieces of insight into the realm of organizational development.This book was published by the American Society for Training and Development. I obviously see where training fits into productivity picture of any organization.  A performance analysis and job/task analysis go hand-in-hand with training and O.D but I wanted to explore other solutions, such as organizational analyses.  The ones it offered were disappointing. As one other reviewer wrote it concentrated on coaching and an organization in transition. I wanted to know how to organize an organization to make it more efficient other than the use or misuse of training.I will look elsewhere.

I got this from Vine and used it to help a friend add some insulation to his attic. There were no jams and the gun went straight through the insulation and wood to make a clean, tight staple.This tool is like luggage. You might not use it very often but you want it to be there when you do.I'm thinking of using it at work too if I have a really thick bunch of papers.Insulation and paper. How 'bout that!

The "Creative Training Techniques Handbook" is one of the very best books on delivering effective training there is on the market.The author emphasizes that adults must be handled with kid gloves, which means that the instructor or training specialist must respect their opinions, attitudes and previous learning experiences that may run contrary to what is being taught.  Actually taught is a bad word.Pike also believes that the training specialist's job is one of facilitation. He calls it instructor-led participant-centered training. This is a common belief in training that people have the intuition to arrive at a solution or develop their knowledge on their own with only guidance and by keeping them involved.By involved the author means keep them writing, keep them creating, and keep them visualizing right down to drawing pictures. This means that lecture never gets more than 15 minutes before participants are engaged in some kind of learning exercise, and exercises are characterized by what he calls C. P. R. which means keeping the content relevant, allowing for adequate participation, and finding ways to review and reinforce key points.His book covers every imaginable event involved in the training experience. This version covers recent training developments such as webinars and eLearning.  Bob even covers such things as the opaque projector, which for the most part was last used during the Eisenhower Administration and still requires a team of mules to move one. He even covers how to use a slide carousel (Kodak made the last one in 2004), and how to apply more than one film on overhead projectors. Actually, he offers too many essentials to be named here, but suffice it to say that anyone embarking on a career in training or simply having been assigned to facilitate training would do well to read this book and make it as important an item as their wallet.Bob Pike is one of the most recognizable names in training. He can charm the socks off professional training specialists (who can be a very tough audience). He dazzles a room full of them, and is particularly impressive showing them how to increase their memory skills in one 15 minute exercise.I have 25 years of training experience and I am already treating this book as a training bible.Turn to the Book of Bob.

The Book of Steak is for the man who won't settle for anything less than some form of dead animal on his plate. The paragon of animal is the sacred cow that made the supreme sacrifice for my dining pleasure. It is for the man whose mouth waters at the words dry rub and fiery horseradish sauce or red wine marinade.The book starts out telling you about buying, freezing and storing, and organic vs. grass fed. It then shows you a cow's profile and where the cuts are. Cooking times follow telling you how long from rare to the (Gawd awful) well done. Then comes the prize, the chapters in cuts: front cuts, rear cuts, steaks for two, and sauces and sides. Each page contained therein give you the ingredients on the left, along with prep time, cook time, and how many it feeds. The instructions never exceed more than five steps. The right side of the page is finished product in all its glory, sometimes with other pictures on top showing the stages of preparation. Almost all photos are juicy rare or medium rare. The sides at the end include things this bachelor has never done before or even thought of making, like my own ketchup, mayonnaise or mustard. One barbecue marinade bears an uncanny resemblance to one marinade given to me by an Amazon friend and chef in his own right. The only difference being it calls for bourbon, which he did too. Only he said to save some for the marinade.The only question you may have to answer after looking at this succulent variety of steaks is, what's your beef?

Just as the king declared that Mozart had too many notes in his music, many cookbooks have too many ingredients, require too many exotic cookware or utensils, herbs and spices I've never heard of, or things I don't do like flambé or sauté.  Cookbooks are complicated. The U.S. Constitution isn't complicated. A five-event, four-stroke horizontally opposed engine isn't complicated. A cookbook is complicated to starve by, or enough to send you running to Thai Tanic's Bang-Bang Chicken House.The Ultimate 4 Ingredient Cookbook never requires more than four ingredients. It tells you what to do with little dots to the left of each bit of instruction. (I like that. It helps me keep my place). And whether it's for breakfast, lunch, dinner, salad, sandwiches, bread, beverages, soup, appetizers or desserts, there's never more than four ingredients except for the index, but who cares? You're not going to prepare index.For the indifferent cook, the man who cooks indifferently, or for the cook whose guests suggest pizza or Chinese every time you threaten to cook for them, this is the book. It's for the man who doesn't feel like making a lot of food, dirtying a lot of dishes, and for the man who has absolutely no pride in his cooking. I'm guilty on all counts.Next is the orange-sauced spare ribs!

Men, are you tired of cooking the same old crap, night after night, the same drippy vegetables, that same dried-out chicken, that overcooked beef or fish? Are you tired of trying to pick up things only to get home to find that you forgot a missing ingredient? Are you tired of cookbooks that tell you to use a shallot of this, or a kale of that when you don't even know what a shallot means or what a kale is? You throw up your hands and put the book back on the shelf only to collect dust again. Well, not with this little baby.This book could have been subtitled "for the biggest bachelor dummy of them all." (I think it was written just for me). Each page shows you the products you will need. Do you need beans or pineapple? It will show you the can of Goya and DelMonte and tell you the size. Don't know what a shoulder steak looks like? No problem. It shows you a picture of a shoulder steak. The contents list easy to prepare, easy to find ingredients by beef, chicken, pork, fish, beans, noodles, veggies, fruit and beer. That's right, you can even make BBQ Beer Ribs or even Mexi Can Pie. Now how can you top that?You can make exotic dishes in a flash. Buy a 6oz. can of Dole Pineapple juice concentrate, 2, 5oz. cans of Dole Pineapple chunks drained and one boneless pork loin (3lbs.), follow the instructions and you've made Pineapple Party Pork for yourself. It will tell you how many it serves, how many calories, grams of fat, carbs, fiber and sodium. There's 99 other recipes that don't require a lot of reading or ingredients. It's just you, a man and his stove/oven.But you must keep this in your car. Keep it in the glove compartment ready for action the next time you pull into your local supermarket. Keep it right above that other book you don't read--the owner's manual. This is a man's man recipe book. After all, you're a man, aren't you?

Okay, I'm crazy--crazy about training. I'm just crazy enough to have packed this into my carry-on for my vacation to Las Vegas, and to have read it in my hotel room sipping overpriced coffee. The book is actually one of the best on training I have read. Why? It's one of the more thorough ones that encompasses most of the stages of training that the actual training specialist will experience.Those stages go by the acronym, A.D.D.I.E. for analysis, design, development, implementation, and evaluation. Saul Carliner, the author, goes into detail of the first three which really constitute 90% of a training project. He adds important remedies to common stumbling blocks such as how to get cooperation from the sponsor, the subject matter expert, and more importantly how to go about identifying the performance discrepancy. The author also uses this space to expound upon adult learning theory, which is critical to getting learner "buy-in." (We don't teach people as much as facilitate their learning).The design and development phases usually intimidate those who have to write them. I've observed it many times. The author provides checklists to help the instructional designer avoid getting swamped in the project. He was even more thorough in going through the do's and dont's of creating visuals and manuals that support the instruction. In fact, this is the best information I have seen anywhere.While there are four levels of evaluation, the author covers three--reaction, learning and work transfer, mainly because most of us never get to practice step 4--measuring results e.g. fewer accidents, more customers, less spoilage, etc.I was quite impressed with this work. In his 10 chapters, the author identified several problems and bumps training specialists face and how to deal with them. Few other books I am aware of do. He has asides, such as 39 Basic Rules and another called "Think About This" that contain important little gems, and, well, rules that should never be broken. Questions followed each chapter to reinforce learning and additional sources are provided in the back.He wrote this for A.S.T.D, which is the American Society for Training and Development (even though he's Canadian, eh?)

Here are 400 brilliant color photographs spanning 19 chapters of varying themes. Chapter titles such as Methods of Thinking, Building our Country Through Diligence and Frugality, and Serving the People point to a highly regulated life from birth to death. The posters show one person, a family or community of them or in the hundreds, smiling or with expressions of steely resolve. Either expression portrays confidence, love of country, communism, or Mao whose image appears apparitional and dominates the cover as the embodiment of a people's spirit.Red is the predominant color and strangely, many of the figures look surprisingly, almost western. Exceptionally few characters are depicted wearing eye glasses as if it is a sign of moral or physical weakness. Most certainly everyone is handsome, gorgeous or downright cute even in middle age or elderly characters. No one looks anything less than benign but never homely. Judging from the book, the Chinese are easily the healthiest and most beautiful people on earth with their square jaws, strong features and dazzling smiles who want to hunt down the imperialist aggression of the United States and the running dogs who follow them, er, us.What is revealing is how a culture sees itself or itself as an ideal.  Mao Zedong appears messianic, and all the people are happy following their duty to advance communism from the non-privacy of their homes to throughout the world.The book is a heavy tome of high quality paper, several hundred mils thick, and is written with English, German, and French text and translations. It is a book that should be seen, as much as read, several times to gain some insight into a culture that is thousands of years old and was conquered and ravaged for centuries. Communism in that country appears to be an outcome of both and a determination that the last invasion of their country would be the last one.These are pictures of a waking giant.Thank you, Helmut.

In the early evening hours of April 19, 1988, a 28 year old investment banker named Trisha Meili was jogging in Central Park when she was attacked and brutally raped. Several suspects were brought in for questioning who described their activities that night as "wilding," slang for making mischief in the form of assault, robbery and general hooliganism in the park. With the young woman in a coma and not expected to live, the five Hispanic and black youths were quickly rounded up by a Police Department that was under pressure to find the hoodlums and bring the case to justice.Adding fuel to the fire was Donald Trump, never missing a moment for self-promotion, put out full page ads in the major New York newspapers calling for a reinstituted death penalty. Former Mayor Ed Koch helped contaminate the jury pool by saying in front of the camera "we have to call them suspects" implying that it was a nicety applied to the guilty. Even the mainstream media jumped on the bandwagon publishing the names and the addresses of the suspects, even those that were under-age. Minority newspapers retaliated outraging white New Yorkers by publishing the name of the victim.  The pictures of the guilt- and shame-ridden faces revealed their guilt to everyone white. It was a D.W. Griffiths nightmare-- the evil black men were raping "our white women," just as portrayed in the movie that glorified the Ku Klux Klan a hundred years earlier.Interrogated hour after hour, each suspect was worn down from the coaxing and cajoling, finally admitting to the crime or implicating someone with them in the belief that they could go home if they just confessed. The parents, as ignorant of the judicial process as their offspring, encouraged them to confess. To their surprise indictments followed, but that was only part of the nightmare. One parent hired a divorce and real estate lawyer to defend her son. One of the defendant's lawyers slept threw some of the testimony.
