As most people I'm also a sucker for buying multiple iPhone cases or in the search of that perfect case. Right now I use Zoogue, which offers plenty protection, but the red/pink colored ones get dirty very easily and hence was looking for replacement. This case is one of the highest rated in Amazon. Although a little slippery, its very well made and offers good protection on the sides as the edges are raised by 1 mm on the sides.However, the front lip, apart from the sides, are only raised by 0.2-0.3 mm and I think probably not enough to make you feel secure against all drops. However, if the front lip is raised all around and if the case is non-slippery, this probably is the best case in the market. At $10 I can only give 3 stars. The search continues.

I read the reviews and bought a size 4 for a 3 year old who is actually very average sized. However, this is still small and will be returning this for a size 5. The materials are okay and the quality seems decent, but for the price and misleading size and description I can only give 3 stars.

There are plenty of reviews of this tool here. I don't think its really worth $6, may be $1. This is really just a thin metal piece with a dome sticker for grip, nothing special and I found this metal very flimsy.Advice for opening iPad (shattered digitizer) -I bought this to pry open an iPad digitizer (glass screen) which was completely cracked and shattered further upon trying to remove it. This tool was basically useless for that purpose since the metal isn't rigid enough and would just bend when I tried to pry it open. In the end I had to use a Henckels kitchen knife to pry the glass pieces one by one, a bit scary but worked 10 times better than this tool. All you have to be careful is to not cut the plastic frame.

I bought this Velcro to modify the headphone case that came with Sony MDR10RBT Bluetooth Headphones. The case didn't have velcro or magnet or buttons to close it and the headphones and cables kept falling from it. I cut two small pieces and used it for the main headphone compartment and the smaller cable pouch. Problem solved. Now that I have it at home, this could be used for several different purposes. Quality product and price is right at $10.

For $3 there is no better shaving gel, I'm not sure you can pay more and get anything significantly better than this either. Everything positive about this gel written here in the reviews are true. Its smooth, gives a comfortable shave, finish feels good after the shave, nice smell and uses a pea-sized amount for lots of foam. Just be careful notto press the button or actuator too hard as its pressured and a slight press is enough for a decent amount.Nothing more to add really, just an excellent product from Nivea!FYI I use it with electric shavers (for wet use), Panasonic ES-LV81-K Arc5  and Braun 3Series 340S-4 Wet & Dry Shaver.

I was in the market for a sub $50 Bluetooth earphone and took a chance with the Bluedio Q2 earphones. There were no reviews for this when I ordered the product, however there were several good reviews for Bluedio R+ bluetooth over-the-ear headphones. I thought its the same manufacturer and from photos the earphones looked decent so decided to take the plunge.Now to the actual review. I had high hopes on this earphone because Bluedio generally gets 4.0 stars or higher on their products and this was a newly release device for which the technology is fairly matured at this point.Price - 5/5I ordered it for $27.95 with prime shipping. As of Aug/2014 There are two listings for Bluedio Q2, one is sold by Amazon.com for $45.99 and the cheaper is sold by Bluedio but fulfilled by Amazon. So you get prime shipping anyway.Build quality - 4/5This is okay for the price and everything is made in plastic, expected at this price range. The flat cord is tangle free and looks durable, I mean it's a short cable since the earphone is Bluetooth. The packing was great and looked very decent for a product under $30. The product comes with a micro USB charging cable, few white ear tips and a user manual.Design and comfort - 3/5The part where they have the buttons and charger port are slightly heavier to my liking and this actually increases the probability of that earphone to fall out of your ears more. So this basically means if you're doing cardio or aerobic then this might be a problem for you. It also doesn't come with stabilizers or clips unlike some of the in-ear earphones. I wish it had the design where both earbuds are identical and with no attachments on the cord. The micro USB charging port has a plastic cover which is really hard to pull and once I had it out it was hard to push it back inside after charging. The durability of this pull-out cover is also questionable. There are no markings on the buttons, but its relatively straightforward. The big round button is the one you use to pair the device, you keep pressing it for a few seconds and select the earphone from your phone's Bluetooth device list; button on the side is for volume control. To fully charge the battery it takes about 2-3 hours and it lasts around 4 hours once fully charged depending on your use; not spectacular, but not shabby either.Sound Quality - 2/5This was the biggest negative as far as I was concerned. Some of the headphones I own and have reviewed here on Amazon are Audio Technica ATH M50s/M50x, Sony MDR10RBT, Sennheiser HD439 for over-the-ear type headphones and Apple iPhone 5 earphones, Xiaomi Piston 2, JBuds J6M, GOgroove audiOHM HF etc. for in-ear earphones. In terms of sound quality the Bluedio Q2 is closest the Gogroove audioOHM which is has the poorest sound quality among all the ones listed above. To be fair, I guess it sounds okay for the price, but in today's world where there are so many earphones/headphones competing for your money this leaves a lot to be desired. The lows(bass) and mids are may be okay (but not really) and the treble or highs are really bad. This earphone comes with a microphone, used it for a few calls and the mic and sound quality was okay for voice calls.Overall ratings - 3/5While I'm glad that this earphone doesn't cost as much as the highly rated and priced JayBird BlueBuds X Sport or the Plantronics BackBeat which sells for $130-140 it just doesn't live up to my expectations. May be I'm being a little harsh since this is one of the cheapest Bluetooth in-ear earphones you can buy, but still, sound quality to me, is the single most important attribute in a earphone. You can have all the bells and whistles, but the sound has to be good at least. Unfortunately for me, this earphone fails to deliver that.

Bought this battery (for Dell Inspiron 1420) at the end of January 2014 and as of end of July it doesn't charge. It shows 0% charge and refuses to charge. However the Dell battery meter shows battery as healthy. I would not expect this $15 battery to last more than a year and its very annoying when you unplug you laptop unknowingly or pull or trip on the cord and everything you're working on is lost. So if you're using the laptop for actual 'work' then spend more and get a proper battery. If this is a beat up old laptop for whatever use (other than important work) then may be take a gamble and you might end up with a decent battery that lasts at least couple of years, unlike mine. In hindsight I should've skipped it.2 stars since it lasted 6 monthsNow that I checked on the item detail page it says there is a 1 year warranty. I'll contact the manufacturer and update the outcome here.== Update Oct/2014 ==When I wrote the review I thought the battery died but it must have been some issue with charger or the port. The battery seems to work fine and after 10 months it still holds charge properly (well at least couple of hours on an old Dell Inspiron laptop) which is more than what I thought it would do.Upgrading it to 4 stars.One word about the warranty. When I thought the battery died I contacted Amazon and they suggested contacting the manufacturer (Tech Rover dot com). I emailed them and they never replied. So reducing 1 star for that.

Finally bought a pair of Bluetooth headphones after reading several reviews and watching the price of a lot of them here on Amazon. Here's my take on the Sony MDR10RBT Bluetooth headphones.These were my criteria for the ideal headphone I was looking for -1) Bluetooth - enough with the cords2) Good sound quality3) Over-ear - a lot of the Bluetooth headphones are on-ear type and I really wanted over-ear headphones which covered ears fully to minimize sound leak so that I can use them on the plane and also while using public transportation4) Noise isolation and no leaks5) Stylish and comfortable6) Supports calls, i.e. have a microphone7) Good battery life i.e. > 10 hours and fast charging8) Works with the regular audio cable in case if the battery dies9) Priced around $150Sound Quality - 3.5/5This is of course subjective and what you're used to. These headphones satisfied all the above criteria, except excellent sound quality. I know people have mentioned it will get better as time goes or after 50 hours of burn-in etc. but the first week I've had this I'm slightly disappointed in the sound quality. My usual headphones are Sennheiser HD 439 and Audio Technica M50s/M50x. To be honest Sony doesn't come close to Audio Technica in terms of sound stage, especially the mids and lows, but its also half the price ($79 for non-BT vs. $169 for M50x). Sennheiser has a decent sound for the price, but is very comfortable and is my everyday beat up headphones. The sound on these Sony headphones aren't bad, its actually really good for listening to music which has predominantly a lot of highs (clear trebles). The mids are somewhat subdued and lows (bass) are not that great. May be a few weeks of usage or burn in will fix it, in that case I will update here after few weeks.Comfort - 5/5; Heat and ears sweating - 3/5This is something I couldn't find in other reviews. A lot has been written about the comfort of these headphones. The first time I put these on I thought these are the most soft, delicate, lightest headphones you can ever buy. The 'pleather' material on headband and on speakers are truly soft and they just press against your ears so softly but firmly enough for a secure fit. These were truly over-ear for me and covered ears fully (medium sized ears). However, I have one minor problem with the material. They seem to get hot rather quickly, at least for me. Any over-ear headphone with leather or pleather pads will have this problem. For reference, Audio Technica makes my ears sweat after 2 hours or so and these headphones only took an hour and I had to just lift them up and put back again. Don't get me wrong, these are super comfortable, more than any headphone I've ever used (barring foam pads), but may be something with the material, it just heats up too quickly for me.Noise isolation - 5/5This headphone fits remarkably well against your ears isolating most of the noise outside and prevents any leakage. I think because of the soft memory foam type of materials used and this actually reminds me of the suction cups. It creates almost like a vacuum when it fits. May be this also is the reason for sweaty ears and material heating up. But anyway, you can use this in any quiet place like library or noisy like planes, trains etc.Battery life - 5/5Lasts really long and at 2 hours of use per day it lasts at least 1 full week. The specification says 17 hours and I think it really delivers. Takes about 3 hours to charge fully. Bluetooth doesn't work while charging and you'll have to use the cable. The red LED indicator is nifty and shows how much charge is left, if it blinks 3 times then battery is full, 2 times half, and 1 time means low. When the battery is about to die the indicator becomes red and when it finally dies it beeps and shuts off.Style and design - 5/5Its actually made of plastics, but looks very stylish and is pretty sturdy. Do not expect aluminium and metal parts, but they actually look like it. There are play, skip up/down and a dedicated volume up/down button. The cable works when there is no battery and once you insert it actually switches off the Bluetooth and buttons. The headphone comes with micro USB charging cable, a 3.5 mm audio cable (can be inserted either way), and a carrying case or pouch.Price - 5/5Bought this for $130 and its a very good price for this!Overall - 4/5Considering everything I can recommend this headphones to anyone, but just do not expect audiophile type sound from $130 headphone. I think I did make that mistake, and it was a disappointment. I will update on the sound quality aspect after a few weeks. In almost every other aspect this is a near perfect headphone. Well done Sony.-- Edit Aug/2014 --The headphones are good for the price; the issue of ear pads getting hot is better since I've found the optimal setting for headbands so that they're not very tightly fitting. I still think the sound quality could've been better.I've also modified the pouch with Velcro Tape so that it stays closed, both the main slot and the smaller inside pocket to store the cables etc. Now the headphones and cables do not fall out and stay secure. Pouch lacks any kind of padding though and won't protect it, its just a carrying case.

Have had this router since Oct 2013 and have replaced it several times already. Amazon's service was excellent and finally I was tired of sending the product back numerous times. Its possible that I got a defective device, but after more than five replacements I can't believe I'm stuck with a bad unit. In all honesty they all behaved the same and I just couldn't find a difference between any of the units I tried.The problem is that 5 Ghz band has 'very' limited range and excellent speed. The 2.4 Ghz band has poor speed and poor range. Also switching between bands isn't seamless as I experienced from other routers. More often than not you'll have to switch the wifi on and off (on the device) to get the connection working again when you move between zones (or rooms/floors). This is just not acceptable from a $150 router. Connection via the cable is fine, but I reckon most people buy this for the wireless connection and not to just use as a $10 LAN switch.Also kept updating the firmware, tried old firmware, added extender, added huge antennae etc. but to no avail. This remains one of the worst tech products I've ever bought and such a disappointment. Every other router I've used in the past 15 years, from $10-40 has worked better than this. Asus tried to help, but it was always the same old advice, i.e.There are three possible reasons of Bad link quality or bad signal strength:1. Interference by other electronic devices that using same radio frequency2. Wireless signal is blocked by thick wall, metal door, ceiling and other obstacles3. Exceed the effective coverage range of wireless router and access point(AP)However, I wasted several days trying to troubleshoot and after replacing the units multiple times I've to conclude that this router is not for everyone. The sheer number of 1 star reviews is a testament to how bad or unreliable this router is. Completely avoid unless you live in a very small apartment/home.

I didn't buy this for the Liftmaster brand remotes for garage door opener. Instead I bought this for a generic gate opener remote which was taking up much space on both our key fobs/key chains. Our remote didn't have any space or opening to insert this clip, so I bought Scotch Exterior Mounting Tape, which is double sided, cut it exactly as the size of the clip and attached it to the remote. The only thing is that the tape is supposed to be permanent, so there might be residue if you try to take it off. Now both our cars have the gate opener on the visor. One less key to carry around and no more juggling through several keys/remote to find it at the gate. Considering that the remote + clip goes for under $10-15 this should only really cost $1-2 or less.Function - 5 starsPrice - 1 starOverall - 3 stars

I bought this to replace the standard bulbs (Philips H7 Standard Headlight Bulb, Pack of 1)I had on my low beams. These are slightly brighter and whiter than the standard fitment, but nothing to write home about. My car has projector headlights and the difference isn't much and I still find these yellow, not perfectly white or blueish, albeit definitely brighter and lighter yellow.According to Philips specifications, life time of this bulb is B3/Tc = 200/400. B3 means time at which 3% of bulbs have failed, i.e. 200 hours and Tc means around 63.2% of bulbs have failed by 400 hours. So if you drive 1 hour on an average per day using the headlight, it should last around 6-7 months or so. The standard bulbs have approximately 750 hours of lifetime, so definitely should last 3-4 times these, i.e couple of years easily. All the 1 star reviews mentioning that this bulb is yellow is true.The difference in price isn't much, $15 for standard vs. $25 for these, but you have to replace them around 3-4 times during the life of a standard bulb and now its $15 vs. $75-100. Save your money and just buy regular bulbs, they last longer and pretty much same visibility too. I went for style over substance and don't make the same mistake.

I actually bought this to punch a hole on a leather watch strap. The 2mm is perfect for that, cuts with ease and a nice finish. Also used it on a leather belt using the 3.5 and 4 mm punch. Its sharp enough for a nice finish and with some pressure you can easily punch holes.The only negative is that the punch holes are lubricated and the only way to turn or select a different punch is to literally rotate it by holding it and grease/oil (black in color) gets in to your hands and/or the material you're punching into. It's also tight and since its slippery kind of hard to rotate. Be careful if you're punching holes on a white leather or any other light colored material. I would've liked the design such that there is a knob to select the different size punch. Okay, may be that's an overkill for punch pliers!This really is a nifty tool to have in your tool box. For $6 or 7 bucks you can't go wrong considering there are other pliers selling for thrice as much, doing pretty much the same thing.

I bought these as a replacement for Apple EarPods with Remote and Mic (the new ones with iPhone 5/5s) that my spouse has been using. These earphones are widely reviewed and I first came across this on a thread on Head-Fi forum (there is a 100+ page thread on these). Everything they say about this is true. I've never seen a earphone this well built, in its price range. Every little detail is perfectly designed and manufactured using quality materials.There are so many fakes you can buy from $1-10 on eBay. Watch this video on YouTube to check the difference between fake and original (pasting the video id number since Amazon remove links, go to YouTube and search for 4nEAsiwYAw0; its in Russian, but hey its a video). I bought it from the seller boat2014 with the symbol MI for $22.99 with free 2 day Prime shipping.Sound Quality - 5/5This is the most important aspect of any earphone. The sound is very neutral but at the same time there is enough bass. Lows aren't overly pronounced and some of you bass-heads won't like this, but once you increase the volume you get a very nice, non-muddy tight bass. If you want more bass check out Xiaomi Piston 1.0. Also the highs are a little sharper or crisp than I personally like, but its really fine. I only felt that when I first listened to it and then I couldn't distinguish it. May be my ears were used to sound from the earphones I always used. The mids are amazing and I think for this price you can't really ask for a better sound. I've had this only for a week so depending on whether you believe in burn-in theory or not this could improve over time. The point is, there is not a single earphone at this price which sounds this great. I have had Apple earphones, Skullcandy's, Jlabs J6Ms, GOgroove audiOHM, Sennheiser 300 and Bose IE2 etc. and I have to say this earphone sounds better than all of these listed. I also think the earphones are better suited for music rather than movies or audio-books or podcast.Comfort and Noise Isolation - 4.5/5The box has 3 extra tips and you can find the one that matches your ear. The one on the earphone was medium (2nd biggest) and when I tried the medium from the box I found it too small, so ended up using the one that came with it. The noise isolation is pretty good and there is hardly any leak. You can easily use this in a quiet environment like airplane, public transportation (train or bus) or library etc. The tips are slightly harder than I expected and hence it can come off your ears easier than some soft tips.Build Quality - 4.5/5The housing is made of metal and has a gold finish with three circle engraving. The cable is covered in a braided fabric, similar to shoelaces, and this prevents noise when cable rubs against your body or clothing. It comes with 3 extra tips (total 4 sets). of There is a mic and 3 buttons, for skip/volume-up/down/play/pause etc. Function of the button also depends on the type of OS and app you're using. The mic is not on the left/right cable, but at the junction of the Y cable which is slightly shorter than I would like. So its not easy to distinguish between the left or right piece and cable could've been a little longer. I compared it to a few earphones lying around and this was 2 inches shorter than most. This is one of the minor negatives I could find. There is also a metal clip, but I didn't like it and thought it was too long. The packing and case are made of amazing quality materials and I think its actually an overkill. I wish the manufacturer actually included a small pouch or carry case instead of the high quality packing.Price - 5/5If you find a better quality earphone (with mic) for under $25 please let me know.Will update the review on reliability and performance as I listen to it more.

We've used the smaller Zo-li and now got the bigger size too. It's very clever design and the straw end stays in liquid no matter how you tilt and turn it. My problem is that the outer straw is made of cheap and thin materials and it cannot withstand toddlers biting, chewing, twisting or turning. We've had this only for less than a month and I've to look for replacement straws already. This was the same exact problem with the smaller bottle too. The bottle also is thin and flimsy made with cheap plastic which probably costs nothing.For the price they charge ($10-15), they've got to make it with better materials!5 stars for the design, 1 star for materials and manufacturing.Update -- 7/2014 --Contacted the manufacturer and they sent me a replacement straw since it lasted only 1 month. According to Zoli the straw is supposed to last around 3 months and customer is supposed to replace it at that time for hygienic reasons.

We've used the smaller Zo-li and now got the bigger size too. It's very clever design and the straw end stays in liquid no matter how you tilt and turn it. My problem is that the outer straw is made of cheap and thin materials and it cannot withstand toddlers biting, chewing, twisting or turning. We've had this only for less than a month and I've to look for replacement straws already. This was the same exact problem with the smaller bottle too. The bottle also is thin and flimsy made with cheap plastic which probably costs nothing.For the price they charge ($10-15), they've got to make it with better materials!5 stars for the design, 1 star for materials and manufacturing.

I bought the same watch band on eBay for $25 and it included the Breitling style deployment buckle as well. This strap is made of quality materials and is very well made. Looks sturdy and hopefully will last long. It's very thick near the lugs and tapers towards the end. Doesn't look cheap at all. The white contrast stitching is thicker than what it should be, but its still great. I probably wouldn't pay $40, but for $25 it was worth it. I ended up changing the buckle to an Omega style buckle which is also listed under the same seller or you can find it on eBay (you have to punch holes if you want to use it with an Omega style clasp). I used the 22mm strap on a 21mm lug and it fits fine (the end/clasp is 20mm).4 stars.--- Update September 2014 ---Initially I had given 4 stars, but now the material is peeling off. I doubt its real leather because real leather doesn't peel-off the surface. Downgrading it to 2 stars only.

This watch is the International version of the very popular Seiko SSC081 (Seiko Men's SSC081 Adventure-Solar Classic Casual Watch is exactly the same). I had seen this watch earlier in Costco for about $180-200 and always liked it, but never bought it. The reviews on Amazon are pretty much 5 stars and there is hardly anything wrong with the watch. I mainly wear automatics and was tired of setting the time and date on them over and over again since the power reserve on most watches don't last more than 2 days (I don't have a watch winder). So long story short, I found this on Smartbargains website for $168 with a $20 coupon and it was a no-brainer for me under $150.A lot of reviews cover the function and settings of this watch so I won't go into too much details that have already been reviewed.Positives first -1) The watch looks awesome (the watch case, bezel and crown all has a gloss finish).2) For the price I couldn't find a better looking and functional watch. It uses Seiko's Cal V172.0AG0 Solar movement.3) Solar charging part is great and I've never had to adjust time since I bought it a month back. I don't wear it everyday, but may be 2-3 days a week. The manual claims 5 hours of charging on a fair weather day in sunlight will fully charge the battery which would then last 6 months! It also mentions that normal office/fluorescent lighting is not enough to fully charge the watch.4) Second hand sweeps like automatics, but it stops after an hour since its function is primarily as a stop watch. Otherwise it stays stationary at the 12 hour. Technical specifications say its a 60-minute stopwatch in 1/5-second increments with split time measurement function.5) The hands and markers has excellent lume and is very bright at night, however it doesn't last all that long.Some negatives -1) Initially I actually liked the honey/caramel/camel/orange/light (whatever brown color) watch band it came with, the band was thick, well made and comes with a polished matte finish tang buckle. However, the strap is very long and this for me was a big negative. I don't have a small wrist by any means, but its still too long and I don't like the way it sits in the loop, especially now that the second loop has become loose. For comparison purposes, this strap is 3/4 inches longer than any other strap I have. Ended up changing the strap to a Breitling style strap Handmade 22mm Genuine Leather Watch Band Strap Alliagtor Style with Deployment Clasp for Breitling with an Omega style buckle 20mm Swiss S/S Deployment Clasp for Omega Seamaster Speedmaster. I bought both of them on eBay for a total of $54 ($25 for the strap and $28 for the buckle).2) The compass is useless, moves around all the time with the slightest of touches.3) Alarm function could've been better, but can be set to ring only once at a designated time within the next 12 hours. It's also feeble unless you use it in a very quiet environment. It also only rings for 20 seconds and to stop you can push any of the buttons.Overall 5 stars for the function, looks and price!Update - 06/30/2014The Hardlex crystal is not very scratch resistant. I already have a small scratch and I can't remember hitting the watch against anything. After reading more about the Hardlex crystal the consensus seems to be that it scratches easier than Sapphire crystal but has better impact resistance.

We got it for our toddler and the shoe looks nice and fits well. However the shoe is now falling apart after only 1 1/2 months of use. The toe is peeling off and the stitches are coming apart. Read the 1 star and 2 star reviews and you can see the problem is exactly the same for everyone complaining. I would contact the manufacturer and see if I can get an exchange or my money back.A $40 shoe for a kid who weighs less than 30 pounds should last longer than this. 1 star considering how expensive this is.-- Update --After contacting Amazon and Marubeni corp, they made it right for me by sending a replacement pair. Excellent customer service by both companies, 5 stars. I would not change the 1 star rating of the product though, no shoe should fall apart in just a month.

I bought this from a seller on eBay, not sure if its the same seller as here, but all items here on Amazon and eBay looks exactly the same and more or less at the same price.The buckle is very well made and fits 20 mm end side or the clasp side watch bands. So this is perfect for most of the 22mm lug side watch bands. Measure both ends of the strap before you order it to make sure. The deployment mechanism works exactly as it should and the stainless steel has a polished chrome look (shiny/glossy and not matte finish). It won't really work with watch bands that are the regular tang type with loops (unless you cut loops out). Among all the different type of deployment buckles out there, I like this one the most. It gives the cleanest fit with the remaining length of the band going inside, rather than sticking outside in the loop (and hence no need of loops). This will work with any watch band without the loops. Deployment buckles help prolong the life of your leather strap also.The buckle looks exactly the same as original Omega buckles, bar the logo, which goes for $200-300. Should be 5 stars, but $30 is still a high price for a piece of stainless steel that weighs less than 1 ounce (or 28 grams). So overall 4 stars.

Disclosure - I received the LifeCHARGE Battery Case as a free sample. I used it on iPhone 5.First the function part. The battery case works very well, exactly as claimed. The case looks good and is well made. The original iPhone 5 battery has 1,440 mAh capacity and this one is 2,300 mAh. So technically about 160% capacity as the iPhone 5 (on a side note it just shows how poor the iPhone batteries are, even the new iPhone 5s is only 1,560 mAh; for comparison purposes Samsung S5 is 2,800 mAh, Nexus 5 is 2,300 mAh). I have to charge the iPhone at least once during the day and this case lasts at least 2 days. The 2-piece sliding case attaches to the lighting port and uses that to charge the iPhone battery and this case in turn is charged via a micro USB port (same as in the new Blackberrys', many Android devices etc.). There is a button on the back of the case with a 4 step indicator. Once you power on the case it starts charging the iPhone battery. You can also switch it off once the desired level of charge is reached. It charges the iPhone battery really fast. The specifications claim 1 hour 30 mins and I found that to be pretty accurate. The battery case itself takes about 3-4 hours for a full charge, but I think mine never ran out completely so it always charged fully in around 2-3 hours. There are plenty of reviews on the charging and battery aspect so I won't get into too many details.Now the form part. This is where I reduced 1 star from the rating (can be 2 if you're very particular). The case is 0.63 inch or 16 mm thick and that's more than twice as thick as the iPhone 5/5s (depth: 0.30 inch or 7.6 mm). Its also 16 mm longer than the phone (or 0.62 inches extra) Once you attach the case the weight also roughly doubles (iPhone 5/5s weight: 3.95 ounces or 112 grams) since the case weighs 3.2 ounces (or 91 grams). So now the end result is that we have a brick that is 16 mm thick and weighing almost half a pound (0.45 pounds or 203 grams), or pretty much the same weight as a Kindle Paperweight or a Logitech Harmony 700 universal remote. You get the idea. Your pocket starts to swell and sag at this point.I understand all battery cases are somewhat in the same size/weight range, so its more of my frustration towards Apple for not including a battery that would last 1 full day or same as any other smartphone in the market nowadays.Summary - I'm kind of getting used to not charging the phone every now and then and not worrying about the phone dying in the middle of something, especially when you're travelling without easy access to chargers. However, its just too bulky and heavy for my personal preferences. I also wouldn't buy it for the full retail price of $79.99, its just not worth it, no cell phone battery is. For me the right price is about $30 (FYI -the Black version is sold by Amazon.com for $39.99). Probably it explains why there is only 1 verified purchaser among the 45 or so reviews so far. If you are a heavy user, travels a lot and don't mind the weight or bulk then buy this.

I'm writing this review almost two years after I bought this laptop. Bought this HP laptop from Staples for $450 on a deal from Slickdeals. This would be the first time I'm buying an HP laptop, I've owned Sony Vaio, Toshiba, Apple Macbook Pro, Dell Inspiron etc. till then (and even now). All the above said laptops have lasted more than 4-7 years. Granted, some of them I've had to replace the battery, certain keys, charger etc. but all of them worked without any component just dying.HP Pavilion DM4-2191US is lightweight, looks good and came with a fingerprint reader. It only has 1 slot for RAM so if you're looking to upgrade then you have to replace it with a 8/16 GB stick. I never liked the keyboard and touchpad; both were flimsy and not very well designed and had bad layout. The display was nice even though it was glossy and had a lot of glare. The laptop was fast enough for most home/office work. Battery life was also more than I expected from laptop of this price. Wifi is a disappointment as the wifi card doesn't support the faster 5 GHz N band (only supports the 2.4 GHz).Now to the bad. Right after the first year of ownership the hard drive crashed and I lost all data. I also lost all the software since I had lost the original keys for Office 2010 and  some other cheap software. I tried to recover data from the hard drive but none of the recovery guys were able to get it done. HP doesn't ship any recovery discs with the laptop so you have to pay around $16 to order recovery discs. I ordered a new hard drive ($62) and finally replaced it. In a few months the LCD screen won't work and is just white. The computer works fine when connected to an external display. Now I'm ordering a replacement screen for another $50. I also spent money in tools, cables, enclosures, IDE/SATA connectors etc. while trying to recover the hard drive. Its just poorly made with cheap quality components and I see a lot of failures going by the reviews on HP laptops. I understand that all electronics/components are susceptible to failure.  But the way multiple parts failed and had to be replaced doesn't inspire confidence and I probably will not buy another HP.

The old balcony door handle finally gave away and broke where its screwed on. Went to Home Depot and they only had the whole set including lock etc. for $20-25 bucks. Well immediately I tried Amazon app on the phone and found an exact match! $8 bucks and got it in 2 days (with Prime). Also most places had the 6 1/2 inch handles and I wanted a 6 5/8 inch one. Measure your handle before you order one. This one looks sturdy and hopefully will last years.One thing to note is that the new fasteners (screws) were slightly longer than the original ones I had. So DO NOT discard the old ones and keep it handy just in case.

I really liked the pumpkin patch since it is hard to find outside decorations that fall between childish and scary. It is 3.5 feet tall at its tallest point and inflates from a single blower at the far left end. The reason I am returning it is because it lacks loops and rope to be tied down. It includes five 5.5 inch metal stakes and that is it. Something this large needs more reinforcement. There isn't even a place to attach ropes if I wanted to. Fall brings strong winds and I just can't take a chance that it will blow away.

I really liked the pumpkin patch since it is hard to find outside decorations that fall between childish and scary. It is 3.5 feet tall at its tallest point and inflates from a single blower at the far left end. The reason I am returning it is because it lacks loops and rope to be tied down. It includes five 5.5 inch metal stakes and that is it. Something this large needs more reinforcement. There isn't even a place to attach ropes if I wanted to. Fall brings strong winds and I just can't take a chance that it will blow away.

This is the only set that has all 7 dogs including the newest dog in 2015 - Everest. These are action pack pups so each one has a special backpack that is triggered by pushing a button on the pups collar. Beautiful metallic finish. Instant hit with my almost 4 year old. I do wish the pups badges were included, especially at this price point. However, the only way to get them is to purchase each pup individually.Please note that this set retails for $49.99 and is an exclusive item at Target.

My son had his first hands on experience with this toy at our State Fair which was visited by the Paw Patrol Tour. They had a tent set up with several Paw Patrol toys and this was by far the most popular toy amongst the children. The best part is that given the extra large size of this thing it can easily be shared by more than one child. It is a generous 27.5 inches long. The photos show it fitting the larger vehicles, which is does, but as an added bonus is also fits the smaller racer cars. When the patroller is closed up it can fit 3 of the larger vehicles or 6 of the racers if they are placed vertically.My disappoint is that it comes with Ryder and not robo pup. Ryder is already available separately and consequently we already have him. I'm not sure why they bother including him at all.This toy retails for $59. Be patient and don't pay the exaggerated prices.

These dolls could not be more perfect for the beach. Their swimsuits are painted on and the doll still looks good after a day in the sand with no paint chipping etc. I bought all 5 of the girl dolls for my daughter. The boy dolls have fabric swim suits and I just don't want to bother with keeping track of doll clothes on the beach.Added bonus: The packaging comes apart very quickly and there are no annoying twist ties etc to fight with.

This top is cute but VERY sheer. The front is more of a light heather grey instead of the white pictured and is made of a lose viscose (almost like cotton) material. The whole thing is hand wash only. The gem details are cute. My opinion is that this top would be better for juniors and not young girls.

I was so excited to get these on sale. I'm normally a 9.5. I got two in size 9 and they were both uncomfortably tight. Amazon exchanged them for size 10 but they are too wide and too big. I guess I'm between sizes and they don't offer half sizes. So sad. They seem really comfortable, especially in the heel.

I bought two for my toddlers bed. They never stayed on top of the bed. Every morning I would find them (still under the sheet) on the side of the mattress. Every night before bed I would put them back. After a week one developed a slow leak in one of the seams. After 6 weeks the other one called it quits at a seam as well.I love that these are made from Phthalate, lead and BPA free plastic. However, it seems the resulting plastic is not strong enough to make a secure seal at the seam.

My daughter loves these shoes. I bought them specifically for the Princess Belle decoration. After a month of regular use the image of Belle is scratching off the gem it was painted on. I'm very disappointed. I find them difficult to get on her feet and my husband really struggles with them. Even with the velcro loosened the resulting hole to stick her foot in is not large enough. I get the majority of her foot in the shoe and then I have her stand up so her weight can force her foot in the rest of the way.At the end of the day, my daughter still loves them. That is what matters.

As mentioned by others, the frame/legs are flimsy. They are a joke really. It came out of the box misshapen but forcing the copper pit in to the frame rounded it out. They are made out of thin sheet metal.The screen is also not a perfect circle and needs to be forced on to the pit. This can be very annoying mid fire when I need to forcefully pull it off the copper pit and then forcefully snap it back on.The copper bowl came dented but a quick chat with Amazon and I got 20% refunded to me for the damage.Lastly, the weather cover doesn't fit. The elastic opening is just not big enough to fit around the bowl.In case you were curious, this product is made in India.I would not buy this again. The value is not there for the price paid. The copper bowl is nice but everything else is cheaply constructed.

I received this toy as a baby shower gift and my son is now 13 months. We introduced the toy at 6 months.Pros:- He likes the shapes. They each make a different sound and are different colors.Cons:- Each of the shapes can fit easily into any of the holes, defeating the purpose of being a shape sorter all together.- When you drop the circle ball into the circle hole it falls out of the square hole on the opposite side.- It is bulky and not something you can just throw into a diaper bag. I wouldn't mind this if the toy was useful, but it isn't.Overall this is an overpriced sack that you can stuff different shaped soft balls into. If you are looking for a proper shape sorter you would be better served by the Toysmith Battat Sound Puzzle Box. If you are looking for a soft toy that your young infant will enjoy and possibly learn from, try the Lamaze High-Contrast Discovery Shapes Activity Puzzle & Crib Gallery. I'm sorry I got this.

We bought the XL (18-24 months) for my 1 year old son. He is 32 inches tall and 22.5lbs. It fit him perfectly and the white shirt is long enough to stay tucked in. I paired it with white knee socks and black shoes and he looked super cute.If you're having a hard time keeping the suspenders up, cross them in the back before you button them in the front.

I got this bottle for my exclusively breastfed 6 month old who was never introduced to a bottle as a young infant. We tried several other bottles and nipples and he would never latch. After reading a review from a lactation consultant I decided to they these.At first I was impressed with the bottle because he would latch 50% of the time - a huge improvement from never latching. Sadly, after several weeks of practice I was never able to get him to latch reliably. I left him with grandma while I attended a wedding and he outright refused to latch for her.They are very annoying to clean. They are dishwasher safe but the interior lip of the bottle always traps water even when placed in the dishwasher completely upright. I never felt like they were completely clean since leftover dishwasher water was sloshing around in them. Even when I hand washed them and set them out to dry the water would pool on the lip.Milk gets trapped inside the bottle lip during feedings. I struggled with milk supply so pumped milk was like gold and it was frustrating to see milk wasted. The only way to get all the milk out is to hold the bottle completely upside down and swirl it around to encourage the milk off the interior lip. Not exactly a natural angle to hold a bottle while feeding a baby.I never did find a good way to warm milk inside this bottle (it is short and fat). Instead, I warmed the milk in the glass bottle that I pump into and then poured it into the mOmma bottle.My son started on a straw sippy cup (Playtex Baby First Lil' Gripper Twist 'n Click Straw Trainer Cup, 7 Ounce, Colors May Vary) at 10 months and I completely gave up on bottles. I've learned the hard lesson for the next baby that I need to introduce a bottle before they are 2 months.It is encouraging to read another review that says the nipples from this bottle fit Avent bottles. If that is true I would skip the bottles all together and just get the nipples. I had some success with the mOmma nipples and perhaps if the bottle wasn't so terrible I would have pushed the bottle training more.----UPDATE----I had some Dr Brown's Wide-neck bottles in the cabinet so I decided to try the mOmma nipples in them. They fit perfectly and didn't leak when I had my son drink his almond milk from it. He still struggles with latching continuously but with some time and patience he drank 4 oz with no leaks. Dr. Brown's BPA Free Polypropylene Natural Flow Wide Neck Bottle, 8 oz - 3-Pack

These nipples are great for breastfed babies. Don't bother with the mOmma bottles. Their round design is terrible for feeding and cleaning. These nipples fit Dr Brown's Wide Neck bottles with no leaking. (Dr. Brown's BPA Free Polypropylene Natural Flow Wide Neck Bottle, 8 oz - 3-PackThe packaging on the mOmma nipples pops open super easy, maybe too easy. I prefer it to the hard shell packaging that other things come in but this may irritate some if it opens in the mail before you get it.

I just got a sample box of these and let my 12 month old have a pouch. He devoured the entire thing and asked for more. I've never seen him like a snack this much, not even his previous favorite: Happy Baby Organic Puffs, Greens Puffs, 2.1-Ounce Containers (Pack of 6). The best part is they are made from just 5 simple ingredients: Organic Apple Juice Puree Concentrate, Organic Apple Juice Concentrate, Cellulose, Pectin, and Natural Flavors.

I got this bottle for my exclusively breastfed 6 month old who was never introduced to a bottle as a young infant. We tried several other bottles and nipples and he would never latch. After reading a review from a lactation consultant I decided to they these.At first I was impressed with the bottle because he would latch 50% of the time - a huge improvement from never latching. Sadly, after several weeks of practice I was never able to get him to latch reliably. I left him with grandma while I attended a wedding and he outright refused to latch for her.They are very annoying to clean. They are dishwasher safe but the interior lip of the bottle always traps water even when placed in the dishwasher completely upright. I never felt like they were completely clean since leftover dishwasher water was sloshing around in them. Even when I hand washed them and set them out to dry the water would pool on the lip.Milk gets trapped inside the bottle lip during feedings. I struggled with milk supply so pumped milk was like gold and it was frustrating to see milk wasted. The only way to get all the milk out is to hold the bottle completely upside down and swirl it around to encourage the milk off the interior lip. Not exactly a natural angle to hold a bottle while feeding a baby.I never did find a good way to warm milk inside this bottle (it is short and fat). Instead, I warmed the milk in the glass bottle that I pump into and then poured it into the mOmma bottle.My son started on a straw sippy cup (Playtex Baby First Lil' Gripper Twist 'n Click Straw Trainer Cup, 7 Ounce, Colors May Vary) at 10 months and I completely gave up on bottles. I've learned the hard lesson for the next baby that I need to introduce a bottle before they are 2 months.It is encouraging to read another review that says the nipples from this bottle fit Avent bottles. If that is true I would skip the bottles all together and just get the nipples. I had some success with the mOmma nipples and perhaps if the bottle wasn't so terrible I would have pushed the bottle training more.----UPDATE----I had some Dr Brown's Wide-neck bottles in the cabinet so I decided to try the mOmma nipples in them. They fit perfectly and didn't leak when I had my son drink his almond milk from it. He still struggles with latching continuously but with some time and patience he drank 4 oz with no leaks. Dr. Brown's BPA Free Polypropylene Natural Flow Wide Neck Bottle, 8 oz - 3-Pack

I spent about 15-20 minutes putting the rampway together. My 1 year old immediately started squealing in delight as cars raced down the rampway. I was so excited to see him be happy with his new toy. He loves to push buttons and get a reaction from toys so I read the box to see which parts should react to him. I was sad to find that the stop sign near the red flashing light was not working at all.I called Fisher Price Customer Service and was told that I needed to mail them the top blue ramp and the two cars the rampway comes with. In return they would send me a whole new rampway. Essentially their policy is that I destroy the toy and pay my own money to mail them parts of a toy that was broken out of the box through no fault of my own.This is the email I just got from them:Thank you for contacting Mattel regarding your Lp Wheelies Rampway.  We apologize for any disappointment or concern this may have caused and thank you for bringing this matter to our attention.We have included a United States Postal Service mailing label for the return of your item. You will need to pay the appropriate postage for your package when you take it to the post office.  It is the mailer's responsibility to obtain proof of mailing, as we will not be responsible for any items lost or not received.  To ensure that you receive service in the event that your package is lost in transit, we recommend that you obtain a receipt for postage paid.  Retain this receipt along with any remainder of your product until you receive your replacement product.Please return your Top Blue Ramp Piece And Cars to us within 30 days.  Upon receipt of your returned package, a replacement product will be sent.  This process may take up to 6 weeks.Basically Fisher Price expects me to pay more money for their broken toy and then wait up to 6 weeks for a new toy to arrive. Meanwhile my son is without his new toy that he really enjoys.Thankfully Amazon cares about its customers and I'll be dealing with them directly. They are more than happy to send me a new toy and pay for the shipping both ways. However, I thought other parents out there should be aware of just how little Fisher Price cares about its customers.

I was really excited for the Skip Hop Elbow Rest. We currently use the very popular Aquatopia Deluxe Safety Easy Bath Kneeler, Blue but I don't like how bulky and difficult it is to stow away between baths. This elbow rest seemed to solve all of my problems, it even has a handy loop to hang it up.Out of the package I was excited to see that it has Velcro to keep the side flaps tucked together when not in use. It also has a nice, thick pad to protect parents' elbows.Unfortunately, that is where my excitement ends. I have sliding shower doors and the flaps of the elbow rest aren't long enough to reach over the door tracks and attach to the tub wall. The elbow pad itself is only 16 inches long (6.5 inches shorter than the Aquatopia Deluxe Safety Easy Bath Kneeler, Blue). For me the elbow rest has two functions. To keep my elbows comfortable and more importantly to protect my son from the shower door tracks if he slips in the tub. This doesn't come close to covering the edge of the tub. I don't expect it to cover the entire tub but 1/3 of it would be nice. On the flip side are a total of 3 suction cups. 1 on the tub side and 2 on the parent side. My sons likes to take apart everything, I doubt that is enough suction cups to keep it securely attached to the tub when a toddler is involved.If I were Skip Hop I would add at least 4 inches to the length, 1 inch to each of the flaps, and more suction cups. Then they would have the perfect elbow rest.I've added photos to the customer images section. Check them out and please let me know if you find them helpful! Thanks!

I got the Large in the Pup Pals print. When I opened the package I immediately noticed a smell that I can only relate to acrylic paint. I have since washed the blanket 3 times (once in hot water) attempting to remove the smell but to no avail. I ordered the same SleepSack in light blue and there is no odor.I emailed Halo and a very nice person responded within hours: "Regarding the smell, we don't treat our fabric or finished items with any chemicals.  I can't explain the odor you experienced but can at least assure you we are chemical free."Separately, at 11 months old my son is 30.5 inches tall and has been walking for 2 months. He cannot comfortably walk while wearing this and actually tripped on the extra fabric. When I expressed this concern to Halo they let me know that a size Medium will be available in early 2013 and offered to send me a sample. I will update my review once I've received it.

I have used this net everyday for almost a year and I can tell you it is so much more than a UV/Mosquito net. We leave it attached to the stroller at all times. It was particularly helpful when my son was very young and I was afraid of strangers touching him. We called it our old lady net.As he got older it became helpful for naps in the stroller. The top gray part folds down over the mosquito screen and completely blocks out light.The negative reviewer that states the net is difficult to attach is incorrect. There are no instructions included so I can see how it could be confusing at first. However,  anyone with common sense can figure it out quickly. There is a Velcro attachment around the front wheels and elastic bands that wrap around the side bars. The net is held across the fully extended sun shade with elastic.This net also fits the Britax B-Ready Stroller 2012, Red.I have washed the net several times and it still looks new. The elastic bands that hold the net to the side bars are beginning to stretch out a little from the continued use but given the overall quality and usefulness of the net itself I have no qualms about replacing the elastic at a later date if need be.

Don't waste your money on this. It barely stays on the B-Ready and the bottom does not attach to anything. When you recline the stroller for baby to take a nap the bottom of the net lays on their feet. It flops around in the slightest of breeze or if you walk fast.Britax makes a much better net for the B-Agile - Britax B-Agile Stroller UV Mosquito Net - I tested it and it fits the B-Ready too! The B-Agile net has elastic to keep it tight around the bottom. I highly recommend it.

This fits the Britax B-Agile perfectly. It does cover the pull strap for folding but it is easily accessible through the hole the crotch strap comes through.The liner does move around a bit and needs to be repositioned but it takes just a second to tug back into place and is way easier than spot cleaning my stroller.It washes well and didn't shrink. I put it in the dryer for 10 minutes and then let it air dry the rest of the way.I don't recommend it for the Britax B-Ready. The B-Ready has a narrow seat and this liner is too wide for it.

This is a nice basic wood frame with glass. I think it is overpriced for the basic quality but I needed something quickly. It was packaged well and had a minor scratch that I corrected with a sharpie. I am happy that the tabs on the back are the swivel kind and not the cheap bendable kind that tend to snap off after a few replacements of the photo.

Be careful what version you are ordering. It seems the glowing recommendations are for the Kindle version or the hardcover.I ordered 4 copies of the paperback version and all 4 looked like they were printed on someone's inkjet printer. The pages were glued together, the images were grainy, and there was a faint black line running across every page from the printer they were printed on. I am shocked Amazon would sell such a terrible piece of garbage. Luckily they gave me my money back.I have posted photos in the customer images section.

The product description does not list the ingredients so here they are:Ingredients: Organic Vegetables (Organic Peas, Organic Carrots), Water, Organic Ground Chicken, Organic Whole Oat Flour, Organic Split Pea Powder.

I watched this item for several months and hesitated ordering it because of the reviews stating that it was to small for Target shopping carts. In March 2012 I noticed some new colors were available so I decided to give it a try. When I received the box it had a sticker on it that read - "New & Improved Larger Size." I brought it to Target and it fit the cart with plenty of room to spare. So far I'm very happy with it.I've posted photos of the box and the cover on a Target shopping cart in the customer photos section.

As a buyer of well-over 300 Baofeng radios (and counting) for the group I belong to (not all of which were purchased through Amazon but many were), I'm always amazed at the lengths some sellers go to to hype their products as being "newer" or "better" than other models, or perhaps (to give them the benefit of the doubt) they just don't know any better.First, the Baofeng UV-5R series (including the original and still extremely popular UV-5R, I'll explain why in a minute) is what is normally referred to by many as a SDR radio (or software defined radio).  While not a true SDR product (you can't use it with your computer to control the radio's functions or scan a wide amount of VHF/UHF frequencies with it), none the less a large chip is programmed on the circuit board built inside each radio.  That chip determines what capability the radio itself can perform.Every UV-5R series radio has the ability to transmit from 136-174 MHz on VHF and from 400-520 MHz on UHF in both narrow-band and wide-band modes (very useful for the occasional FRS or MURS use, which requires narrow-band mode to work correctly).Every model does "at least" 4W on VHF/UHF from the factory, but occasionally you'll get a batch that does 4.5W or even 5W out, but the difference between 4W and 5W is minimal at best.  A 4W radio with a better antenna will easily outperform a 5W radio with the standard crappy antenna that Baofeng ships on ALL (including the UV-5RA, -5RAX, and -5RAX+) models.Baofeng DOES NOT program those chips any differently for the UV-5R vs. any other UV-5R series (including the UV-5RA).  Version 307 of the firmware (which is the most current release I have in any of my radios) works EXACTLY the same way as previous older releases of firmware at least back to the 295 release (over a year ago), so any claim from a seller that this release provides additional features (at least from a user's perspective) is simply BOGUS, since the firmware inside both radios have the same features.  In fact, my UV-5R radios with the 307 firmware release is EXACTLY the same radio (inside and within the firmware) as my UV-5RA radios with the 307 firmware release.Second, you CANNOT in any way upgrade the firmware (unless you count buying a different radio and it comes with a different firmware release), so again the claim in the listing from some sellers that you can is simply BOGUS.Third, you can believe that two thinner pieces (glued or screwed together on the faceplate of the UV-5RA) is somehow stronger than one thicker piece of plastic (on the original UV-5R series) if you like (and maybe it is), but I haven't seen that in real-world use from my own UV-5RA units.  The standard UV-5R units that we use seem to hold up just as well (when dropped in the desert dirt or rolling down a hill) as any other Baofeng radio we own and use.Fourth, and my biggest issue with all of the non-standard UV-5RA, UV-5RAX and UV-5RAX+ units, is that NONE of the Baofeng battery accessories (except the little 1800 mAh standard battery) work WITHOUT modification (unless you use a Dremel tool to grind or cut off part of your extended battery that works on the standard UV-5R - but won't work on your UV-5RA, UV-5RAX or UV-5RAX+).Getting new UV-5RA units that don't work with Extended 3800 mAh batteries (without modification) doesn't make my group happy.  That may not bother you, but NONE of the sellers of the non-standard UV-5RA, UV-5RAX, and UV-5RAX+ units ever seem to mention that lack of hardware compatibility in their listings, so buyer beware!BTW, NONE of the "AA" or "AAA" battery shell packs work on the UV-5RA, UV-5RAX, or UV-5RAX+ units either, so that's 3 different battery accessories (including the 3800 mAh extended battery) that you can't use on these radios without hacking them with a Dremel tool (but they all work without modification on the original UV-5R units).So "if" you want a "pretty" radio (as my wife calls it), buy one of the various versions of the UV-5RA (or -5RAX, or -5RAX+) with the shiny face plate and live with the fact that you'll be modifying ALL of the battery accessories you buy later in order to get them to work.  Oh, you should see how well that shiny faceplate lights up when a flashlight hits it in the dark, just the thing you don't want for night use.Virtually every guy in our group ends up carrying a standard UV-5R and giving the UV-5RA, -5RAX, or -5RAX+ to the wife or kids, since the wife and/or kids rarely care about the other accessories working and they (the wife and kids) tend to like the "pretty" radios, but again there is NO INTERNAL difference and NO EXTRA FEATURES in the UV-5RA, -5RAX, or -5RAX+ units (other than a different looking shiny faceplate) vs. the original and still wildly popular UV-5R (which I refer to as the M16 of radios, as all the accessories you match it up with just plain work).Now you know the real background on these radios.

That chip determines what capability the radio itself can perform.Every UV-5R series radio has the ability to transmit from 136-174 MHz on VHF and from 400-520 MHz on UHF in both narrow-band and wide-band modes (very useful for the occasional FRS or MURS use, which requires narrow-band mode to work correctly).Every model does "at least" 4W on VHF/UHF from the factory, but occasionally you'll get a batch that does 4.5W or even 5W out, but the difference between 4W and 5W is minimal at best.  A 4W radio with a better antenna will easily outperform a 5W radio with the standard crappy antenna that Baofeng ships on ALL (including the UV-5RA, -5RAX, and -5RAX+) models.Baofeng DOES NOT program those chips any differently for the UV-5R vs. any other UV-5R series (including the UV-5RA).  Version 307 of the firmware (which is the most current release I have in any of my radios) works EXACTLY the same way as previous older releases of firmware at least back to the 295 release (over a year ago), so any claim from a seller that this release provides additional features (at least from a user's perspective) is simply BOGUS, since the firmware inside both radios have the same features.  In fact, my UV-5R radios with the 307 firmware release is EXACTLY the same radio (inside and within the firmware) as my UV-5RA radios with the 307 firmware release.Second, you CANNOT in any way upgrade the firmware (unless you count buying a different radio and it comes with a different firmware release), so again the claim in the listing from some sellers that you can is simply BOGUS.Third, you can believe that two thinner pieces (glued or screwed together on the faceplate of the UV-5RA) is somehow stronger than one thicker piece of plastic (on the original UV-5R series) if you like (and maybe it is), but I haven't seen that in real-world use from my own UV-5RA units.  The standard UV-5R units that we use seem to hold up just as well (when dropped in the desert dirt or rolling down a hill) as any other Baofeng radio we own and use.Fourth, and my biggest issue with all of the non-standard UV-5RA, UV-5RAX and UV-5RAX+ units, is that NONE of the Baofeng battery accessories (except the little 1800 mAh standard battery) work WITHOUT modification (unless you use a Dremel tool to grind or cut off part of your extended battery that works on the standard UV-5R - but won't work on your UV-5RA, UV-5RAX or UV-5RAX+).Getting new UV-5RA units that don't work with Extended 3800 mAh batteries (without modification) doesn't make my group happy.  That may not bother you, but NONE of the sellers of the non-standard UV-5RA, UV-5RAX, and UV-5RAX+ units ever seem to mention that lack of hardware compatibility in their listings, so buyer beware!BTW, NONE of the "AA" or "AAA" battery shell packs work on the UV-5RA, UV-5RAX, or UV-5RAX+ units either, so that's 3 different battery accessories (including the 3800 mAh extended battery) that you can't use on these radios without hacking them with a Dremel tool (but they all work without modification on the original UV-5R units).So "if" you want a "pretty" radio (as my wife calls it), buy one of the various versions of the UV-5RA (or -5RAX, or -5RAX+) with the shiny face plate and live with the fact that you'll be modifying ALL of the battery accessories you buy later in order to get them to work.  Oh, you should see how well that shiny faceplate lights up when a flashlight hits it in the dark, just the thing you don't want for night use.Virtually every guy in our group ends up carrying a standard UV-5R and giving the UV-5RA, -5RAX, or -5RAX+ to the wife or kids, since the wife and/or kids rarely care about the other accessories working and they (the wife and kids) tend to like the "pretty" radios, but again there is NO INTERNAL difference and NO EXTRA FEATURES in the UV-5RA, -5RAX, or -5RAX+ units (other than a different looking shiny faceplate) vs. the original and still wildly popular UV-5R (which I refer to as the M16 of radios, as all the accessories you match it up with just plain work).Now you know the real background on these radios.

The standard UV-5R units that we use seem to hold up just as well (when dropped in the desert dirt or rolling down a hill) as any other Baofeng radio we own and use.Fourth, and my biggest issue with all of the non-standard UV-5RA, UV-5RA+, UV-5RAX and UV-5RAX+ units, is that NONE of the Baofeng battery accessories (except the little 1800 mAh standard battery) work WITHOUT modification (unless you use a Dremel tool to grind or cut off part of your extended battery that works on the standard UV-5R - but won't work on your UV-5RA, UV-5RA+, UV-5RAX or UV-5RAX+).Getting new UV-5RA+ units that don't work with Extended 3800 mAh batteries (without modification) doesn't make my group happy.  That may not bother you, but NONE of the sellers of the non-standard UV-5RA, UV-5RA+, UV-5RAX, and UV-5RAX+ units ever seem to mention that lack of hardware compatibility in their listings, so buyer beware!BTW, NONE of the "AA" or "AAA" battery shell packs work on the UV-5RA, UV-5RA+, UV-5RAX, or UV-5RAX+ units either, so that's 3 different battery accessories (including the 3800 mAh extended battery) that you can't use on these radios without hacking them with a Dremel tool (but they all work without modification on the original UV-5R units).So "if" you want a "pretty" radio (as my wife calls it), buy one of the various versions of the UV-5RA (-5RA+, -5RAX, or -5RAX+) with the shiny face plate and live with the fact that you'll be modifying ALL of the battery accessories you buy later in order to get them to work.  Oh, you should see how well that shiny faceplate lights up when a flashlight hits it in the dark, just the thing you don't want for night use.Virtually every guy in our group ends up carrying a standard UV-5R and giving the UV-5RA, -5RA+, -5RAX, or -5RAX+ to the wife or kids, since the wife and/or kids rarely care about the other accessories working and they (the wife and kids) tend to like the "pretty" radios, but again there is NO INTERNAL difference and NO EXTRA FEATURES in the UV-5RA, -5RA+, -5RAX, or -5RAX+ units (other than a different looking shiny faceplate) vs. the original and still wildly popular UV-5R (which I refer to as the M16 of radios, as all the accessories you match it up with just plain work).Now you know the real background on these radios.

As a buyer of well-over 300 Baofeng radios (and counting) for the group I belong to (not all of which were purchased through Amazon but many were), I'm always amazed at the lengths some sellers go to to hype their products as being "newer" or "better" than other models, or perhaps (to give them the benefit of the doubt) they just don't know any better.First, the Baofeng UV-5R series (including the original and still extremely popular UV-5R, I'll explain why in a minute) is what is normally referred to by many as a SDR radio (or software defined radio).  While not a true SDR product (you can't use it with your computer to control the radio's functions or scan a wide amount of VHF/UHF frequencies with it), none the less a large chip is programmed on the circuit board built inside each radio.  That chip determines what capability the radio itself can perform.Every UV-5R series radio has the ability to transmit from 136-174 MHz on VHF and from 400-520 MHz on UHF in both narrow-band and wide-band modes (very useful for the occasional FRS or MURS use, which requires narrow-band mode to work correctly).Every model does "at least" 4W on VHF/UHF from the factory, but occasionally you'll get a batch that does 4.5W or even 5W out, but the difference between 4W and 5W is minimal at best.  A 4W radio with a better antenna will easily outperform a 5W radio with the standard crappy antenna that Baofeng ships on ALL (including the UV-5RA, -5RAX, and -5RAX+) models.Baofeng DOES NOT program those chips any differently for the UV-5R vs. any other UV-5R series (including the UV-5RAX+).  Version 307 of the firmware (which is the most current release I have in any of my radios) works EXACTLY the same way as previous older releases of firmware at least back to the 295 release (over a year ago), so any claim from a seller that this release provides additional features (at least from a user's perspective) is simply BOGUS, since the firmware inside both radios have the same features.  In fact, my UV-5R radios with the 307 firmware release is EXACTLY the same radio (inside and within the firmware) as my UV-5RAX+ radios with the 307 firmware release.Second, you CANNOT in any way upgrade the firmware (unless you count buying a different radio and it comes with a different firmware release), so again the claim in the listing from some sellers that you can is simply BOGUS.Third, you can believe that two thinner pieces (glued or screwed together on the faceplate of the UV-5RAX+) is somehow stronger than one thicker piece of plastic (on the original UV-5R series) if you like (and maybe it is), but I haven't seen that in real-world use from my own UV-5RAX+ units.  The standard UV-5R units that we use seem to hold up just as well (when dropped in the desert dirt or rolling down a hill) as any other Baofeng radio we own and use.Fourth, and my biggest issue with all of the non-standard UV-5RAX and UV-5RAX+ units, is that NONE of the Baofeng battery accessories (except the little 1800 mAh standard battery) work WITHOUT modification (unless you use a Dremel tool to grind or cut off part of your extended battery that works on the standard UV-5R - but won't work on your UV-5RA, UV-5RAX or UV-5RAX+).Getting new UV-5RAX+ units that don't work with Extended 3800 mAh batteries (without modification) doesn't make my group happy.  That may not bother you, but NONE of the sellers of the non-standard UV-5RA, UV-5RAX, and UV-5RAX+ units ever seem to mention that lack of hardware compatibility in their listings, so buyer beware!BTW, NONE of the "AA" or "AAA" battery shell packs work on the UV-5RA, UV-5RAX, or UV-5RAX+ units either, so that's 3 different battery accessories (including the 3800 mAh extended battery) that you can't use on these radios without hacking them with a Dremel tool (but they all work without modification on the original UV-5R units).So "if" you want a "pretty" radio (as my wife calls it), buy one of the various versions of the UV-5RA (or -5RAX, or -5RAX+) with the shiny face plate and live with the fact that you'll be modifying ALL of the battery accessories you buy later in order to get them to work.  Oh, you should see how well that shiny faceplate lights up when a flashlight hits it in the dark, just the thing you don't want for night use.Virtually every guy in our group ends up carrying a standard UV-5R and giving the UV-5RA, -5RAX, or -5RAX+ to the wife or kids, since the wife and/or kids rarely care about the other accessories working and they (the wife and kids) tend to like the "pretty" radios, but again there is NO INTERNAL difference and NO EXTRA FEATURES in the UV-5RA, -5RAX, or -5RAX+ units (other than a different looking shiny faceplate) vs. the UV-5R (which I refer to as the M16 of radios, as all accessories you match it up with just plain work).Now you know the real background on these radios.

One of the primary "knocks" against the UV-5R series of radios (made by the same company - Baofeng) is that their receivers in these little radios are as wide as barn doors.  Sensitive, yes, selective - no way.  Yes I know they can transmit from 136-174 and 400-520 mHz (even though other reviewers aren't aware of this apparently), but up until now selectivity (the ability of the receiver to ignore things that you don't want to hear) has been, well, wanting to say the least.Until now.  The B6 series (when set to narrow-band mode) simply blows away any UV-5R series receiver - period.  One word of caution, however, you'll won't see much difference in the receivers (between the UV-5R series and the B5/B6 series) if both radios are set to wide-band mode (the default setting on both rigs).  When you change both receivers to narrow-band it's like comparing black and white tv to HDTV, you just can't believe the difference.One of my close friends is an EE specializing in RF design.  When we compared the two radios (in wide-band mode) he wasn't too impressed with either of them (to say the least), but when we re-ran the tests with both radios in narrow-band mode he couldn't believe the difference on the B6 and checked his instruments again just to make sure he hadn't made a mistake in the measurements.For most folks considering a radio purchase the narrow-band receive capabilities of this radio will simply be wasted, as many will use it for prepping, scanning, FRS, or GMRS (legal or not), and for those folks (most of which barely understand how to program it let alone what narrow-band is), either radio (UV-5R or B6) is a quantum leap ahead in technology vs. the poor FRS/GMRS bubble-pack radios available in warehouse stores.  For those folks that need a radio that truly can do both Part 90 transmit AND receive, this B6 may just be the low priced unit that they have been looking for.  By the way, the B5 model is the same radio without the built-in LED flashlight, otherwise the units are identical.I own both radios, so let me explain some of the differences of the two different series units so you can decide which one is "best" for your needs:Standard Battery Size:1800mAh (UV-5R)  2000mAh (B5/B6)Battery Size / Options Available:3800mAh Extended Battery, AA 6-Cell Pack, AAA 6-Cell Pack, & Car Battery Adapter (UV-5R)NO Battery Options available for the B5/B6 (although the radio is new, so Baofeng may eventually add some options)FM Commercial Radio Receiver Memory Channels:None on the UV-5R (although you can direct enter one FM frequency at a time to listen)16 Memory Channels on the B5/B6 SeriesTotal Programmed Frequency Memories Available for "Talking":128 (UV-5R)  99 (B5/B6)Number of available alpha-numberic spaces (to name your displayed frequency):6 (UV-5R)  5 (B5/B6)Colors of radio available:Black, Blue, Camo, Red, Yellow (UV-5R)Black Only (B5/B6)Transmit Frequency Range:136-174 mHz (VHF)400-520 mHz (UHF)Both radios support this.There may other differences I'll discover as I use the B6 longer, if so, I'll revise the review and post them here.In short, if you want the maximum number of options available, you'll love the original UV-5R series.  If you need narrow-band receive capabilities, you'll love the receiver in the B5/B6 series and will (for now at least) have to give up some of the options the UV-5R series folks have already.  My choice was easy, I got both.I can't wait to see what the newest UV-82 series will have (available soon)!Update: 01-23-2014Sadly, the UV-82 series isn't better than a UV-5R when comparing transmit or receive functions (dealers are already giving the same radio different labeling so that they can claim their radio is "newer" than the other guy's radio).  It is slightly wider and they finally moved the 0 (zero) on the keypad to the correct location, but it doesn't have more power, or any new features (when comparing a stand UV-5R to a standard UV-82).  Some folks have discovered that the UV-82 is available with 2m and 222MHz (which is true), but that option is also available in the UV-5R (just not on Amazon).  Again, because the case design of the UV-82 is different, none of the battery or power options that work on the UV-5R will even fit a UV-82.

Be advised that a particular seller (that claims to be the actual distributor for Baofeng based in KY) advertises the original UV-5R radio but then ships the UV-5RA instead.  Normally this would be no big deal, as the UV-5R series of radios are exactly the same inside and have no additional features except one - the "newer" UV-5RA unit has a different front plastic face plate but that newer faceplate causes additional problems - the design of the newer faceplate on the UV-5RA does NOT allow you to use the normal Baofeng 3800mAH battery (nor the cheaper 3600mAH generic clone battery that the same "distributor" claims (and lists) as an actual Baofeng 3800mAH battery.  They claim their generic battery will work unmodified on the UV-5R series of radios (their justification for the switch), but it doesn't.  See my Baofeng Extended Battery review for more info).Yes, you can modify (on your own) the Extended Battery so it will fit the UV-5RA (or the other series of UV-5R radios with modified faceplates), but if the "distributor" lists the UV-5R (but then switches your order to whatever they have in stock - instead of what they have listed) and then ships (in the same order) a generic clone Extended Battery that isn't the actual Baofeng AND doesn't work/fit with the radio they shipped, why is it your job to modify their items to make them work?In addition, when you (as an Amazon customer) point out their multiple listing errors (shipping a non-Baofeng battery, shipping a less than advertised 3600mAH model (vs. the actual Baofeng 3800mAH model that was advertised on the listing), and shipping an Extended Battery that won't work on the UV-5RA radios that they switched your order to and shipped with them in the same box), they claim that:a) Baofeng doesn't even make an Extended Battery (funny since I own several already with Baofeng Electronics' label on the inside of the case and Baofeng's name imprinted into the back of the plastic battery case), and thatb) if I'm not happy I should pay to ship my order back to them (this is how they treat a customer that ordered multiple radios, extended batteries, and programming cables all at once and paid over $117 in shipping fees)?None of these issues may bother some folks, especially those that either don't care which model of radio they get and/or never plan to get an Extended Battery as an accessory, but I wanted folks to know what customer service issues you may face in dealing with this Baofeng "distributor" in KY.
